P, Q and R are possible bomb-experts. R, S and T are possible leaders. U, V and W are possible soldiers. Also, P and R prefers to work with each other in the same team. T prefers to work only if V works.
How many different possible Groups can Major Steve make?
Hint: Draw it out!
Human Solution:
Major Steve can make 8 different possible groups.
As 2 bomb-experts to be selected from the given 3 and also P & R prefers to work together, PR must be there in all the possible Groups. Also, T prefers to work only if V works. It doesn't mean that V won't work without T.
Hence, possible groups are:
PR - S - UV
PR - S - VW
PR - S - WU
PR - T - UV
PR - T - VW
PQ - R - UV
PQ - R - VW
PQ - R - WU
Hence,  8 different groups are possible.
Response:
Let us handle the problem role–by–role, always respecting the two conditions  

(1) P and R must be together (either both in the group or neither),  
(2) T can be chosen only if V is also chosen.

The five-member team consists of  
• 1 leader chosen from R, S, T,  
• 2 bomb–experts chosen from P, Q, R,  
• 2 soldiers chosen from U, V, W.  
(No person can hold two different roles.)

------------------------------------------------------------------
CASE 1 Leader = R  
If R is the leader, P must also be present, therefore P must be one bomb-expert.  
The second bomb-expert can only be Q.  
Soldiers: any 2 of U, V, W.      C(3,2)=3 ways.

⇒ 3 groups in this case.

------------------------------------------------------------------
CASE 2 Leader = S  
Bomb-experts must be chosen from P, Q, R with the P–R rule:

• {P,R}  (valid)  
• {P,Q}  invalid (R absent)  
• {Q,R}  invalid (P absent)

Hence the only possible pair is {P,R}.  
Soldiers: again any 2 of U, V, W ⇒ 3 ways.

⇒ 3 groups in this case.

------------------------------------------------------------------
CASE 3 Leader = T  
If T is leader then V must be a soldier.  
Bomb-experts: as before the only valid pair is {P,R}.  
Soldiers must contain V plus one of the remaining two soldiers:

• {V,U}  
• {V,W}   2 ways.

⇒ 2 groups in this case.

------------------------------------------------------------------
Total number of admissible groups  
3 (leader R) + 3 (leader S) + 2 (leader T) = 8.

Final answer: 8

Question:
LTVX
AFHKNZ
_ _ _
What three letters fill in the blanks?
Hint:
- The title has a partial clue.
- Look down.
- They are grouped horizontally.
Human Solution:
E M W
The first row requires two straight lines to make. (LTVX)
The Second row requires three straight lines to make.  (AFHKNZ)
Following the pattern, the next row should have four straight lines to make, and the only letters that do that are EMW.
(Also everything has been so far in alphabetical order so it has to be "EMW", not EWM, MEW, MWE, WME, or WEM.)
Response:
The capital letters of the Roman alphabet can be grouped by the minimum number of straight-line strokes needed to draw them (using the simplest “stick-letter” form, and only straight segments).

2-stroke letters  
L T V X

3-stroke letters  
A F H K N Z

4-stroke letters  
E M W

(In this style I needs only one stroke and is therefore not placed in either of the first two displayed rows.)

The first given row lists all the 2-stroke straight-line letters.  
The second given row lists all the 3-stroke straight-line letters.  
Therefore the third row must contain the remaining straight-line letters, those that take 4 strokes.

Thus the three blanks are filled by

E M W

Final answer: EMW

Question:
List the order in which each person finished.
Tommy Tombstone finished after Lance Lamers and Brett Brown but before Mitch Monday.
Peter Poultry finished before Daniel Dusk and Lance Lamers.
Sam Sunny finished after Peter Poultry and before Jack Jill and Harry Hills.
Keri Kernel finished after Peter Poultry, Mitch Monday and Tommy Tombstone.
Lance Lamers finished after Brett Brown and Daniel Dusk, but before Jack Jill and Mitch Monday.
Mitch Monday finished after Sam Sunny and Brett Brown.
Brett Brown finished before Jack Jill, Mitch Monday and Peter Poultry.
Daniel Dusk finished before Keri Kernel and Tommy Tombstone, but after Sam Sunny.
Jack Jill finished before Keri Kernel, Tommy Tombstone and Mitch Monday, but after Peter Poultry and Daniel Dusk.
Harry Hills finished before Mitch Monday but after Lance Lamers, Jack Jill and Tommy Tombstone.
Hint: Figure out who could possibly be first? Work from there
Human Solution:
1.Brett Brown
2.Peter Poultry
3.Sam Sunny
4.Daniel Dusk
5.Lance Lamers
6.Jack Jill
7.Tommy Tombstone
8.Harry Hills
9.Mitch Monday
10.Keri Kernel
Response: Final answer: Brett Brown, Peter Poultry, Sam Sunny, Daniel Dusk, Lance Lamers, Jack Jill, Tommy Tombstone, Harry Hills, Mitch Monday, Keri Kernel

Question: A prisoner sat alone in his cell staring through the bars at the six doors to the guardroom beyond them. Suddenly, there was the sound of footsteps. One guard came in through door A and a second entered through door F. They unlocked the cell door. "We shall set you free," said one of the guards, "but first you must pass through all six doors, each door once only, in the correct order. Three are entrances only and three are exits only. Door A must be followed by door B or E; B by C or E; C by D or F; D by A or F; E by B or D; and F by C or D." With that the guards left through door B. In what order must the prisoner pass through the doors?
Hint: The prisoner must alternate exits and entrances. List the six possible orders then study the conditions to eliminate possibilities.
Human Solution:
The order is CFDABE. The guards entered through doors A and F and exited at door B. The prisoner must alternate exits and entrances. Let the unknown entrance be X. With a "_" denoting an exit door the possible orders are:
(a) _A_F_X ; (b) _F_A_X ; (c) _X_A_F ; (d) _X_F_A ; (e) _A_X_F ; (f) _F_X_A
Neither (a) nor (c) are possible since A is followed by B or E and neither leads to F. Since A can only be preceded by D, (e) and (f) are possible as DA_X_F and _F_XDA, respectively. With D used, door F can only be preceded by C to give DA_XCF and CF_XDA, respectively. Door B must occupy the remaining space in each possibility (third door is exit) so X=E but C cannot follow E in the former and for the latter, B cannot follow F. This eliminates (e) and (f). Since only D precedes A, (b) is possible as _FDA_X and (d) as _X_FDA. For (d), the exit B must occupy a "_" but cannot be followed by F, and if it is the first door, neither the C or E that must follow as X can be followed by the remaining E or C, respectively. This only leaves (b) and only C (of the possible B,C,E) can precede F as CFDA_X and B must occupy the final "_" as an exit leaving E=X. Notice that the condition that E is followed by B or D cannot be satisfied until the prisoner has completed his task and finally wins his freedom through B or D!
Response:
Let  

• an entrance door be one that can be used only to come ​into​ the guard-room (direction O → G)  
• an exit door be one that can be used only to go ​out of​ the guard-room (direction G → O)

Because the prisoner starts inside the guard-room, the six doors he uses must alternate  

exit – entrance – exit – entrance – exit – entrance .

The story already fixes three of the doors:

A guard came in through A  ⇒  A is an entrance.  
Another guard came in through F  ⇒  F is an entrance.  
Both guards left through B       ⇒  B is an exit.

Hence we still need one more entrance and two more exits.

Now impose the “follow” rules

A → B or E  
B → C or E  
C → D or F  
D → A or F  
E → B or D  
F → C or D

and remember that after an exit the next door must be an entrance, and after an entrance the next door must be an exit.

–––– Determining which remaining doors are entrances/exits ––––

1.  Suppose C were an entrance.  
    Then its followers (D or F) would both have to be exits, contradicting “F is an entrance”.  
    So C is an exit.

2.  Try making D an entrance.  
    Then its follower (A or F) would have to be an exit, contradicting “A and F are entrances”.  
    So D is an exit.

3.  That leaves E; it must therefore be the third entrance.

Thus  
Entrances = A, E, F  Exits = B, C, D.

–––– Building the 6-door chain ––––

Let us start with any exit and follow the rules while keeping the required alternation.

(1) C is an exit.  
    C → D or F, but the next door must be an entrance, so choose F.

(2) F (entrance).  
    F → C or D, the next door must be an exit, so choose D.

(3) D (exit).  
    D → A or F, the next door must be an entrance, so choose A.

(4) A (entrance).  
    A → B or E, the next door must be an exit, so choose B.

(5) B (exit).  
    B → C or E, but C is already used, so choose E.

(6) E (entrance) – the sixth and last unused door.

Sequence obtained: C → F → D → A → B → E

Check: every pair is allowed by the rules and every door appears exactly once.

Therefore the prisoner must pass through the doors in the order

C, F, D, A, B, E.

Final answer: CF DABE

Question:
You've been placed on a course of expensive medication in which you are to take one tablet of Sildenafil and one tablet of Citrate daily. You must be careful that you take just one of each because taking more of either can have serious side effects.
Taking Sildenafil without taking Citrate, or vice versa, can also be very serious, because they must be taken together in order to be effective. In summary, you must take exactly one of the Sildenafil pills and one of the Citrate pills at one time. Therefore, you open up the Sildenafil bottle, and you tap one Sildenafil pill into your hand. You put that bottle aside and you open the Citrate bottle. You do the same, but by mistake, two Citrates fall into your hand with the Sildenafil pill.
Now, here's the problem. You weren't watching your hand as the pills fell into it, so you can't tell the Sildenafil pill apart from the two Citrate pills. The pills look identical. They are both the same size, same weight (10 micrograms), same color (Blue), same shape (perfect square), same everything, and they are not marked differently in any way.
What are you going to do? You cannot tell which pill is which, and they cost $300 a piece, so you cannot afford to throw them away and start over again. How do you get your daily dose of exactly one Sildenafil and exactly one Citrate without wasting any of the pills?
Hint: You can cut pills in half
Human Solution: Carefully cut each of the three pills in half, and carefully separate them into two piles, with half of each pill in each pile. You do not know which pill is which, but you are 100% sure that each of the two piles now contains two halves of Citrate and half of Sildenafil. Now go back into the Sildenafil bottle, take out a pill, cut it in half, and add one half to each stack. Now you have two stacks, each one containing two halves of Sildenafil and two halves of Citrate. Take one stack of pills today, and save the second stack for tomorrow.
Response:
Step-by-step reasoning

1. Put the three indistinguishable tablets (1 Sildenafil + 2 Citrates) on the table.  
2. With a pill-cutter or a razor blade, cut every one of the three tablets exactly in half.  
   Now you have six half-tablets:  
   • S½ , S½ (the two halves of the Sildenafil)  
   • C½ , C½ (the halves of the first Citrate)  
   • C½ , C½ (the halves of the second Citrate)
3. Make TWO piles as follows: take one half from each of the three original tablets for pile A, and the remaining halves for pile B.  
   So each pile now contains:  
   – one half-Sildenafil (½ S)  
   – two half-Citrates (½ C + ½ C = 1 full Citrate)  
   Hence each pile is ½ S + 1 C.
4. From the Sildenafil bottle take ONE more whole Sildenafil tablet, cut it in half, and add one half to each pile.  
   After this addition each pile contains:  
   – ½ S (from step 3) + ½ S (just added) = 1 full Sildenafil  
   – 1 full Citrate (already there)  
   Therefore every pile is exactly 1 S + 1 C.
5. Swallow any one of the two piles today; label and keep the other pile for tomorrow.

Result  
Today you ingest exactly one Sildenafil tablet and one Citrate tablet, and no pill is wasted. The saved pile gives you tomorrow’s exact dose as well.

Final answer: Cut all three indistinguishable tablets in half, split the halves into two equal piles, add half of a freshly cut Sildenafil tablet to each pile, then take one pile today and the other tomorrow—each pile contains exactly one Sildenafil and one Citrate.

Question:
Al, Ben, Carl, and Dan live in four adjacent apartments. The apartments are set up like this:
|1|2|3|4|
with apartment 1 being the westernmost apartment and apartment 4 being the easternmost. One of the four is the landlord. Here are some facts:
1. If Carl does not live next to Ben, then Al is the landlord and he lives in apartment 1.
2. If Al lives east of Carl, then Dan is the landlord and he lives in apartment 4.
3. If Ben does not live next to Dan, then Carl is the landlord and he lives in apartment 3.
4. If Dan lives east of Al, then Ben is the landlord and he lives in apartment 2.
Who is the landlord?
Hint: All four facts are in the form of "hypothesis and conclusion" statements. If the hypothesis of such a statement is false, the whole statement is true. If the conclusion is true, the whole statement is true. However, if the hypothesis is true and the conclusion is false, the statement is false. This means that each statement has either a false hypothesis or a true conclusion.
Human Solution:
Carl is the landlord.
Obviously only one conclusion is true at most. Let us suppose that all conclusions are false. This would mean that each hypothesis is also false. From facts 1 and 3, Ben lives next to both Carl and Dan, and therefore between Carl and Dan. Then either Al lives east of both Carl and Dan (contradicting fact 4) or Carl and Dan both live east of Al (contradicting fact 2.) So there must be exactly one true hypothesis, which will be paired with the one true conclusion. Obviously each of the three false conclusions is paired with a false hypothesis.
If conclusion 1 is true, then Al lives in apartment 1. But since hypothesis 4 is false, Al has to live east of Dan. So this cannot be right.
If conclusion 2 is true, then Dan lives in apartment 4. But since hypothesis 4 is false, Al must live east of Dan. So this cannot be right, either.
If conclusion 4 is true, Ben lives in apartment 2. Then, since hypotheses 1 and 3 are false, Ben lives between Carl and Dan, putting Al in apartment 4. But since hypothesis 2 is false, Carl must live east of Al. Therefore, conclusion 3 is true.
Response:
Step 1.  Show that Al cannot live in apartment 1.  
• If Al were in 1, Dan would necessarily be east of him (in 2, 3 or 4).  
• “Dan east of Al” triggers rule 4, forcing Ben to be the landlord in apartment 2.  
• With Ben in 2, Dan must be in 3 (otherwise Ben would not be next to Dan and rule 3 would then force Carl to be the landlord).  
• That leaves apartment 4 for Carl, making Carl NOT next to Ben; rule 1 would then make Al the landlord, contradicting the earlier conclusion that Ben is the landlord.  
Hence Al cannot be in apartment 1.

Step 2.  Because rule 1’s conclusion (“Al is landlord and in 1”) is impossible, its hypothesis must be false.  
Therefore Carl and Ben must be next-door neighbours.

Step 3.  Enumerate the adjoining positions for Carl and Ben, eliminating any containing apartment 1 (since Al is not in 1):

a) Ben 2 – Carl 1 (rejected: Al would be east of Carl, rule 2 would force Dan-landlord in 4, contradicting rule 4)  
b) Ben 1 – Carl 2 (rejected similarly)  
c) Ben 2 – Carl 3 (rejected: Al must be 4, but rule 2 then fails)  
d) Ben 3 – Carl 2 (rejected likewise)  
e) Ben 3 – Carl 4 (rejected by rule 3)  
f) Ben 4 – Carl 3 (still possible)

Step 4.  Examine the only surviving pattern (Ben 4, Carl 3).  
The remaining apartments 1 and 2 go to Dan and Al, but Al cannot be in 1, so place Al 2 and Dan 1.

Apartment assignment now is  
Al 2 Ben 4 Carl 3 Dan 1

Check every rule:

1. Carl is next to Ben → hypothesis false → rule satisfied.  
2. Al is west of Carl → hypothesis false → rule satisfied.  
3. Ben is not next to Dan (4 vs 1) → hypothesis true, and the conclusion is “Carl landlord in 3”, which is exactly the case.  
4. Dan is west of Al → hypothesis false → rule satisfied.

All rules are satisfied, so this arrangement is consistent.

Conclusion: The only consistent arrangement makes Carl the landlord (in apartment 3).

Final answer: Carl

Question:
In the following code, each symbol stands for one of five letters.
@ stands for M, O, F, L, or V
$ stands for B, N, R, E, or J
% stands for T, F, B, L, or A
! stands for W, T, S, E, or I
# stands for F, O, A, T, or L
The five letter code word, %$#@!, can be translated into two English words that are opposites. What are the two words?
Hint: Prepositions
Human Solution: Above and Below
Response:
We have one encoded “word’’ consisting of five symbols in fixed order:

% $ # @ !

Each symbol may be replaced only by a letter from its own small set:  
%  →  T / F / B / L / A  
$  →  B / N / R / E / J  
#  →  F / O / A / T / L  
@  →  M / O / F / L / V  
!  →  W / T / S / E / I  

The task is to find two different translations of the symbol string into real English words that are opposites (antonyms).

Step-by-step search

1. Look for common five-letter antonym pairs:  
   ABOVE / BELOW, LARGE / SMALL, FALSE / TRUE, NORTH / SOUTH, EARLY / LATE, START / STOP, etc.

2. Test each word of a candidate pair against the allowed letters in its position.

   Pair: ABOVE  
   • A   (pos 1) is in {T,F,B,L,A} ✓  
   • B   (pos 2) is in {B,N,R,E,J} ✓  
   • O   (pos 3) is in {F,O,A,T,L} ✓  
   • V   (pos 4) is in {M,O,F,L,V} ✓  
   • E   (pos 5) is in {W,T,S,E,I} ✓  

   Pair: BELOW  
   • B   (pos 1) is in {T,F,B,L,A} ✓  
   • E   (pos 2) is in {B,N,R,E,J} ✓  
   • L   (pos 3) is in {F,O,A,T,L} ✓  
   • O   (pos 4) is in {M,O,F,L,V} ✓  
   • W   (pos 5) is in {W,T,S,E,I} ✓  

   Every letter of both words fits its allowed symbol set, so ABOVE and BELOW are legal decodings.

3. Check other pairs quickly: LARGE/SMALL, FALSE/TRUE, EARLY/LATE, etc. Each of them fails at least one position, so no other antonym pair works.

Therefore the unique pair of opposite English words that can be formed is:

ABOVE and BELOW.

Final answer: ABOVE and BELOW

Question: Two friends, Joe and Smoe, were born in May, one in 1932, the other a year later. Each had an antique grandfather clock of which he was extremely proud. Both of the clocks worked fairly well considering their age, but one clock gained ten seconds per hour while the other one lost ten seconds per hour. On a day in January, the two friends set both clocks correctly at 12:00 noon. "Do you realize," asked Joe, "that the next time both of our clocks will show exactly the same time will be on your 47th birthday?" Smoe agreed. Who is older, Joe or Smoe?
Hint: To find the answer, we have to find how long it will be before the clocks show the same time again
Human Solution: To find the answer, we have to find how long it will be before the clocks show the same time again. This is when the slow clock loses six hours, and the fast one gains six hours. This will take 90 days. In 90 days they will come together at 6:00. On a calendar, there are 90 days between noon January 31, and noon May 1 in years with no leap year. If Smoe had been born in 1933, his 47th birthday would have been in 1980, a leap year. This means that Smoe must be older, born in 1932, and the time of this problem is 1979.
Response:
Let us translate the story into mathematics.

1.  One clock gains 10 s per hour, the other loses 10 s per hour.  
    Hence the faster clock pulls ahead of the slower clock at a rate  
    10 s + 10 s = 20 seconds per real hour.

2.  The two dials look alike whenever their indications differ by an exact
    multiple of 12 hours (a grandfather clock’s face repeats every 12 h).
    The smallest positive difference is 12 h = 43 200 s.

3.  How long does it take the faster dial to get 43 200 s ahead of the
    slower one?
              time  =  43 200 s  ÷  20 s/h  = 2160 h.
    2160 h ÷ 24 h/day = 90 days.

    Therefore the displays coincide every 90 days, and the first
    coincidence after the initial setting occurs exactly 90 days later.

4.  Joe said that this first future coincidence would happen on Smoe’s
    47th birthday.  They set the clocks at noon on “a day in January”, so
    Smoe’s 47th birthday must be 90 days after that January date.

5.  Work forward 90 days from each January day (non-leap year):

       Jan 31 → Feb 28 (28 d)
                 → Mar 31 (+31 d = 59)
                 → Apr 30 (+30 d = 89)
                 → May 1  (+1 d  = 90)

    Only January 31 + 90 days lands in May, namely on May 1.  Thus

       start date : 31 January  
       Smoe’s birthday : 1 May

6.  For May 1 to be Smoe’s 47th birthday the year must be 1979, because

       1932 + 47 = 1979   (1932 is not a leap year ⇒ May 1 is the 121st
                           day, consistent with the count above)

    If Smoe had been born in 1933 he would turn 47 in 1980, a leap year;
    but in a leap year May 1 is the 122nd day, and no January date is
    exactly 90 days earlier.  Hence that alternative is impossible.

So Smoe must have been born on 1 May 1932, while Joe was born in May 1933.

Final answer:  Smoe is the older of the two.

Question:
Ole Santa's pack held thirty toys
Made by his elfin crew;
And though none made the same amount,
Each elf made more than two.
The elf named Cher made one more Christmas toy
Than the elf who dressed in reds,
But Cher made one less Christmas toy
Than the elf who made the sleds.
Spry Johnny Elf made racing cars;
Five toys were made by Jane.
The elf who dressed in yellow suits
Made each and every train.
The elf who always dressed in green
Made one-third as many as Sue;
Cute Marcia elf was dressed in orange,
And one elf dressed in blue.
The elf who made the spinning tops
Made the most toys of them all.
Another perky smiling elf
Made each and every ball.
Ole Santa's pack held thirty gifts
All tagged for girls and boys.
From the clues that you've been given,
Now guess who made the toys!
Hint: This puzzle involves five elves dressed in five different colors each making a different toy. Figure out the numbers that fit these conditions and can add up to thirty!
Human Solution:
Cute Marcia was in orange and made seven sleds.
Sue was in blue and made nine spinning tops.
Jane was in red and made five balls.
Spry Johnny was in green and made three racing cars.
Cher was in yellow and made six trains.
Response:
Jane – dressed in red – made 5 balls.  
Johnny – dressed in green – made 3 racing-cars.  
Cher – dressed in yellow – made 6 trains.  
Marcia – dressed in orange – made 7 sleds.  
Sue – dressed in blue – made 9 spinning tops.

Final answer: Jane/red/balls/5, Johnny/green/racing-cars/3, Cher/yellow/trains/6, Marcia/orange/sleds/7, Sue/blue/spinning-tops/9

Question:
You are back on the same game show with four other contestants. You didn't realise last time that the winner gets another appearance on the show! You now have another chance to win half a million dollars and become a millionaire! The objective is to crack the combination of the safe using the clues. The first person to do so will win $500,000.
The safe combination looks like this:
??-??-??-??
A digit can be used more than once in the code, and there are no zeroes.
Here are the clues:
1. When adding the first number of the third set with the second number of the second set, you will get a number below 8.
2. The only digits not used in the code are 5 and 7.
3. When adding the two digits of the first set together, you will not get 10.
4. If you multiply the second set by 4, you will get the fourth set reversed.
5. No set has a number above 90.
6. The product of both the digits in the first set is below 30 but above 20.
7. One of the number sets is 66.
8. There is only one 8 in the combination, and it is in the last set.
Now, get cracking!
Human Solution:
The set is 39-21-66-48.
First of all, the second clue tells you there are no 5's or 7's in the combination.
Now we go to the fourth clue. It tells you that if you multiply the second set by 4, you will get the fourth set reversed. There are only a few numbers that will satisfy this:
11, 12, 16, 21, 22, 23 and 24.
Now we skip down to clue 8, which tells us there is one 8 only, and it is in the last set. It could either be the first digit or the second digit.
However, this eliminates these numbers from being in the second set: 11, 16, 23 and 24. Now, only 12, 21 and 22 are the possibilities for being in the second set.
Now, let's look at clue 7. This tells us that 66 is one of the four number sets. We know it can't be in the second, or fourth, and since clue six tells us the product of the two numbers in the first set ranges from 21-29, 66 must go in the third set.
??-??-66-??
Now we must look at the first clue. The first number of the third set (6) plus the second number of the second set will get a number below 8. This means it cannot be 12 or 22, because they would both total 8. This means that the second set of numbers is 21. Making good progress!
??-21-66-??
Now, we come back to clue 4 which tells us the second set multiplied by 4 equals the fourth set reversed. 21 multiplied by 4 is 84, which when reversed is 48!
??-21-66-48
Now, we come back to clue 6, which tells us the product of the digits in the first set is above 20 but below 30. These are the only numbers that satisfy that condition - and remember, no 5's, 7's or 8's are left in the combination:
39 (3 * 9 = 27)
46 (4 * 6 = 24)
64 (6 * 4 = 24)
93 (9 * 3 = 27)
Now, we look at clue 5. This eliminates 93. Now, come to clue 3. This tells us the sum of the two digits in the first set does not equal 10. This eliminates 46 and 64. The only number left is.... 39!
Now you have your answer;
39-21-66-48
Congratulations!!! You won, again!! You are over the moon! You have become the first millionaire in five generations of your family history!!
Response:
We have four two–digit “sets”: S₁–S₄, written ??-??-??-??.

Facts that drive the solution

1. 4 × S₂  =  (S₄ reversed) [clue 4]  
   Hence 4·S₂ must still be a two–digit number.  
   ⇒ S₂ ≤ 24 (because 25·4 = 100).  
   So S₂ ∈ {11,12,…,24}.

2. 5 and 7 never appear, 0 never appears, and the only 8 in the whole code is in S₄.  
   Therefore the number 4·S₂ must contain exactly one 8 and no 0,5,7.

3. Compute 4 × n for n = 11,…,24:

   11→44, 12→48, 13→52, 14→56, 15→60, 16→64,  
   17→68, 18→72, 19→76, 20→80, 21→84, 22→88, 23→92, 24→96

   The only products that (i) are two–digit, (ii) avoid 0,5,7, and (iii) contain exactly one 8 are
   48 and 84.

   • 12 × 4 = 48 ⇒ S₂ = 12, S₄ = 84  
   • 21 × 4 = 84 ⇒ S₂ = 21, S₄ = 48

   The latter choice is the only one that keeps the single 8 in the last set (clue 8).  
   So we must have

   S₂ = 21 and S₄ = 48.

4. One set is 66 (clue 7).  
   It cannot be S₄ (already 48) nor S₂ (already 21).  
   If it were S₁ the product of its digits would be 36, contradicting clue 6 (“below 30”).  
   Therefore S₃ = 66.

5. Clue 1: (first digit of S₃) + (second digit of S₂) < 8.  
   That is 6 + 1 = 7, which is indeed < 8.  Good.

6. We still need S₁.  Let its digits be a and b.

   • Product ab is between 21 and 29 (clue 6).  
   • Sum a + b ≠ 10 (clue 3).  
   • Digits may not be 0,5,7,8.

   Products 21–29 obtainable with single-digit factors:
     24 = 4·6 (sum 10 – forbidden)  
     27 = 3·9 (sum 12 – allowed)

   Thus {a,b} = {3,9}.  
   The two possible numbers are 39 and 93, but clue 5 forbids numbers above 90, so S₁ = 39.

7. Final check of all clues:
   39-21-66-48  
   • Only one 8 and it is in the last set ✓  
   • Digits 5 and 7 absent ✓  
   • 4 × 21 = 84 = (48 reversed) ✓  
   • No set exceeds 90 ✓  
   • (3)(9) = 27 (between 20 and 30) ✓  
   • 3 + 9 ≠ 10 ✓  
   • 6 + 1 = 7 (<8) ✓  
   • One set is 66 ✓

Everything is satisfied.

Final answer: 39-21-66-48

Question: A warden at a prison decides to give some prisoners a chance to escape by working together to solve a puzzle. He prepares a colored hat for every one of them and tells them the rules. The hats can be either black or white and will be placed on everyone's head.  The prisoners will get a chance to discuss a strategy together, which they will all follow, then they will be marched out into a large room where they will see everybody else's hat color. Each prisoner will then simultaneously guess which of the two hat colors they have. If every one of them is right, or every one of them is wrong, they will all go free. However, the prisoners will not be allowed to communicate in any way during this process. Also, the warden will hear their strategy and place hats any way he can to prevent them from going free. What strategy do they use to escape?
Hint: Think about it for two people and then three people. What will be the difference between what a white hatted person sees and a black hatted person sees?
Human Solution: Every prisoner should count up how many black hats they see. If they count an odd number of black hats, they say that they have a black hat. If they count an even number of black hats, then they say that they have a white hat.
Response:
Strategy

1.  During their discussion the prisoners agree on the following rule.  
    • Count how many black hats you can see on the other prisoners.  
    • If what you see is an EVEN number of black hats, say   “black”.  
    • If what you see is an ODD number of black hats, say   “white”.

2.  They do ​nothing​ else – no prisoner tries to deduce his own colour in any
    more complicated way.

Why it works

Let k be the total number of black hats actually put on by the warden.

Case 1 :  k is odd  
 Each black-hatted prisoner sees k–1 black hats, an even number, so he says
 “black” – correct.  
 Each white-hatted prisoner sees k black hats, an odd number, so he says
 “white” – correct.  
 Therefore every single guess is correct.

Case 2 :  k is even  
 Each black-hatted prisoner now sees k–1 black hats, an odd number, so he says
 “white” – wrong.  
 Each white-hatted prisoner sees k black hats, an even number, so he says
 “black” – wrong.  
 Therefore every single guess is wrong.

In either case the prisoners meet the warden’s requirement that they are
EITHER all right OR all wrong, so they all go free.

Because the rule is fixed in advance and depends only on what each prisoner
can see, hearing the strategy does not help the warden: no matter how he
distributes the hats, one of the two cases above must occur.

Final answer:  Each prisoner counts the black hats he can see; if that count is even he says “black”, if it is odd he says “white”.  This guarantees that either everyone is correct (odd total number of black hats) or everyone is wrong (even total), so the prisoners always escape.

Question:
Madadian Multi-Squillionaire Sheik Ratelunroll has bought four prestige cars from the Madadian Motor Company (MMC) - The Silver Dream, The Golden Pleasure, The Devine Lightning, and a The Rusting Bucket, - as presents for his sons' birthdays, all of which are next week (strange things like this happen in Madadia all the time). Given the following information, what will each son get?
1, Derek will not get The Golden Pleasure unless Berrick gets The Silver Dream and Eric gets The Rusting Bucket.
2, Berrick will not get The Rusting Bucket unless Merick gets The Devine Lightning and Derek gets The Silver Dream.
3, Eric will not get The Devine Lightning unless Derek gets The Golden Pleasure and Berrick gets The Silver Dream.
4, Derek will not get The Silver Dream unless Merick gets The Devine Lightning and Eric gets The Rusting Bucket.
5, Berrick will not get The Silver Dream unless Derek gets The Devine Lightning and Eric gets The Rusting Bucket.
6, Derek will not get The Devine Lightning unless Berrick gets The Golden Pleasure and Merick gets The Silver Dream.
7, Merick will not get The Devine Lightning unless Berrick gets The Golden Pleasure and Derek gets The Rusting Bucket.
8, Derek will not get The Rusting Bucket unless Berrick gets The Devine Lightning and Eric gets The Golden Pleasure.
9, Merick will not get The Silver Dream unless Eric gets The Golden Pleasure.
Hint: Starting with the simplest requirement, #9, assume that Eric does in fact get The Golden Pleasure, then Merick gets The Silver Dream.
Human Solution:
Starting with the simplest requirement, #9, assume that Eric does in fact get The Golden Pleasure, then Merick gets The Silver Dream. This leaves The Rusting Bucket and The Devine Lightning for Berrick and Derek. Going to rule #8, Eric already has The Golden Pleasure, so if Berrick gets The Devine Lightning, then Derek can have The Rusting Bucket. This gives us the following that complies with rules 8 & 9:
Eric = The Golden Pleasure
Merick = The Silver Dream
Berrick = The Devine Lightning
Derek = The Rusting Bucket
Now, to see if this works, just check it out against rules 1 through 7, where you'll find no rules are violated and everyone's happy except Derek who got stuck with The Rusting Bucket.
Response:
Reasoning  

Let the cars be  
S = The Silver Dream  
G = The Golden Pleasure  
L = The Devine Lightning  
R = The Rusting Bucket  

Let D, B, E, M stand for Derek, Berrick, Eric, Merick.  
Each of the nine sentences is an implication; e.g.  
1. D-G ⇒ (B-S ∧ E-R)  
and so on.

Check systematically which car Derek can receive.

1. Suppose D gets G.  
   Then by (1) B gets S and E gets R.  
   But B-S triggers (5) → D must get L as well, impossible.  
   So D ≠ G.

2. Suppose D gets S.  
   Then by (4) M gets L and E gets R.  
   M-L triggers (7) → D must also get R, impossible.  
   So D ≠ S.

3. Suppose D gets L.  
   Then by (6) B gets G and M gets S.  
   M-S triggers (9) → E gets G as well, giving G to both B and E, impossible.  
   So D ≠ L.

4. The only remaining possibility is D gets R.  
   Statement (8) then forces B-L and E-G.  
   The lone car left for Merick is S, so M-S.  
   Check the remaining triggered implications:  
   • M-S activates (9) → E-G (already true).  
   All other antecedents are false, so every implication is satisfied.

Thus a unique assignment satisfies all nine conditions:

Derek : The Rusting Bucket  
Berrick : The Devine Lightning  
Eric   : The Golden Pleasure  
Merick : The Silver Dream  

Final answer: Derek gets The Rusting Bucket; Berrick gets The Devine Lightning; Eric gets The Golden Pleasure; Merick gets The Silver Dream.

Question:
Thirty fans hire a bus to attend a football game. On the way to the stadium, they realize that exactly half of them are fans of one team and the other half are fans of the other team. With still some way to go before reaching the stadium, the bus develops mechanical problems and the driver announces to his passengers that the only way to continue the journey is for half of them to get out and walk. There is a huge fight that doesn't stop until the driver speaks to them again and suggests a way of selecting the passengers who are to get off the bus.
"All of you," he said, "get into a big circle. When you are ready, beginning at this spot, I'll count nine people clockwise. The ninth person leaves the circle and continues on foot. Then I'll count another nine starting from where I stopped, and the ninth person leaves the circle and continues on foot. And so on until fifteen people have left the circle."
Suppose that you are one of the fans. How should you arrange all the other fans of your team so that none of them will have to leave?
Hint: Just keep counting in circles and see where you each spot lands
Human Solution: If the two teams are A and B and you are a supporter of team A and don't want any of your fellow supporters to end up walking to the stadium, organize them in a circle starting at the point where the driver starts and reading clockwise as follows: A, A, A, A, B, B, B, B, B, A, A, B, A, A, A, B, A, B, B, A, A, B, B, B, A, B, B, A, A, B.
Response:
Number the places round the circle 1,2,3,… ,30 clockwise, and let the driver begin his count with the person standing in place 1.  
The counting-off procedure is the Josephus problem J(30,9): starting from the current place, every 9-th person is sent away and the count then resumes with the next person still in the circle.  Carrying the count through fifteen dismissals gives

order of people who have to leave  
9, 18, 27, 6, 16, 26, 7, 19, 30, 12, 24, 8, 22, 5, 23  (15 people)

and the places that are never called, i.e. the 15 places that remain in the circle, are  

1, 2, 3, 4, 10, 11, 13, 14, 15, 17, 20, 21, 25, 28, 29.

Therefore put yourself and the other fourteen supporters of your team in exactly those fifteen places (1,2,3,4,10,11,13,14,15,17,20,21,25,28,29) and let the supporters of the opposite team stand in the remaining fifteen places.  
When the driver counts off by nines, every person who is told to leave will belong to the other team, and no member of your team will have to get off the bus.

Final answer: Stand your own supporters in positions 1, 2, 3, 4, 10, 11, 13, 14, 15, 17, 20, 21, 25, 28 and 29 (counting clockwise from the driver’s starting spot); all fifteen people who are sent away will then be fans of the other team.

Question:
It appears that you have angered the spirit of Halloween by failing to revere the Great Pumpkin, and now a curse has befallen you.  On the walkway to your house is a Ward of Seven Jack O'Lanterns arranged in a circle.  If midnight comes and any of the seven are still lit, a dark reaper and seven dark horses with seven dark riders shall visit thy abode.  They shall surround thy domicile and, while circling it, they will proceed to pelt thy dwelling with eggs and cream of shaving.  And come morn there will be a great mess to be reckoned with.  Verily.  So you better get those lanterns out.
You quickly discover something odd about these lanterns.  When you blow out the first one, the lanterns on either side extinguish as well!  But there is more.  If you blow out a lantern adjacent to one that is extinguished, the extinguished one(s) will relight.  It seems that blowing on any lantern will change the state of three - the one you blew on and its two neighbors.  Finally, you can blow on an extinguished lantern and it will relight, and its neighbors will light/extinguish as applicable.  After trying once and finding all seven lit again, you decide, being the excellent puzzler, you sit down and examine this closer.  But hurry, I hear the beating of many hooves...
Hint: If you examine the setup carefully, you'll note a number of facts which make the puzzle easier to solve by deduction.  First, blowing on a lantern is a commutative property; blowing on lanterns 1, 5, then 3 is the same as blowing on 3, then 1, and then 5.  No matter what order the lanterns are blown on, if the same lanterns are blown on the same number of times, the result won't change.
Human Solution:
If you examine the setup carefully, you'll note a number of facts which make the puzzle easier to solve by deduction.  First, blowing on a lantern is a commutative property; blowing on lanterns 1, 5, then 3 is the same as blowing on 3, then 1, and then 5.  No matter what order the lanterns are blown on, if the same lanterns are blown on the same number of times, the result won't change.  For that reason, blowing on a lantern twice is as good as not blowing on it at all.  And three times is as good as one time. So, it seems that it should be able to be done in seven steps or less.
What else can we tell about the solution?  Since each operation changes the state of three lanterns, and there are 7 lanterns, and each lantern must change its state an odd number of times, it's a safe bet that there will need to be an odd number of steps.  We can easily see it can't be done in 1 or 3 steps, so it must be 5 or 7.  Trying 5 steps comes up with 3 different patterns that are not symmetrical and fail to leave all lanterns extinguished.  So that leaves 7 steps and to your surprise, based on the commutative property, the easiest solution is to blow on each one in order!  So doing this, the Great Pumpkin has decided to give you a treat for figuring this out and you find all seven lanterns full of candy the next morning!  Congratulations!
Response:
Number the pumpkins 1,2,…,7 clockwise round the circle and let  

xi = 0 or 1 according as you finally do not blow (0) or do blow (1) on pumpkin i.  
Because a blow switches the one you blow on and its two neighbours, after
all blows each pumpkin j has been toggled

xj-1  +  xj  +  xj+1  (mod 2).

(Indices are taken mod 7, so 0≡7.)  
We want every pumpkin to end up out, i.e. to have been toggled an odd number
of times, so for every j

xj-1  +  xj  +  xj+1 = 1  (1)

(mod 2).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Only one possible pattern of blows
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Write the equation for j and for j+1 and add them:

(xj-1 + xj + xj+1) + (xj + xj+1 + xj+2) = 1 + 1 = 0  
⇒ xj-1 + xj+2 = 0  (mod 2)  
⇒ xj+2 = xj-1.                                             (2)

Relation (2) says every third variable is equal, so
x0 = x3 = x6 = x2 = x5 = x1 = x4 = x0;
hence

x0 = x1 = … = x6 = a   for some a ∈ {0,1}.

Put this in (1):  a + a + a = 1  ⇒  3a = a = 1 (mod 2)  ⇒  a = 1.

Thus the ONLY solution is  

x0 = x1 = … = x6 = 1.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
What to do
--------------------------------------------------------------------
You must blow on every single pumpkin, exactly once each
(the order does not matter).  After the seventh blow each pumpkin has
been toggled three times and therefore is out.

It is impossible to extinguish the ward with fewer than seven blows, and
any sequence that omits even one pumpkin will leave at least one light
still burning.

Final answer: blow on all seven jack-o’-lanterns once (in any order); that – and only that – extinguishes them all.

Question:
Every day from Monday through Sunday in this week, Mr. Peter picks two shirts from the five colours red, blue, yellow, green and black. Peter follows the rules:
1. Peter doesn't use the same combination on two days of this week.
2. Peter doesn't use the same colour on two consecutive days of this week.
3. Peter uses some colour on four days.
4. Peter uses blue and black on Monday.
5. Peter uses green on Thursday.
6. Peter doesn't use yellow on Friday.
7. Peter doesn't combine red with black.
What colours does Peter use on Saturday?
Hint: Start from rules 2 and 3
Human Solution:
From rules 2 and 3, Peter must use one colour on Monday, Wednesday, Friday and Sunday, which can be blue or black.
If it's black, from rules 1 and 4, Peter must combine black with red, yellow and green on Wednesday, Friday and Sunday, but rule 7 disallows combining black with red.
Therefore, it's blue, and Peter must combine blue with red, yellow and green on Wednesday, Friday and Sunday. From rule 5, Peter uses green on Thursday, he can't use green on Wednesday or Friday, and only on Sunday.
From rule 6, Peter doesn't use yellow on Friday, and he can only use red on Friday and yellow on Wednesday.
Since Peter uses blue, red and green on Friday and Sunday, from rule 2, he can only use black and yellow on Saturday.
Response:
Reasoning  

Let the colours be abbreviated:  
B = blue, K = black, R = red, G = green, Y = yellow.  
Each day Peter wears an unordered pair of different colours.

1.  Monday is fixed by rule 4: Mon = {B,K}.  
2.  No colour may be repeated on two consecutive days (rule 2).

–––––  Make blue the colour that is used on exactly four days  –––––  

Because blue is already used on Monday it must appear three more times, with at least one clear day between any two blue-days.  
The only 4-day pattern that satisfies this in one week is  
Mon (1), Wed (3), Fri (5), Sun (7).  

Hence blue must occur on Wednesday, Friday and Sunday as well.

Let the partners of blue on these three days be different and taken from {R,G,Y};  
(B,K) is already used on Monday, so K can’t partner blue again.

Choose temporarily  

 Wed = {B,Y}, Fri = {B,R}, Sun = {B,G}. (1)

3.  Choose Tuesday.  
It must avoid B and K (Monday) and Y (Wednesday): so Tue = {G,R}.  (2)

4.  Choose Thursday (must contain G by rule 5 and avoid B,Y adjacent to Wednesday).  
Take Thu = {G,K}.  (3)

This gives so far  

Mon  {B,K}  
Tue  {G,R}  
Wed  {B,Y}  
Thu  {G,K}  
Fri  {B,R}  
Sat  ———  
Sun  {B,G}

5.  Friday already satisfies rule 6 (no yellow), and {B,R} does not clash with Thursday.

6.  Determine Saturday.  
Saturday must avoid every colour used on Friday (B,R) and on Sunday (B,G):  
so it may use only K and Y.  
The pair {K,Y} is allowed (rule 7 forbids only {R,K}), and it has not been used before.

Thus  

Sat = {K,Y}.  (4)

7.  Check all rules.  
• All seven pairs are distinct.  
• Adjacent days share no colour.  
• Blue appears on exactly four days (Mon, Wed, Fri, Sun).  
• Rule 6 and rule 7 are satisfied.

The completed week is  

Mon {B,K}  
Tue {G,R}  
Wed {B,Y}  
Thu {G,K}  
Fri {B,R}  
Sat {K,Y}  
Sun {B,G}

Everything is consistent, so Saturday’s colours are black and yellow.

Final answer: Peter wears black and yellow on Saturday.

Question:
At the Christmas party of the "Sweaty Chef" kebab shop, the owner Mr Juan, took note of how many people were present. Although he was a bit tipsy when he made his note, and thus made a mistake.  His notes were as follows:-
1, There were 9 men and children.
2, There were 2 more women than children.
3, The number of different man-woman couples possible was 24. Note that if there were 7 men and 5 women, then there would have been 35 man-woman couples possible.
Also, of the three groups - men, women and children - at the party:
4, There were 4 of one group.
5, There were 6 of one group.
6, There were 8 of one group.
Exactly one of the above 6 statements is false.
Can you tell which one is false? Also, how many men, women and children are there at the party?
Hint: Can 4,5,6 all be true at the same time?
Human Solution:
Statement (4) is false. There are 3 men, 8 women and 6 children.
Assume that Statements (4), (5) and (6) are all true. Then, Statement (1) is false. But then Statement (2) and (3) both can not be true. Thus, contradictory to the fact that exactly one statement is false.
So Statement (4) or Statement (5) or Statement (6) is false. Also, Statements (1), (2) and (3) all are true.
From (1) and (2), there are 11 men and women. Then from (3), there are 2 possible cases - either there are 8 men and 3 women or there are 3 men and 8 women.
If there are 8 men and 3 women, then there is 1 child. Then Statements (4) and (5) both are false, which is not possible.
Hence, there are 3 men, 8 women and 6 children. Statement (4) is false.
Response:
Let  

M = number of men  
W = number of women  
C = number of children  

Assume that only one of the six statements is wrong.

Make the first three statements true and allow exactly one of 4-6 to be wrong.

1.  M + C = 9  
2.  W = C + 2  
3.  M·W = 24  

Solve these simultaneously:

From 2: W = C + 2  
From 1: M = 9 − C  

Insert into 3:  
(9 − C)(C + 2) = 24  
−C² + 7C + 18 = 24  
C² − 7C + 6 = 0  
(C − 6)(C − 1) = 0

So C = 6 or C = 1.

• If C = 6: W = 8, M = 3.  
• If C = 1: W = 3, M = 8.

Now check statements 4, 5, 6.

Counts (M, W, C) = (3, 8, 6)

4. “There were 4 of one group.” False (groups are 3, 8, 6).  
5. “There were 6 of one group.” True (children).  
6. “There were 8 of one group.” True (women).

Exactly one statement (number 4) is false.

Counts (8, 3, 1) would make two of 4-6 false, so they are rejected.

Therefore:

False statement: 4 – “There were 4 of one group.”  
Numbers present: 3 men, 8 women, 6 children.

Final answer: Statement 4 is false; there were 3 men, 8 women, and 6 children at the party.

Question: Write on a piece of paper a 5x5 letter square using the alphabet, minus the letter Q, where A is in the upper left-hand corner and Z is in the lower right-hand corner.  After you have done this, can you tell me which letter comes just above the letter which comes between the letter just before the letter just below B and the letter just before the letter just above Y?
Hint: One step at a time
Human Solution:
The letter is G.
The two letters to initially find are F & S. The letter above the one which is between them is G.
Response:
Step 1 – Build the 5 × 5 square (omitting Q and writing row-wise):

A  B  C  D  E  
F  G  H  I  J  
K  L  M  N  O  
P  R  S  T  U  
V  W  X  Y  Z  

(Row and column positions are useful; e.g. A = (1,1), B = (1,2), …, Z = (5,5).)

Step 2 – Decode the chain inside-out

A. “the letter just below B”  
   B is (1,2); just below it is (2,2) = G.

B. “the letter just before the letter just below B”  
   In the same row as G (row 2) the square reads F G H I J, so the letter just before G is F.

So the first key letter is F (position (2,1)).

C. “the letter just above Y”  
   Y is (5,4); just above it is (4,4) = T.

D. “the letter just before the letter just above Y”  
   In row 4 the sequence is P R S T U, so the letter just before T is S.

So the second key letter is S (position (4,3)).

E. “the letter which comes between [F] and [S]”  
   In the 5 × 5 square, F is (2,1) and S is (4,3).  
   The cell exactly between those two (mid-row 3, mid-column 2) is (3,2) = L.  
   (Alphabetically, L is also the middle letter of the run F … S.)

Thus the “letter which comes between …” is L (row 3, column 2).

F. “the letter just above [L]”  
   Above L (3,2) is (2,2) = G.

Step 3 – Give the requested letter

The letter sought is G.

Final answer: G

Question:
I woke up late that morning to welcome a bright sunny day after a long and hectic week. It was a holiday and I was determined to spend the day playing cards with my friend Tweeto. Tweeto's favorite card game was the Romankachi card game.
The rules of the game are as follows :-
1) One person 'serves' and the other 'receives' cards in each round.
2) The person who serves cards in the round gains 2 cards if he wins the round and loses only 1 card if he loses the round.
3) On the other hand, the person who receives cards in the round, gains only 1 card if he wins the round and loses 2 cards if he loses the round.
4) Finally the person who wins in one round, serves in the next round.
5) The game is stopped when a player loses all his cards.
We started off with 5 cards each and I served in the first round.
At the end of three rounds if I had exactly 4 cards then which of the following statements must be true:-
A) Tweeto must have won exactly two rounds.
B) I must have won the first round.
C) Tweeto must have won the third round.
NOTE: Out of the given set of 3 statements, it is not necessary that one and only one statement is true. One or more statements may be true.
Hint: First, think about what possible results could lead to you having 4 cards?
Human Solution:
Statements A and C must be true.
The rules of the Romankachi card game are given below.
1) One person 'serves' and the other 'receives' cards in each round.
2) The person who serves cards in the round gains 2 cards if he wins the round and loses only 1 card if he loses the round.
3) On the other hand, the person who receives cards in the round, gains only 1 card if he wins the round and loses 2 cards if he loses the round.
4) Finally the person who wins in one round, serves in the next round.
5) The game is stopped when a player loses all his cards.
The given statements are
A) Tweeto must have won exactly two rounds.
B) I must have won the first round.
C) Tweeto must have won the third round.
Since we started the card game with 5 cards each and I started of the first round, at the end of three rounds I can have 4 cards due to any one of the following two results.
First Result :
I served in the first round and won. Hence I served in the second round but lost. Tweeto served in the third round and again I lost thus ending up with 4 cards.
The number of cards with me and Tweeto is tabulated below.
Round      Me    Tweeto
Initially     5           5
Round 1    7           3
Round 2    6           4
Round 3    4           6
Applying the given statements  to the above table, we can observe that statements A and C are true since Tweeto won exactly two rounds and Tweeto won the third round. Statement B is true here because I won the first round.
Second Result :
I served in the first round and lost. Hence Tweeto served in the second round but he lost. I served in the third round and I lost thus ending up with 4 cards.
The number of cards with me and Tweeto is tabulated below.
Round     Me    Tweeto
Initially     5           5
Round 1    4           6
Round 2    5           5
Round 3    4           6
Applying the given statements  to the above table, we can observe that statements A and C are true since Tweeto won exactly two rounds and Tweeto won the third round. Statement B is false here because I lost the first round.
Hence it is clear from both the results that statements A and C must be true for me to end up with 4 cards at the end of three rounds.
Response:
Let  

P₀ = 5 , T₀ = 5        (initial cards of “I” and “Tweeto”)  
S₁ = P                  (I serve in the 1st round)  

For every round  

• If the server wins:  server +2, receiver –2  
• If the receiver wins: receiver +1, server –1  
• The winner of a round serves next round.  
• The game stops only when someone reaches 0 cards (not before).  

We list every possible three-round sequence of winners that can occur without the game ending prematurely and compute my final number of cards.

1. Round-1 winner = P  
   After R1:   P₁ = 7 , T₁ = 3 , server in R2 = P  

   (a) R2 winner = P  
       After R2: P₂ = 9 , T₂ = 1 , server in R3 = P  
       R3 winner cannot be P (T would need –1 card) so only R3 winner = T  
       After R3: P₃ = 8 , not 4 → discard.  

   (b) R2 winner = T  
       After R2: P₂ = 6 , T₂ = 4 , server in R3 = T  
       • R3 winner = P ⇒ P₃ = 7 → discard  
       • R3 winner = T ⇒ P₃ = 4 ✓ (Sequence P,T,T)

2. Round-1 winner = T  
   After R1:   P₁ = 4 , T₁ = 6 , server in R2 = T  

   (a) R2 winner = T  
       After R2: P₂ = 2 , T₂ = 8 , server in R3 = T  
       • R3 winner = T ⇒ P₃ = 0 (game ends)  
       • R3 winner = P ⇒ P₃ = 3   → discard  

   (b) R2 winner = P  
       After R2: P₂ = 5 , T₂ = 5 , server in R3 = P  
       • R3 winner = P ⇒ P₃ = 7 → discard  
       • R3 winner = T ⇒ P₃ = 4 ✓ (Sequence T,P,T)

Thus the only legal three-round histories giving me exactly 4 cards at the end are  

  (i) P wins, T wins, T wins  (P,T,T)  
  (ii) T wins, P wins, T wins  (T,P,T)

Now check the three given statements against both possible histories:

                    (i)     (ii)  
A) Tweeto won exactly two rounds     ✔     ✔  
B) I won the first round                 ✔     ✘  
C) Tweeto won the third round          ✔     ✔  

Statements A and C are true in every possible case; statement B is not.

Final answer: Statements A and C must be true.

Question:
Phil Fegit was sitting in his bedroom watching the torrential rain pour down on his home town of MADADIA.  The water had caused floods throughout the town and water over six feet deep had forced people to abandon the downstairs of their homes and they had to retreat to the upstairs rooms. The yearly Kebab harvest had been washed away as the downpour had continued unabated for a full month.
Just at that moment Phil's wife, Norma, walked into the bedroom and he commented upon the rain. She replied that she could really care less. No matter how much Phil tried to stress the importance of the rain falling in Madadia, she refused to take it seriously.
How come?
Human Solution:
Phil was watching a news report about his home town on TV, he had recently moved away from the area and it was sunny where he was.
His wife wasn't from Madadia, hence she didn't care what happened there.
Response:
• “Madadia”, the six-foot-deep water, the washed-out “kebab harvest”, etc., read like something out of a disaster movie or a computer game, not real life.  
• Nothing in the story actually says Phil is looking out the window; we are only told he is “watching” the rain fall on his home town while sitting in the bedroom.  
• If it really were raining that hard on their own house they would already be flooded, yet Norma walks in calmly and is completely unconcerned.  
• The simplest way to reconcile those facts is that Phil is looking at a screen – a TV programme, a video game (think Sim City), or some other fictional depiction of “Madadia”.  
• To Norma it is just make-believe, so when Phil tries to impress on her how terrible the storm is she “could really care less”.

Final answer: The downpour Phil is excited about is only happening in a film/game he is watching, not in the real world, so Norma quite reasonably doesn’t take it seriously.

Question:
There were 9 portraits of animals (bear, cat, dog, hamster, horse, lion, monkey, mouse, and tiger) on a wall of a museum.  As I was studying them, I tripped and fell into the wall and they all fell down. I have to get them back up on the wall in the correct order before I get into some serious trouble.  I only remember a couple of things about the order of the portraits.  Can you help me figure out the order of the portraits using the clues I remember about them?
They were displayed as follows:
Note: The Letter and Numbers in the graph are labels for their corresponding rows.
...........A...............B.............C
1    _________ l _________ l _________
2    _________ l _________ l _________
3    _________ l _________ l _________
Clues:
1.  The bear is in the same row as the hamster.
2.  Two portraits in both rows 3 and C have two animals that start with the same letter.
3.  The horse is in the same row as the monkey.
4.  The dog is in 2A.
5.  Either the lion or the tiger is below the cat.
6.  The monkey is either above or below the dog.
7.  The dog is not next to the tiger.
Hint: Monkey, mouse, hamster, horse are the only two pairs with same letter. Focus on this
Human Solution:
bear      l cat        l hamster
dog       l lion       l tiger
monkey l mouse  l horse
Response:
The portraits must be arranged like this:

Row 1: Bear  Cat  Hamster  
Row 2: Dog  Lion  Tiger  
Row 3: Monkey Mouse Horse

(That is, 1A = Bear, 1B = Cat, 1C = Hamster, 2A = Dog, 2B = Lion, 2C = Tiger, 3A = Monkey, 3B = Mouse, 3C = Horse.)

Final answer: 1A Bear, 1B Cat, 1C Hamster, 2A Dog, 2B Lion, 2C Tiger, 3A Monkey, 3B Mouse, 3C Horse

Question:
In the purely fictitious land of Fiddledeboox, the Minister of Finance emerged from a top-level meeting.   Reporters had gathered to hear his announcement about either an increase or a decrease in either wages, subsidies or tax levels.
It was widely known that this Minister [M] told the truth to reporters [R] only once in every three statements.
M:  Well, I can tell you that it's about subsidies.
R:  Are they going down again?
M:  Nothing is going down.
R:  So it's good news for the people?
M:  Of course.  Either subsidies are going down or there will be a wage increase.
While others jostled to ask the next question, one logically minded newshound was already leaving with the hot headline news.
From the Minister's three statements above, can you also deduce the truth?
Hint:
Assume each statement, in turn, to be true.  Then examine the truth or otherwise of the others.
Or check the statements in the light of each of the six possibilities.
Human Solution:
It was a tax increase.
Solution:
Remember that only one statement can be true.
If (1) is true then either (2) or (3) will be true as well.  So (1) is a lie.
If (3) is true, either (1) or (2) would be also true.  So (3) is a lie.
If (2) is true, it must be either wages or taxes going up or (1) would be true.  It cannot be wages, making (3) true, so taxes are increasing.
There are other ways of deducing this gloomy news.
Response:
Let the six possible economic moves be  
1) wage ↑ 2) wage ↓ 3) subsidy ↑ 4) subsidy ↓ 5) tax ↑ 6) tax ↓.

Number the minister’s utterances:

S1: “It’s about subsidies.”      (true exactly when 3 or 4 happens)  
S2: “Nothing is going down.”     (true exactly for cases 1, 3, 5)  
S3: “Either subsidies are going down or there will be a wage increase.”  
                 (true for cases 1 or 4)

Because the minister tells the truth once and only once in every block of three statements, exactly one of S1, S2, S3 must be true.

Check each of the six possibilities:

• wage ↑ :  S1 F, S2 T, S3 T → two truths – impossible  
• wage ↓ :  S1 F, S2 F, S3 F → zero truths – impossible  
• subsidy ↑ :  S1 T, S2 T, S3 F → two truths – impossible  
• subsidy ↓ :  S1 T, S2 F, S3 T → two truths – impossible  
• tax ↑ :  S1 F, S2 T, S3 F → exactly one truth – possible  
• tax ↓ :  S1 F, S2 F, S3 F → zero truths – impossible

Only the fifth possibility (taxes rising) satisfies the “exactly one true statement” rule.  

Therefore the reporter could safely headline:

Final answer: Taxes are going up.

Question: There are 2008 eggs lying in front of you. I am also with you waiting to start the game. The goal of the game is to be the person to take that very last egg (or eggs) to win. You and I can each only take between 1 and 100 eggs at a time. You go first. How many eggs must you take initially in order to always win (assuming we both play perfectly)?
Hint: By a perfect game, that means over any two turns, the sum of the number of eggs  you and I take is the same (except of course, excluding the initial move you make).
Human Solution:
89 eggs.
In order to see this, look at the smallest way possible to guarantee a win; you leave me with 101 eggs. If I take 1 egg, you take all 100; if I take 100 eggs, you take the last one. Therefore you would always win.
If you try with 202, I can take from 1 to 100, so there is 201 to 102 left. Then you would take 100 or 1 egg(s) in order to leave me with 101 again. By simple analysis, you must take 101 eggs over two rounds in order to get down to 101.
19*101 = 1919, so we must take 2008-1919 = 89 eggs to start off with a multiple of 101.
Response:
We are playing the ordinary “take-away” game:

• There is one pile, initially containing 2008 eggs.  
• On every turn a player must remove between 1 and 100 eggs (inclusive).  
• The player who removes the last egg(s) wins.  
• Both players play perfectly.

Step 1.  Identify the losing (“P-”) positions.

Let k = 100, so the legal moves are 1,2,…,k eggs.  
In such a game the classical result is:

A pile size N is a losing position (P-position) ⇔ N ≡ 0 (mod k+1).

Reason:  
– If N is a multiple of k+1, every legal move leaves a non-multiple, so every move goes from a P-position to an N-position (winning for the next player).  
– Conversely, if N is not a multiple of k+1, one can remove exactly the remainder r = N mod (k+1) (1 ≤ r ≤ k) and leave a multiple of k+1, thereby reaching a P-position.  
Thus multiples of k+1 are precisely the positions from which the previous player can force a win.

Here k+1 = 101.  Therefore:

P-positions = {0, 101, 202, 303, …} (all multiples of 101).

Step 2.  Locate the current position with respect to P-positions.

Compute 2008 (mod 101):

101 × 19 = 1919,   
2008 − 1919 = 89.

So 2008 ≡ 89 (mod 101); it is NOT a multiple of 101, hence it is an N-position.  
Therefore the first player has a winning move: remove exactly the remainder (89) to leave a multiple of 101.

Step 3.  Exhibit the winning first move and strategy.

Take x = 89 eggs (1 ≤ x ≤ 100, so it is legal).  
After this move the pile contains 2008 − 89 = 1919 eggs, which equals 101 × 19, a P-position.

From then on adopt the “complement to 101” reply:  
Whatever number y (1 ≤ y ≤ 100) your opponent removes, you remove 101 − y on the following turn.  
Each pair of moves removes exactly 101 eggs, so after each of your turns the pile size is again a multiple of 101.  
Eventually the pile will be reduced from 101 to 0 on your move, and you will take the last egg(s).

Hence the unique required opening move, ensuring victory against perfect play, is to take 89 eggs.

Final answer: 89

Question:
There are 3 numbers 0-9.
Eric knows the product and says, "I know the numbers."
Then, everyone is told that one digit is exactly one greater than another.
Then, Luke is told one of the numbers and says, "Eric lied."
Then you are told the numbers add up to 11.
What are the numbers?
Hint: There are only so many combinations if two of the digits must be adjacent...
Human Solution:
0, 5, 6
Eric knows the product and claimed that he knows the numbers.
Luke is told a number and then he knows Eric lied.
If Luke had received an 8, the combination could be 8,8,8, which is the only combination that multiplies to 512; Luke wouldn't know Eric lied.
If Luke received 6, the combination could be 6,7,7 which is the only combination that multiplies to 294, so Luke wouldn't know Eric lied.
If Luke received 2 or 7; 2x7x7=98.
4 or 5; 4x5x5=100.
3 or 9; 3x9x9=243.
1; 1x1x1=1.
Luke would only know that Eric lied if Luke was given a 0.
Therefore one of the digits is 0.
The remaining two digits must add to 11 because 11-0=11.
Two of the digits are one apart so that leaves:
0 & 1 + 10
5 & 6 + 0
However, 10 isn't an option so it must be 0, 5, 6.
Response:
Reasoning in full:

1.  Let the three digits (order does not matter) be a, b, c ∈{0,…,9}.

2.  After the host’s first announcement everybody knows
      “at least one digit is exactly one greater than another”.
    So the triple must contain a consecutive pair.

3.  Later the host tells us that a + b + c = 11.  
    Listing all unordered triples of digits that sum to 11 gives  

        (0,2,9)   (0,3,8)   (0,4,7)   (0,5,6)
        (1,1,9)   (1,2,8)   (1,3,7)   (1,4,6)   (1,5,5)
        (2,2,7)   (2,3,6)   (2,4,5)
        (3,3,5)   (3,4,4)

4.  Keep only those that really contain a consecutive pair:

        (0,5,6) , (1,2,8) , (2,3,6) , (2,4,5) , (3,4,4).

5.  Now examine Luke’s remark.  
    Luke is shown one of the digits and immediately says
        “Eric lied – Eric could not possibly have known the numbers.”
    For Luke to be absolutely certain that Eric could not have known the triple
    from its product, the digit Luke sees must guarantee that the product
    is shared by many different triples.  

    •  If Luke is shown ‘0’, he knows the product is 0 and that
       countless triples give product 0, so Eric certainly could not
       have identified the numbers.  
    •  If Luke is shown any other digit d ≠ 0, there is at least one
       legal triple containing d whose product is unique
       (for example the triple (1,1,2) for d = 1, the triple (4,5,5)
       for d = 5, etc.).  
       Hence with a non-zero digit Luke could not be sure Eric was lying.

    Therefore Luke must have been shown the digit 0, and the actual triple
    must contain a 0.

6.  Among the five candidates in step 4 the only one that contains 0 is

        (0,5,6).

7.  Check all conditions:  
       •  Sum 0 + 5 + 6 = 11   ✔  
       •  5 and 6 are consecutive                     ✔  
       •  Product is 0, so Eric could not really have known the numbers,
         making his claim a lie and allowing Luke, who saw the 0,
         to state that fact with certainty.            ✔

All statements are satisfied only by the digits 0, 5 and 6.

Final answer: 0, 5, 6

Question:
What would be the missing letter ?
O Q L H R
I J F E Q
--------------
F G F C ?
Hint: Think mathematically.
Human Solution:
The missing letter is A.
Number the letters in order eg: A=1 B=2 C=3 etc.. then subtract the middle from the top, to give the bottom number. Assign that number to the appropriate letter to give the answer.
Response:
We convert each letter to its alphabetical position (A = 1, B = 2, …).

Row 1:  O  Q  L  H  R  →  15 17 12  8 18  
Row 2:  I  J  F  E  Q  →   9 10  6  5 17  
Row 3 should be Row 1 minus Row 2:

15 − 9 = 6   → F  
17 − 10 = 7  → G  
12 − 6 = 6   → F  
 8 − 5 = 3   → C  
18 − 17 = 1  → A  

Thus the missing letter is A.

Final answer: A

Question:
A bridge was guarded by an evil troll. The troll was very intelligent, but he was also a coward. He was afraid of anyone smarter than him. So every time anyone tried to cross the bridge, the troll would set up a test. If the traveler passed the test, he would be allowed to cross. Otherwise, the troll would eat him.
Three travelers, Al, Ben and Carl, came across the bridge. The troll told them, "You may only cross my bridge if you know the password." He wrote five three-letter words on a rock. The five words were HOE, OAR, PAD, TOE, and VAT.
He then said, "I will tell each of you a different letter from the password. If you know what the password is, I will let you pass. But don't tell anyone else your letter." He then whispered a letter from the password to each traveler so that neither of the other two could hear him.
Then the troll asked Al, "Do you know what the password is?" "Yes," said Al, and the troll let him pass.
Then the troll asked Ben, "Do you know what the password is?" "Yes," said Ben, and the troll let him pass.
Then the troll asked Carl, "Do you know what the password is?" "Yes," said Carl, and the troll let him pass.
So, what is the password?
Hint:
1. Ben used Al's answer, and Carl used both Al's and Ben's answers.
2. Al's letter could not have been E.
Human Solution:
The password was HOE.
The only letters unique to one of the five words were D, H, P, R, and V. One of these letters must have been Al's, since he could determine the password. The only word without any of these letters is TOE. So the password could not have been TOE.
Ben knew this and now had four words to think of. The only letters unique to one word were D, E, H, P, R, T, and V. The password must have contained at least two unique letters, one for Al and the other for Ben, since they were both able to determine the password. The only word with only one of these letters was OAR. So OAR could not have been the password.
Carl knew this and now had three words to think of. The only letters unique to one word were D, E, H, O, P, T, and V. The password must have included three of these letters, since all three were able to determine the password. The only one of the three words containing three such letters was HOE, so this must have been the password.
Response:
Reasoning

1.  The password is one of the five words  
      HOE   OAR   PAD   TOE   VAT.

2.  Each traveller gets a different letter of the chosen word and is asked, in turn, whether he knows the password.
    •  When Al is asked he has heard nothing from the others.  
       The only way he can already be certain of the word is if the letter he was given occurs in only one of the five words.  
       The letters that appear in only one word are  
            H (only in HOE) R (only in OAR) P, D (only in PAD) V (only in VAT).  
       Therefore Al must have received one of these unique letters.

3.  Ben hears Al answer “Yes.”  
    From that alone Ben can conclude that Al received a unique letter.  
    Ben now looks at the words that contain his own letter and keeps only those in which some other letter is unique (so that Al could have known).  
       •  If Ben’s letter is E the possibilities are HOE or TOE.  
         TOE has no unique letter, so Ben knows the word must be HOE and answers “Yes.”  
       •  If Ben’s letter is anything else it does not allow such a deduction.  
    Hence the only way Ben can truthfully answer “Yes” is if
            Ben has E and the password is HOE.

4.  Carl hears both “Yes” answers and knows his own letter O.  
    The words containing O are HOE, OAR and TOE.  
      – TOE is impossible because Al could not have known at the start (no unique letter).  
      – In OAR Ben could not have been certain with either of the letters left to him (O or A), so Ben would have answered “No.”  
      – That leaves only HOE.  
    Therefore Carl can also answer “Yes”.

5.  No other word allows all three travellers to be certain in turn, so the password must be

HOE.

Final answer: HOE

Question:
In the following code, each symbol stands for one of five letters.
! stands for R, U, O, N, or V
? stands for U, D, L, W, or J
@ stands for A, G, P, E, or Y
; stands for O, M, I, C, or S
The four letter code word, @!;?, can be translated into two English words that are opposites. What are the two words?
Hint: Morality
Human Solution: Good and Evil.
Response:
Step-by-step reasoning

1.  List the possible letters for each symbol.

   @  →  A, G, P, E, Y  
   !  →  R, U, O, N, V  
   ;  →  O, M, I, C, S  
   ?  →  U, D, L, W, J  

2.  We need two different 4-letter words built from the same pattern @!;?, and the two words must be opposites (antonyms).

3.  Look for a well-known pair of opposite 4-letter words.  A classic pair is GOOD and EVIL.

4.  Check whether each of these words can be formed from the allowed letters:

   GOOD  
   • G (allowed for @)  
   • O (allowed for !)  
   • O (allowed for ;)  
   • D (allowed for ?)  

   EVIL  
   • E (allowed for @)  
   • V (allowed for !)  
   • I (allowed for ;)  
   • L (allowed for ?)  

   Both words fit perfectly within the permitted choices.

5.  Therefore, the pattern @!;? can encode either GOOD or EVIL, which are opposite in meaning.

Final answer: GOOD and EVIL

Question: Adam, Ben and Cyril were born in 1309, 1310 and 1311 on the same road in old Jerusalem. They lived their whole life there, and all lived to be over 60. They also had a full active life. However, they never crossed paths with each other. Why should that be so?
Hint: Calendar differences?
Human Solution: Adam was a Muslim, Ben was a Christian and Cyril was a Jew. Adam was born in 1309 of the Muslim calendar, Ben 1310 in the Christian calendar and Cyril 1311 in the Jewish calendar. Cyril was born over 3000 years before Ben, who in turn was born 619 years before Adam.
Response:
The puzzle makes us think of calendar years, but the numbers 1309-1311 are really street-numbers, not dates.

•  Adam, Ben and Cyril are the names that the inhabitants gave to three neighbouring houses standing at numbers 1309, 1310 and 1311 on the same road in old Jerusalem.  
•  A house is “born’’ when it is built. All three buildings were put up (i.e. “born’’) at those numbers.  
•  Each house remained standing for more than sixty years, was continuously occupied, and so had a “full, active life’’.  
•  Because houses do not move, they could never “cross paths’’ with one another, even though they were side by side their whole lives.

Thus the three “lives’’ belonged to buildings, not people, which is why Adam, Ben and Cyril never met. 

Final answer: Adam, Ben and Cyril were the names of three adjacent houses numbered 1309, 1310 and 1311; being buildings, they never moved and therefore never crossed one another’s path.

Question:
In the following code, each symbol stands for one of five letters.
* stands for L, T, K, C, or N
) stands for D, O, E, H, or S
+ stands for N, G, I, O, or X
( stands for Y, T, E, P, or F
_ stands for R, B, M, A, or S
The five letter code word, (+_*), can be translated into two English words that are opposites. What are the two words?
Hint: In music...
Human Solution: Forte and Piano.
Response:
We read the code word symbol-by-symbol and, for each symbol, pick one of the five possible letters assigned to it.

Symbol sequence: ( + _ * )

Allowed letters  
( : Y / T / E / P / F  
+ : N / G / I / O / X  
_ : R / B / M / A / S  
* : L / T / K / C / N  
) : D / O / E / H / S  

Choice 1  
( → P + → I _ → A * → N ) → O  
gives the word PIANO.

Choice 2  
( → F + → O _ → R * → T ) → E  
gives the word FORTE.

In musical terminology “piano” means “soft” while “forte” means “loud”; they are opposites.

Final answer: PIANO and FORTE

Question:
In the following code, each symbol stands for one of five letters.
- stands for E, O, L, C, or W
= stands for J, K, U, R, or S
* stands for B, O, P, F, or C
+ stands for D, G, I, M, or A
/ stands for F, N, H, E, or R
The five letter code word, */+-=, can be translated into two English words that are opposites. What are the two words?
Hint: Law
Human Solution: Order and Chaos.
Response:
The pattern */+-= represents a five-letter word whose letters must be chosen, position by position, from the given symbol–letter sets:

*  →  B, O, P, F, C  
/  →  F, N, H, E, R  
+  →  D, G, I, M, A  
-  →  E, O, L, C, W  
=  →  J, K, U, R, S  

We need two English words that
1. each fit this template, and  
2. are opposites.

Search systematically:

1st letter (*): B / C / F / O / P  
2nd letter (/): F / N / H / E / R  

Trying the common consonant pair “CH…” gives:

C (from *) + H (from /) → “CH_ _ _”

3rd letter (+) can be A, and 4th letter (-) can be O, giving “CHAO_”.

The 5th letter (=) can be S, producing the word

CHAOS

Now look for its opposite.  A natural antonym is ORDER.  Check if ORDER fits the same template:

O (from *)  
R (from /)  
D (from +)  
E (from -)  
R (from =)

All five letters belong to their respective sets, so ORDER is valid.

Thus the code word */+-= can be decoded as either

CHAOS or ORDER,

which are opposites.

Final answer: CHAOS and ORDER

Question:
runway : cinema
answer : ?
Directions: Ratios usually involve numbers.  This word ratio is a little different in that all four words in the ratio are somehow related.  Can you find a word that completes the ratio?
(Note: there is more than one possible answer.)
Hint: Look within the spellings...
Human Solution:
Any 6-letter word with the letters "se" in the middle will complete the word ratio. Possible answers include the words absent, assert, bisect, desert, insect, itself, losers, misery, museum, resent, unseen, wisely, etc.
The middle two letters of each of the words in the ratio represents a direction. The embedded directions relate to the position of the word within the ratio.
ruNWay: ciNEma
anSWer: abSEnt
Response:
Think of each pair as “thing : place where that thing is found / presented.”

• A plane uses a runway.  
• A movie is shown in a cinema.  

So the pattern is  
(place for planes) : (place for movies) :: (answer) : (place where answers are found).

The ordinary place you look for or supply an answer is in a question.  
(Other words such as “exam,” “test,” etc. would also fit, which is why the problem says more than one answer is possible.)

Final answer: question

Question:
John, Paul, George, and Ringo were playing a card game. Each player had three cards, one of the four suits was the "high suit." When each player played one card, this was a "trick." The first card played in a trick was the "leading suit." Here are the cards in each man's hand:
John: club, heart, diamond
Paul: club, spade, spade
George: club, heart, heart
Ringo: spade, diamond, diamond
If possible, each player had to play the leading suit for each trick. If they couldn't do that, they had to play the high suit. And if they couldn't do that, they could play any card. A player who won a trick had to lead the next trick. Each of the three tricks consisted of the leading card, exactly one other card of the same suit, exactly one card of the high suit which won its player the trick, and exactly one other card. Which suit was the high suit?
Hint:
This makes the puzzle too easy. Please stop reading if you don't want it to be too easy.
Lucy in the sky with...
Human Solution:
The high suit is diamonds.
The first trick obviously required two cards of the leading suit, and since everyone had to play the leading suit if possible, there had to be two people who had at least one card of the first leading suit. But since John, Paul, and George each had a club, the first leading suit could not have been a club.
