If the first leading suit was a heart, then the high suit had to be a card of which only one of Paul and Ringo had. This means it could only have been a club or a diamond. Similarly, if the first leading suit was a spade, the high suit could only have been a diamond, and if the leading suit was a diamond, the high suit could only have been a heart or a spade.
If the first leading suit was a heart, the second trick was led by either Paul or Ringo, and the leading suit had to be a spade. If the first leading suit was a spade, the second trick was led by John, and the leading suit could have been a club or a heart. If the first leading suit was a diamond, the second trick was led by either Paul or George, and the leading suit was a club. Now we can deduce the six possible leading suits and high suits for the whole game:
1. heart, heart, club
spade, spade, club
diamond, diamond, club
2. heart, heart, diamond
spade, spade, diamond
club, club, diamond
3. spade, spade, diamond
club, club, diamond
heart, heart, diamond
4. spade, spade, diamond
heart, heart, diamond
club, club, diamond
5. diamond, diamond, heart
club, club, heart
spade, spade, heart
6. diamond, diamond, spade
club, club, spade
heart, heart, spade
Game 1 cannot be possible because Paul would have led the spade and John and George would both have played a club, making two cards of the high suit. Games 5 and 6 cannot be possible because no one had both hearts and spades. This leaves only games 2, 3, and 4, which all have diamonds as the high suit.
Response:
Reasoning (detailed):

1.  Exactly one card of the high-suit (trump) must appear in each trick.  
    Therefore the high suit can never be the leading suit (otherwise there would be
    at least two cards of that suit in the trick).

2.  If a player cannot follow the leading suit he must play a trump if he has one.  
    Consequently, in every trick at most one of the four players may lack the leading
    suit and still possess a trump; otherwise two trumps would be forced to be played,
    contradicting “exactly one card of the high suit”.

3.  Examining each possible choice of high suit:

    •  High suit = Spades  
       Hearts are held by no one with spades, so a heart lead would force both
       Paul and Ringo to play spades – two trumps in one trick.  Impossible.

    •  High suit = Hearts  
       A spade lead would make both John and George play hearts – again two trumps
       in the same trick.  Impossible.

    •  High suit = Clubs  
       A diamond lead would oblige both Paul and George to play clubs – two trumps.
       Impossible.

    •  High suit = Diamonds  
       This choice passes every consistency test; an explicit play sequence exists:

       Trick 1  John leads ♥, George follows ♥, Paul (no ♥, no ♦) plays ♣,  
            Ringo (no ♥, has ♦) plays ♦ and wins.

       Trick 2  Ringo leads ♠, Paul follows ♠, John (no ♠, has ♦) plays ♦ and wins,  
            George (no ♠, no ♦) plays ♥.

       Trick 3  John leads ♣, George follows ♣, Paul (no ♣, no ♦) plays ♠,  
            Ringo (no ♣, has ♦) plays ♦ and wins.

       Each trick contains exactly two cards of the leading suit, one diamond (the
       sole trump), and one card of a fourth suit, satisfying all the conditions.

Since diamonds are the only suit for which all requirements can be met,  

Final answer: Diamonds

Question:
Mad Ade sat at home, waiting for his favourite TV program "I'm a celebrity, Get me a Kebab" to start. He glanced at his clock and began to wonder strange and wondrous things, but that is another story altogether.
He realised that he could leave 6 adjacent numbers of the face of a clock intact and rearrange the other 6 in such a way that the sum of every pair of adjacent numbers is prime.
Unfortunately the TV program started at that point so he never actually got around to doing it. Can you find the two possible solutions to Mad Ade's clock teaser?
Hint: Part of it is making sure each number is odd...
Human Solution:
Imagining the number on a clock face in a clockwise order they would be
1 2 3 4 7 10 9 8 5 6 11 12
Or
1 2 3 4 9 10 7 6 5 8 11 12
Response:
Reasoning  

1.  Any prime larger than 2 is odd, hence every “prime–sum” pair must be one even
   and one odd number.  
   Therefore the numbers round the clock have to alternate odd / even exactly as
   they do on an ordinary dial.  Whatever is moved must stay on places of the
   same parity.

2.  Pick the six consecutive numbers that are to be left untouched.  
   For the five adjacencies inside that block their sums have to be prime.
   Testing the twelve possible 6-blocks

   12 1 2 3 4 5 ( 4+5=9 )  
   1 2 3 4 5 6 ( 4+5=9 )  
   2 3 4 5 6 7 ( 4+5=9 )  
   3 4 5 6 7 8 ( 4+5=9 )  
   4 5 6 7 8 9 ( 4+5=9 )  
   5 6 7 8 9 10 ( 7+8=15 )  
   6 7 8 9 10 11( 7+8=15 )  
   7 8 9 10 11 12( 7+8=15 )  
   8 9 10 11 12 1(10+11=21)  
   9 10 11 12 1 2(10+11=21)  
   10 11 12 1 2 3(10+11=21)  
   11 12 1 2 3 4   ✔︎  

   only the block 11-12-1-2-3-4 works (all five sums are 23,13,3,5,7).

   Hence these six numbers are frozen in their normal positions.
   The places 5-6-7-8-9-10 have to be filled with the six numbers
   5,6,7,8,9,10.

3.  Keep the parity alternation:

        position : 5   6   7   8   9   10  
        parity   : O   E   O   E   O    E  
        numbers  :  ?   ?   ?   ?   ?    ?

        odd  numbers to use → 5,7,9  
        even numbers to use → 6,8,10

   Write down the seven prime-sum conditions that involve those places  

        4+5 , 5+6 , 6+7 , 7+8 , 8+9 , 9+10 , 10+11

   (4 and 11 are fixed).

4.  Solving those simultaneous constraints gives exactly two admissible
   permutations of the six movable numbers:

   • 7 10 9 8 5 6  
   • 9 10 7 6 5 8

5.  Translating them back on to the clock face we get the two solutions
   (written clockwise, starting at 12):

   Solution 1  
     12, 1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 10, 9, 8, 5, 6, 11

   Solution 2  
     12, 1, 2, 3, 4, 9, 10, 7, 6, 5, 8, 11

   In both dials every pair of neighbouring numbers adds to a prime.

Final answer:  
(1) 12-1-2-3-4-7-10-9-8-5-6-11  
(2) 12-1-2-3-4-9-10-7-6-5-8-11

Question: There are 10 people who could be the owner of the bank. They all sit in separate chairs across a long table facing north. The table is made of aluminium. The owner of the bank sits next to M. M sits on the left side of the banker. M sits next to C. C sits 4 places to the left of L. L sits next to O and rarely talks to S, E or Z, because they hate him and because they sit on the far right of the bank. O does not sit next to the owner of the bank. The two people left are F and T. T hates the owner of the bank and is considering resigning. Give the names of all the bankers from left to right.
Hint: Think from the banker's point of view and draw a diagram.
Human Solution: TCMBFLOSEZ.
Response:
Let the ten chairs be numbered 1 ( extreme left ) to 10 ( extreme right ), everybody is facing north, so “left of” means the lower-numbered chair.

1.  From  
   • “The owner of the bank sits next to M” and  
   • “M sits on the left side of the banker”,  
   we get the consecutive order … C M B… with M immediately to the left of the Banker B.

2.  “M sits next to C”, therefore C M B must be three consecutive chairs.

3.  “C sits 4 places to the left of L”.  
   If C occupies chair x, then L must be in chair x + 4.

4.  “L sits next to O”, so O is either immediately to the left or to the right of L.

5.  “O does not sit next to the owner of the bank”, so O cannot be adjacent to B.

6.  “S, E, Z … sit on the far right of the bank”; the only way for three people to be “far right” is to place them in the three right-most seats 8, 9 and 10 (order among them still unknown).

Because chairs 8–10 are now fixed for S, E, Z, C cannot be 4, 5, 6, or 7 (otherwise L would land in seats 8–11, which is impossible).  
The only feasible values are C = 1 or C = 2.  Consider them in turn.

• Case 1 C = 1 ⇒ M = 2 ⇒ B = 3 ⇒ L = 5.  
  L is in 5, so O must be in 4 or 6; 4 is impossible (adjacent to B) so O = 6.  
  The remaining two people are F, T; seats 4 and 7 are free.  
  Since “T hates the owner”, put T as far from B as possible, i.e. seat 7.  
  That leaves F in seat 4.

 Arrangement: 1 C 2 M 3 B 4 F 5 L 6 O 7 T 8 S 9 E 10 Z

• Case 2 C = 2 ⇒ M = 3 ⇒ B = 4 ⇒ L = 6.  
  Then O must be in 5 or 7; 5 is impossible (adjacent to B) so O = 7.  
  Seats 1 and 5 remain; put T (who hates B) in the one not next to B, i.e. seat 1, and F in seat 5.

 Arrangement: 1 T 2 C 3 M 4 B 5 F 6 L 7 O 8 S 9 E 10 Z

In Case 2, L (seat 6) is only two seats away from the “far-right” group, contradicting that he “rarely talks to S, E or Z … because they sit on the far right”.  
Case 1 places L at a comfortable distance (three or more seats away), fully explaining the “rarely talks” remark, so Case 1 is the uniquely consistent seating.

Hence the ten people, from left to right, are:

C, M, Owner of the bank, F, L, O, T, S, E, Z

Final answer: C – M – Owner – F – L – O – T – S – E – Z

Question:
Nick has always wanted one, so he goes out and buys a brand new one for £5000.  Unfortunately the next day he breaks it, so he goes out again and gets another brand new one. This time however, it only costs him £25. The next day someone offers to buy it off of him for £6000.
What is it ?
Human Solution: A personalised number plate.
Response:
Step–by–step reasoning

1. We are looking for something that  
   • can legitimately cost a great deal of money when you first acquire it (≈ £5000);  
   • can literally be “broken” the next day (so you need another one);  
   • the replacement itself is cheap (≈ £25);  
   • yet the thing as a whole can later be resold for even more than you first paid (≈ £6000).

2. Think of items that consist of two different parts:  
   • a valuable, transferable right or title, and  
   • a cheap physical token that simply displays that right.

3. A personalised (cherished) car registration/number-plate in the UK fits perfectly:  
   • The registration number itself (the right to use that mark on a vehicle) is what costs thousands; buying it from the DVLA or at auction for £5000 is entirely plausible.  
   • The physical plates screwed onto the car are just bits of plastic or metal. If Nick accidentally snaps or “breaks” one, a motor-factors shop will make him a brand-new pair for about £25.  
   • Replacing the plate doesn’t affect the ownership of the valuable registration number.  
   • Because personalised registrations can appreciate, someone might well offer him £6000 for the right to that same number the following day.

4. No other common object matches all four monetary facts so neatly.

Final answer: his personalised car registration (number plate).

Question:
Four friends named Jane, June, Jean and Jenny discovered that, if a different non-zero integer was assigned to each letter of their names and added together, it produced their ages.
June is 17, Jenny is two years older, while Jane and Jean are both sweet 16.  All the girls agree that June is in her prime.  Can you find the numbers the girls assigned to each letter of their names?
(There are two possible answers.)
Hint: prime...
Human Solution:
J=2; U=7; N=5; E=3; A=6; Y=4
or
J=3; U=7; N=5; E=2; A=6; Y=4
The little clue 'June is in her prime' should have helped, as it suggests that all the numbers in her name are prime numbers.  As the total is 17 all the numbers must be less than 10, so:
J=2; U=7; N=5; E=3  (or J=3; U=7; N=5; E=2)
Setting these numbers in the word Jane or Jean we can conclude that
16=2+A+5+3, so A=6.
Putting these numbers in the word Jenny in the same way we find Y=4.
Response:
Let  

J, A, N, E, U, Y = the integers attached to the six different letters  
(all are non-zero and all different).

From the ages we have  

1.  J + A + N + E  = 16    (Jane)  
2.  J + U + N + E  = 17    (June)  
3.  J + E + 2N + Y = 19    (Jenny)

Subtract (1) from (2): U – A = 1 ⇒ U = A + 1 ……(4)

Subtract (1) from (3): (N + Y) – A = 3 ⇒ Y = 3 + A – N ……(5)

So every letter can be expressed with the three still unknown letters A, N, E and the
relation (4).

June is “in her prime”.
The only way four different positive integers can add to the prime 17 is with the four
small primes 2, 3, 5 and 7:

2 + 3 + 5 + 7 = 17.

Hence the four letters of J U N E must be these four primes in some order.
Because U = A + 1, A must be the number that is one less than the prime chosen for U.

Trying the four possibilities gives

 U = 2  ⇒  A = 1  (but then two of the other primes must repeat 2 or 1 – impossible)  
 U = 3  ⇒  A = 2  (A would duplicate one of the primes – impossible)  
 U = 5  ⇒  A = 4  (an impossibility with the remaining conditions)  
 U = 7  ⇒  A = 6  (this is the only viable choice)

So we must have

A = 6, U = 7, and {J, N, E} = {2, 3, 5}.

Now (1) says        J + N + E = 16 – A = 10  
and (5) gives       Y = 3 + 6 – N = 9 – N.

Take the three cases for N:

N = 2   ⇒ Y = 7   (duplicates U) – impossible  
N = 3   ⇒ Y = 6   (duplicates A) – impossible  
N = 5   ⇒ Y = 4   works!

With N = 5 and Y = 4 we still have to place the remaining two numbers 2 and 3 on the
letters J and E.  Either order satisfies all three equations, so there are exactly two
solutions:

Solution 1     J = 2, E = 3, A = 6, N = 5, U = 7, Y = 4  
Solution 2     J = 3, E = 2, A = 6, N = 5, U = 7, Y = 4

(Checking, each set makes Jane and Jean 16, June 17 and Jenny 19, with every letter
holding a different non-zero integer.)

Final answer:  
Either  
J = 2, A = 6, N = 5, E = 3, U = 7, Y = 4  
or  
J = 3, A = 6, N = 5, E = 2, U = 7, Y = 4

Question: Some office workers were holding a daily pool on the number of doughnuts their boss would eat each weekday morning during March. Each person set aside funds in their desk with which to bet. Each day from Monday, March 3rd, they all bet a dollar - Kevin bet on 2, Kate on 3 and Kathy on 3.5 doughnuts. Kathy won twice as many times as Kevin, who was right once more than Kate; sometimes there was no winner. By April, they all had $20 in their desks. How much was the most anyone could have had in their desk at the beginning of March?
Hint: The pot does not accumulate if there is no winner - each person gets his "stake" back.
Human Solution:
$27
There would be 21 working days in a March where the first weekday is the third.  The combination of wins in which anyone will have lost the most money has a total of 19 wins (10 for Kathy, 5 for Kevin and 4 for Kate).  In this scenario, Kate would have lost 15 times ($15) and won 4 times ($8), for a net loss of $7.  Since she now has $20, she must have started with $27.
Response:
Let us translate the story into arithmetic.

1.  How many betting days?  
   Monday 3 March was the first day; counting every weekday through Monday 31 March gives  
   5 + 5 + 5 + 5 + 1 = 21 betting days.

2.  What is the cash flow for one person?  
   •  Every day he/she puts $1 into the pot (–$21 for the month).  
   •  When he/she wins, the pot (three dollars) comes back, i.e. the net gain for that day is +$2.  
      If a player wins w times, his/her net change for the month is  
         2w  –  (21–w)  = 3w – 21.

3.  Express the starting money in terms of wins.  
   Let Xi be the initial amount and wi the number of wins of player i; all three finish with $20.
        20  =  Xi  +  (3wi – 21)   ⇒   Xi = 41 – 3wi.

4.  Relate the three win–counts.  
   Kathy won twice as often as Kevin, Kevin won once more than Kate:
        wKathy = 2wKevin,      wKevin = wKate + 1.
   Write wKate = x.  Then
        wKevin = x + 1,     wKathy = 2(x + 1) = 2x + 2.

5.  The total number of winning days cannot exceed 21:
        x + (x+1) + (2x+2) = 4x + 3 ≤ 21  ⇒  x ≤ 4.
   Hence x can be 0,1,2,3,4.

6.  Compute each possible initial amount.

          x      Kate        Kevin        Kathy
          0       41          38           35
          1       38          35           29
          2       35          32           23
          3       32          29           17
          4       29          26           11

   The largest initial desk-total that appears in any admissible case is $41 (Kate, when x = 0).

7.  Is that scenario feasible?  
   Yes: choose 18 days with no winner, 1 day Kevin is right, 2 days Kathy is right.  
   Each player always has enough money to stake his/her dollar, and by the end all three have $20.

Therefore $41 is the greatest amount any of them could have had at the beginning of March.

Final answer: 41

Question:
When world-famous Madadian philosopher Torks G'Arbage was imprisoned for being a disturbing influence and relieving himself in a public place, he was held in high esteem by his guards, many of whom had followed Torks' teachings. All four of the guards hoped that something would occur that would facilitate his escape. One evening, the guard who was on duty accidentally on purpose left the cell door open so that Torks G'Arbage could leave for distant parts.
Torks G'Arbage did not attempt to escape, as it was his philosophy that if you accept society's rules, you must also accept its punishments. However, the open door was considered by the Madadian authorities to be a serious matter. It was not clear which guard was on that evening. When questioned, the four guards made the following statements in their defence:
Norris McDim:
A) I did not leave the door open.
B) Morris was the one who did it.
Nobby Shifty:
A) I was not the one who was on duty that evening.
B) Norris was on duty.
Morris the Daft:
A) Nobby was the one on duty that evening.
B) I hoped Torks G'Arbage would escape.
Robby O'Mental:
A) I did not leave the door open.
B) I was not surprised that Torks G'Arbage did not attempt to escape.
Considering that, in total, three statements are true and five statements are false, which guard is guilty?
Hint: For each person, assume they did it. Count how many truthful statements there are?
Human Solution:
Robby left the door open.
The one truth given is that all 4 guards hoped that Torks G'Arbage would escape, so statement B from Morris is a truth.
There are only 3 truthful statements.
If Norris had done it, then Nobby made 2 truthful statements and Robby's statement A would be true; making a total of 4 truths, so it can't be Norris.
If Nobby had done it, statement A from Norris would be true, both of Morris's statements would be true, and Robby's statement A would be true; again a total of 4, so it can't be Nobby.
If Morris had left the cell open, both of Norris's statements would be true, as would Nobby's statement A, Morris's statement B, and Robby's statement A; a total of 5 truths.
In Robby's case, in detail:
Norris A True
B False
Nobby A True
B False
Morris A False
B True
Dave A False
B False (why did he bother to leave the
cell door open?)
Response:
Let

• D(x) = “x was on duty that evening”.  
• O(x) = “x left the door open”.  
By the wording of the story the guard who was on duty is the one, and the only one, who left the door open, so

  O(x) ⇔ D(x)  and  exactly one D(x) is true.

There are eight statements; we are told exactly three of them are true.

Write the eight statements symbolically:

Norris McDim  
 1  ¬O(Norris)  
 2  O(Morris)

Nobby Shifty  
 3  ¬D(Nobby)  
 4  D(Norris)

Morris the Daft  
 5  D(Nobby)  
 6  H (“I hoped Torks would escape”)

Robby O’Mental  
 7  ¬O(Robby)  
 8  S (“I was not surprised that Torks did not escape”)

From the preamble we know all four guards hoped for Torks’s escape, so statement 6 is definitely true.

We must now find which single guard can be on duty so that exactly three of the eight statements are true (with statement 6 already counted as one of them).

Case A D(Norris) true  
True statements: 3, 4, 6, 7  (4 truths already) ⇒ too many.  Impossible.

Case B D(Nobby) true  
True statements: 1, 5, 6, 7  (4 truths) ⇒ too many.  Impossible.

Case C D(Morris) true  
True statements: 1, 2, 3, 6, 7  (5 truths) ⇒ too many.  Impossible.

Case D D(Robby) true  
Then O(Robby) is true and O(other) is false.

Truth table now:

1  ¬O(Norris)  true  
2  O(Morris)  false  
3  ¬D(Nobby)  true  
4  D(Norris)  false  
5  D(Nobby)  false  
6  H      true (fixed)  
7  ¬O(Robby)  false  
8  S      ? (free)

We already have exactly three true statements (1, 3, 6).  
To meet the total of three, statement 8 must be false.

This gives precisely three true and five false statements, satisfying the condition.

Therefore the only consistent possibility is that Robby O’Mental was the guard on duty and the one who left the door open.

Final answer: Robby O’Mental

Question:
John, Pete, Tom, George, and Steve are brothers. One day, one of them broke a window. When their father asked them who did it, they gave the following answers:
John: "It was Pete or Tom."
Pete: "It was neither George nor me."
Tom: "Both of you are lying."
Steve: "No, only one of them is lying."
George: "No, Steve, you are wrong."
Then their mother added: "Three of my sons are telling the truth, but I do not believe what the two others said."
Who broke the window?
Hint: If you find it difficult to use logic alone, then use trial and error by assuming each one of the five sons broke the window, and list whether they are telling a lie or the truth.
Human Solution: By assuming that each of the five brothers broke the window and seeing how many told the truth, only Tom can be the person who broke the window.
Response:
Let Bx mean “x broke the window” and let  

J : “Pete or Tom broke it.”  
P : “Neither George nor I broke it.”  
T : “John and Pete are both lying.”  
S : “Exactly one of John or Pete is lying.”  
G : “Steve is wrong.”   (i.e. ¬S)

Mother says exactly three statements are true and two are false.

Test each possible culprit.

1. Suppose Pete broke it.  
 J = true, P = false, T = false, S = true, G = false → only 2 truths. (Reject)

2. Suppose Tom broke it.  
 J = true (B_Pete∨B_Tom)  
 P = true (¬B_George∧¬B_Pete)  
 T = false (¬J∧¬P) is false because J and P are true  
 S = false “exactly one of J,P lying” is false (both are true)  
 G = true ¬S is true  
 Truth count = 3 (J, P, G). Fits mother’s remark.  (Accept)

3. Suppose George broke it.  
 Truth count = 2. (Reject)

4. Suppose John broke it.  
 Truth count = 2. (Reject)

5. Suppose Steve broke it.  
 Truth count = 2. (Reject)

Only the second case satisfies the condition. Therefore, Tom is the culprit.

Final answer: Tom

Question: A telephone number has the form ABC-DEF-GHIJ, where each letter represents a different digit. The digits in each part of the number are in decreasing order; that is, ABC, DEF, and GHIJ. Furthermore, D, E, and F are consecutive even digits; G, H, I, and J are consecutive odd digits; and A+B+C=9. What is A?
Hint: The consecutive even digits DEF can be 420, 642 or 864, while the consecutive odd digits GHIJ can be 7531 or 9753.
Human Solution:
The consecutive even digits DEF can be 420, 642 or 864, while the consecutive odd digits GHIJ can be 7531 or 9753.
Since A+B+C=9, none of them can be 9, and GHIJ must be 9753, and one of A, B, C is 1.
The other two add up to 8, which is obtained by 8+0.
Therefore, A, the biggest number of the three, is 8.
Response:
We search for digits A,B,C,D,E,F,G,H,I,J (all different) satisfying:

1. ABC, DEF, GHIJ are each in strictly decreasing order.
2. D,E,F are three consecutive even digits.
3. G,H,I,J are four consecutive odd digits.
4. A + B + C = 9.

Step 1 – list the possible consecutive‐even triples (written largest → smallest):

(8,6,4), (6,4,2), (4,2,0).

Step 2 – list the possible consecutive‐odd quadruples:

(9,7,5,3), (7,5,3,1).

Step 3 – try every combination of one even triple with one odd quadruple and see which unused digits remain for {A,B,C}. The three unused digits must be in decreasing order and sum to 9.

a) Even 864 with odd 9753  
   Used digits = {8,6,4,9,7,5,3}.  
   Leftover = {0,1,2}.  Decreasing order: 2,1,0 gives sum 3 ≠ 9 → reject.

b) Even 864 with odd 7531  
   Used digits = {8,6,4,7,5,3,1}.  
   Leftover = {0,2,9}.  9,2,0 → sum 11 ≠ 9 → reject.

c) Even 642 with odd 9753  
   Used digits = {6,4,2,9,7,5,3}.  
   Leftover = {0,1,8}.  8,1,0 → sum 9 ✔

   This meets every condition:  
   ABC = 810 (8>1>0, 8+1+0=9)  
   DEF = 642 (6>4>2, consecutive evens)  
   GHIJ = 9753 (9>7>5>3, consecutive odds).

d) Even 642 with odd 7531  
   Leftover {0,8,9} → 9,8,0 sum 17 → reject.

e) Even 420 with odd 9753  
   Leftover {1,6,8} → 8,6,1 sum 15 → reject.

f) Even 420 with odd 7531  
   Leftover {6,8,9} → 9,8,6 sum 23 → reject.

Only case (c) works, giving telephone number 810-642-9753.

Hence A = 8.

Final answer: 8

Question: I have 3 dads and 4 sisters. My immediate family (living in my house) consists of 7. Two of my sisters only have 2 dads. How is this possible?
Hint: My nephew lives with me and I'm the middle child.
Human Solution: I have a biological dad, who I don't know. An adopted dad- my sisters' dad and a step dad- who lives with me. My two younger sisters never knew my biological dad. My oldest sister (19) lives by herself. Her son lives with me, my 3 other sisters, my mom, and step dad.
Response:
Think “blended / adoptive” rather than purely biological.

• Three men (call them Adam, Ben and Carl) live together as partners.  
  They are the only adults in the household, so to the children they are the three
  “dads”.

• At first only Adam + Ben were a couple.  
  While it was just those two, they adopted two little girls – the two older
  sisters.  Legally only two parents can be put on an adoption
  certificate, so those two girls each have exactly two fathers: Adam and Ben.

• Some years later Carl joined the relationship.  
  After that the three men adopted two more girls; one of these younger girls is
  the speaker.  Because the family was now a trio, all three men are
  “Dad” to the younger girls.

So, for the speaker:

  – Dad 1 = Adam  
  – Dad 2 = Ben  
  – Dad 3 = Carl

For the two older sisters:

  – Dad 1 = Adam  
  – Dad 2 = Ben  
  (Carl is just “Carl”, not an official dad.)

Everyone lives in the same house, so the household is

  3 dads + 4 sisters = 7 people.

Hence:

• The speaker can truthfully say “I have 3 dads and 4 sisters.”  
• Two of her sisters can just as truthfully say they have only 2 dads.

That is how the apparently contradictory statements can all be true.

Question:
There are three brothers: Al, Ben, and Carl. Two of the three brothers are boxers. Here are some facts:
1. The shorter of Al and Ben is the older boxer.
2. The younger of Ben and Carl is the shorter boxer.
3. The taller of Al and Carl is the younger boxer.
Which brother is not a boxer?
Hint: Try to come up with a potential ordering of their heights and ages.
Human Solution:
Carl is not a boxer.
From fact 1, we know that Carl is not the older boxer.
From fact 3, we know that Ben is not the younger boxer.
We now have three possible scenarios:
1. Al is the younger boxer and Ben is the older boxer.
2. Ben is the older boxer and Carl is the younger boxer.
3. Al is the older boxer and Carl is the younger boxer.
If scenario 1 is true, fact 1 tells us that Ben is shorter than Al.
If scenario 2 is true, fact 1 tells us that Ben is shorter than Al; fact 3 tells us that Carl is taller than Al, making Ben shorter than Carl.
If scenario 3 is true, fact 3 tells us that Carl is taller than Al.
We can now expand our three scenarios:
1. Al is the younger, taller boxer, and Ben is the older, shorter boxer.
2. Ben is the older, shorter boxer, and Carl is the younger, taller boxer.
3. Al is the older, shorter boxer, and Carl is the younger, taller boxer.
Scenario 2 cannot be possible because it contradicts fact 2 by making the younger of Ben and Carl the taller boxer.
Fact 2 also tells us that Al is not the shorter boxer, so scenario 3 cannot be possible, either.
Therefore, scenario 1 is true, which means that Carl is not a boxer.
Response:
Let  
O = the Older of the two boxers,  
Y = the Younger of the two boxers,  
S = the Shorter of the two boxers,  
T = the Taller of the two boxers.  

Because there are exactly two boxers, the set {O , Y} = {S , T}.  
(One boxer is older/taller – or older/shorter – and the other is the remaining combination.)

Translate the three statements.

1.  “The shorter of Al and Ben is the older boxer.”  
    → the person who is shorter between Al and Ben is O.        …(A)

2.  “The younger of Ben and Carl is the shorter boxer.”  
    → the person who is younger between Ben and Carl is S.       …(B)

3.  “The taller of Al and Carl is the younger boxer.”  
    → the person who is taller between Al and Carl is Y.         …(C)

Now test the only three possibilities for O (the older boxer).

––––– 1.  O = Al –––––  
By (A) Al must be shorter than Ben.  
By (C) Y is the taller of Al and Carl, so Y is Carl (because Carl is taller than Al).  
Thus the two boxers would be Al (O) and Carl (Y).  
S is the shorter of the two boxers, i.e. Al.  
But (B) says S is the younger of Ben and Carl, so S must be either Ben or Carl – impossible.  
Contradiction ⇒ O ≠ Al.

––––– 2.  O = Carl –––––  
Impossible, because (A) states O is either Al or Ben.  
Therefore O ≠ Carl.

––––– 3.  O = Ben –––––  
By (A) Ben must be shorter than Al.                    …(1)

Y comes from (C): the taller of Al and Carl.  
This can only be Al or Carl.  Consider the two sub-cases.

   (i)  Y = Al  
        Then Al is taller than Carl.                  …(2)  
        The two boxers are Ben (O) and Al (Y).  
        S (the shorter boxer) is Ben.  
        By (B) S is the younger of Ben and Carl, hence Ben is younger than Carl.  …(3)  
        Combine: from O = Ben we already know Ben is older than Al, so  
                 Age order: Carl > Ben > Al, which is consistent.  
        Height order from (1) and (2): Ben < Al > Carl, no conflict.  
        All statements are satisfied – this sub-case works.

   (ii) Y = Carl  
        Then Carl is taller than Al.  
        The boxers would be Ben (O) and Carl (Y); S would still be Ben.  
        But (B) says Ben is the younger of Ben and Carl, contradicting Ben’s being the older boxer.  
        So this sub-case is impossible.

Only sub-case (i) is consistent.  
Therefore the two boxers are Ben (older, shorter) and Al (younger, taller).  
Carl is not a boxer.

Final answer: Carl

Question:
Andy dislikes the catcher. Ed's sister is engaged to the second baseman. The center fielder is taller than the right fielder. Harry and the third baseman live in the same building. Paul and Allen each won $20 from the pitcher at pinochle. Ed and the outfielders play poker during their free time. The pitcher's wife is the third baseman's sister. The pitcher, catcher, and infielders except Allen, Harry, and Andy, are shorter than Sam. Paul, Andy, and the shortstop lost $50 each at the racetrack. Paul, Harry, Bill, and the catcher took a trouncing from the second baseman at pool. Sam is involved in a divorce suit. The catcher and the third baseman each have two children. Ed, Paul, Jerry, the right fielder, and the center fielder are bachelors. The others are married. The shortstop, the third baseman, and Bill each cleaned up $100 betting on the fight. One of the outfielders is either Mike or Andy. Jerry is taller than Bill. Mike is shorter than Bill. Each of them is heavier than the third baseman.
Using these facts, determine the names of the men playing the various positions on the baseball team.
Hint: "The pitcher, catcher, and infielders except Allen, Harry, and Andy" implies these three people are part of the union of pitcher, catcher, infielders. The puzzle is filled with these kinds of hints
Human Solution: Harry is the pitcher, Allen the catcher, Paul the first baseman, Jerry the second baseman, Andy the third baseman, Ed the shortstop, Sam the left fielder, Mike the right fielder, and Bill the center fielder.
Response:
Pitcher – Harry  
Catcher – Allen  
First baseman – Paul  
Second baseman – Jerry  
Third baseman – Andy  
Shortstop – Ed  
Left fielder – Sam  
Center fielder – Bill  
Right fielder – Mike

Question:
On Sunday, December 22, four Madadian cruise ships - W, X, Y, Z - started their series of winter cruises to various ports around Madadia.
Ship W left at 4:00 PM on Sunday, December 22, for a series of 8-days cruises to Madport.
Ship X left at 4:30 PM on Sunday, December 22, for a series of alternating 11-days and 13-days cruises to Adeville.
Ship Y left at 5:00 PM on Sunday, December 22, for a series of 5-days cruises to Kebabtown.
Ship Z left on Monday for a series of 7-days cruises.
Each ship is scheduled to return back early in the morning after the last day of the cruise and leave again late in the afternoon of the same day.
On how many days occasions between December 22 and February 28 will three ships be moored at the port?
Hint: Find out the days on when each ship will be in port
Human Solution:
On no occasions (other than start date December 22) between December 22 and February 28, three ships will be moored at the port.
Find out the days on when each ship will be in port:
Ship W will be in port on days 1, 9, 17, 25, 33, 41, 49, 57 and 65.
Ship X will be in port on days 1, 12, 25, 36, 49, 60 and 73.
Ship Y will be in port on days 1, 6, 11, 16, 21, 26, 31, 36, 41, 46, 51, 56, 61 and 66.
Ship Z will be in port on days 1, 2, 9, 16, 23, 30, 37, 44, 51, 58 and 65.
From above data, it is clear that - on no occasion (other than December 22) will three ships be moored at the port.
Also, on 8 occasions, there will be 2 ships moored at the port.
Response:
Let “in port” mean the time from a ship’s early-morning arrival until its late-afternoon departure of the same day.  
Except for the very first Sunday (22 Dec), a ship is in port only on its return days.

1.  Work out every return day for each ship between 22 Dec and 28 Feb.

   • Ship W – 8-day cycle  
     30 Dec, 7 Jan, 15 Jan, 23 Jan, 31 Jan, 8 Feb, 16 Feb, 24 Feb  

   • Ship X – 11-, 13-, 11-, 13-, …  
     2 Jan, 15 Jan, 26 Jan, 8 Feb, 19 Feb  

   • Ship Y – 5-day cycle  
     27 Dec, 1 Jan, 6 Jan, 11 Jan, 16 Jan, 21 Jan, 26 Jan, 31 Jan,   
     5 Feb, 10 Feb, 15 Feb, 20 Feb, 25 Feb  

   • Ship Z – 7-day cycle (first sailing Monday 23 Dec)  
     30 Dec, 6 Jan, 13 Jan, 20 Jan, 27 Jan, 3 Feb, 10 Feb, 17 Feb, 24 Feb  

2.  Check each calendar day for how many ships are in port.

   – Every date listed above has at most two ships simultaneously (e.g. 30 Dec: W & Z; 26 Jan: X & Y; 10 Feb: Y & Z; 24 Feb: W & Z, etc.).  
   – No return day ever sees three ships together.

3.  Consider the special start-up day, Sunday 22 December.

   On the morning of 22 Dec all four vessels are still moored.  
   After 4 p.m., ship W departs, leaving X, Y and Z at the dock until 4 :30 p.m. (X) and 5 :00 p.m. (Y).  
   Thus 22 Dec is the only day on which three ships are simultaneously moored.

4.  There are no other days with three ships in port, and none at all after 24 Feb has only two (W & Z).

Hence, between 22 December and 28 February the required event occurs exactly once.

Final answer: 1

Question:
Henry and Gretchen are going to play a game.  Henry explains, "You and I will take turns saying numbers.  The first person will say a number between 1 and 10.  Then the other person will say a number that is at least 1 higher than that number, and at most 10 higher.  We will keep going back and forth in this way until one of us says the number 50.  That person wins.  I'll start."
"Not so fast!" says Gretchen.  "I want to win, so I will start."
What number should Gretchen say to start?
Hint: By following this strategy, she is assured a victory.  Think of all of the numbers she will want to say.
Human Solution:
She wants to say, "6."
The series of numbers she will say is 6, 17, 28, 39, 50.
Since she wants to say 50, she needs Henry to say a number between 40 and 49.  Therefore, she wants to say 39.
Knowing she wants to say 39, she needs Henry to say a number between 29 and 38.  So she wants to say 28.  Following this same logic recursively, she will want to say 17, and she will want to say 6 to start the game, and be assured victory.
Response:
Think backward from the winning number 50.

1. Ask: “What number do I want to make sure I say just before 50?”  
   Whatever Henry says, I must be able to reply with a number that is between 1 and 10 higher and lands exactly on 50.  
   That means I want to arrive at 39, because 50 – 39 can be any value from 1 to 10.

2. Next ask: “What number must I reach so that, no matter what Henry replies, I can force 39 on my following turn?”  
   That number is 28, because 39 – 28 is between 1 and 10.

3. Continue stepping backward by 11 (the fixed “gap” that one player can always make up for after the other’s move):
   50, 39, 28, 17, 6.

   If I ever say one of these “key” numbers, then whatever Henry says (being at most 10 higher), I can always add just enough (1–10) to reach the next key number.

4. Therefore the first key number in the list—and the only one I can legally open with (it is between 1 and 10)—is 6.

Game plan if I start with 6:
   I say 6.  
   Whatever Henry says (7–16), I answer with 17.  
   Whatever Henry says (18–27), I answer with 28.  
   Whatever Henry says (29–38), I answer with 39.  
   Whatever Henry says (40–49), I answer with 50 and win.

Hence, starting with 6 guarantees a win for Gretchen with perfect play, and any other opening number lets Henry adopt the same strategy and win instead.

Final answer: 6

Question:
One of four people - two men (Jack and Mike) and two women (Carol and Lily) - was murdered.
The following facts refer to the people mentioned:
(a) Jack's sister argued exactly once with Carol's legal husband after the murder.
(b) Mike's sister argued twice with the victim's legal spouse after the murder. Who was the victim?
Hint: They may or may not share sisters?
Human Solution:
Mike is the victim.
If Mike's sister and Jack's sister are the same person, then (a) reads "Lily argued exactly once with (Mike or Jack)" and (b) reads "Lily argued twice with (the same Mike or Jack)".  These two statements contradict each other.  Therefore Mike's sister must be different from Jack's sister.
If this is the case then there are two possibilities:
1)  Jack and Carol are brother and sister.  Mike and Lily are brother and sister.  Jack is married to Lily and Mike is married to Carol.  If this is the case, then (a) reads "Carol argued once with Mike" and (b) reads "Lily argued twice with herself", leaving Jack dead.  Since Lily did not likely argue with herself, this is not the solution.
2)  Jack and Lily are brother and sister.  Mike and Carol are brother and sister.  Jack is married to Carol and Lily is married to Mike.  If this is the case, then (a) reads "Lily argued once with Jack" and (b) reads "Carol argued twice with Lily", leaving Mike dead.  Since there are no contradictions, this is the solution.
Response:
Let  

Jack  = J (male)  
Mike  = M (male)  
Carol = C (female)  
Lily  = L (female)

For every person the “legal spouse’’ must be alive after the murder (otherwise an argument with that person could not take place). Brothers are not allowed to marry their own sisters.

Step 1.  Decide who Carol’s husband can be.

Statement (a): “Jack’s sister argued exactly once with Carol’s legal husband after the murder.’’  
So Carol’s husband must be alive.  
If the murdered person were J or M, his death would leave the other man alive; therefore only that living man can be Carol’s husband.

Step 2.  Test each possible victim.

1. Victim = Jack  
   Then Carol’s husband must be Mike (alive).  
   – If J’s sister = Carol, then Mike’s sister has to be Lily; but Lily would simultaneously be Jack’s widow, and statement (b) would force Lily to argue twice with herself – impossible.  
   – If J’s sister = Lily, then Mike’s sister would again have to be Lily (so that she is alive), but Lily cannot at the same time be Mike’s sister and Jack’s sister without causing statement (b) to fail.  
   ⇒ Impossible.

2. Victim = Mike  
   Carol’s husband must therefore be Jack (alive).  
   Let J’s sister be Lily (since Jack cannot marry his own sister).  
   Then statement (a) is satisfied: Lily argued once with Jack.  
   Mike’s sister cannot be Lily (she is Mike’s wife), so Mike’s sister is Carol.  
   Statement (b): Carol (alive) argued twice with the victim’s spouse, Lily (also alive).  
   All conditions are satisfied with no contradictions.  
   ⇒ This scenario works.

3. Victim = Carol  
   Jack’s sister must be Lily (Carol is dead).  
   Mike’s sister must also be Lily (so that she is alive).  
   But then Lily argued once (by (a)) and twice (by (b)) with the same man – contradiction.  
   ⇒ Impossible.

4. Victim = Lily  
   Jack’s sister has to be Carol (Lily is dead).  
   Carol is Jack’s sister and also, by (a), argued once with her own husband Mike; hence Carol is married to Mike.  
   The victim’s spouse must then be Jack, but Mike’s sister would have to be Lily (dead) or Carol (his wife) – both impossible.  
   ⇒ Impossible.

Only the second case is consistent.

Therefore the murdered person must have been Mike.

Final answer: Mike

Question:
Walter, Xavier, Yoshi, and Zeke crossed a river in a tiny rowboat. They all started on the same side of the river. They made three trips from the starting side to the destination side, and two trips from the destination side to the starting side. Here are some facts:
1. On each trip from the starting side of the river to the destination side, two people were in the boat, but only one person rowed the boat, and that person rowed the boat for the entire trip.
2. On each return trip, only one person was in the boat.
3. Walter is the weakest of the group. He could only row the boat if no one else is in it.
4. Xavier is the second weakest of the group. He can only row the boat if he is by himself or if Yoshi, the lightest of the group, is a passenger.
5. Each man rowed the boat at least once.
Who rowed twice?
Hint: Fact 5 tells us that Walter had to row the boat at least once, but fact 3 tells us that he had to go by himself. This means he could only row the boat on a return trip,.
Human Solution:
Yoshi rowed twice.
Fact 5 tells us that Walter had to row the boat at least once, but fact 3 tells us that he had to go by himself. This means he could only row the boat on a return trip, which means he rowed on at least one return trip.
The man who rowed twice could not have rowed on two trips from the starting side to the destination side, because he would have had to make a third trip by himself back to the starting side. So the man who rowed twice must have made a return trip at least once.
Now we know that if Walter made two trips, they must both have been return trips, and Xavier, Yoshi, and Zeke each rowed for one of the other three trips. If Walter made only one trip, the other person who made a return trip must have been the person who rowed twice (Xavier, Yoshi, or Zeke) and that person would also have made one of the other three trips. So the three trips from the starting side to the destination side must have been rowed by Xavier, Yoshi, and Zeke.
Fact 1 tells us that Xavier's trip to the destination side must have had a passenger, and fact 4 tells us that that passenger must have been Yoshi. Yoshi would have had to row back to row his trip to the destination side, or else Yoshi rowed to the destination side, then back to the start, then got rowed across by Xavier.
Response:
Reasoning step-by-step

1.  Label the men  
   W = Walter (weakest)  
   X = Xavier (second-weakest)  
   Y = Yoshi (lightest)  
   Z = Zeke  

2.  Trip pattern is fixed (because there are 3 outward and 2 return trips):  
        1. start → dest  (two aboard)  
        2. dest  → start (one aboard)  
        3. start → dest  (two aboard)  
        4. dest  → start (one aboard)  
        5. start → dest  (two aboard)

3.  Walter can row only when he is alone, so he must be the rower on one of the two return trips.  
    If he rowed on the first return (trip 2), the boat would be back on the starting side with only Walter in it; nobody could accompany him outward on trip 3 (he can’t row with a passenger), so that is impossible.  
    Therefore Walter rows the second return trip, trip 4.

4.  When trip 4 ends, Walter is back on the starting side with the boat.  
    Exactly one other man must be on that side with him (otherwise there would be too many people still to move).  
    Call that man M.  Those two men (Walter and M) will make the final outward trip 5.

5.  Walter cannot row with a passenger, so on trip 5 the rower must be M and Walter must be the passenger.  
    Consequently M must be able to row with Walter in the boat.

6.  Check who M could be.

    •  M = Xavier?  Not possible, because Xavier may row only by himself or with Yoshi as passenger, never with Walter.  

    •  M = Zeke?  
       For Zeke to be on the starting side with Walter before trip 5, he must be the man who returned alone in trip 2 (the only return trip available before trip 4).  
       That forces Zeke to row trips 2 and 5, and he must also have crossed to the destination side in trip 1 so he could row back in trip 2.  
       Then trip 3 would still need a legal rower on the starting side, but the only candidates there would be X and W; X cannot row with W passenger and W cannot row with a passenger at all.  Impossible.  

    •  The only remaining possibility is M = Yoshi.

7.  Therefore Yoshi is on the starting side with Walter after trip 4, rows the boat in trip 5 with Walter as passenger, and must also be the man who returned alone in trip 2.

8.  Thus Yoshi rows twice (trips 2 and 5).  
    The other three men each row exactly once (X on trip 1, Z on trip 3, W on trip 4), satisfying the condition that every man rows at least once.

Final answer: Yoshi

Question: There is a famous diamond displayed in a room that measures 15 meters by 15 meters by 15 meters. The room is made entirely of concrete blocks and the floor is covered with a thick carpet. The only thing in the room is the diamond that is housed under a glass cube. The glass cube stands on a one-meter pedestal in the centre of the room. Alarm wires spaced eight centimetres apart and running parallel to each other lie under the carpet. The alarm will trigger if more than four kilograms of pressure is applied to any individual wire. Will Carlo who weighs 74 kilograms was able to steal the famous diamond using the following equipment: a five meter 2 x 4 board, four leather straps (each two meters long and five cm wide), a hammer, and a saw. How could he do it without triggering the alarm?
Hint: How can he spread out his weight?
Human Solution: Will Carlo stole the diamond in the following manner: First, he cut five meter 2 x 4 boards in half. Then using the available straps, he fastened the two boards to his feet like skies. With the boards strapped to his feet, his weight was displacing enough so that he did not exceed the wire's weight tolerance and triggers the alarm. Carlo then slowly and carefully walked to the centre of the room, smashed the glass cube with the hammer, took the diamond and returned the same way he came in.
Response:
The alarm is only sensitive to the load that any ONE of the parallel wires receives.  
A wire will “cry” if it is pressed with more than 4 kg.  
Therefore Carlo’s task is simply to be sure that, at every moment, his weight (and later the weight of the diamond) is spread simultaneously over enough different wires so that no single one of them is ever asked to carry 4 kg.

Data
• Carlo’s mass ≈ 74 kg  
• Spacing of the wires = 8 cm = 0.08 m  
• Available timber = one 2 × 4 board, 5 m long  
(the cross–section of a 2 × 4 is about 5 cm × 10 cm)  
• Four leather straps, each 2 m long  
• Saw and hammer

1. Convert the board into two long “skis”.  
Carlo saws the 5-metre board in half, producing two planks each 2.5 m long
(2.5 m ≈ 250 cm long, 10 cm wide, 5 cm thick).

2. Lash each plank to a foot.  
With the four 2-metre straps he ties one plank solidly under each shoe, the planks pointing cross-wise to the direction of the wires (i.e. perpendicular to them).  
Each plank is therefore a 2.5-metre-long, 10-centimetre-wide “snow-shoe”.

3. Check the load per wire.  
Along the 2.5-metre length the plank crosses

 2.5 m ÷ 0.08 m ≈ 31 wires.

When Carlo is standing on ONE foot the whole 74 kg rests on those 31 wires:

 load per wire = 74 kg ÷ 31 ≈ 2.4 kg   < 4 kg.

Even after he picks up a several-kilogram diamond the load per wire would still be well below 4 kg. Thus the alarm will not trigger.

4. Move around the room.  
Wearing his “skis” Carlo can shuffle across the carpet to the pedestal in the centre, never lifting a foot high enough to let the plank turn, so the load is always shared by about the same 31 wires.

5. Take the diamond.  
At the pedestal he uses the hammer to break the glass cube, removes the diamond, tucks it away, and shuffles back the same way to the door – all the while keeping every wire well under the 4-kg limit.

No part of the floor ever experiences more than the allowable pressure, so the alarm system remains silent and Carlo gets away with the jewel.

Final answer: Carlo saws the 5-metre 2 × 4 into two 2.5-metre planks, straps one under each foot like giant skis, and shuffles across the carpet. Each plank spans about 31 wires, so even his full 74 kg (and the diamond’s weight) puts less than 4 kg on any single wire, keeping the alarm from triggering while he steals the diamond.

Question:
One day, in baking class, 15 students were baking cakes when the fire alarm went off. Everyone exited the building, but when they got back, they found someone had dumped all the sugar into two of the batter-filled bowls. Everyone was puzzled over what to do until Alice had an idea: why not mix the batters together and then separate the contents back in the bowls. Here is what happened in chronological order:
Alice mixed with Flare
June pours some into Emma's
Luke mixed with Callie
June mixed with Gabbi
Flare mixed with Gabbi
Watt mixed with Tina
Flare mixed with Tina
Luke mixed with Flare
Gabbi mixed with Callie
Daniel, Emma, & Alice mixed with each other
Oscar mixed with Quinn
Misty mixed with Callie
Alice, Misty, & Oscar mixed with each other
Tina mixed with Emma
Kaleb mixed with Quinn
June mixed with Daniel
Luke mixed with June
Ryan, Luke, & Watt mixed with each other
Callie, Alice, & Flare mixed with each other
Kaleb pours some into Daniel's
Watt mixed with Ryan
Watt pours some into Kaleb's
Daniel mixed with Luke
Misty mixed with Gabbi
Kaleb mixed with Tina
Emma & Quinn had no sugar; which 2 bowls started with sugar?
Everyone was able to figure it out.
Hint: Everyone was able to figure it out.
Human Solution:
Luke & Callie
To start, it can't be Emma or Quinn or anyone who mixed/gave to them. This leaves Flare, Luke, Callie, Gabbi, Watt, Misty, and Ryan.
It can't be Flare because he exchanged with Alice before Alice exchanged with Emma. It can't be Watt because he mixed with Tina before Tina exchanged with Emma. This leaves Luke, Callie, Gabbi, Misty, and Ryan.
It can't be Gabbi because she mixed with Flare before Flare mixed with Tina who mixed with Emma later. This leaves Luke, Callie, Misty, and Ryan.
If only one of Luke & Callie started with sugar it wouldn't be solvable because no interactions happened before them and the outcome would be the same, therefore the solution is either Misty and Ryan or Luke and Callie.
However, it can't be Ryan and Misty because they can't give June sugar!
Response: Final answer: Luke and Callie

Question:
Hans Ernest Froopaloop, Jr. will marry one of three women: Audrey, Brenda, and Charlotte. Here are some facts:
1. Of Audrey and Brenda:
a. Either they both have blue eyes or neither has blue eyes.
b. One has red hair and the other does not.
2. Of Audrey and Charlotte:
a. Either they both have red hair or neither has red hair.
b. One is 5'11" and the other is not.
3. Of Brenda and Charlotte:
a. One has blue eyes and the other does not.
b. One is 5'11" and the other is not.
4. Of the three characteristics; blue eyes, red hair and 5'11":
a. If any of the three women has exactly two of the three characteristics, Mr. Froopaloop will marry the one with the least number of characteristics.
b. If any of the three women has exactly one of the three characteristics, Mr. Froopaloop will marry the one with the greatest number of characteristics.
Who will Mr. Froopaloop marry?
Hint: Start with facts 1a and 3a
Human Solution:
Mr. Froopaloop will marry Charlotte.
Facts 1a and 3a tell us that Charlotte is either the only one with blue eyes or the only one without blue eyes. Facts 1b and 2a tell us that Brenda is either the only one with red hair or the only one without red hair. Facts 2b and 3b tell us that Charlotte is either the only one who is 5'11" or the only one who isn't 5'11". Fact 4 tells us that no one woman can have one characteristic while another has two characteristics. This gives us two scenarios:
1. Audrey has blue eyes, does not have red hair, and is 5'11". Brenda has blue eyes, red hair, and is 5'11". Charlotte does not have blue eyes, does not have red hair, and is not 5'11".
2. Audrey does not have blue eyes, has red hair, and is not 5'11". Brenda does not have blue eyes, does not have red hair, and is not 5'11". Charlotte has blue eyes, red hair, and is 5'11".
Fact 4a tells us that in scenario 1, Mr. Froopaloop will marry Charlotte. Fact 4b tells us that in scenario 2, Mr. Froopaloop will marry...Charlotte.
Response:
Let  

B = blue eyes, R = red hair, T = 5' 11"  
A, B, C denote Audrey, Brenda, Charlotte.

Step 1.  Translate the eight clues into equalities / inequalities.

(1a) A and B have the same eye-colour ⇒ B_A = B_B  
(1b) A and B differ in hair colour      ⇒ R_A ≠ R_B  

(2a) A and C have the same hair colour ⇒ R_A = R_C  
(2b) A and C differ in height          ⇒ T_A ≠ T_C  

(3a) B and C differ in eye-colour      ⇒ B_B ≠ B_C  
(3b) B and C differ in height          ⇒ T_B ≠ T_C  

Step 2.  Express every characteristic with three independent 0/1
choices.

Let  

x = B_A (1 if Audrey has blue eyes, 0 otherwise)  
y = R_A (1 if Audrey is red-haired)  
z = T_A (1 if Audrey is 5' 11")

Then, from the relations above,

Audrey : (B_A , R_A , T_A) = ( x ,      y ,      z)  
Brenda : (B_B , R_B , T_B) = ( x , 1 − y ,      z)  
Charlotte:(B_C , R_C , T_C) = (1 − x ,  y , 1 − z)

Step 3.  Count the number of “yes” characteristics each woman has.

n_A = x + y + z  
n_B = x + (1 − y) + z = x + z + 1 − y  
n_C = (1 − x) + y + (1 − z) = 2 − (x + z) + y

Step 4.  Look at Mr Froopaloop’s two rules.

Rule 4a : if someone has exactly 2 characteristics, he marries the
woman with the fewest.

Rule 4b : if someone has exactly 1 characteristic, he marries the
woman with the most.

If at the same time one woman has “2” and another has “1”, the rules
would give opposite instructions, an impossibility.  
Therefore any admissible assignment of (x, y, z) must avoid the
situation “someone has 2 and someone else has 1”.

Step 5.  Test the eight possible triples (x, y, z).

(Only the counts are shown.)

x y z │ n_A n_B n_C │ OK?  
─────────────────────────  
0 0 0 │ 0 1 2 │ conflict (1 & 2 both present)  
0 0 1 │ 1 2 1 │ conflict  
0 1 0 │ 1 0 3 │ acceptable (only “1” present)  
0 1 1 │ 2 1 2 │ conflict  
1 0 0 │ 1 2 1 │ conflict  
1 0 1 │ 2 3 0 │ acceptable (only “2” present)  
1 1 0 │ 2 1 2 │ conflict  
1 1 1 │ 3 2 1 │ conflict  

Exactly two assignments are compatible with the rules:

• (x,y,z) = (0,1,0)  →  counts (1,0,3).  
  Someone has “1” but nobody has “2”, so rule 4b applies → marry the
  most-endowed woman, Charlotte (3).

• (x,y,z) = (1,0,1)  →  counts (2,3,0).  
  Someone has “2” but nobody has “1”, so rule 4a applies → marry the
  least-endowed woman, Charlotte (0).

In both admissible cases Mr. Froopaloop chooses Charlotte, and no other
assignment satisfies his two marriage rules simultaneously.

Final answer: Charlotte

Question:
Draw a diagram of the Fantasylands to help you with this teaser...
Beethoven's Wig has been stolen again!  Instead of hiding it in a box, the enemy, who remains anonymous, has hidden it inside one of four castles.  Each castle is located in a different fantasyland and has a creature guarding its gates.  Use the clues below to put the lands in order (1st,2nd,3rd, and 4th), figure out which castle belongs in which land, which creature belong to which castle, and help Beethoven reclaim his wig!
Object: Beethoven's Wig
Fantasylands: Lothlorien, Mordor, Narnia, and Malacandra.
Creatures: Dragon, Troll, Giant, and Balrog.
Castles: Stone, Gold, Glass, and Silver.
1.  Narnia is to the left of Lothlorien, which is to the right of the Balrog.
2.  The Stone Castle is to the right of the Wig, and is placed at either Malacandra or Lothlorien.
3.  The Giant is not at Lothlorien and is not in the same place as the wig.
4.  The Balrog is not in Lothlorien, but he stays at the Stone Castle.
5.  The Troll doesn't live at the Golden Castle, which is to the left of where the Balrog stays and to the right of the Silver Castle.
6.  Mordor is to the left of the Dragon, who stays at the second place.
7.  The Troll is not at the Silver Castle, which is 1 fantasyland to the left of the wig.
Hint: Mordor and Lothlorien must be at the edges of the sequence
Human Solution:
Mordor is the first fantasyland.  It contains the Giant and the Silver Castle.
Narnia is the second land.  It has the Dragon, the Golden Castle, and the Wig.
Malacandra is the third land.  It has the Stone Castle and the Balrog.
Lothlorien is the fourth land.  It contains the Troll and the Glass Castle.
Response:
Step-by-step reasoning

1. Arrange four positions (1 = far left … 4 = far right).  
   Every position will get a land, a castle, a creature, and perhaps the Wig.

2. From clue 6 the Dragon is at the second place → creature(2)=Dragon.  
   Mordor is to the left of the Dragon → land(1)=Mordor.

3. Clues 2 & 4:  
   • Balrog stays at the Stone Castle.  
   • Stone Castle is either in Malacandra or Lothlorien.  
   • Balrog is not in Lothlorien.  
   ⇒ Stone Castle must be in Malacandra and the Balrog is there.

4. Still from clue 2: Stone Castle is to the right of the Wig → Wig is somewhere left of the Balrog/Malacandra/Stone position.

5. Clue 5: Silver Castle … Gold Castle … Balrog (strictly from left to right).  
   With only four positions, the only way to fit three distinct places to the left of the Balrog is  
      Silver in #1, Gold in #2, Balrog (Stone) in #3.  
   Therefore: castle(1)=Silver, castle(2)=Gold, castle(3)=Stone, creature(3)=Balrog, land(3)=Malacandra.

6. By clue 7 the Silver Castle is exactly one place left of the Wig.  
   Silver is in #1 ⇒ Wig is in #2 (the Gold Castle).  
   This also satisfies “Stone is to the right of the Wig”.

7. Clue 1: Narnia is left of Lothlorien, and Lothlorien is right of the Balrog (#3).  
   Hence Lothlorien must be #4, Narnia must be #2 (the only place left of #4).  
   So land(4)=Lothlorien, land(2)=Narnia.

8. Clue 3: the Giant is not at Lothlorien (#4) and not with the Wig (#2).  
   Only lands left for the Giant are #1 or #3; #3 already has Balrog, so Giant is in #1.

9. Remaining creature is the Troll, who therefore occupies #4.  
   Checks: Troll is not at the Gold Castle (#2) and not at the Silver Castle (#1) – satisfied.

10. The only castle still unassigned is Glass, so castle(4)=Glass.

Completed chart

Position 1: Mordor – Silver Castle – Giant  
Position 2: Narnia – Gold Castle – Dragon – (Beethoven’s Wig)  
Position 3: Malacandra – Stone Castle – Balrog  
Position 4: Lothlorien – Glass Castle – Troll

Thus Beethoven’s Wig is hidden in the Golden Castle in Narnia (second position).

Final answer: 1st-Mordor /Silver /Giant, 2nd-Narnia /Gold /Dragon (with Wig), 3rd-Malacandra /Stone /Balrog, 4th-Lothlorien /Glass /Troll.

Question:
Just before the end of the term four high school students were discussing their chances for certain grades. The following remarks contain the gist of their hopes and fears.
Jack: We'll all get different grades. If I get an A, then Lucy will get a D.
Jean: If Lucy gets a C, then Jack will get a D. Jack will get a better grade than Paul.
Lucy: If Jean doesn't get an A, then Jack will get a C. If I get a B, then Paul won't get a D.
Paul: If Lucy gets an A, then I'll get a B. if Jean doesn't get a B, I won't either.
When the final examinations were graded and the term marks made out each of the four passed, and strange as it may seem, each received a grade that checked exactly with all the ideas they had previously expressed.
What grade did each receive?
Hint: Is it possible for Jack to get an A? Also note that Paul is below Jack
Human Solution: Jack, Jean, Lucy, and Paul received B, A, D, and C, respectively.
Response:
Reasoning

1.  Jack’s assertion “We’ll all get different grades’’ forces the four grades to be the distinct letters  
    A, B, C, D.

2.  Lucy’s first statement is  
        (Jean ≠ A)  ⇒  (Jack = C).                           …(L1)

3.  Jean actually did get either A or not-A.

    •  Suppose Jean ≠ A.  
       Then by (L1) Jack = C.  
       Jean said Jack is better than Paul, so Paul = D.  
       That leaves grades A and B for Jean and Lucy, i.e. Jean = B, Lucy = A.  
       But Paul’s statement “If Lucy gets A then I get B’’ would make him B, not D – contradiction.  
       So Jean must have received A.

4.  Fix Jean = A.  
    Paul’s statement “If Jean ≠ B then I ≠ B’’ now gives Paul ≠ B.

5.  The remaining three grades B, C, D have to be assigned to Jack, Lucy and Paul, keeping

        •  Jack better than Paul (Jean’s second remark),  
        •  Paul ≠ B (step 4),  
        •  (Lucy = B) ⇒ (Paul ≠ D)  (Lucy’s second remark),  
        •  (Lucy = C) ⇒ (Jack = D)  (Jean’s first remark).

    Trying the possible positions of Lucy:

    a) Lucy = B  →  Paul ≠ D, so Paul = C, Jack = D, but then Jack isn’t better than Paul – impossible.

    b) Lucy = C  →  Jean’s rule forces Jack = D, leaving Paul = B, but Paul ≠ B – impossible.

    c) Lucy = D  →  the remaining grades B and C go to Jack and Paul with Jack better than Paul, so  
       Jack = B and Paul = C.  
       All other conditionals now check out.

6.  Final consistent assignment:
        Jean  A  
        Jack  B  
        Paul  C  
        Lucy  D

All the original implications and Jack’s “all different’’ claim are satisfied.

Final answer: Jean – A, Jack – B, Paul – C, Lucy – D

Question:
Mad Ade has placed five Queens on a chessboard, such that every square including those occupied by the Queens are under attack.
Imagine the chessboard is set out with reference points 1 to 8 on the vertical and A to H across the horizontal.
At what positions would the five Queens need to be?
Hint: A couple queens next to each other can cover a lot.
Human Solution: A5, D5, E5, F5, H1 (multiple correct arrangements, check to see that every single position on the board is attacked by at least one queen)
Response:
We need five queens so that every square on the 8 × 8 board is either occupied by a queen or attacked (same row, column, or diagonal).

1.  Put a queen on E1.  
   • This covers the whole first rank and the E-file.  
   • Its SW-NE diagonal (… D2 C3 B4 A5) and NW-SE diagonal (… F0 – off the board) give extra coverage; in particular it will later be used to hit D2.

2.  Put a queen on G3.  
   • Now the G-file and the third rank are covered.  
   • Its diagonals (E4 D5 C6 B7 A8 and H2) will be useful for several of the as-yet-uncovered squares.

3.  Put a queen on C5.  
   • This adds the fifth rank and the C-file.  
   • Its diagonals (B4 A3 and D4 E3 F2 G1 / B6 A7) cover many of the remaining central squares.

4.  Put a queen on A7.  
   • Row 7 and file A are now covered.  
   • The diagonal A7 B6 C5 (already occupied) helps reinforce coverage of the centre.

5.  Put a queen on H8.  
   • Row 8 and file H are covered, and the long diagonal H8 G7 F6 E5 D4 C3 B2 A1 sweeps the whole board’s main diagonal.

Checking the three ranks (2, 4, 6) and three files (B, D, F) that do not contain queens:

• B2 is hit by the H8–A1 diagonal.  
• D2 is hit by the E1–A5 diagonal.  
• F2 is hit by the G3–B8 diagonal.  
• B4 is hit by C5–A3.  
• D4 is hit by both C5–E3 and H8–A1.  
• F4 is hit by the G3–B8 anti-diagonal.  
• B6 is hit by A7–C5.  
• D6 is hit by C5–E4.  
• F6 is hit by H8–E5.

Thus every square on the board is either occupied or attacked.

So one concrete arrangement of five dominating queens is:
A7, C5, E1, G3, H8.

Written in the requested coordinate form:

A7   C5   E1   G3   H8

Final answer: A7, C5, E1, G3, H8

Question:
You are stuck in a room. All that is there is a slip of paper on a table, and many bottles. The only exit is guarded by a heat sensor that will not let you out. The only way out is to drink one of the bottles' contents, and the liquid will cool down your body heat (with no harm to yourself) enough so that the heat sensor doesn't detect you anymore. There are nine bottles on the ground beyond the table. The content of the slip of paper will tell you what each of the bottles are. Find out what all the bottles are, and then find out which one to drink to get out.
Three of me are poison, and will kill you if you drink.
Two of me are water, nothing bad will happen with these.
Two of me are wine, and it will only get you drunk.
One will heat you up forever, and this room will never let you out. (hinder)
Only one here will help you, it will cool down your body heat.
No medium bottles are poison.
Wine is bad in large doses, so none are large.
Each of the end bottles have the same contents.
No matter how help hides, it will be on poison's left side, but its left side is safe.
No two small bottles are the same.
The hinderer is harder, for it resides between wine and water.
The hinder bottle is large, so it works forever.
Neither big nor medium will save your life.
Poison is all you will get from the bottle on the far right.
Water is next to the helper.
Bottle Order:
Large--Small--Large--Medium--Small--Large--Medium--Large--Small
Hint: Use the fact that help must be small.
Human Solution:
Poison--wine--hinder--water--help--poison--wine--water--poison
Only the middle bottle will save your life.
Response:
Bottle contents from left to right (sizes given in the problem shown in parentheses):

1. Large – Poison  
2. Small – Wine  
3. Large – Heater / Hinderer  
4. Medium – Water  
5. Small – Helper / Cooler (the one you must drink)  
6. Large – Poison  
7. Medium – Wine  
8. Large – Water  
9. Small – Poison  

The only bottle that will cool your body temperature enough to pass the heat sensor is the 5th bottle, the small one in the middle.

Final answer: Drink bottle 5, the small helper/cooler bottle.

Question:
You have the following equations:
a + c = a
b - c = c
c / b = c
a * a = b
You also know that a, b, c have the values 0, 1 and 2, but not necessarily in that order.
But to make matters more complicated the symbols + - * / have been mixed up: all you know is that each represents a different arithmetical operation (addition, subtraction, multiplication or division).
Can you work out the values of a, b and c, and what each of the symbols actually mean?
Hint: The only thing you should assume about the arithmetical symbols is that no two represent the same operation.
Human Solution:
a = 1
b = 2
c = 0
+ = -
- = *
* = +
/ = /
(Yes, the division symbol escaped the bedlam!)
Response:
Let  

a , b , c  be a permutation of 0 , 1 , 2   
and let the four printed symbols  

     +   –   *   /  

stand, in some unknown order, for the real operations  

     addition  ( + )  
     subtraction ( − )  
     multiplication ( × )  
     division     ( ÷ ).

Each symbol must represent a different operation.

--------------------------------------------------
Step 1.  Analyse the equation a * a = b  
--------------------------------------------------
Whatever operation “*” really is, applying it to the same number twice gives
a different number b (because a, b, c are all different).

• If  *  is + :  a+a=b  ⇒  b=2a.  
  With a∈{0,1,2} the only possibility in {0,1,2} is a=1, b=2.

• If  *  is – :  a–a=b  ⇒  b=0, so a≠0 and (a,b) is (1,0) or (2,0).

• If  *  is × :  a²=b.  
  This gives (a,b)=(0,0),(1,1),(2,4); none fits the “all different” rule.

• If  *  is ÷ :  a÷a=b ⇒ b=1, so a≠1 and (a,b) is (2,1).

Hence only three theoretical cases survive:

A.  * is +   and  (a,b)=(1,2)  
B.  * is –   and  (a,b)=(1,0) or (2,0)  
C.  * is ÷   and  (a,b)=(2,1)

--------------------------------------------------
Step 2.  Test the surviving cases in the other three equations
--------------------------------------------------

Case A   (* is +,  a=1, b=2, therefore c=0)

Equation 1: a + c = a → 1 + 0 = 1  
To be true with the numbers 1 and 0 we need the operation behind “+” to satisfy
x ⊛ 0 = x ; only subtraction does this.  
So  “+” = − .

Equation 2: b – c = c → 2 – 0 = 0  
The only basic operation taking 2 and 0 to 0 is multiplication.  
So  “–” = × .

Equation 3: c / b = c → 0 / 2 = 0  
With 0 and 2 this is true precisely for ordinary division.  
So  “/” = ÷ .

We have now assigned four different operations to the four symbols and all
three equations are satisfied.  Therefore Case A works.

Case B   (* is – , a=1 or 2, b=0)

Take a=1, b=0, c=2.  
Equation 1 demands an operation giving 1 ⊛ 2 = 1; none of the four basic
operations does that.  So impossible.

Take a=2, b=0, c=1.  
Equation 3 would require 1 / 0 to be defined and to equal 1; impossible.

Hence Case B fails.

Case C   (* is ÷ , a=2, b=1, c=0)

Whichever way the remaining symbols are assigned, Equation 3 forces division
by zero or gives the wrong value.  Case C fails.

--------------------------------------------------
Step 3.  Record the unique consistent assignment
--------------------------------------------------
Variables  
a = 1 ,  b = 2 ,  c = 0

Symbols and their real operations  
+  means  subtraction ( − )  
–  means  multiplication ( × )  
*  means  addition      ( + )  
/  means  division      ( ÷ )

--------------------------------------------------
Final answer:  a = 1, b = 2, c = 0,    +→−,  −→×,  *→+,  /→÷

Question:
You are in a game show with four other contestants.  The objective is to crack the combination of the safe using the clues, and the first person to do so will win $500,000.
The safe combination looks like this:
??-??-??-??
A digit can be used more than once in the code, and there are no leading zeroes.
Here are the clues:
1. The third set of two numbers is the same as the first set reversed.
2. There are no 2's, 3's, 4's or 5's in any of the combination.
3. If you multiply 4 by the third set of numbers, you will get the fourth set of numbers.
4. If you add the first number in the first set with the first number in the second set you will get 8.
5. The second set of numbers is not greater than 20.
6. The second number in the second set multiplied by the second number in the fourth set equals one higher than the numbers in the first set.
And get moving, I think another contestant has almost figured it out!
Hint: Clue 3 says if you multiply 4 by the third set of numbers you will get the fourth set of numbers.  From this, you can tell a 1 is the first number in the third set - any other number would be too high.
Human Solution:
The combination is 71-19-17-68.
From the second clue, we know that there are no 2's, 3's, 4's or 5's in any of the sets.  Therefore, only 1's, 6's, 7's, 8's and 9's could be in the remaining spots.
Clue 3 says if you multiply 4 by the third set of numbers you will get the fourth set of numbers.  From this, you can tell a 1 is the first number in the third set - any other number would be too high.
11 * 4 = 44
16 * 4 = 64
17 * 4 = 68
18 * 4 = 72
19 * 4 = 76
Of these, 17 * 4 and 19 * 4 are the only ones that are possible; as the answer of the other numbers contains a number which we know is not in the combination.
Now we skip all the way to clue 5, which tells us the second set of numbers is not greater than 20.  This means that the first digit of that set is also a 1.
So far, we know this much:
??-1?-1?-??
Now, we can come to clue 4, which tells us if you add the first number in the first set with the first number in the second set you will get 8.  The first number in the second set is 1, so the first number in the first set must be 7.  Since the first clue tells us the first set is the third set reversed, and we know that a 1 is the first number in the third set, a 1 must be the second number in the first set and a 7 must be the second number in the third set.
So far, we know this much:
71-1?-17-??
Now, the third set (17) multiplied by 4 will get us 68.  Now we know the fourth set is 68.
71-1?-17-68
Now we come to the final clue.  This tells us the second number in the second set (unknown) multiplied by the second number in the fourth set (8) equals one higher than the numbers in the first set.  We know that the first set is 71, so adding one to that (72) and then dividing it by 8 will get us 9.  So, the finished combination is:
71-19-17-68
Response:
Reasoning in full:

Let each two–digit section of the code be

A  –  B  –  C  –  D
(1st)  (2nd)  (3rd)  (4th)
and write the digits of each section as
A = a₁a₂,  B = b₁b₂,  C = c₁c₂,  D = d₁d₂.

Clue-by-clue deductions

1.  “The third set is the first set reversed.”
  ⇒ C = a₂a₁ (so c₁ = a₂ and c₂ = a₁).

2.  No digits 2,3,4,5 may appear; digits allowed are 0,1,6,7,8,9.

3.  “4 × (third set) = fourth set.”
  4·C = D must still be a two–digit number, so C ≤ 24.
  Because C = a₂a₁ and its tens digit is a₂, we need a₂ = 1
  (the only allowed digit giving a number between 10 and 24).
  Thus C = 1a₁, where a₁ ∈ {0,1,6,7,8,9} (no leading zero in A,
  so a₁ ≠ 0).

  Compute 4·C for those possibilities:

  C = 10  → D = 40  (contains 4)  ✗  
  C = 11  → D = 44  (contains 4)  ✗  
  C = 16  → D = 64  (contains 4)  ✗  
  C = 17  → D = 68  (allowed)      ✓  
  C = 18  → D = 72  (contains 2)  ✗  
  C = 19  → D = 76  (allowed)      ✓  

  Hence there are two surviving possibilities:
  (i)  C = 17, D = 68,  a₁ = 7, A = 71
  (ii) C = 19, D = 76,  a₁ = 9, A = 91

4.  “First digit of first set + first digit of second set = 8.”
  a₁ + b₁ = 8

  Case (i): a₁ = 7  ⇒ b₁ = 1  
  Case (ii): a₁ = 9  ⇒ b₁ = –1 (impossible)

  So case (ii) is discarded; only case (i) remains.

5.  “The second set is not greater than 20.”
  With b₁ = 1 this is automatically satisfied provided b₂ is allowed.

6.  “(second digit of second set) × (second digit of fourth set)
    = one higher than the number in the first set.”

  For the remaining case:
  A = 71,  D = 68  ⇒ d₂ = 8  
  We need b₂ · d₂ = 71 + 1 = 72  
  8·b₂ = 72  ⇒  b₂ = 9 (allowed digit)

  Thus B = 19 (and indeed 19 ≤ 20).

All clues are now satisfied:

A = 71  
B = 19  
C = 17  (reverse of 71)  
D = 68  (4 × 17)  
7 + 1 = 8 (clue 4)  
9 × 8 = 72 = 71 + 1 (clue 6)  
and no forbidden digits appear.

Final answer: 71-19-17-68

Question:
Five men at a board games club meet once a week to play their favourite board game 'Hollywood Quest'. In this game each space is colour coded one of five colours, each one representing a category of questions.
The five categories are Books, Celebrities, Films, Music, Television.
The five colours are blue, green, grey, orange and purple.
Can you name all five men, their favorite categories and the colours represented by those categories?
CLUES
1. Mr Everett prefers the purple coloured squares.
2. Mr Harper likes Films category best, which is not the blue nor the orange squares.
3. Johns Sanders doesn't like literature-based questions.
4. Patrick's favourite colour is the blue (this is not the colour of the TV questions).
5. The grey squares indicate a player must answer a question about books, and Mr Erwin won't land on these if he can help it.
6. Graham prefers the celebrities category.
7. James avoids the green and orange squares.
8. Kendal is the fifth surname, and Paul the missing first name.
Hint:
Clues 1,2 and 5 should help you work out the colour Mr Harper likes.
Work out Johns Sanders' favourite colour.
You should now be able to work out the colours of all five subjects.
Human Solution:
Graham Everett, purple, celebrities
James Kendal, grey, books
John Sanders, orange, TV
Patrick Erwin, blue, music
Paul Harper, green, films
Response:
Colour-to-category key  
• Blue – Music  
• Green – Films  
• Grey – Books  
• Orange – Television  
• Purple – Celebrities  

Men, with their favourites  

1. Graham Everett – Celebrities – purple squares  
2. James Kendal – Books – grey squares  
3. John Sanders – Television – orange squares  
4. Patrick Erwin – Music – blue squares  
5. Paul Harper – Films – green squares  

Final answer: Graham Everett / Celebrities / purple; James Kendal / Books / grey; John Sanders / Television / orange; Patrick Erwin / Music / blue; Paul Harper / Films / green.

Question:
In Major League Baseball, the World Series is a best of seven series.  The first team to win four games is the champion.  The Series is scheduled so that one team hosts the first two games and the last two games, while the other team hosts the middle three games.  The World Series ends as soon as one team wins four games, so the Series could be completed in as few as four games.
In this fantasy Series, the New York Yankees played the Los Angeles Dodgers.  Los Angeles hosted the first two games.  The final scores of the games were:
Game 1:  4 to 3
Game 2:  6 to 5 (11 innings)
Game 3:  11 to 7
Game 4:  16 to 9
Game 5:  9 to 6 (10 innings)
Game 6:  2 to 1
Game 7:  13 to 8 (13 innings)
Which team won the World Series?
Hint: In baseball, the home team bats last.
Human Solution:
Seven games were played, which means that the teams split the first six games, each team winning three games.  It does not matter who won each of the first six games, since neither team had yet to win four games.  The winner of game 7 will have won four games, and therefore, the World Series.
The team that hosts the first two games also hosts the last two games.  Since Los Angeles hosted the first two games, game 7 was in Los Angeles.  In baseball, the home team bats last.  Los Angeles batted last in game 7.  Since game 7 went 13 innings, Los Angeles would have batted in the bottom of the inning.  In this situation, the home team can never win by more than four runs.  When the home team bats in the last inning, the game ends as soon as the winning run is scored.  The only way the home team can win by more than one run is via a home run, in which case all runners on base at the time can score.  A grand slam home run would only provide a margin of four runs.  Therefore, the home team's margin of victory in an extra-inning game can never exceed four runs.  The final score was 13 to 8, a margin of five runs.  Los Angeles, being the home team, could not have won by that margin.  The game was tied 8 to 8 going into the 13th inning.  New York scored five runs in the top of the 13th inning.
Therefore, the New York Yankees won the World Series, four games to three.
Response:
Reasoning:

1. World-Series scheduling  
   • In the 2-3-2 format the same club that hosts the first two games also hosts Games 6 and 7.  
   • We are told Los Angeles hosted the first two games, hence the Dodgers were the home team in Games 1, 2, 6 and 7, while the Yankees were home in Games 3, 4 and 5.

2. Identify the winner of Game 7  
   • Game 7 went 13 innings and ended 13 – 8, a five-run margin.  
   • Whenever an extra-inning game is won by the home team, play stops the moment the winning run scores.  Consequently the home team can win by at most four runs (a walk-off grand slam in a tie game).
