6:00 6:10 6:40 7:30 7:50.

-----------------------------------------------------------
Which child is which?

Brand and Elana are 50 minutes apart; the only 50-minute gap in the ruler is
between the 4-unit and 9-unit marks, i.e. between 6:40 and 7:30.
Thus

6:40  Brand  7:30  Elana.

Now impose Victor’s three remarks about the nurses:

• Order assumed by first letters (A,B,C,D,E) – every name was wrong.  
• Order assumed by last letters (E,B,C,D,A) – every name was wrong.  
• Even reversing that order (A,D,C,B,E) would still make every name wrong.

Call the five chronological positions 1–5.  The “all wrong” condition yields:

Position 1 ≠ A,E  Position 2 ≠ B,C  Position 3 ≠ C,D  
Position 4 ≠ B,C,D  Position 5 ≠ A,E.

With Brand fixed in position 3 and Elana in position 4, the remaining possibilities are

1 = C or D  2 = A or D  5 = C or D,

subject to distinctness.  Two of these combinations violate the above “≠” conditions;
the only one that works is

1 Caleb  2 Adele  5 Derec.

(That at once satisfies all three “all-wrong” lists, and it also makes Caleb share the
family birth-position of his Aunt Nora, as Victor requested.)

-----------------------------------------------------------
Birth order and times

6:00 A.M.  Caleb    
6:10 A.M.  Adele    
6:40 A.M.  Brand    
7:30 A.M.  Elana    
7:50 A.M.  Derec  

All ten pairwise intervals are different ten-minute multiples, lacking only 60 min, and
Brand and Elana are indeed 50 minutes apart.

Final answer: Caleb 6:00, Adele 6:10, Brand 6:40, Elana 7:30, Derec 7:50.

Question:
Seven horses in a farm in Kentucky,
Of three blacks, the oldest is a daddy;
Of two browns, the 3 year old male is called BILLY,
And the horse SNOWY is white as a lily.
Of two half-sister mares, the black won in the Derby,
She's a shade lighter than her daughter, BEAUTY;
BEAUTY and her cousin LUCKY, both half the age of their auntie,
But faster than either ROCKY or SUNNY.
Three of the horses are ready for the Derby,
A horse must be three years to be an entry;
Maybe this year the farm gets lucky,
Their stallion's loss last year was a pity.
CHALLENGE: Describe the horse that lost in last year's Derby.
Hint:
For purposes of this riddle the following terms are defined as:
Mare- female horse
Stallion- mature male horse
Derby- a race for three year old horses.
Human Solution:
SNOWY, a 4 year old male white horse lost last year.
The Derby is for three year old horses. Therefore only a current four year old horse could have lost last year.
SNOWY is the only horse which could have been three last year (four this year).
The farm is preparing three of the seven horses for this years Derby. There must therefore be at least three 3-year old horses among the seven. BILLY is 3-years old. Necessarily, BEAUTY and her cousin LUCKY must be 3 years old both. (They are of the same age).
Beauty's mom could not be three because she won in the Derby before. The oldest black is even older than BEAUTY's mom.
BEAUTY's aunt could not be three. If she were, then SNOWY must also be three to complete the three entries this year. This would mean that no horse would be four years old as BEAUTY and LUCKY would be one and a half years old. BEAUTY's mom won in the DERBY as a three year old, she could not win and lose at the same time. (The riddle suggests that the farm did not win last year so the mom must be over 5 years old).
In sum, if BILLY, BEAUTY, and LUCKY are three years old, their aunt must be six. BEAUTY's mom must be five or more. The oldest black must be older than the black mom. Only SNOWY could be four this year.
SNOWY is white (given), 4 years as deduced, and male from the fact that it was a stallion which lost last year.
The names of BEAUTY's mom and aunt and that of the oldest black are immaterial. The same is true with the color of lucky.
Response:
First observe the data that the riddle fixes.

1. Colours  
   – 3 black horses  
   – 2 brown horses (one of them the three-year-old male BILLY)  
   – 1 white horse (SNOWY)  
   – 7 − (3+2+1) = 1 horse whose colour is something else.

2. Family relations  
   – The oldest of the three blacks is a sire (“daddy”).  
   – Two of the blacks are a half-sister mare and her darker–shaded daughter BEAUTY.  
   – There is a second half-sister mare; her foal is LUCKY.  
   – Thus the two mares are the daughters of the old black sire, and BEAUTY and LUCKY are first cousins.

3. Ages  
   – “Beauty and her cousin Lucky, both half the age of their auntie …”.   
     If the two mares are the “aunties”, let their common age be 6; then  
       age( BEAUTY ) = age( LUCKY ) = 3.  
   – “Three of the horses are ready for the Derby, / A horse must be three …”.  
     Together with Billy (explicitly 3), the three Derby entries this year are therefore  
       BEAUTY (3) , LUCKY (3) , BILLY (3).  
   – The two mares are 6, and the old black sire is older than 6.  
   – One horse is left over; since last year it was 3 (to run the Derby) it is now 4.

4. Sexes  
   – The two mares are female, the old black sire is male.  
   – Billy is the 3-year-old brown male mentioned.  
   – The only other male mentioned is called “their stallion” – a mature male horse.  
     That must be the single 4-year-old just identified (all the other horses are either 3, 6, or
     the still older black sire).  
   – Because BEAUTY and LUCKY are said to be “faster than either ROCKY or SUNNY”, the two slower horses must be
     the older pair: one is the 6-year-old brown mare (their aunt) and the other is the 4-year-old stallion.  
     Normal usage makes ROCKY the more likely male name, leaving SUNNY for the mare.

Hence

• ROCKY is the farm’s only 4-year-old horse;  
• he is a stallion (the “their stallion” who raced last year);  
• his coat cannot be black, brown or white (those numbers are already filled), so it is the single “other” colour (for instance chestnut).

Final answer: The horse that lost in last year’s Derby is ROCKY – the farm’s four-year-old stallion, a chestnut (i.e. neither black, brown nor white) horse.

Question:
There is a 10-digit number, represented by ABCDEFGHIJ, where each numeral, 0 through 9, is used once.  Given the following clues, what is the number?
1) A + D = a square number
2) G + J = a triangle number
3) B + I = an even number
4) E * F = an odd number
5) C * H = a prime number
6) A / G = G / C
7) E + I = B + H
Hint: A triangle number can be expressed as the sum of the numbers 1 to n, for any integer value of n.  Therefore the triangle numbers are 1, 3, 6, 10, 15, 21, 28, ...
Human Solution:
4615972308
For the product of two numbers to be a prime number (clue #5), one of those two numbers must be 1.  Therefore, either C or H must be 1.
To achieve the required proportion (clue #6), the numerals [AGC] must be one of the following combinations:  931 or 421 or 842.
If [AGC] = 842, then D would have to be 1 (clue #1).  Since either C or H must be 1, then D can not be 1.  Since D can not be 1, then A can not be 8.  Therefore, [AGC] can not be 842.  The only remaining possibilities for [AGC] are 931 and 421.  In either case, C = 1.
If [AGC] = 931, then D must be either 0 or 7 (clue #1) and J must be either 0 or 7 (clue #2).  Therefore, between them, D and J must use 0 and 7.  E and F must both be odd (clue #4).  However, four of the odd numerals would already be assigned (A = 9, G = 3, C = 1, either D or J = 7).  Therefore, [AGC] can not be 931.  This means that [AGC] must be 421.  Therefore, A = 4 and G = 2.
Since G = 2, then J = 8 (clue #2).  J can not be 1 or 4, since those two numerals are now assigned.
The only remaining letters that can be assigned to 6 are B and I.  D can not be 6, as it would not produce a square number (clue #1).  Neither E nor F can be 6, since that would not produce an odd number (clue #4). H can not be 6, as it would not produce a prime number (clue #5).  Since either B or I must be 6, then 6 must be paired with 0 (clue #3), as the other even numerals have now been assigned.
Since B and I share 0 and 6, then D = 5 (clue #1).
Since B and I share 0 and 6, then E and H must also be separated by 6 (clue #7).  The only remaining numerals that satisfy this requirement are 3 and 9.  This means that F = 7.  This sets H = 3 and  E = 9, which then sets B = 6 and I = 0.
Response:
Let  

 A B C D E F G H I J  

be a permutation of the ten different digits 0–9 that satisfies the seven listed conditions.


STEP 1 Interpreting condition (6)

A / G = G / C  ⇔ A · C = G².

Since A, C, G are single digits, A·C must be one of the perfect squares not exceeding 81:

0, 1, 4, 9, 16, 25, 36, 49, 64, 81.

Because A and C have to be different digits, the only squares that can be expressed as a product of two different digits are

4 = 1·4   9 = 1·9   16 = 2·8  
36 = 4·9.

Hence the only admissible (A,C,G) triples are

(1,4,2) (4,1,2) (2,8,4) (8,2,4) (4,9,6) (9,4,6).

The first triple (1,4,2) is impossible, because condition (5) would force 4·H to be prime, which can’t happen.  
We therefore continue with the second triple.

So from now on we take

A = 4, C = 1, G = 2.  (1)


STEP 2 Using conditions (2) and (5)

(5) C·H must be prime.  
With C = 1 this gives H ∈ {2,3,5,7}.  
Digit 2 is already G, so

H ∈ {3,5,7}.  (2)

(2) G + J must be a triangular number.  
With G = 2 the possibilities are

2 + J ∈ {1,3,6,10,15}  ⇒ J ∈ {–1,1,4,8,13}.  

Only 1,4,8 are digits, and 1 and 4 are already used, so

J = 8.  (3)


STEP 3 Using condition (1)

(1) A + D must be a square.  
With A = 4,

4 + D ∈ {4,9,16}  ⇒ D ∈ {0,5}.  (4)


STEP 4 Trying D = 0

Take D = 0.  
The unused digits are {3,5,6,7,9}.  

• E·F must be odd  ⇒ E, F are odd digits.  
• B + I must be even  ⇒ B, I are either both odd or both even.  
With only one even digit (6) left, B and I must both be odd, so altogether four different odd digits would be needed for B, E, F, I, but only three are available.  
Therefore D = 0 is impossible.


STEP 5 Taking D = 5

Now fix

D = 5.  (5)

Digits used so far: 4,1,2,5,8.  
The unused digits are {0,3,6,7,9}.

From (2): H ∈ {3,7}. 
We consider each possibility.


••• 5a If H = 7

Odd digits still free: 3,9.  
But we need four odd digits for B, E, F, I while only two are left ⇒ impossible.


••• 5b If H = 3

Digits now fixed:  
A = 4, B =?, C = 1, D = 5, E =?, F =?, G = 2, H = 3, I =?, J = 8.

Unused digits: {0,6,7,9}.

– E·F odd ⇒ E, F are the two odd digits 7 and 9.  
– B + I even ⇒ B and I are the two even digits 0 and 6 (in some order).

Apply condition (7): E + I = B + H = B + 3.

Try both orders for (B, I):

• B = 0, I = 6 ⇒ E + 6 = 0 + 3 ⇒ E = –3 (impossible).  
• B = 6, I = 0 ⇒ E + 0 = 6 + 3 ⇒ E = 9.

That forces

E = 9, F = 7, B = 6, I = 0.

All ten digits are now assigned and distinct:

A B C D E F G H I J  
4 6 1 5 9 7 2 3 0 8


STEP 6 Checking every condition

1) A + D = 4 + 5 = 9, a square ✓  
2) G + J = 2 + 8 = 10, a triangular number ✓  
3) B + I = 6 + 0 = 6, even ✓  
4) E · F = 9 · 7 = 63, odd ✓  
5) C · H = 1 · 3 = 3, prime ✓  
6) A / G = 4 / 2 = 2 and G / C = 2 / 1 = 2 ✓  
7) E + I = 9 + 0 = 9 and B + H = 6 + 3 = 9 ✓

All seven conditions are satisfied, and every digit 0–9 is used exactly once.


Final answer: 4615972308

Question:
Did you know that the mango is one of the world's most popular fruits? The mango is grown in North, South and Central America, the Caribbean, south and central Africa, as well as its native southern and south-east Asia.
The mango is also packed with vitamins A, B and C.
While eating a mango the other day, I started thinking about the ABC's. Then I remembered the set of 5-sided alphabet pyramids I had as a child.
Here are some 5-letter words that can be spelled with just 5 of my pyramids:
BELOW
CANDY
FORTY
HELIX
JABOT
LEMON
LIGHT
MANGO
OCHRE
PEACH
QUEST
QUICK
VIEUX
Using these words, can you figure out which letters appear on each pyramid?
Hint: Start with MANGO and LEMON; because they share three letters, you can start off with a pretty strong reduction and only have to consider how the other two pairs must be arranged
Human Solution:
Let's start with the word MANGO, and assign a number to each pyramid.
1: M
2: A
3: N
4: G
5: O
The word LEMON shares 3 letters with MANGO, so the L and E must go with the A and G, in some order. Because of the word PEACH, the E and A cannot be on the same pyramid, so the E must be on pyramid 4, while the L is on pyramid 2.
Because of the word OCHRE, neither the C or H of PEACH can be on the same pyramid with the O, so the P must be on pyramid 5.
Because of the word CANDY, the C cannot be on the same pyramid as the N, so it is with the M, leaving the H with the N. The Y cannot be with the O (FORTY), so it must be with the G, and the D is with the O. The R must then be on pyramid 2, to complete OCHRE.
1: M, C
2: A, L, R
3: N, H
4: G, E, Y
5: O, P, D
The F and T of FORTY must be on pyramids 1 and 3, but the H and T cannot be on the same pyramid (LIGHT), so the T is on pyramid 1 and the F is on pyramid 3. This means that the I must be on pyramid 5, in order to complete LIGHT.
1: M, C, T
2: A, L, R
3: N, H, F
4: G, E, Y
5: O, P, D, I
The J and B of JABOT must be on pyramids 3 and 4, but the B cannot be with the E, or else one cannot spell BELOW. Also, the W must be on pyramid 1.
1: M, C, T, W
2: A, L, R
3: N, H, F, B
4: G, E, Y, J
5: O, P, D, I
The X in HELIX must be on pyramid 1, so we now have all the letters on that pyramid. There is only one letter left on pyramid 3, and it must be in VIEUX, QUEST and QUICK, so it must be the U. The V from VIEUX must therefore be on pyramid 2.
The Q cannot be on the same pyramid as the I, in order to spell QUICK, so it is also on pyramid 2. The S cannot be on the same pyramid as the E (QUEST), so is therefore on pyramid 5, and the K is the last letter on pyramid 4.
1: M, C, T, W, X
2: A, L, R, V, Q
3: N, H, F, B, U
4: G, E, Y, J, K
5: O, P, D, I, S
Response:
One (and, up to a relabelling of the 5 pyramids, the only) assignment that lets every one of the thirteen words be read using exactly one letter from each pyramid is

Pyramid 1:  C  M  T  W  X  
Pyramid 2:  B  F  H  N  U  
Pyramid 3:  D  I  O  P  S  
Pyramid 4:  A  L  Q  R  V  
Pyramid 5:  E  G  J  K  Y  

With this arrangement each of the words

BELOW   CANDY   FORTY   HELIX   JABOT  
LEMON   LIGHT   MANGO   OCHRE   PEACH  
QUEST   QUICK   VIEUX  

indeed uses one and only one letter from every pyramid.

Final answer: CMTWX / BFHNU / DIOPS / ALQRV / EGJKY

Question:
You roll five dice. The computer calculates the score. Your job is to find out what the computer based the score on.
If you roll 5, 4, 6, 3, and 5, the score is 10.
If you roll 1, 3, 3, 4, and 2, the score is 4.
If you roll 1, 6, 2, 6, and 4,the score is 0.
What is the method?
Hint: Think of the title. The score is never odd. Picture the dice in your head.
Human Solution: Only the dice that have a centre dot are counted (3 and five). Count the number of dots around the centre dot. These "petals" are the score. A five on the die gets a score of 4, and a three on the die gets a score of 2.
Response:
For every die that shows an odd number (1, 3, 5) the computer subtracts 1, then it adds the resulting numbers.  
Even faces (2, 4, 6) contribute nothing.

Equivalently  
score = (sum of the odd faces) − (number of odd faces).

Check the three rolls:

1. 5  4  6  3  5  
   Odd faces: 5, 3, 5 → sum = 13, count = 3  
   Score = 13 − 3 = 10.

2. 1  3  3  4  2  
   Odd faces: 1, 3, 3 → sum = 7, count = 3  
   Score = 7 − 3 = 4.

3. 1  6  2  6  4  
   Odd face: 1 → sum = 1, count = 1  
   Score = 1 − 1 = 0.

Since each odd face is reduced by 1 before the sum is taken, every term in the total is even, so the score can never be odd—exactly as the hint states.

Final answer: The computer looks only at the dice that show odd numbers; it subtracts 1 from each of those dice and then adds the results (or, equivalently, it takes the sum of the odd faces and subtracts the number of odd faces).

Question:
Carl, Draco, Emma, Ivy, June, & Xavior are playing a game with you in which you have to guess their roles in exactly 16 statements.
The roles are:
Normal - Has no abilities
Liar - Knows all roles & has to lie
Detective - Knows all roles
Switcher - Switches 2 roles after the first statement (cannot switch themselves)
Cupid - Pairs 2 players and lets them see each other's roles (cannot pair themselves)
Spy - Knows who was switched
The following 16 statements were made:
Carl is not Cupid - June
Ivy is the Liar - Carl
I know someone's role - Draco
I know the Switcher - Xavior
Ivy is not Normal - Emma
I wasn't switched - Ivy
Emma knows Draco's role - June
Xavior knows who was switched - Carl
Emma & I are not the Spy - Draco
Draco or June is Normal - Xavior
I don't know the Spy - Emma
I'm the Spy - Ivy
The Cupid wasn't switched - June
Xavior isn't Cupid - Carl
I don't know the Detective - Draco
I'm not the Spy - Xavior
Who is who?
*The Detective/Liar knows who was switched; if the Detective/Liar is switched then only the new Detective/Liar is updated
Hint:
Step 1: Draco, Xavior, & Emma are telling the truth
"Ivy is the Liar - Carl"
If Carl is telling the truth then Ivy is lying, otherwise Carl is lying
Since Carl or Ivy is lying & there is only 1 liar, the other are honest
Human Solution:
Normal=Draco
Liar=Ivy
Detective=Xavior
Switcher=Emma
Cupid=June
Spy=Carl
Explanation:
Step 1: Draco, Xavior, & Emma are telling the truth
"Ivy is the Liar - Carl"
If Carl is telling the truth then Ivy is lying, otherwise Carl is lying
Since Carl or Ivy is lying & there is only 1 liar, the other are honest
Step 2: June is telling the truth (can't prove the 1st statement yet)
"Ivy is the Liar - Carl"
If Carl is telling the truth then Ivy is lying, if Carl is lying then Carl is lying
However, since June is the 1st one to talk, June could have been swapped and started as the liar
Step 3: Emma is paired
"Emma knows Draco's role - June"
This leaves 5 scenarios:
1. Emma is the Detective & is paired with June
2. June is Cupid & paired Draco & Emma
3. Emma is the Liar & is paired with June
4. Emma is the Liar & June is the Detective
5. June is lying
Statements 3-5 can't be true since Emma & June are telling the truth; therefore Emma is paired with Draco or June
Step 4: Emma isn't the Cupid or Normal
"Cupid - Pairs 2 players and lets them see each other's roles (cannot pair themselves)"
Cupid can't pair themselves
"Draco or June is Normal - Xavior"
Xavior is telling the truth; therefore Emma can't be Normal
Step 5: Emma isn't the Detective or Spy:
"I don't know the Spy - Emma"
If Emma was the Detective or Spy, then Emma would know the Spy
This leaves Emma with Switcher
Step 6: June is Cupid & Draco is Paired
"Emma knows Draco's role - June"
We had 2 possible scenarios:
1. Emma is the Detective & is paired with June
2. June is Cupid & paired Draco & Emma
However, Emma isn't the detective; therefore Draco & Emma are paired by June the Cupid
Step 7: Draco = Normal
"Draco or June is Normal - Xavior"
June is Cupid & Xavior is telling the truth; therefore Draco is Normal
Step 8: The final 3
"I'm not the Spy - Xavior"
This leaves the Detective.
"Xavior knows who was switched - Carl"
This is true, which means Ivy is the liar & Carl is the Spy.
Ivy & Carl were swapped
Response:
Consistent with every statement, the hint, the single-liar condition, and the “switch after the first line’’ rule, the only possible assignment is

Carl  –  CUPID  
Draco –  NORMAL  
Emma –  DETECTIVE  
Ivy   –  LIAR  
June  –  SPY  
Xavior – SWITCHER  

( Xavior, the Switcher, exchanged Ivy’s original role of Spy with June’s original role of Liar immediately after June’s first, lying, statement. )

Question:
One day, an eccentric billionaire decided to give a destitute man a break. But not a total break, as we shall see. So, he invites him into a room in his mansion with seven doors. There is also a large-screen projector that projects the following five images, repeatedly, one at a time:
A human brain, Earth, the incomplete phrase: 'Fair and ____,' the letters AZCONMUT and a cheese sandwich on plain white bread with the edges perfectly cut off.
The poor man was allowed an entire day to study the images, after which he would have to choose the door that corresponded to the commonality of the images. The next day the man walked through the correct door, and the billionaire made him rich. What door did the man choose?
Hint: Take a snack break, have one of the images.
Human Solution:
The man chose door number FOUR. Here's why:
The image of the human brain made the man think of 'four corners of the mind.'
He recognized the capital letters AZCONMUT to be the abbreviations of the 'Four corner states' Arizona, Colorado, New Mexico, and Utah. He completed the phrase
'Fair and ____' with the word SQUARE, which also has also four corners. When he got hungry, he ordered the same sandwich in the last image. But instead of eating right away, he studied it, until he got the point that it too had four corners. Thus, the poor guy walked into a mansion poorer than poor, and walked out with a cheese sandwich, and enough dough to buy a small country. What he actually did with the money is anybody's guess.
Response:
The five pictures are all clues that point to “four corners.”

1.  Brain – The human brain is divided into four principal lobes (frontal, parietal, temporal, occipital), one in each “corner” of the cranium.  
2.  Earth – The old expression “the four corners of the earth” refers to the whole world.  
3.  Fair and ____ – The missing word is “square.”  A square has four equal sides and therefore four corners.  
4.  AZ CO NM UT – Those are the postal abbreviations for Arizona, Colorado, New Mexico and Utah, the four states that meet at the famous “Four-Corners Monument.”  
5.  Crust-removed cheese sandwich – With the crust cut off, one is left with a perfect square of bread – again, a figure with four corners.  (The hint about taking the sandwich as a snack is meant to draw attention to its shape.)

Thus the commonality required by the billionaire is “four corners.”  
With seven unlabeled doors the most natural way to encode that idea is by numbering or marking one of them “4.”  
Therefore the destitute man had to choose (and did choose) the fourth door.

Final answer: the man walked through Door #4.

Question:
A car thief, who had managed to evade the authorities in the past, unknowingly took the automobile that belonged to Inspector Detweiler.  The sleuth wasted no time and spared no effort in discovering and carefully examining the available clues.  He was able to identify four suspects with certainty that one of them was the culprit.
The four make the statements below.  In total, six statements are true and six false.
Suspect A:
1. C and I have met many times before today.
2. B is guilty.
3. The car thief did not know it was the Inspector's car.
Suspect B:
1. D did not do it.
2. D's third statement is false.
3. I am innocent.
Suspect C:
1. I have never met A before today.
2. B is not guilty.
3. D knows how to drive.
Suspect D:
1. B's first statement is false.
2. I do not know how to drive.
3. A did it.
Which one is the car thief?
Hint: Consider that six statements are false. A's first statement and C's first statement contradict each other.  One of them is false.  C's and D's  contradict each other.  One of them is false.  Therefore, there are four additional false statements.
Human Solution:
Consider that six statements are false. A's first statement and C's first statement contradict each other.  One of them is false.  C's and D's  contradict each other.  One of them is false.  Therefore, there are four additional false statements.
Assume A is guilty.  If so, A's second statement, B's second statement, and D's first statement are the additional false statements.
Assume D is guilty.  If so, A's second statement, B's first statement, and D's third statement are false.  This also only makes five false statements.  D did not do it.
Assume C did it.  If so, A's second statement, D's first and third statements are false.  This again, makes only five false statements.
After ruling out suspects A, C and D, B is the culprit.  B's third statement, C's second statement, and D's first and third statements are the additional false statements.  This adds up to six.
Response:
Let us label the twelve statements

A1  “C and I have met many times before today.”  
A2  “B is guilty.”  
A3  “The car thief did not know it was the Inspector’s car.”

B1  “D did not do it.”  
B2  “D’s third statement is false.”  
B3  “I am innocent.”

C1  “I have never met A before today.”  
C2  “B is not guilty.”  
C3  “D knows how to drive.”

D1  “B’s first statement is false.”  
D2  “I do not know how to drive.”  
D3  “A did it.”

Facts given in the problem
• Exactly six of the twelve statements are true and six are false.  
• Only one of the four suspects is the thief.  
• The thief “unknowingly took the automobile that belonged to Inspector Detweiler”; hence the thief really did NOT know the car belonged to the inspector.  
 Consequently statement A3 is TRUE.

Step 1 Handle the two explicit contradictions.

A1 contradicts C1, so exactly one of them is false.  
C3 contradicts D2, so exactly one of them is false.

Thus two of the six false statements are already located, leaving four more false statements still to be identified.

Step 2 Handle the two statements that negate each other.

D1 says “B1 is false”; therefore B1 and D1 cannot have the same truth value.  
Exactly one of {B1, D1} is false; that accounts for a third false statement, leaving three more to be found.

Step 3 Handle the pair B2 / D3.

B2 asserts that D3 is false, so B2 and D3 must have opposite truth values.  
Exactly one of {B2, D3} is false; that accounts for a fourth false statement, leaving exactly two more false
statements still unassigned.

So far we know where four of the six false statements are:
 • one in {A1, C1}  • one in {C3, D2}  
 • one in {B1, D1}  • one in {B2, D3}

Step 4 Look at the only two statements that are not yet tied to any contradiction pair: A2 and B3 (C2 is tied to A2 because it is its negation).

Among the six statements that have not yet been categorised,
 A2, B2/B3, C2, D3,
exactly two must be false (to bring the total number of false statements up to six).

Because C2 is the negation of A2, precisely one of {A2, C2} is false.  Therefore exactly one more false statement is still needed, and that false statement must be B3 or A3.

But A3 is already known to be true (from the wording of the problem).  
Therefore B3 is the final false statement.

Thus we now have all six false statements:

• one of {A1, C1}  
• one of {C3, D2}  
• one of {B1, D1}  
• one of {B2, D3}  
• the false member of {A2, C2}  
• B3

Step 5 Determine which member of each contradictory pair is the false one.

Because B3 is false, B is lying when he claims to be innocent; therefore B is the guilty party.

Knowing B is guilty fixes the truth values consistently:

A2 (B is guilty)    TRUE  
C2 (B is not guilty)  FALSE  
B1 (D did not do it)  TRUE (since B, not D, is the thief)  
D1 (“B1 is false”)   FALSE  
D3 (A did it)     FALSE  
B2 (“D3 is false”)   TRUE

Now the only way to make the totals come out 6 true / 6 false is to choose

C1 TRUE and A1 FALSE     (so A and C have never met)  
C3 FALSE and D2 TRUE     (so D really cannot drive)

Counting gives exactly six true and six false statements, all conditions satisfied, with B alone guilty.

Hence the car thief is Suspect B.

Final answer: B

Question:
These five businessmen represented different companies at a recent trade fair. Unfortunately, the hotel they were all due to stay in had accidentally double booked their rooms. They tried other hotels in the area, but all were fully booked. Consequently, they all agreed to share the only two rooms available in the hotel - one twin and one triple.
From the clues, can you work out each man's name, company and official title?
1. When the five men realized their dilemma, they drew straws to see who would share with whom. The outcome for four of them was that the CEO shared with the businessman from ABM Inc. and Edgar shared with the Developer.
2. Alan does not work for Reed Right and is not the Director. The Director does not work for Lantel or Blue Teeth.
3. Neither Clarkson nor Grimaldi works for Reed Right. Grimaldi is either the IT Analyst or the CEO.
4. The businessman from Reed Right did not share a room with Thomas.
5. Clarkson, who does not work for Lantel, shared with either Thomas or Grimaldi but not both.
6. Edgar's surname is either Casson or Graves. Edgar did not share with Carl.
7. The businessman from Chiptech shared with the businessman from Lantel.
8. The CEO shared with the IT Analyst.
9. Casson works for either Blue Teeth or Chiptech.
10. Neither Joshua nor Alan works for ABM Inc.
11. Fielder shared with the Director.
12. The Accountant from Blue Teeth shared with the Developer.
First names: Alan, Carl, Edgar, Joshua, Thomas.
Last names: Casson, Clarkson, Fielder, Graves, Grimaldi.
Company: ABM Inc., Blue Teeth, Chiptech, Lantel, Reed
Hint: To solve this teaser, you first need to determine who shared which room with whom
Human Solution:
First Name, Last Name, Company, Position:
Carl Grimaldi, ABM Inc., IT Analyst
Edgar Casson, Chiptech, Director
Joshua Graves, Reed Right, CEO
Alan Clarkson, Blue Teeth, Accountant
Thomas Fielder, Lantel, Developer
To solve this teaser, you first need to determine who shared which room with whom. Three delegates shared the triple and two shared the twin. The CEO shared with the businessman from ABM in one room and Edgar shared with the Developer in the other (1). Since Grimaldi is either the IT Analyst or the CEO (3) and the CEO shared with the IT Analyst, Grimaldi is in the same room as whoever is the CEO, IT Analyst and ABM delegate although Grimaldi could have been one of these people. Edgar did not share with Carl (6) so Carl is in the same bedroom as, and possibly is, the CEO, IT Analyst, Grimaldi and/or the ABM delegate. Grimaldi and Thomas were in different rooms so Thomas shared a room with Clarkson (5) and the Reed Right delegate was in a different room to Thomas. At this stage we know:
Room 1
CEO
IT Analyst
ABM delegate
Grimaldi
Carl
Reed Right delegate
Room 2
Edgar
Developer
Thomas
Clarkson
Since the Chiptech delegate shared with the Lantel delegate (7), both of these must have been in room 2 otherwise there would be four delegates in room 1 which is not possible.
Now this has been ascertained, the puzzle can be solved:
The CEO shared with the IT Analyst so the IT Analyst must work for ABM (Clues 1 and 8) so the CEO must work for Reed Right. Since Grimaldi does not work for Reed Right, he must be the IT Analyst. Clarkson, Fielder and Casson are in room 2 so the CEO must be Graves. Graves is not Edgar (1), Thomas (4), Carl (IT Analyst) or Alan (2) so must be Joshua. Clarkson is not Thomas (5), Edgar (6), Carl or Joshua (in room 1) so must be Alan. The Director does not work for Lantel or Blue Teeth (2), Reed Right or ABM (room 1) so must work for Chiptech. This is not Graves or Grimaldi (room 1), Clarkson (2) or Fielder (11) so must be Casson. Since Graves; first name is Joshua, Casson must be Edgar (6). Alan Clarkson does not work for Reed Right or ABM (room 1); Lantel (5) or Chiptech so must work for Blue Teeth. Since he is not the Developer (12) he must be the Accountant. This leaves Thomas Fielder who is the Developer for Lantel.
Response:
The only arrangement that satisfies every one of the clues is:

Joshua Graves – CEO, Reed Right  
Carl Grimaldi – IT Analyst, ABM Inc.  
Thomas Fielder – Developer, Lantel  
Edgar Casson – Director, Chiptech  
Alan Clarkson – Accountant, Blue Teeth  

Final answer: Joshua Graves – CEO (Reed Right); Carl Grimaldi – IT Analyst (ABM Inc.); Thomas Fielder – Developer (Lantel); Edgar Casson – Director (Chiptech); Alan Clarkson – Accountant (Blue Teeth).

Question:
A child has 4 blocks with a different letter on each side (no letter is repeated on different blocks either). If the list of words below can all be formed using these blocks, figure out which letters belong on which blocks...
skid
hoax
joey
glum
rand
grit
monk
fair
vane
wide
cafe
dupe
joke
bail
shop
Hint: Look for pairs of words with lots of letters in common! Also consider letters which appear lots (like "e")
Human Solution:
Block 1: S, E, M, B, R, X
Block 2: K, W, Y, A, G, P
Block 3: I, U, N, H, J, C
Block 4: D, L, O, V, T, F
Response:
A labelling that lets every word be spelled with one letter from each of the four cubes is:

Block 1: B E M R S X  
Block 2: A G K P W Y  
Block 3: C H I J N U  
Block 4: D F L O T V  

(Each of the fifteen words then uses one letter from each different block.)

Question:
On an otherwise deserted and isolated island, 200 perfect logicians are stranded. The islanders are perfectly logical in every decision they make, and they will not do anything unless they are absolutely certain of the outcome. However, they cannot communicate with each other. They are forbidden from speaking with one another, or signing, or writing messages in the sand, else they be smited by the god of the island.
Of the 200 islanders, 100 have blue eyes, and 100 have brown eyes. However, no individual knows what color their own eyes are. There are no reflective surfaces on the island for the inhabitants to see a reflection of their own eyes. They can each see the 199 other islanders and their eye colors, but any given individual does not know if his or her own eyes are brown, blue, or perhaps another color entirely. And remember, they cannot communicate with each other in any way under penalty of death.
Each night, when a ship comes, the islanders have a chance to leave the barren and desolate spit of land they have been marooned on. If an islander tells the captain of the ship the color of his or her own eyes, they may board the ship and leave. If they get it wrong, they will be shot dead.
Now, there is one more person on the island: the guru, who the islanders know to always tell the truth. The guru has green eyes. One day, she stands up before all 200 islanders and says:
"I see a person with blue eyes."
Who leaves the island? And when do they leave?
Hint: What would happen if there was only one blue-eyed person on the island and the rest of the islanders were brown-eyed? What about two? What about three?
Human Solution: All 100 blue-eyed people leave on the 100th night. First, we propose that two blue-eyed people are on the island. They would both leave on the second night, because they would each look at the other blue-eyed person on the second morning and realize that the only reason the other blue-eyed person wouldn't leave on the first night is because they see another person with blue eyes. Seeing no one else with blue eyes, each of these two people realize it must be them. Now consider the case of three blue-eyed islanders. It has been established that if only two people had blue eyes they would leave on the second night. You, the third blue-eyed person in our example, know this, as do the other two blue-eyed people. So when you wake up on the third morning, and the two other blue-eyed people have not left, you know that they must see another person with blue eyes, and you can see that no one else on the island has blue eyes, so you know it must be you. All three of you realize this simultaneously, and all three leave on the third night. If a fourth blue-eyed person is on the island, he will reason the scenario with three blue-eyed people on the island, and when he sees that they have not left the island during the fourth morning, he/she/it will leave the island on the fourth day, and so will all the other blue-eyed people. If we follow this pattern, we will eventually reach the answer of 100 people leaving the island after 100 days.
Response:
First recall the rules that govern every islander’s behaviour  

• Each acts only when logically certain of the result.  
• They cannot exchange any information except by what is publicly visible.  
• Each night they may announce a colour to the ship’s captain; a correct announcement lets them leave, an incorrect one is fatal.

The single public utterance the guru makes is

“I see a person with blue eyes.”

Because the guru is known to be infallibly truthful, her sentence becomes common knowledge: every islander now knows that at least one islander has blue eyes, and also knows that every other islander knows this, and knows that they know that they know it, ad infinitum.  
That last point—the creation of common knowledge—is the crucial new element; before the guru spoke no such common knowledge existed.

We analyse what happens by induction on the number n of blue-eyed islanders.

Base case n = 1  
Suppose there were exactly one blue-eyed person B.  
• B sees 0 blue eyes when looking at the other 199 people.  
• Yet the guru has truthfully stated that there exists a blue-eyed person.  
  Therefore B deduces with certainty, “It must be me.”  
That night (night 1) B tells the captain “my eyes are blue,” is correct, and departs.  
Everyone else, all brown-eyed, stays.

Case n = 2  
Call the two blue-eyed islanders B₁ and B₂.  
• B₁ sees exactly one blue-eyed person (B₂).  
  From B₁’s viewpoint two logical possibilities exist:  
  (i) There is only that blue-eyed person B₂ (so n = 1);  
  (ii) B₁ himself is also blue-eyed (so n = 2).  
• Exactly the same reasoning is held by B₂ (with roles reversed).

Hence each waits to see what happens on night 1:  
– If n = 1 had been the real world, that lone blue-eyed individual would have left immediately.  
– When morning comes and nobody has left, each blue-eyed islander knows case (i) is false, so each is certain of (ii).  
On the following night, night 2, both B₁ and B₂ announce “my eyes are blue” and leave together.

Inductive step  
Assume the statement holds for any number of blue-eyed islanders strictly less than k (k ≥ 2):  
“If there are m < k blue-eyed islanders, then all of them leave on night m.”

Now suppose exactly k blue-eyed islanders are present.  
Each blue-eyed person sees k – 1 others with blue eyes.  
From his viewpoint there are two possibilities:  
(i) those k – 1 are the only blue-eyed ones (so the real total is k – 1);  
(ii) he himself is an additional blue-eyed person (total k).

Each of the k blue-eyed islanders watches the pier for k – 1 successive nights.  
By the induction hypothesis, if (i) were true all blue-eyed people would have left on night k – 1.  
When dawn after night k – 1 arrives and nobody has gone, every blue-eyed islander can rule out (i) and becomes certain that (ii) is correct—there are k blue-eyed people and he is one of them.  
Consequently every blue-eyed islander announces “my eyes are blue” on night k and departs; no brown-eyed islander ever gains certainty and so none leave.

Conclusion for the actual island (k = 100)  
There are 100 blue-eyed and 100 brown-eyed islanders.  
Applying the inductive result with k = 100:

Night 1 … Night 99 No one leaves.  
Night 100 All 100 blue-eyed islanders, and only they, now know their own eye colour with certainty; each says “my eyes are blue” and boards the ship.  
After that night no further departures are possible.

Final answer: On the 100th night after the guru’s statement, all and only the 100 blue-eyed islanders correctly announce “my eyes are blue” and leave the island; every brown-eyed islander remains forever.

Question:
It is your task to determine how high you can drop a billiard ball without it breaking. There is a 100 story building and you must determine which is the highest floor you can drop a ball from without it breaking. You have only two billiard balls to use as test objects. If both of them break before you determine the answer then you have failed at your task. What is the order of floors that you should drop the balls from to minimize the number of droppings that you will have to make to determine the answer?
Assume that if a ball doesn't break you can reuse it without worrying about it being weakened.
Hint: When you have one ball remaining, the strategy to find the desired height is clear. Then consider how many tries this will take conditioned on when the first ball breaks (and you then have one ball remaining)
Human Solution:
If the proper order is chosen, you can determine the breaking point with a maximum of 14 drops.  Here's how to do it:
First drop the first ball from the 14th floor. If it breaks you can determine the exact breaking point with the other ball in at most 13 more droppings, starting at the bottom and going up one floor at a time.
If the first ball survives the 14 floor drop then drop it again from the 27th (14+13) floor. If it breaks you can determine the exact breaking point with at most 12 more droppings.
If the first ball survives the 27 floor drop then drop it again from the 39th (14+13+12) floor. If it breaks you can determine the exact breaking point with at most 11 more droppings.
Keep repeating this process always going up one less floor than the last dropping until the first ball breaks. If it breaks on the xth dropping you will only need at most 14-x more droppings with the second ball to find the breaking point. By the 11th dropping of the first ball, if you get that far, you will have reached the 99th floor.
Response:
Let N be the unknown highest safe floor (0 ≤ N ≤ 100).  
Call a single release of a ball a “drop”.  We want a procedure whose
largest possible number of drops is as small as possible when only two
balls are available.

1.  How many drops are really necessary?

   Suppose we allow ourselves k drops in the worst case.  
   After the first drop we may have at most k–1 drops left.  
   • If the first ball breaks, only one ball is left, so with the
     remaining k–1 drops we could test at most k–1 floors one-by-one
     (because with one ball the only safe strategy is linear search).  
   • Therefore the first drop must not be higher than floor k, otherwise
     we could not finish in the required k drops if it broke.

   Now look at the other possibility: the first ball survives the first
   drop from floor k.  We still have k–1 drops left and still two balls
   intact.  Exactly the same reasoning says that with k–1 further drops
   we can cover at most
         (k–1) + (k–2) + … + 1 = (k–1)k / 2
   additional floors.

   Hence with k total drops we can cover

         k + (k–1)k / 2 = k(k+1)/2   floors.

   To be able to handle every N up to 100 we need

         k(k+1)/2  ≥  100.

   The smallest integer k that satisfies this inequality is k = 14
   (because 13·14/2 = 91 < 100 while 14·15/2 = 105 ≥ 100).

   Consequently no strategy can guarantee success in fewer than 14
   drops, and we must design a plan that always succeeds in 14 or less.

2.  A strategy that achieves the bound k = 14.

   Use the first ball in such a way that after its i-th drop there are
   exactly k–i drops left for the worst-case linear search.  
   That is accomplished by decreasing the spacing between successive
   trials by one each time:

        first gap  = 14,
        next gap   = 13,
        next gap   = 12,
        … ,
        last gap   =  1.

   Beginning at floor 14 and adding these gaps produces the sequence

        14,
        14+13 = 27,
        27+12 = 39,
        39+11 = 50,
        50+10 = 60,
        60+ 9 = 69,
        69+ 8 = 77,
        77+ 7 = 84,
        84+ 6 = 90,
        90+ 5 = 95,
        95+ 4 = 99,
        99+ 3 = 102   (already above the roof, so stop at 100).

   Thus an explicit list of floors that works is  

        14, 27, 39, 50, 60, 69, 77, 84, 90, 95, 99, 100.

   (If the first ball has not broken by the 11th drop at floor 99 we
   know the safe floor is at least 99; the 12th drop from 100 either
   ends the search by breaking or confirms that every floor is safe.)

   How does this meet the 14-drop guarantee?  
   If the first ball breaks on the very first try (floor 14) we may need
   at most 13 further linear tests (floors 1–13) with the second ball,
   totalling 14 drops.  
   Generally, if the first ball breaks on the i-th trial, the largest
   set of candidate floors that remain to be tested is exactly the
   previous gap (at most 14–i), and we still have 14–i drops left—so we
   can finish within the allotted 14.

3.  Optimality.

   Section 1 proved that 14 drops are necessary; section 2 gives a plan
   that always finishes in at most 14; therefore the plan is optimal.

Order of floors to drop the first ball from (stopping earlier if it
breaks):

14, 27, 39, 50, 60, 69, 77, 84, 90, 95, 99, 100  
(then use the second ball floor-by-floor upward from the last known safe
floor).

This strategy guarantees the answer in no more than 14 drops, and no
other strategy can do better.

Final answer: 14, 27, 39, 50, 60, 69, 77, 84, 90, 95, 99, 100

Question:
Every year during his birthday, the Sultan sponsors 3 camel races with the following prizes (listed in order 1st, 2nd, 3rd):
RACE A
$500
300
100
RACE B
$250
150
75
RACE C
$150
100
50
$500 bonus for winning all 3 Races. (SLAM)
$200 bonus for winning 1st, 2nd, and 3rd in any one Race (SWEEP).
ALI BOBO tells you that he owns the 3rd ("Aluminum"), 6th("Boron"), and 9th("Copper") fastest camels. He concedes that KAREEM owns the 1st, 4th, and 7th fastest camels, while SHARIF has the 2nd, 5th, and 8th fastest entries. There are other owners but with far inferior camels.
The Rules
a. Maximum 3 camels per owner.
b. A camel can run only in one race.
c. An owner may enter his camels all in one race or distribute them as he desires.
Last year ALI BOBO's camels won third place in each of the 3 Races. His gross winnings amounted to $225.
ALI BOBO wants a risk-free strategy to increase his total winnings.
QUESTION: What should be ALI BOBO's strategy?
Hint: Sometimes we must sacrifice some battles to win the war.
Human Solution:
Ali Bobo must enter Copper in Race A, Aluminum in Race B, and Boron in Race C.
SCENARIOS
1. Kareem defends his Slam and fields his camels in RACES A,B, and C according to their speed. Shariff follows that same strategy.
ALI's Aluminum will win in Race B over the K(4th) and S(5th). Boron will win in Race C over K(7th) and S(8th). Copper will still place 3rd in Race A. Total Winnings $500.
2. Kareem defends his SLAM. Shariff follows Ali's strategy.
Aluminum will place second to S(2nd) in Race B. Boron will place second to S(5th) in Race C. Copper will place third to K(1st) and S(8th). Total winnings: $350.
3. Kareem loses his mind and does not go for the grand slam. He enters his 3 camels in Race A. Shariff follows his strategy in Scenario 1.
Copper will not win anything in Race A. Aluminum will win in Race B. Boron will win in Race C. Winnings: $400.
4. Same as Scenario 3 but Shariff has same strategy as Ali.
Copper loses in Race A. Aluminum places second in Race B. Boron places second in Race C. Winnings $250.
5. Kareem camels all in Race A. Shariff's all in race B.
Copper loses in Race A. Aluminum still places second in Race B. Boron wins in Race C. Winnings $300.
6. Kareem defends his slam. Shariff camels all in race B.
Copper will place second in Race A. Aluminum will still be second in Race B. Boron will win over K(7th) Winnings:$600.
7. Kareem and Shariff has same strategy as Ali.
Copper will be third, Aluminum will be third. Boron will be third. Winnings:$225. Same as last year.
There are other scenarios but with the strategy with the worst case scenario for Ali is $225.
Response:
Label Ali Bobo’s camels, in order of absolute speed,  

 Aluminum  = A₁  (3rd fastest overall)  
 Boron     = A₂  (6th fastest overall)  
 Copper    = A₃  (9th  fastest overall)

The six quicker camels are

 Kareem : K₁ (1st), K₂ (4th), K₃ (7th)  
 Sharif  : S₁ (2nd), S₂ (5th), S₃ (8th)

Observation 1  
The richest race is A ($500-300-100).  
Whatever the other owners do, K₁ is unbeatable; it will therefore be entered in race A, because moving it to any other race would immediately cost Kareem at least \$250.  
For exactly the same reason Sharif’s S₁ will also go to A (second there is \$300, more than a first anywhere else).  
Hence race A is hopeless for Ali: the best he can ever do there is 3rd (\$100).

Observation 2  
Once K₁ and S₁ are tied down in race A, Aluminum (A₁) is the fastest remaining camel.  
If Ali places Aluminum in race B it cannot be beaten, so he is certain of first place in B (\$250).

Observation 3  
With his strongest animal secure, Ali still has Boron (A₂, 6th fastest) and Copper (A₃, 9th fastest).  
Put both of them in the remaining race C.  
Whatever Kareem and Sharif do with their four leftover camels (K₂ ,K₃ ,S₂ ,S₃),

 • at most two of them, K₂ (=4th) and S₂ (=5th), are quicker than Boron;  
 • Boron is quicker than the other two (K₃ and S₃).  

So in the worst possible case race C finishes  

 1st : one of {K₂ , S₂}  
 2nd : the other of {K₂ , S₂}  
 3rd : Boron (A₂)

and Ali still pockets the 3rd-prize money in C (\$50).  
Copper is slower than everyone just listed, but its presence cannot push Boron out of the money.

Guaranteed result for Ali with the placement

 Race A : none of his camels  
 Race B : Aluminum (A₁)  
 Race C : Boron (A₂) and Copper (A₃)

 Race B, 1st  ……………………………………… \$250  
 Race C, 3rd (worst-case) …………………  \$ 50  
 Total (certain) ……………………………………  \$300

$300 exceeds his previous sure total of \$225, and no conceivable, self-interested allocation by Kareem or Sharif can reduce it below \$300.

Final answer:  
Keep completely out of race A; enter Aluminum in race B and both Boron and Copper in race C.  This guarantees Ali Bobo at least \$300, an increase of \$75 over last year with no risk.

Question:
In a forest somewhere in Scotland lives a group of 100 dwarves. Each night they meet in the middle of the forest for a grand feast.  When morning comes, they all go home.  Each dwarf is wearing either a red hat or a blue hat. Curiously, there are no mirrors in the forest, so no dwarf knows the color of his own hat. A dwarf would never take off his hat to see its color, and a major dwarf faux pas is to comment on the color of another dwarf's hat.  The dwarves know, however, that there is at least one red hatted dwarf and one blue hatted dwarf. One day, the master dwarf announces that the nightly feast will only be intended for blue hatted dwarves, and as soon as a dwarf knows that he is wearing a red hat, he should not come back the next day, and he should never return.
How many days does it take before there are no dwarves left with red hats at the party? (Assume all the dwarves are equally capable of figuring it out, in other words, there are no smart dwarves, and no stupid dwarves...)
Hint: The number of days depends on the number of red hats.
Human Solution:
It will take one more day than the number of dwarves with red hats.
How this works is: assume that there is only one red-hatted dwarf. He would go to the party only to see 99 blue hats. He knows that there is at least one red hat. Since all he sees is blue, he knows it must be him, so he knows not to come back the next day. Meanwhile, the blue hatted dwarves can only see one red hat, so they think that if he comes back tomorrow, then he must have seen another red hat.  Since each blue hatted dwarf only sees one red hat, he would assume that if the red hatted dwarf came back tomorrow, then he must be the other red hat that the first red hatted dwarf saw. So the second day, all the blue hatted dwarves would come expecting to see if the red hatted dwarf came back. Which he wouldn't, because he knows he has a red hat. So the first day there are no dwarves with red hats is day 2, or one day more than the number of dwarves with red hats.
If there were two dwarves with red hats, each red hatted dwarf would realize on the second day that he was wearing a red hat, because he would see that the other red hat had come back, and that means that he must have seen another red hat. Since the red hats would see 98 blue hats, they would know on the second day, and the third day would be the first day that no red hatted dwarves came to the feast. This same system works for any number of red hats, because each time a blue hatted dwarf is thinking that if the red hats come back tomorrow, then he must have a red hat, the red hatted dwarves already know, and so they don't come the next day.
Response:
Let R be the (unknown) number of red-hatted dwarves present the first night.

Step 1.  Suppose R = 1.  
The unique red-hatted dwarf sees 99 blue hats and, knowing that at least one red hat exists, immediately realises it must be his own.  
He therefore stays away the very next night.  
Hence all red hats disappear after 1 day.

Step 2.  Assume inductively that if there are k red hats (k ≥ 1), they all stop coming after exactly k days.  

Step 3.  Consider the case R = k + 1.  
Every red-hatted dwarf now sees k red hats.  
Each reasons:

• “If there were only k red hats altogether, those k would leave on day k (by the inductive hypothesis).  
• When day k passes and every one of those k red hats is still attending, it must be because there is one more red hat than I can see – namely my own.”

Thus, on the morning of day k + 1, all k + 1 red-hatted dwarves stay away, and no red hats are ever seen again at the feast.

By induction, for every positive integer R, all R red-hatted dwarves leave after exactly R days.

Therefore:

Final answer: If R is the initial number of red-hatted dwarves, there will be no red hats at the feast after R days.

Question:
Please do Military Fun and Military Fun 2 first before doing this teaser. This teaser continues on from the first and second times the friends got together, and will give away the answer to Military Fun and Military Fun 2. So, please do those teasers first.
This time the same 10 friends are going to go through a training camp so that they can be ready for their next pretend battle. More friends are finding out about this military fun and want to join, Private Brianna and Private Ben have come into this group too. Today the friends will be running 3 laps around the park. At the end of the race, the friends will move up or down in ranks according on how they did. If you can't move up or down any ranks, you will stay in the same rank that you are currently in. The scoring will be as follows
1st Place- Move up 5 ranks
2nd Place- Move up 4 ranks
3rd Place- Move up 3 ranks
4th and 5th Places- Move up 1 rank each
6th and 7th Places- Stay the same rank
8th and 9th Places- Move down 1 rank each
10th and 11th Places- Move down 2 ranks each
12th Place- Move down 3 ranks
The ranks people have right now:
Lieutenant General Stephen
Colonel Anna
Major Felicia
Captain Clark
Sergeant Abby
Sergeant Brad
Corporal Jessica
Private Paul
Private Kelsey
Private Luke
Private Brianna
Private Ben
This is a list of the ranks again, just in case anyone forgot it.
Ranks
1. Lieutenant General
2. Brigadier General
3. Colonel
4. Lieutenant Colonel
5. Major
6. Captain
7. First Lieutenant
8. Second Lieutenant
9. First Sergeant
10. Sergeant
11. Corporal
12. Private
The First Lap:
Stephen, Ben, Paul, and Jessica took off sprinting taking the top 4 spots. Felicia and Brianna aren't far behind though. Kelsey, Anna and Abby were bringing up the back as they had a late start.
In the top 4 runners, the bottom two ranked people were doing the best and the top ranked person was doing the worst. The Major was in 6th place as Brianna passed her for 5th. Luke was just about to pass Felicia, but tripped and fell back to 9th place as Clark and Brad passed him in that order. The back three girls were in their places according to their rank, the highest rank being 10th place and the lowest rank being 12th place.
The Second Lap:
Paul slipped on a water puddle and fell back to third place, leaving the person he was right by, way in front. Clark moved up 2 spots, pushing those two people back one place each. Then, Felicia and Anna switched places, and Luke and Brad switched places. The people in 11th and 12th ended up switching places just before the third lap as well.
The Third Lap:
The two people in 10th and 11th place switched spots, the two people in 5th and 6th places switched spots, and the two people in 7th and 8th places switched spots. Brad ended up getting passed by the two people directly behind him, and Jessica was passed by the person directly behind her. Everyone then finished in the order that they are currently in.
Can you figure out which place everyone is in, and what rank they will be after this race?
Hint: On the first lap the top 4 runners were Stephen, Ben, Paul, and Jessica. Felicia and Brianna weren't far behind which means they were in 5th and 6th place. With Kelsey, Anna, and Abby in the back (10th, 11th, and 12th places), that means Luke, Brad, and Clark were in 7th, 8th, and 9th.
Human Solution:
The Order the finished in was: Ben, Paul, Jessica, Stephen, Brianna, Clark, Luke, Anna, Kelsey, Felicia, Brad, Abby.
Here is how they got there:
On the first lap the top 4 runners were Stephen, Ben, Paul, and Jessica. Felicia and Brianna weren't far behind which means they were in 5th and 6th place. With Kelsey, Anna, and Abby in the back (10th, 11th, and 12th places), that means Luke, Brad, and Clark were in 7th, 8th, and 9th. In the top 4 runners, the bottom two ranked people are Ben and Paul, which means that they were in 1st and 2nd, and the top ranked person was doing the worst, Stephen, which means that he was in 4th putting Jessica in 3rd place. Brianna was in 5th place, and Major Felicia was in 6th place. Clark and Brad passed Luke in a certain order, making Clark 7th, Brad 8th, and Luke 9th. The three girls in back then were in their places according to their rank, so that put Anna in 10th, Abby in 11th, and Kelsey in 12th. So, now we know what place everyone is after this lap.
On the second lap Paul slipped and was passed by Jessica, putting Ben in 1st, Jessica in 2nd, and Paul in 3rd. Clark moved up 2 spots putting him in 5th place, Brianna in 6th place, and Felicia in 7th place. Felicia then switched places with Anna, which put Felicia in 10th place, and Anna in 7th place. Luke and Brad switched places as well, which put Luke in 8th, and Brad in 9th. The 11th and 12th place people switched places too, which put Kelsey in 11th, and Abby in 12th.
On the third lap the 10th and 11th place people switched spots, putting Kelsey in 10th, and Felicia in 11th. 5th and 6th place switched, making Brianna in 5th, and Clark in 6th, and the 7th and 8th place people switched, putting Luke in 7th and Anna in 8th. Brad was passed by the two people who were directly behind him which made Kelsey in 9th, Felicia in 10th, and Brad in 11th. Jessica was also passed by Paul, the person directly behind her, putting Paul in 2nd, and Jessica in 3rd.
Their new ranks are:
Lieutenant General Stephen
Lieutenant Colonel Anna
Captain Clark
First Lieutenant Ben
First Lieutenant Felicia
Second Lieutenant Jessica
Second Lieutenant Paul
Corporal Brianna
Private Luke
Private Kelsey
Private Brad
Private Abby
Response:
Finishing order and new ranks

1st – Private Ben ⟶ moves up 5 ranks to First Lieutenant  
2nd – Private Paul ⟶ moves up 4 ranks to Second Lieutenant  
3rd – Corporal Jessica ⟶ moves up 3 ranks to Second Lieutenant  
4th – Lieutenant General Stephen ⟶ cannot rise, remains Lieutenant General  
5th – Private Brianna ⟶ moves up 1 rank to Corporal  
6th – Captain Clark ⟶ “stay-the-same” position, remains Captain  
7th – Private Luke ⟶ “stay-the-same” position, remains Private  
8th – Colonel Anna ⟶ moves down 1 rank to Lieutenant Colonel  
9th – Private Kelsey ⟶ would move down 1 rank but is already a Private, remains Private  
10th – Major Felicia ⟶ moves down 2 ranks to First Lieutenant  
11th – Sergeant Brad ⟶ moves down 2 ranks to Private  
12th – Sergeant Abby ⟶ moves down 3 ranks but cannot go lower than Private, so becomes Private

Final answer:  
Ben 1st – First Lieutenant; Paul 2nd – Second Lieutenant; Jessica 3rd – Second Lieutenant; Stephen 4th – Lieutenant General; Brianna 5th – Corporal; Clark 6th – Captain; Luke 7th – Private; Anna 8th – Lieutenant Colonel; Kelsey 9th – Private; Felicia 10th – First Lieutenant; Brad 11th – Private; Abby 12th – Private

Question:
In Numberrangements, you are given an arrangement of letters. The letters represent all of the whole numbers from 1 to the total number of letters used. Each letter represents a different number. Using the clues given, find which number each letter represents.
ABC
DEF
GHI
1. The sum of the top row is greater than the sum of the middle row, which is greater than the sum of the bottom row.
2. E is a prime factor of G.
3. F is greater than A.
4. The sum of B and G is equal to H.
5. I is not 1.
Hint: Start with casework on clue 2.
Human Solution:
A=7, B=1, C=9
D=6, E=2, F=8
G=4, H=5, I=3
From Clue 2, E must be 2, 3, 5, or 7, but it cannot be 5 or 7 because that would force G to be a greater multiple of 5 or 7, and only the numbers 1 to 9 are used. E must be 2 or 3 and G must be 4, 6, 8, or 9.
Let's try I=2. In that case, E=3 and G=6. H must be greater than 6 because of Clue 4. The most G+H+I can be is 14 because of Clue 1, since the sum of all nine numbers is only 45. So, I cannot be 2, and it therefore must be at least 3 because of Clue 5.
If I=4, then G cannot be 4, and must be 6, 8, or 9. Again, since H must be greater than G, the bottom row's sum will be too high.  If I = 5, then the minimums for G and H would be 4 and 6, respectively -- a sum of 15. If I = 6, then the minimum sum again is 15.
This means I MUST be 3, which forces E=2 and G=4, 6, or 8.  If G is 6 or 8, the sum of the bottom row will be too great, so G=4. The greatest that H can be is 7, which also means that B can only be 1, 2, or 3, from Clue 4. But 2 and 3 are already used, so B=1 and H=5.
This leaves A, C, D, and F, to be paired with 6, 7, 8, and 9, in some order. We know from Clue 1 that A+B+C > D+E+F, but E is already 1 greater than B, and from Clue 3, we know that F > A. This means that C must be at least 3 greater than D to make up for the top row trailing by at least 2. So, C must be 9, and D must be 6. This leaves 7 and 8 to be A and F, so of course, F=8 and A=7.
Response:
Reasoning sketch  
1.  Because E is a prime factor of G, E must be 2 or 3.  
   •  If E = 3, then G must be 6 or 9.  Both of those choices force H = B + G ≥ B + 6, and every attempt violates the row–sum condition S₁ > S₂ > S₃, so E ≠ 3.  
   •  Hence E = 2 and G is an even multiple of 2 that is ≤ 9, i.e. G ∈ {4, 6, 8}.  

2.  Take G = 4 (the smallest possibility).  
   Then H = B + 4, so B can be only 1, 3, 5 (to keep H ≤ 9 and distinct).  
   Trying B = 3 or 5 eventually contradicts S₁ > S₂ > S₃, but B = 1 remains possible, so fix  

      B = 1  and  H = 5.

   The numbers now used are 1, 2, 4, 5; the numbers still free are 3, 6, 7, 8, 9.

3.  Write the three row–sums with the letters still unknown:

      S₁ = A + 1 + C,  
      S₂ = D + 2 + F,  
      S₃ = 4 + 5 + I = 9 + I.

   The inequalities S₁ > S₂ > S₃ become

      (i) A + C  >  D + F + 1,  
      (ii) D + F  >  7 + I,  
      (iii) A + C >  8 + I.

4.  All five unused digits 3, 6, 7, 8, 9 must now fill {A, C, D, F, I}.  
   Notice from (iii) that I must be small; take I = 3.  
   This forces A + C ≥ 12.  Choose A = 7, C = 9 (large enough) leaving D = 6, F = 8.  
   Check every requirement:

      •  F > A → 8 > 7 ✔  
      •  Inequality (i): 7 + 9 = 16 > 6 + 8 + 1 = 15 ✔  
      •  Inequality (ii): 6 + 8 = 14 > 7 + 3 = 10 ✔  
      •  Row sums: S₁ = 17,  S₂ = 16,  S₃ = 12 → 17 > 16 > 12 ✔  
      •  I = 3 ≠ 1 ✔  

5.  All nine digits 1–9 are now used exactly once, and every clue is met.

The unique assignment is therefore  
A = 7, B = 1, C = 9,  
D = 6, E = 2, F = 8,  
G = 4, H = 5, I = 3.

Final answer: A 7, B 1, C 9, D 6, E 2, F 8, G 4, H 5, I 3

Question: A man named Stewart is traveling all over the world. First he travels to Cape Town in South Africa. Then to Jakarta in Indonesia. Then to Canberra in Australia. Then to Rome in Italy. Then to Panama City in Panama. Where does he travel next?
Hint: Each time he travels to a continent he has not traveled to.
Human Solution: Santiago in Chile. He travels to each continent in alphabetical order then to the capital of the country that has the most southern latitude.
Response:
At each step Stewart has picked a city on a continent he has not yet set foot on:

• Cape Town – Africa  
• Jakarta – Asia  
• Canberra – Australia (Oceania)  
• Rome – Europe  
• Panama City – North America  

The only inhabited continent still missing from the list is South America.  
A natural next stop, therefore, is a South-American capital city; for example Buenos Aires, Argentina.

Final answer: Buenos Aires, Argentina

Question:
The boffins from NASA have received and decoded a digital message from the Galactic Council, informing them that four alien ambassadors from the solar system are due to visit Earth in the next 24 hours. The aliens are Agurgle from Uranus, Wym-Inar from Venus, ChimChim from Pluto and Mr. Arthur Johnson from Saturn. 24 hours later, they receive a mystery message saying that if any alien comes off the ship that is green, tentacled and slimy, then they are actually an undercover assassin from Neptune. By then, however, the aliens have all landed and are in adjacent decontamination booths, waiting to be let in to NASA Headquarters. One alien turns out to be green, tentacled and slimy!
From the clues below, who is the Neptunian Assassin?
1) Wym-Inar from Venus is the only ambassador in a booth next to exactly one tentacled alien.
2). Two of the ambassadors who are not green, are each in booths next to Agurgle from Uranus.
3) ChimChim from Pluto is the only ambassador not in a booth next to exactly one Un-slimy alien.
Who do the NASA boffins not let out of the booth?
Hint: Don't get too confused with the Un-slimy bit.
Human Solution:
ChimChim from Pluto is green, tentacled and slimy and so, is the Assassin.
Looking at clue 2 we know that both the ambassadors standing next to Agurgle from Uranus are not green. Also, from the body of the teaser, we also know only one alien is green, tentacled and slimy. So there are two deductions to be made: (Note the key is - Alien (Green, Tentacled, Un-Slimey). Where "Y" stands for Yes and "N" stands for No. "?" denotes unknown, and each set of braces[] indicates a booth)
Either Deduction A
[ N, ?, ?] [Agurgle from Uranus Y, Y, N] [ N, ?, ?] [ ?, ?, ?]
Or Deduction B
[N, ?, ?] [Agurgle from Uranus ?, ?, ?][ N, ?, ?] [Y, Y, N]
You can see that either Agurgle from Uranus or the alien at the extreme right hand booth is green, tentacled and slimy.
Now taking clue 3, you can work out that ChimChim from Pluto's booth is next to a slimy alien AND each of the other aliens' booths are next to precisely one slimy alien.
So, based on the first set of deductions, you can infer the following.
Deduction A (ii):
[ChimChim from Pluto N, ?, N] [Agurgle from Uranus Y, Y, N] [N, ?, Y] [?, ?, Y]
Or Deduction B (ii):
[N, ?, Y] [Agurgle from Uranus ?, ?, Y][ N, ?, N] [ChimChim from Pluto Y, Y, N]
You can then use clue 1 to eliminate one of these deductions: Wym-Inar from Venus is the only alien in a booth next to exactly one tentacled alien. But in Deduction A(ii), ChimChim from Pluto's booth is next to exactly one tentacled alien.  Therefore, Deduction A (ii) is not possible and Deduction B (ii) is the correct one.
Deduction B (ii):
[N, ?, Y] [Agurgle from Uranus ?, ?, Y][ N, ?, N] [ChimChim from Pluto Y, Y, N]
So, looking again at clues 2 and 3, there are a further 2 possible deductions to be made.
Deduction A (iii)
[Mr. Arthur Johnson from Saturn N, N, Y] [Agurgle from Uranus] [?, N, Y] [Wym-Inar from Venus N, N, N][ChimChim from Pluto Y, Y, N]
Deduction B (iii)
[Wym-Inar from Venus N, N, Y][Agurgle from Uranus ?, Y, Y][Mr. Arthur Johnson from Saturn N, N, N][ChimChim from Pluto Y, Y, N]
So, ChimChim from Pluto is green, tentacled and slimy, and is therefore our Neptunian Assassin.
Response:
Reasoning

Step 1 – Label the four adjacent booths 1 – 4 (from left to right).  
Step 2 – Translate the three clues.

• Clue 1: Wym-Inar (W) is the only ambassador whose booth is beside exactly one tentacled alien.  
• Clue 2: Both neighbours of Agurgle (A) are not green; therefore A must occupy an interior booth (2 or 3).  
• Clue 3: ChimChim (C) is the only ambassador whose booth is NOT beside exactly one un-slimy (i.e. non-slimy) alien.

Step 3 – Put W and A into the two interior booths, because Agurgle must be interior (clue 2) and Wym-Inar cannot be on an end (otherwise some other end-booth alien would also have “exactly one” tentacled neighbour, contradicting clue 1).

Two arrangements are possible:

(a) 1 ? 2 A 3 W 4 ?  or  (b) 1 ? 2 W 3 A 4 ?

(Here “?” stands for the remaining pair: ChimChim and Mr Johnson.)

Case (a) fails

Placing W in booth 3 cannot satisfy simultaneously  
• “only W has one tentacled neighbour” and  
• the existence of a green & tentacled alien,  
so arrangement (a) is impossible.

Case (b) succeeds

Put W in booth 2 and A in booth 3:

booth 1 booth 2 booth 3 booth 4  
   X      W      A      Y      

(X and Y are C and J in some order.)

Tentacles (T)

To satisfy clue 1:

• Let the alien in booth 1 be tentacled.  
• No other alien is tentacled.

Then W sees exactly one tentacled neighbour (booth 1).  
All others see either zero or two tentacled neighbours, so clue 1 is met.

Green (G)

Clue 2 already forces both neighbours of A (i.e. W in booth 2 and Y in booth 4) to be non-green.  
The tentacled alien in booth 1 is free to be green.  
Hence green & tentacled can occur only in booth 1.

Slimy (S) and clue 3

Put ChimChim in booth 1 and Mr Johnson in booth 4.

Choose Slimy/Un-slimy so that

• W (booth 2), A (booth 3) and Y (booth 4) each have exactly one un-slimy neighbour.  
• C (booth 1) has zero un-slimy neighbours.

That is achieved with  
S(booth 1)=slimy  S(booth 2)=slimy  S(booth 3)=un-slimy  S(booth 4)=un-slimy.

Now ChimChim alone is NOT beside exactly one un-slimy neighbour (he is beside none), so clue 3 is satisfied.

The assassin

The alien in booth 1 (ChimChim) is

• green  • tentacled  • slimy.

By the Galactic Council’s warning, that combination identifies the undercover Neptunian assassin.

Final answer: ChimChim from Pluto is the assassin.

Question:
Four men are in a line at the Madadian Police station, charged with unlicensed kebab breeding.
The men are Mad Ade, Buster Artery, Cliff Hedge and Donny Moe - and they are standing in a straight line.
One man is fair, handsome and unscarred.
Two men who are not fair, are each standing next to Mad Ade
Buster Artery is the only man standing next to exactly one handsome man.
Cliff Hedge is the only man not standing next to exactly one scarred man.
Who is fair, handsome and unscarred?
Hint: From (2), both the men standing next to Mad Ade are not fair. Also, exactly one man is fair, handsome and unscarred. Hence, there are two cases:
Human Solution:
Cliff Hedge is fair, handsome and unscarred.
From (2), both the men standing next to Mad Ade are not fair. Also, exactly one man is fair, handsome and unscarred. Hence, there are two cases:
Case 1 :: ? (N, ?, ?) : Mad Ade (Y, Y, N) : ? (N, ?, ?) : ? (?, ?, ?)
Case 2 :: ? (N, ?, ?) : Mad Ade (?, ?, ?) : ? (N, ?, ?) : ? (Y, Y, N)
Note the representation - Name (Fair, Handsome, Scarred). "Y" stands for Yes and "N" stands for No. Mad Ade (Y, Y, N) means Mad Ade is Fair, Handsome and Unscarred.(oh, how true this is..NOT)
It is clear that either Mad Ade or the man at the extreme right is fair, handsome and unscarred.
From (4), it is deduced that Cliff Hedge is standing next to unscarred man and each of the other men standing next to exactly one scarred man.
Case 1 :: Cliff Hedge (N, ?, N) : Mad Ade (Y, Y, N) : ? (N, ?, Y) : ? (?, ?, Y)
Case 2 :: ? (N, ?, Y) : Mad Ade (?, ?, Y) : ? (N, ?, N) : Cliff Hedge (Y, Y, N)
From (3), Buster Artery is the only man standing next to exactly one handsome man. But in Case 1, Cliff Hedge is standing next to exactly one handsome man. Hence, Case 1 is not possible and Case 2 is the correct one.
Case 2 :: ? (N, ?, Y) : Mad Ade (?, ?, Y) : ? (N, ?, N) : Cliff Hedge (Y, Y, N)
Again from (3) and (4), there are 2 possibilities as shown below.
Case 2a :: Donny Moe (N, N, Y) : Mad Ade (?, N, Y) : Buster Artery (N, N, N) : Cliff Hedge (Y, Y, N)
Case 2b :: Buster Artery (N, N, Y) : Mad Ade (?, Y, Y) : Donny Moe (N, N, N) : Cliff Hedge (Y, Y, N)
Thus, Cliff Hedge is fair, handsome and unscarred. Also, Mad Ade may be either fair or not fair.
Response:
Let the four positions in the line be numbered

1 ─ 2 ─ 3 ─ 4 .

“Standing next to’’ means “in an adjacent position”.  
Write F for fair, H for handsome, S for scarred,   and  ¬ for the negation of a property.

0.  Exactly one man is F H ¬S (fair, handsome and un-scarred).

1.  “Two men who are not fair are each standing next to Mad Ade.’’  
     Therefore Mad Ade is in an interior place (2 or 3) and both of his neighbours are ¬F.

2.  “Buster Artery is the only man standing next to exactly one handsome man.’’  
     Denote by h(x) the number of handsome neighbours of x.  
     Hence h(Buster)=1 and for every other man h(x)≠1, i.e. h(x)=0 or 2.

3.  “Cliff Hedge is the only man not standing next to exactly one scarred man.’’  
     Denote by s(x) the number of scarred neighbours of x.  
     Then s(Cliff)≠1 (so it is 0 or 2) and for every other man s(x)=1.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Step 1.  Who can be the unique F H ¬S ?

Because the two men next to Mad Ade are ¬F, the unique F H ¬S man is either

(A) Mad Ade himself, or (B) the man at the end that is *not* next to Mad Ade.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Step 2.  Case (A) is impossible.

Put Mad Ade at 2 (the case 3 is symmetrical) and assume he is F H ¬S.

Since Mad Ade is handsome, any neighbour of his has at least one handsome neighbour.  
Let the row be

1 : X  2 : Mad Ade  3 : Y  4 : Z .

Because X has exactly one neighbour, h(X)=1; therefore X must be Buster.  
To make Buster the *only* man with h(x)=1 we are forced to make

 Y not handsome, Z handsome, X (Buster) not handsome.

Now Buster stands at an end whose only neighbour (Mad Ade) is ¬S, so s(Buster)=0.  
But every man except Cliff must have s(x)=1, and Buster is *not* Cliff.  
Contradiction.  Thus case (A) is impossible.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Step 3.  Case (B) – the unique F H ¬S man is the end man *opposite* Mad Ade.

Without loss of generality put

position 2 : Mad Ade    (position 3 is the mirror case)  
position 4 : Z = F H ¬S .

The row is

1 : P  2 : Mad Ade  3 : Q  4 : Z(=F H ¬S) ,

with P,Q the two remaining men.

(a)  Handsomeness.

Let the handsome status be

H(P)=a, H(Mad Ade)=b, H(Q)=c, H(Z)=1 .

Neighbour-handsome counts are  
h(P)=b ;  h(Mad Ade)=a+c ;  h(Q)=b+1 ;  h(Z)=c .

Because h(Z)=c must *not* be 1 (Buster is the only one with count 1), take c=0.

Then h(Z)=0 and h(Q)=b+1.  
To have a single count 1, set b=0 and a=0; then

h(P)=0,  h(Mad Ade)=0,  h(Q)=1,  h(Z)=0.

Therefore Q is the only man with a count 1, so Q is Buster, and

H-status: H(Z)=1, others not handsome.

(b)  Fairness.

Mad Ade’s neighbours P and Q must be ¬F, so Z (already F) is the *only* fair man.

(c)  Scars.

Put S-status

S(Z)=0 (given), S(Buster)=u, S(Mad Ade)=v, S(P)=w.

Neighbour-scar counts:

s(P)=v ;  s(Buster)=v ;  s(Mad Ade)=w+u ;  s(Z)=u .

Make Cliff the only man whose count is not 1.

Choose Cliff = Z.  
Then we need s(Z)=u≠1 ⇒ u=0.

Now require the other three counts to equal 1:

 s(P)=v=1, s(Buster)=v=1 ⇒ v=1 ;

 s(Mad Ade)=w+u = w+0 =1 ⇒ w=1.

Thus

S-status: P scarred, Mad Ade scarred, Buster unscarred, Z unscarred.

All conditions are now satisfied:

•  only Z is F H ¬S;  
•  the two neighbours of Mad Ade (P and Buster) are ¬F;  
•  h(Buster)=1, others 0;  
•  s(Z)=0≠1, and every other man has s(x)=1.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Step 4.  Identifying the names.

Row obtained:

position 1 : Donny Moe  (scarred, ¬F, ¬H)  
position 2 : Mad Ade   (scarred, possibly F, ¬H)  
position 3 : Buster Artery (unscarred, ¬F, ¬H)  
position 4 : Cliff Hedge  (unscarred, F, H) .

(The mirror arrangement, with positions 1 and 4 interchanged, gives the same
conclusion.)

Hence the only man who is fair, handsome and unscarred is

Cliff Hedge.

Final answer: Cliff Hedge

Question:
Mad Ade's rich uncle "Uncle Rich" owned the famous Madadian Race horse breeding stables "The Gluepot".
It has a private race track that has five lanes.
Uncle Rich has 25 horses and wishes to know which are the three fastest.
What is the least number of races needed to be run to find the answer?
Note that it is only the ranking of the horses being found not the actual timings.
Hint: Subgroups!
Human Solution:
Answer: 7 races
Race #1 to Race #5 - Divide the horses into 5 groups of 5. Race each group to rank the first 3 in each - that's 5 races.
Race #6 - Race the winner from each group. The winner in this race is the fastest horse.
Race #7 - Race the second and third horses from the race in which the fastest horse raced initially,
the first and second horses from the group of the second horse in Race #6, and the third horse in Race #6 (that's a total of 5 horses).
The first and second horses in Race #7 are the second and third horses of the entire stable.
Response:
We can never measure times; in every race we only learn the finishing order of the five horses that ran.  
The task is therefore purely one of eliminating horses that can no longer finish in the overall top-three.

Step-by-step procedure and proof of minimality

1. Split the 25 horses into five arbitrary groups of five and run
   Race 1, Race 2, Race 3, Race 4, Race 5 – one race for each group.  
   Inside every group we now know the full order
        A1 A2 A3 A4 A5
        B1 B2 B3 B4 B5
        C1 C2 C3 C4 C5
        D1 D2 D3 D4 D5
        E1 E2 E3 E4 E5
   (subscripts indicate the placing within that race).

2. Race 6: run the five winners A1,B1,C1,D1,E1.  
   Suppose they finish A1 ≺ B1 ≺ C1 ≺ D1 ≺ E1.  
   We now know the speed ranking of the five whole groups:
        every A-horse is faster than every B-horse,
        every B-horse is faster than every C-horse,
        etc.

   Consequences:
   • No horse in groups D or E can reach the overall top-three: at least A1,B1,C1 beat them.  
   • Within group C only C1 can still be in the top-three (C2,C3,… all lose to C1, who loses to at least A1,B1), so C2,… can be discarded.  
   • Within group B only B1 or B2 can still matter (B3 loses to B2).  
   • Within group A, A1 is already best overall; A2 or A3 might still be 2nd or 3rd.

   The only horses not yet eliminated are therefore
        A2, A3, B1, B2, C1   (five horses).

3. Race 7: run exactly those five survivors.  
   • The winner of this race is the second-fastest horse overall.  
   • The runner-up of this race is the third-fastest overall.  
   • Together with A1 (known fastest) the overall top-three are now identified.

Why 7 races are minimal  
• The first five races are unavoidable: each lane holds only one horse and every horse must run at least once.  
• After only six races (five heats + one winners’ race) the best we can know is that the candidates for places 2 and 3 are down to five horses; one further race is indispensable to choose the exact two among them.  
Hence no scheme can finish in fewer than 7 races, and the above scheme achieves that bound.

Final answer: 7

Question: In a wood-cutting factory, five large sawing machines stand in a windowless room. Each machine has an on/off switch attached, there being no doubt as to which switch controls which machine.
