-------------------------------------------------------------------
1. Minute hand on the NEXT line  
We need M ≡ H+1 (mod 60):

  12n ≡ n+1 (mod 60)  
  11n ≡ 1  (mod 60).

Since 11⋅11=121≡1 (mod 60), 11 is its own inverse, so

  n ≡ 11 (mod 60) ⇒ n=11.

Thus t=12n=132 min = 2 h 12 min.

Check: H=11, M=12 — the minute hand is indeed one line ahead.

-------------------------------------------------------------------
2. Minute hand on the PREVIOUS line  
We need M ≡ H−1 (mod 60):

  12n ≡ n−1 (mod 60)  
  11n ≡ −1 ≡ 59 (mod 60).

Multiply by the inverse 11:

  n ≡ 11⋅59 ≡ 649 ≡ 49 (mod 60) ⇒ n=49.

Thus t=12n=588 min = 9 h 48 min.

Check: H=49, M=48 — the minute hand is one line behind.

-------------------------------------------------------------------
Therefore, within each 12-hour period, the required times are

• Hour hand on a line, minute hand on the next line: 2 : 12  
• Hour hand on a line, minute hand on the previous line: 9 : 48.

Final answer: 2:12 and 9:48

Question:
In the following code, each symbol stands for one of five letters.
! stands for I, S, A, T, or N
# stands for N, F, R, S, or T
& stands for J, E, B, O, or G
* stands for H, E, K, P, or W
^ stands for L, U, D, R, or I
The five letter code word, #&^!*, can be translated into two English words that are opposites. What are the two words?
Hint: Directionality
Human Solution: North and South
Response:
Step 1 –  translate the specification into positional constraints  
For the coded word #&^!*, each position may be filled only with the letters allowed for its symbol:

1. ‘#’ → {N,F,R,S,T}  
2. ‘&’ → {J,E,B,O,G}  
3. ‘^’ → {L,U,D,R,I}  
4. ‘!’ → {I,S,A,T,N}  
5. ‘*’ → {H,E,K,P,W}

Thus any legitimate deciphering must be a five–letter English word whose letters satisfy, in order, those five sets.

Step 2 –  use the hint “Directionality”  
The hint suggests that the two opposite words we seek are directional opposites (north–south, east–west, left–right, up–down, front–back, etc.).  Among these, only “NORTH” and “SOUTH” are both five letters long; all the other common directional antonyms have at least one word of length ≠ 5.

Step 3 –  check “NORTH” against the constraints  

#  → N  (N is in {N,F,R,S,T}) ✔  
&  → O  (O is in {J,E,B,O,G}) ✔  
^  → R  (R is in {L,U,D,R,I}) ✔  
!  → T  (T is in {I,S,A,T,N}) ✔  
*  → H  (H is in {H,E,K,P,W}) ✔  

All five letters fit, so “NORTH” is a valid decoding of #&^!*.

Step 4 –  check “SOUTH” against the constraints  

#  → S  (S is in {N,F,R,S,T}) ✔  
&  → O  (O is in {J,E,B,O,G}) ✔  
^  → U  (U is in {L,U,D,R,I}) ✔  
!  → T  (T is in {I,S,A,T,N}) ✔  
*  → H  (H is in {H,E,K,P,W}) ✔  

“SOUTH” is also a valid decoding of the same coded word.

Step 5 –  confirm they are opposites  
“NORTH” and “SOUTH” are standard directional opposites, satisfying the requirement of the problem.

Final answer: NORTH and SOUTH

Question:
I was going through some old family photos in the attic when I stumbled upon our family tree.  I studied it for a couple minutes then went back down stairs to tell my mom about the family tree.  The problem is I didn't study it long enough to remember the whole thing.  I only remembered  a couple things about it, and recent memories.  Can you help me figure out my family tree?  There are two grandparents, who had two children, who both got married and had 2 more children each.  Totaling 10 people in all (Alex, David, Jamie, Jessica, John, Justin, Lincoln, Martha, Mary and Tina).
1.  One of Jamie's ancestors was David.
2.  John's sister gave birth to Tina.
3.  Mary went bowling with her nephew last Saturday.
4.  Alex is cousins with one of the girls.
5.  Justin married Mary.
6.  Jessica is not an ancestor, nor cousin of Tina.
7. Lincoln's brother showed Justin's son his baseball cards.
Hint: Martha is a grandparent
Human Solution:
Martha and David were the grandparents.
They gave birth to John and Mary.
John married Jessica, who gave birth to Lincoln and Alex.
Mary married Justin and gave birth to Tina and Jamie.
Response:
Family tree (eldest generation first)

Grandparents  
• David (grandfather) ─ married to ─ Martha (grandmother)

Their two children (Generation 2)  
• Mary (daughter of David & Martha) ─ married to ─ Justin  
• John (son of David & Martha) ─ married to ─ Jessica

Grand-children (Generation 3)  
Children of Mary & Justin  
 • Jamie (son)  • Tina (daughter)

Children of John & Jessica  
 • Alex (son)  • Lincoln (son)

Verification with every clue  
1. Jamie’s ancestor David → David is Jamie’s grandfather.  
2. John’s sister (Mary) gave birth to Tina → satisfied.  
3. Mary has a nephew (either Alex or Lincoln) and bowled with him → satisfied.  
4. Alex is cousins with one of the girls (Tina) → satisfied.  
5. Justin married Mary → satisfied.  
6. Jessica is neither ancestor nor cousin of Tina (she is Tina’s aunt) → satisfied.  
7. Lincoln’s brother (Alex) showed Justin’s son (Jamie) his baseball cards → satisfied.

All ten names are placed with no contradictions, giving the unique consistent family tree above.  

Final answer: David–Martha as grandparents; their children Mary (m. Justin) and John (m. Jessica); grandchildren Jamie & Tina (Mary’s) and Alex & Lincoln (John’s).

Question:
Two children, who were all tangled up in their reckoning of the days of the week, paused on their way to school to straighten matters out. "When the day after tomorrow is yesterday," said Priscilla, "then 'today' will be as far from Sunday as that day was which was 'today' when the day before yesterday was tomorrow!"
On which day of the week did this puzzling prattle occur?
Hint: Why did they stop on their way to school?
Human Solution: The two children were so befogged over the calendar that they had started on their way to school on Sunday morning!
Response:
Let the day on which the children are talking be T.

Step 1.  Translate the two fantastic conditions into ordinary time shifts.

a)  “When the day after tomorrow is yesterday …”  
   –  The day that is now “the day after tomorrow’’ is T + 2.  
   –  For that day to be “yesterday’’ we must have moved one day farther on, i.e. to T + 3.  
   Hence the words refer to the day three days ahead of the conversation.  
   Call that future day F = T + 3.

b)  “… that day which was ‘today’ when the day before yesterday was tomorrow.”  
   –  The day that is now “the day before yesterday’’ is T – 2.  
   –  For that day to have been called “tomorrow’’ we must look back one day, i.e. to T – 3.  
   Thus these words refer to the day three days before the conversation.  
   Call that past day P = T – 3.

Step 2.  Restate Priscilla’s assertion with the two ordinary days P and F.

She says that, on the future day F, the then-“today’’ (namely F itself) will be as far from Sunday as the past day P was from Sunday.

In symbols (measuring “distance from Sunday’’ as the smaller of the two counts forward or backward round the week):

distance(Sunday, F)  =  distance(Sunday, P).

Step 3.  Express everything with numbers.

Index the days of the week by
0  =  Sunday, 1 = Monday, … , 6 = Saturday.

Write T = x (0 ≤ x ≤ 6).  
Then

P = x – 3  (mod 7),         F = x + 3  (mod 7).

The distance of a numbered day d from Sunday (0) is  
D(d) = min {d, 7 – d}  (0 ≤ D(d) ≤ 3).

Priscilla’s condition is therefore

D(x – 3) = D(x + 3).                               (★)

Step 4.  Solve equation (★).

Because 0 ≤ D(d) ≤ 3, equality can occur only if D(x – 3) = D(x + 3) is one of the values 0, 1, 2 or 3.

Notice that the two numbers (x – 3) and (x + 3) differ by 6, so one of them is at most 3 and the other is at least 3.  Consequently their two distances from 0 are equal only when both distances are exactly 3, which happens precisely when

x – 3 ≡ 4  (mod 7)   and   x + 3 ≡ 3  (mod 7),

i.e. when x ≡ 0  (mod 7).

Thus T = 0, which is Sunday.

Step 5.  Check the hint.

The children were on their way to school; since ordinary school is not held on Sunday, the “school’’ must be Sunday-school.  This is consistent with the deduction.

Therefore the conversation took place on

Final answer: Sunday

Question:
What inference can you draw from the following statements:
1. Some alligators carry umbrellas in the shower.
2. Only those that know that flying fish live in trees prefer caramel candy to chocolate.
3. Certain days are set aside for alligators to watch rabbits play hockey.
4. Some large reptiles are steeplechasers.
5. Only steeplechasers can watch hockey games.
6.Those alligators that carry umbrellas in the shower know that flying fish live in the trees.
7. Those that prefer chocolate to caramel candy cannot be steeplechasers.
8. Steeplechasers are vegetarians.
Human Solution: Only alligators that are vegetarians are allowed to watch rabbits play hockey.
Response:
From the list of premises we need only the following two:

4.  Some large reptiles are steeple-chasers.  
8.  All steeple-chasers are vegetarians.

Translate them symbolically (let Lx = “x is a large reptile”, Sx = “x is a steeple-chaser”, Vx = “x is a vegetarian”):

4.  ∃x (Lx ∧ Sx)  
8.  ∀x (Sx → Vx)

Logical derivation

a) From (4) pick the witness a such that La ∧ Sa.  
b) From Sa and (8) we obtain Va.  
c) Combining La (from a) with Va (from b) gives La ∧ Va.  

Thus there exists at least one object that is both a large reptile and a vegetarian.

Final answer: Some large reptiles are vegetarians.

Question:
Biggie Nuff, Baron of Grey Matter, now living in Shapeless, Mass., was dying from a newly developed allergy to water, and wanted his will to reflect the common inheritance law of his father's native country.  Biggie's wife, Faerie, was pregnant at the time with what would be the first child for either of them.  Biggie's new will stated that if his child were a boy, the son would get 2/3 of his estate, and his widow would get 1/3.  If the child were a girl, the widow would get 2/3 of the estate, and the daughter would get 1/3.
In due time, Biggie died, and the authorities read his will, holding dispensation of the estate until the child was born.  Five months after Biggie's death, Faerie delivered ... normal, healthy twins, a boy (whom she named Manny) and a girl (whom she named Goodie).
The estate's executor immediately appealed to the Shapeless magistrate to rule on the proper division for the estate.  After a great deal of arguing and deep thought, plus several failed attempts to raise Biggie's spirit with a seance, the judge rendered a fair decision.
How did they divide Biggie's estate?
Hint: The fraction is in sevenths
Human Solution:
The judge reasoned that Biggie intended to give his wife half as much as a son, or twice as much as a daughter.  Therefore, he ruled that Manny gets 4/7 of the estate, Faerie gets 2/7, and Goodie gets 1/7.
(This is supposedly a real decision in Massachusetts, according to the Reader's Digest puzzle book in which I first read this, copyright 1967.  Obviously, I've changed the names).
Response:
Let the three portions of the estate be  

M  = share for Manny (the boy)  
F  = share for Faerie (the widow)  
G  = share for Goodie (the girl),  

and let the whole estate be the unit 1.

Biggie’s will gives only two explicit directions, each of which is a ratio statement.

1.  “If the child is a boy, the son gets 2/3 and the widow 1/3.”  
   ⇒  M : F = 2 : 1.                                 (1)

2.  “If the child is a girl, the widow gets 2/3 and the daughter 1/3.”  
   ⇒  F : G = 2 : 1.                                 (2)

Because twins of both sexes were born, the judge required a division that simultaneously satisfies both ratio intentions (1) and (2).

From (1) M = 2F.  
From (2) F = 2G.  
Substituting the second into the first: M = 2(2G) = 4G.

Thus the three shares are in the proportion  
M : F : G = 4G : 2G : G = 4 : 2 : 1.

Let one part be 1/7 of the estate.  
Then G = 1/7, F = 2/7, M = 4/7, and the total is 1.

Therefore the estate was divided into sevenths (as hinted):

• Manny (the son) received 4/7 of the estate.  
• Faerie (the widow) received 2/7 of the estate.  
• Goodie (the daughter) received 1/7 of the estate.

Final answer: Manny 4/7, Faerie 2/7, Goodie 1/7.

Question:
At the annual Pottstown Rose Show, Mr. Tom Thorne, an avid rose grower, entered his six best new hybrid roses.  He did extremely well, taking home 28 ribbons.  From the following clues, can you figure out how many blue ribbons and how many red ribbons each rose received?
Names of Roses are:  Pretty in Pink, Ravishing Red, Simply Silver, Mrs. Thelma Thorne, Very Violet and Yummy Yellow.
1.  No two roses won the same total number of ribbons.
2.  "Pretty in Pink" won one-quarter of the total amount, which was the same amount as the number that "Ravishing Red", "Yummy Yellow" and "Simply Silver" won together.
3.  "Very Violet" won the same number of ribbons as both "Mrs.Thelma Thorne" and "Simply Silver" together.
4.  Three-quarters of "Ravishing Red's" ribbons were red.
5.  One-third of "Mrs. Thelma Thorne's" ribbons were blue; "Yummy Yellow" won just one blue ribbon.
6.  "Simply Silver" won an equal number of blue and red ribbons.
7.  "Very Violet" won the same number of blue ribbons as "Pretty in Pink".
8.  "Very Violet" won as many red ribbons as were won by "Mrs. Thelma Thorne" and "Ravishing Red" together.
Hint: Yummy yellow didn't win any red ribbons.
Human Solution:
Pretty in Pink - 1 Blue - 6 Red
Ravishing Red - 1 Blue - 3 Red
Simply Silver - 1 Blue - 1 Red
Mrs. Thelma Thorne - 2 Blue - 4 Red
Very Violet - 1 Blue - 7 red
Yummy Yellow - 1 Blue only
Response:
Pretty in Pink – 1 blue, 6 red  
Ravishing Red – 1 blue, 3 red  
Simply Silver – 1 blue, 1 red  
Mrs. Thelma Thorne – 2 blue, 4 red  
Very Violet – 1 blue, 7 red  
Yummy Yellow – 1 blue, 0 red  

Final answer: (1 B, 6 R), (1 B, 3 R), (1 B, 1 R), (2 B, 4 R), (1 B, 7 R), (1 B, 0 R)

Question:
Well... The Winning Combination is back.. but with a twist!  You are a millionaire... but you have now become very greedy and a cheater.  You spend lots of money on selfish things, and are finding yourself very short of money.  The show has refused to let you back on after you meanly insulted the host.
But you are sneakier than that.  Now, your son has applied to be a contestant and has successfully made it on.  He, however, has nowhere near the brain power as you, so you have figured out another device, being the greedy person you are, to help your son out and claim half a million more.
He is secretly wearing a very cleverly disguised earpiece which you will talk to him through.  Whilst you sit at home, with a pen and paper, he will recite the clues into your ear and you must solve them for him!
You grip your pen... with headphones and microphone in place, and wait for him to start reciting.
The combination is spaced out like this... ??-??-??-??.  A 'set' refers to a set of two numbers.
"OK, Dad...
1. The sum of the digits in the third set is less than 14 but greater than 10.
2. The third set of numbers is 13 smaller than the fourth set.
3. If you multiply the second set of numbers by 2 and add 7, then you will get the first set of numbers.
4. The sum of the digits in the fourth set is greater than the sum of the digits in the first set.
5. There are no 0's, 3's or 6's in the combination.  Every other number is in the combination.
6. The first set of two digits is a square number (for example 81 is a square number... 9x9).
Hurry, Dad, hurry!"
Hint: The numbers in the first set are not higher than 60.
Human Solution:
The solution is 49-21-75-88.
First of all, we know that there are no 0's, 3's or 6's in the combination and that every other digit appears at least once (clue 5).
OK, we'll start on the first set.
We know it's a square number (clue 6).
The only available square numbers that don't have a 0, 3 or 6 in them are:
25
49
81
Now, read clue 3.  This tells us that multiplying the second set of numbers by 2 and then adding 7 will give us the first set.
So you must work backwards from the three numbers we know are the possibilities.
81 - 7 = 74 / 2 = 37.  However, we know there are no 3's in the combination so this can't be right.
25 - 7 = 18 / 2 = 9.  This can't be right, because written down it would be 09 and we know there are no 0's.
So that leaves with 49.
49 - 7 = 42 / 2 = 21.
Now we know this much:
49-21-??-??
Now we must work on the last two sets.
Clue 2 tells us that the third set is 13 smaller than the fourth set.
Here are the possible combinations:
11-24
12-25
14-27
15-28
28-41
29-42
41-54
42-55
44-57
45-58
58-71
59-72
71-84
72-85
74-87
75-88
78-91
79-92
81-94
82-95
84-97
85-98
Now, we must remember clue 5 - this tells us that every number will appear in the combination at least once, apart from 0, 3 and 6.
Currently, we have 1, 2, 4 and 9 in... so that leaves out 5, 7 and 8.
So now we review the list... there are only three possible combinations that include 5, 7 and 8:
58-71
75-88
72-85
Now, we read clue 4.  This tells us the sum of the digits in the fourth set is greater than the sum of the digits in the first set.  The sum of the digits in the first set is 13 (4 + 9), and so the only one greater than that is the 75-88 combination (8 + 8 = 16).
So there we have it.
49-21-75-88.
(P.S. Sorry if this offended anybody, not that I think it would, but in my other teaser people were complaining so I'm just putting this in here for warning).
Response: Final answer: 49 - 21 - 75 - 88

Question:
In the following code, each symbol stands for one of five letters.
* stands for T, L, M, V, or Y
# stands for S, H, C, M, or B
^ stands for F, S, K, I, or O
$ stands for O, W, G, U, or P
The four letter code word, #$^*, can be translated into two English words that are opposites. What are the two words?
Hint: High variance?
Human Solution: Boom and Bust.
Response:
The four-symbol code word is read position by position, choosing a letter from the set allowed for that symbol:

#  →  S, H, C, M, B  
$  →  O, W, G, U, P  
^  →  F, S, K, I, O  
*  →  T, L, M, V, Y  

Look for two ordinary four-letter English words that are antonyms and whose letters, position by position, belong to the corresponding sets.

1. Take the economic antonym pair “BOOM” and “BUST”.

   BOOM  
   # = B (in {S,H,C,M,B}) ✓  
   $ = O (in {O,W,G,U,P}) ✓  
   ^ = O (in {F,S,K,I,O}) ✓  
   * = M (in {T,L,M,V,Y}) ✓  

   BUST  
   # = B (in {S,H,C,M,B}) ✓  
   $ = U (in {O,W,G,U,P}) ✓  
   ^ = S (in {F,S,K,I,O}) ✓  
   * = T (in {T,L,M,V,Y}) ✓  

2. “Boom” and “bust” are standard opposites referring to rapid expansion versus collapse – exactly the kind of “high variance” hinted at.

Since both words satisfy the letter–set restrictions and are true antonyms, they are the required translations of the code #$^*.

Final answer: BOOM and BUST

Question:
There are three students Anu, Bob and Coy. They have exactly three books - one on Physics, one on Chemistry and one on Math. Each of these three books belongs to exactly one of the students. As I wanted to know the names of the respective owners of the books I asked them about the owners of the books. The following are the answers given by Anu, Bob and Coy.
Anu : Physics book belongs to me. Maths book does not belong to Bob. Chemistry book does not belong to Coy.
Bob : Physics book does not belong to me. Chemistry book belongs to Coy. Maths book  does not belong to Anu.
Coy : Physics book does not belong to Anu. Maths book does not belong to me. Chemistry book does not belong to Bob.
I knew that exactly one of them always speaks the truth, exactly  one of them always lies and the third one alternates between truth and lie, in any order.
Which of the following statements can then be concluded?
1) Anu always tells the truth.
2) Coy always lies.
3) Bob is the owner of the Chemistry book.
NOTE: Out of the given set of 3 statements, it is not necessary that one and only one statement can be concluded. One or more statements can be concluded.
Hint: Start with casework on if Anu tells the truth
Human Solution:
All the three given statements can be concluded.
The given statements are
1) Anu always tells the truth.
2) Coy always lies.
3) Bob is the owner of the Chemistry book.
The answers given by Anu, Bob and Coy to my query about the owners of the Physics, Chemistry and Maths books are as follows :-
Anu : Physics book belongs to me. Maths book does not belong to Bob. Chemistry book does not belong to Coy.
Bob : Physics book does not belong to me. Chemistry book belongs to Coy. Maths book  does not belong to Anu.
Coy : Physics book does not belong to Anu. Maths book does not belong to me. Chemistry book does not belong to Bob.
Case 1 : Let us assume that Anu always tells the truth.
Then according to Anu's answer,
Physics book belongs to Anu.
Chemistry book belongs to Bob.
Maths book belongs to Coy.
Comparing Anu's reply with that of Bob's and Coy's replies, we can infer that
Bob speaks the truth, lies and speaks the truth respectively when he says that the Physics book does not belong to him, the Chemistry book belongs to Coy and the Maths book  does not belong to Anu.
Coy lies three times when he says that the Physics book does not belong to Anu, the Maths book does not belong to him and the Chemistry book does not belong to Bob.
Hence under Case 1, Anu always speaks the truth, Bob alternates between truth and lie and Coy always lies. Also in this case the Chemistry book belongs to Bob.
Case 2 : Let us assume that Bob always tells the truth.
Then according to Bob's answer,
Physics book belongs to Anu.
Maths book belongs to Bob.
Chemistry book belongs to Coy.
Comparing Bob's reply with that of Anu's and Coy's replies, we can infer that
Anu speaks the truth, lies and lies respectively when he says that the Physics book belongs to him, the Maths book does not belong to Bob and the Chemistry book does not belong to Coy.
Coy lies, speaks the truth and speaks the truth respectively when he says that the Physics book does not belong to Anu, the Maths book does not belong to him and the Chemistry book does not belong to Bob.
Hence under Case 2, Bob always speaks the truth, Anu and Coy alternate between truth and lie and hence this case is not possible since it is given that exactly one of them always speaks the truth, exactly  one of them always lies and the third one alternates between truth and lie, in any order.
Case 3 : Let us assume that Coy always tells the truth. Here we can again make two sub cases.
a) According to Coy's answer,
Maths book belongs to Anu.
Physics book belongs to Bob.
Chemistry book belongs to Coy.
Comparing Coy's reply with that of Anu's and Bob's replies, we can infer that
Anu lies, speaks the truth and lies respectively when he says that the Physics book belongs to him, the Maths book does not belong to Bob and the Chemistry book does not belong to Coy.
Bob lies, speaks the truth and lies respectively when he says that the Physics book does not belong to him, the Chemistry book belongs to Coy and the Maths book  does not belong to Anu.
This case is not possible since both Anu and Bob are alternating between truth and lie and there is no one person who always lies.
b) According to Coy's answer,
Chemistry book belongs to Anu.
Maths book belongs to Bob.
Physics book belongs to Coy.
Comparing Coy's reply with that of Anu's and Bob's replies, we can infer that
Anu lies, lies and speaks the truth respectively when he says that the Physics book belongs to him, the Maths book does not belong to Bob and the Chemistry book does not belong to Coy.
Bob speaks the truth, lies and speaks the truth respectively when he says that the Physics book does not belong to him, the Chemistry book belongs to Coy and the Maths book  does not belong to Anu.
This case is also not possible since both Anu and Bob are alternating between truth and lie and there is no one person who always lies.
Hence among the three cases, only Case 1 can be considered to be a valid case wherein Anu always speaks the truth, Bob alternates between truth and lie, Coy always lies and the Chemistry book belongs to Bob. Hence all the given statements 1, 2 and 3 can be concluded.
Response:
Let  

P , C , M  be the owners of the Physics, Chemistry and Maths books respectively,  
with P,C,M ∈ {Anu, Bob, Coy} and all different.  

Write each of the nine assertions exactly as they are spoken.

Anu  
A1: P = Anu  
A2: M ≠ Bob  
A3: C ≠ Coy  

Bob  
B1: P ≠ Bob  
B2: C = Coy  
B3: M ≠ Anu  

Coy  
C1: P ≠ Anu  
C2: M ≠ Coy  
C3: C ≠ Bob  

Exactly one pupil is a truth-teller (all three statements true), exactly one a liar (all three false) and the third alternates (at least one true and one false).

------------------------------------------------
CASE 1 Anu is the truth-teller  
------------------------------------------------
Then A1, A2, A3 are all true, so  
P = Anu, M ≠ Bob, C ≠ Coy.        (1)

Either Bob or Coy is the liar.

• Suppose Bob is the liar.  
 B1 would then be false, giving P = Bob, contradicting P = Anu from (1).  
 Hence Bob cannot be the liar.

• Therefore Coy is the liar and all of C1,C2,C3 are false:  
 C1 false  ⇒  P = Anu (consistent)  
 C2 false  ⇒  M = Coy  
 C3 false  ⇒  C = Bob.                (2)

Now Bob must be the alternator.  Check his three sentences against (1)–(2):

 B1: P ≠ Bob   true  
 B2: C = Coy   false  
 B3: M ≠ Anu   true  

Bob indeed tells a mix of truth and lies, so (1)–(2) satisfy every condition.

Thus the unique distribution is  

Physics → Anu  
Chemistry → Bob  
Maths → Coy  

and the rôle pattern is  

Anu = truth-teller, Coy = liar, Bob = alternator.

------------------------------------------------
CASE 2 Anu is the liar  
------------------------------------------------
All of A1–A3 would be false:  
P ≠ Anu, M = Bob, C = Coy.  
With Bob and Coy left for “truth” and “alternator”, the only remaining owner for Physics would be Anu, contradicting P ≠ Anu.  Impossible.

------------------------------------------------
CASE 3 Anu is the alternator  
------------------------------------------------
Then one of Bob, Coy must be truth-teller, the other liar.

(i) Bob true, Coy false:  
 From Bob true: P ≠ Bob, C = Coy, M ≠ Anu.  
 From Coy false: P = Anu, M = Coy, C = Bob.  
 Contradiction C = Coy vs. C = Bob.

(ii) Bob false, Coy true:  
 Bob false: P = Bob, C ≠ Coy, M = Anu.  
 Coy true:  P ≠ Anu, M ≠ Coy, C ≠ Bob.  
 This forces C = Anu, making Anu owner of two books.  Impossible.

Hence no arrangement is possible when Anu alternates.

------------------------------------------------
Conclusion (uniqueness)
------------------------------------------------
The only viable configuration is that found in Case 1.  Therefore it is certain that

1) Anu always tells the truth.  
2) Coy always lies.  
3) Bob owns the Chemistry book.

All three statements must be concluded.

Final answer: 1, 2 and 3.

Question:
Grobi is a very unique creature.
Grobi:
1...is round in shape.
2...is six inches in diameter.
3...lives on an acre-sized flat field.
4...moves only by jumping; cannot walk, crawl, fly, or move in any manner other than jumping.
5...can jump, in any one jump, a minimum of 6 inches or a maximum of 72 inches (6 feet) across the field (cannot jump straight up-down).  Grobi can therefore, in any one jump, jump any distance across the field at or between the 6-72 inch limits.
6...can jump directly north, south, east, or west only; cannot jump diagonally.
7...must jump four times in any one direction (N-S-E-W) before changing direction (N-S-E-W) or to continue in the same direction (N-S-E-W).
8...dines on mushrooms which grow in the field.  The mushrooms grow to a maximum of six inches in diameter and to a height of an inch.
9...can ingest a mushroom only by landing directly atop the mushroom.
10...is very adept at precisely determining distances.
One day Grobi - happily jumping around in the middle of the field - locates a six-inch diameter mushroom six inches away (center of Grobi to center of mushroom distance) directly west of Grobi.
Grobi quickly (and accurately) calculates that FOUR jumps is the fastest way to get to the mushroom and eat, which Grobi does.
Describe the route taken by Grobi to eat the mushroom including the direction of jumps, each approximate jump-distance, and the specific number of jumps in each direction.
Hint: No need to "invent" anything new for Grobi such as extraordinary motivating or grasping or ingestion appendages.  The problem can be solved using the information given.  Key words in the puzzle are "happily jumping around".
Human Solution:
Grobi had already taken ONE jump to the east (in a new four-jump 'direction' series) when the mushroom was located to the west.  Grobi therefore had to take THREE more jumps to the east before being able to change direction and head back west.  Grobi took three minimum jumps (six inches or so each) to the east and then a long (24 inches or so) FOURTH jump to the west to land atop the mushroom.
No other conditions would solve the puzzle as written:
1.  If Grobi had been jumping west (as part of a four-jump 'direction' series), or had just concluded a four-jump 'direction' series, then the mushroom could have been attained in one jump.
2.  If Grobi had been jumping north or south (as part of a four-jump 'direction' series) then four additional jumps (even if able to change direction) would have put Grobi out of alignment with the mushroom.
3.  If Grobi had been jumping east (and had done two or three jumps as part of a four-jump 'direction' series) then the mushroom could have been attained in two or three additional jumps and not the four that was Grobi's correct calculation.
Response:
Because he is always “happily jumping around”, Grobi is never at rest; at the instant he notices the mushroom he is already part-way through one of his compulsory blocks of four jumps in the same cardinal direction (rule 7).

(1) What direction was that block?  
If the mushroom lies six inches directly west, it is natural that the direction he happened to be using is WEST.  We shall call the jump that has just been completed Jump 0.  Jump 0 was the first jump of a four-jump WEST block.

After Jump 0 Grobi is exactly 6 inches east of the mushroom’s centre.  
He must still make three more WEST jumps to finish the block before he is permitted to point in any other direction.

(2) The three remaining WEST jumps (Jumps 1–3).  
Grobi chooses the minimum legal distance, 6 inches, for each of these jumps; this lets him finish the block while getting no farther from the target than necessary.

 Jump 1 WEST 6 inches  
 Jump 2 WEST 6 inches  
 Jump 3 WEST 6 inches  

After these three jumps he has gone a further 18 inches west, so he now stands 12 inches west of the mushroom.

(3) The fourth and final jump (Jump 4).  
Having completed four consecutive WEST jumps (Jump 0 plus Jumps 1–3), Grobi is now free to select a new direction.  
He turns around and makes one jump due EAST of exactly 12 inches:

 Jump 4 EAST 12 inches  

Landing point of Jump 4 = previous position 12 inches west of the mushroom + 12 inches east = exactly on the mushroom’s centre.  Because Grobi’s centre now coincides with the mushroom’s centre (rule 9), he eats it immediately.

(4) Why four jumps is the minimum possible.  
• He could not change direction until he had completed the first block of four WEST jumps; from the moment he noticed the mushroom that requirement forced at least three further jumps.  
• Landing on the mushroom on any of those three compulsory WEST jumps would still leave him obliged to take at least one more WEST jump, moving him off the mushroom again.  
• Therefore he must first finish the block (three jumps) and then make one more jump in the opposite direction; that totals four jumps, and no shorter sequence can satisfy all the rules.

Route summary  

 Direction Number of jumps Distances (inches)  
 WEST   3     6, 6, 6  
 EAST   1     12  

Total jumps after sighting the mushroom: 4.  Grobi ends exactly on the mushroom and dines.

Question:
A king heard that the nearby kingdoms were being destroyed by a fierce dragon. He called forth his most trusted and skilled knights to meet and plan how to protect the kingdom.  The 6 knights, Sir William, Sir Andrew, Sir Luke, Sir Calvin, Sir Charles and Sir Vincent, decided that two knights would venture out to find and slay the dragon while the other 4 would defend the kingdom.
From the statements below, which two knights went to seek the dragon?
1. If neither Sir William or Sir Vincent rode out, then Sir Calvin did.
2. If either Sir Calvin or Sir Vincent went to kill the dragon, then Sir Andrew did not.
3.  If neither Sir Andrew or Sir William were of the brave two that left the kingdom, then Sir Charles was.
4.  If neither Sir Luke or Sir Andrew went out, then Sir Vincent did.
5. If Sir William was one of the two, then either Sir Calvin or Sir Charles was with him.
6. If Sir Vincent was not of the two who went to slay the dragon, then neither was Sir Andrew nor Sir Charles.
Hint: If statement 1 is valid, Calvin was one of the two that left. If not, either William or Vincent was one of the two. Therefore the PAIR could not be Andrew and Luke, Sir Andrew and Charles or Luke and Charles.
Human Solution:
Sir Vincent and Sir Charles went out of the kingdom to slay the dragon.
If statement 1 is valid, Calvin was one of the two that left. If not, either William or Vincent was one of the two. Therefore the PAIR could not be Andrew and Luke, Sir Andrew and Charles or Luke and Charles.
From 3, the PAIR that left was not Luke and Calvin, Luke and Vincent or Calvin and Vincent. From 4, the two could not have been William and Calvin, William and Charles or Calvin and Charles.
From 5, William did not venture out and therefore from 4 the pair was not William and Calvin or William and Charles.
From 6, Vincent must have been one of the two since the statement identifies three of the four knights not eliminated. From 2, Vincent was one of the two, and by elimination, the other is Charles.
Response:
Let  

W = “Sir William went”,  
A = “Sir Andrew went”,  
L = “Sir Luke went”,  
C = “Sir Calvin went”,  
Ch = “Sir Charles went”,  
V = “Sir Vincent went”.  

Exactly two of these six propositions are true.  
Translate the six clues:

1. (¬W ∧ ¬V) ⇒ C  
2. (C ∨ V)  ⇒ ¬A  
3. (¬A ∧ ¬W) ⇒ Ch  
4. (¬L ∧ ¬A) ⇒ V  
5. W ⇒ (C ∨ Ch) (the second knight with W is C or Ch)  
6. ¬V ⇒ (¬A ∧ ¬Ch)

Step 1.  Show that V must go.  
Assume, for contradiction, that ¬V is true.

 (a)  From (6) we obtain ¬A and ¬Ch.  
 (b)  Because A is absent, the pair consists of two among {W, L, C}.  
 (c)  If W were also absent, then ¬A ∧ ¬W would be true and (3) would force Ch to go, contradicting ¬Ch.  
 (d)  Hence W must be present.  By (5) W’s companion must be C (Ch is forbidden), so the tentative pair is {W, C}.  
 (e)  In this pair L is absent and A is absent, so ¬L ∧ ¬A is true; by (4) that would make V go, contradicting our original assumption ¬V.

Therefore the assumption ¬V is impossible; V must be one of the two knights.

Step 2.  Consequences of V’s presence.  
With V true,

 • (2) gives ¬A.  
 • (6) is irrelevant.  

Step 3.  Show that W cannot go.  
Suppose W is also in the pair.  Then, by (5), the second knight with W must be C or Ch.  But V is already one of the two, so a third knight would be required—impossible.  Hence W is absent.

Step 4.  Determine the required companion of V.  
Now we have ¬W and ¬A.  Thus the antecedent of (3) is true and forces Ch to go.  So Ch is the second knight.  

Step 5.  Verify that the pair {V, Ch} satisfies every statement.

1.  ¬W ∧ ¬V is false (V goes) – statement satisfied.  
2.  V goes ⇒ ¬A – A indeed stays.  
3.  ¬A ∧ ¬W is true ⇒ Ch must go – Ch goes.  
4.  ¬L ∧ ¬A is true ⇒ V must go – V goes.  
5.  W is absent – statement vacuously true.  
6.  V goes – antecedent false, statement satisfied.

All conditions are met, and every other possibility has been eliminated.

Final answer: Sir Vincent and Sir Charles are the two knights who went to slay the dragon.

Question:
My entire family lives on Braingle Street, and for some strange reason I got to choose where everyone lives.
My mother Vera lives at 2005 Braingle St.
My cousin Lucy lives at 1150 Braingle St.
Where do I live?
Hint: If Lucy changed her name to Irene, she'd have to move to 1101 Braingle St.
Human Solution:
The addresses are based on the first letters of the residents' relations to me, converted to Roman Numerals.
My Mother Vera = MMV = 2005
My Cousin Lucy = MCL = 1150
This leaves "Me" living at 1000 Braingle Street.
I could also accept 1 Braingle St. (referring to myself as "I") as a valid answer.
Response:
Write each house number with Roman-numeral symbols and compare the last letter of that numeral with the first letter of the occupant’s name.

2005 → MMV – the numeral ends with V, the first letter of Vera.  
1150 → MCL – the numeral ends with L, the first letter of Lucy.  
1101 → MCI – the numeral ends with I, the first letter of Irene (the name Lucy would adopt).

So I put every relative in a house whose Roman-numeral address ends with the first letter of the person’s name.

My own name begins with the only Roman-numeral letter that has not yet appeared, X (my name is Xavier).  
The least positive integer whose Roman-numeral form ends in X is 10 (X).

Therefore I live at 10 Braingle Street.

Final answer: 10 Braingle St.

Question:
Mad Ade's cousin Steve lies a lot. He tells the truth on only one day in a week.
One day he said: "I lie on Mondays and Tuesdays."
The next day he said: "Today is either Sunday, Saturday, or Thursday."
The next day he said: "I lie on Fridays and Wednesdays."
On which day of the week does Steve tell the truth?
Hint: The first and third statements are incompatible
Human Solution:
Mad Ade's cousin  Steve tells the truth on Tuesdays
The first and third statements are incompatible; they cannot of course both be true, and they can only be lies if on one of the days mentioned Steve tells the truth. But, they have no such day in common. Therefore one of them must be true, and the other must refer to that day. Looking at the second statement (which must be a lie, as there can at most be one true statement and we have one), the first day cannot be Wednesday, Friday or Saturday. Therefore, the first statement cannot be true, since the third cannot refer to it by day. Therefore, the third statement is true, and must (from the first statement) be a Monday or Tuesday. Statement two, however, rules out Monday, leaving only Tuesday as the 'day of truth'. Thus: 'one day' is a Sunday; on the third day (Tuesday) Steve is truthful.
Response:
Let  

S₁ : “I lie on Mondays and Tuesdays.” (said on day D₁)  
S₂ : “Today is either Sunday, Saturday, or Thursday.” (said on day D₂=D₁+1)  
S₃ : “I lie on Fridays and Wednesdays.” (said on day D₃=D₁+2)  

Steve tells the truth on exactly one day of every week; he lies on the other six.

1.  Only one of S₁, S₂, S₃ can be true.  
    (The hint also tells us S₁ and S₃ cannot both be true.)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
I.  Suppose S₁ is the true statement (truth day = D₁).

    “I lie on Mondays and Tuesdays” being true means the truth day is
    not Monday or Tuesday.

    Because S₁ is the only true statement, S₃ must be false.
    S₃ is false ⇔ at least one of Friday, Wednesday is a truth day.
    Hence the truth day D₁ would have to be Friday or Wednesday.

    • If D₁ = Wednesday, then D₂ = Thursday.  
      On Thursday Steve lies, yet S₂ (“Today is … Thursday”) would
      be true – contradiction.

    • If D₁ = Friday, then D₂ = Saturday.  
      On Saturday Steve lies, yet S₂ (“Today is … Saturday”) would
      be true – contradiction.

    Therefore S₁ cannot be the true statement.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
II. Suppose S₂ is the true statement (truth day = D₂).

    Then D₂ ∈ {Sunday, Saturday, Thursday}.

    Since S₁ is false, “I lie on Mondays and Tuesdays” is false, so
    at least one of Monday, Tuesday is a truth day.  
    Thus the truth day must be Monday or Tuesday, contradicting
    D₂ ∈ {Sunday, Saturday, Thursday}.  Impossible.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
III. Therefore S₃ must be the true statement (truth day = D₃).

    S₃ true  ⇒  Steve really does lie on Friday and Wednesday, so
    the truth day is neither Friday nor Wednesday.

    S₁ is false ⇒ at least one of Monday, Tuesday is the truth day,
    hence D₃ is Monday or Tuesday.

    S₂ is false, and it is spoken on D₂ = D₃ − 1.
    For S₂ (“Today is Sunday, Saturday, or Thursday”) to be false
    the day D₂ must be Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, or Friday.

    Combining:  
       D₃ ∈ {Monday, Tuesday} and D₂ ∈ {Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Friday}
       with D₂ = D₃ − 1.

    The only consistent chain of three consecutive days is

            D₁ = Sunday,   D₂ = Monday,   D₃ = Tuesday.

    Check:

    • Sunday (lie): “I lie on Mondays and Tuesdays.”  
      Tuesday is the upcoming truth day, so statement is false.

    • Monday (lie): “Today is either Sunday, Saturday, or Thursday.”  
      Day is Monday → statement false.

    • Tuesday (truth): “I lie on Fridays and Wednesdays.”  
      He does lie on those days → statement true.

    All conditions are satisfied with exactly one truth day.

Hence Steve’s single day of truth-telling is Tuesday.

Final answer: Tuesday

Question:
Mad Ade's Great Uncle Gaseous O' Windpants owned the Madadian Grocery store "The Beggars Can't Be Choosers". Madadia was well renowned for its pungent cheeses, especially its "Kebabrie" and "Chillirella".
On display in the store were six cheese pieces weighing 15, 16, 18, 19 , 20 and 31 Pounds. Five out of the six pieces are "Kebabrie" and the remaining one is "Chillirella".
Norma Leigh-Sobar purchased two pieces of "Kebabrie" and Laura Anne-Hardy also purchased some "Kebabrie" , but she purchased twice as much in weight than Norma .
How much does the remaining "Chillirella" weigh?
Hint: Norma Leigh-Sobar must have purchased at least 31 pounds and so Laura Anne-Hardy must have bought three wedges since the two heaviest wedges together only total 51 pounds.
Human Solution:
Norma Leigh-Sobar must have purchased at least 31 pounds and so Laura Anne-Hardy must have bought three wedges since the two heaviest wedges together only total 51 pounds.
Since Laura bought twice what Norma bought, the total amount of cheese bought by the two together equals 3 times that purchased by Norma alone. Now, the total weight of all the wedges at the grocery divided by 3 leaves a remainder of 2, so the "Chillirella" wedge must leave a remainder of 2 when divided by 3. But the only such wedge is the 20 pound wedge, thus the "Chillirella" wedge must have weighed 20 pounds.
Thus Norma purchased the 15 and 18 pound pieces which equals 33 pounds and Laura purchased the 16, 19 and 31 pound pieces which equals 66 pounds.
Response:
Let the two wedges that Norma buys weigh x lb and y lb.

Norma’s total: N = x + y

Laura buys only Kebabrie and her purchase weighs twice as much:

Laura’s total: L = 2N

Altogether the five Kebabrie wedges (Norma’s two plus Laura’s three) weigh

N + L = N + 2N = 3N  (1)

The six displayed wedges weigh  
15 + 16 + 18 + 19 + 20 + 31 = 119 lb.

If the single Chillirella wedge weighs w lb, the total weight of the Kebabrie wedges is 119 – w.  
From (1):

3N = 119 – w  ⇒ 119 – w is a multiple of 3. (2)

Because 119 ≡ 2 (mod 3), condition (2) requires

w ≡ 2  (mod 3).

Among the six given weights only 20 lb satisfies this congruence, so

Chillirella must weigh 20 lb.

Now the five remaining weights {15, 16, 18, 19, 31} are Kebabrie.

From (1) with w = 20 we have  
3N = 119 – 20 = 99 ⇒ N = 33 lb.

Norma needs two of the five Kebabrie wedges whose weights sum to 33 lb.  
The only possible pair is 15 lb + 18 lb.

Hence Norma buys the 15-lb and 18-lb wedges (33 lb), and Laura buys the remaining three Kebabrie wedges 16 lb + 19 lb + 31 lb (66 lb = 2 × 33 lb).

All conditions are satisfied and the solution is unique.

Final answer: 20 pounds

Question:
Twelve men are in a room, some of them always tell lies, while the others always tell the truth.
The first man says: "None of us is a truthteller."
The second man says: "At most one of us is a truthteller."
The third man says: "At most two of us are truthtellers."
...
The twelfth and last man says: "At most eleven of us are truthtellers."
Who are the liars?
Hint: It's OK to use trial and error, however, there might exist better methods.
Human Solution:
If there are exactly N liars, then the last N men are truthtellers, leaving the first (12-N) men to be liars.
Therefore, N=12-N, N=6. The first 6 men are liars, and the last 6 men are truthtellers.
Response:
Let T be the actual number of truthtellers among the 12 men.  
Man k (k = 1,…,12) states

 Sₖ : “At most k − 1 of us are truthtellers,”  
i.e. Sₖ ⇔ T ≤ k − 1.

Truth value of Sₖ for a given T  
• Sₖ is true exactly when T ≤ k − 1 (equivalently k ≥ T + 1).  
• Sₖ is false when k ≤ T.

Therefore, for any fixed T

 indices k ≤ T → liars,  
 indices k ≥ T + 1 → truth-tellers.

Hence the number of true statements equals the number of indices k satisfying k ≥ T + 1, namely 12 − T.  
But the number of true statements must equal T (the number of truthtellers). So

 T = 12 − T ⇒ 2T = 12 ⇒ T = 6.

With T = 6 the truth pattern is:

k=1,…,6 → liars (statements false because 6 > k − 1),  
k=7,…,12 → truth-tellers (statements true because 6 ≤ k − 1).

This satisfies every requirement: exactly six true statements and six false ones.

Final answer: The first six men (1 through 6) are liars; the remaining six men (7 through 12) are truthtellers.

Question: A man has 3 cards face down on a table.  One is a jack and two are aces.  He knows the order but you do not.  You can ask him one yes or no question, but when you do, you have to point to one of the cards.  If you point to an ace, he will tell the truth, if you point to the jack, he will randomly say yes or no.  You have to find one of the aces.
Hint: Yes, there is always a chance you will be pointing to the jack, and that the answer will be meaningless (just a random yes/no) but there is a way to work around it.  Don't give up!
Human Solution: Point to the middle card and say,  "Is the card to the right an ace?"  If the answer is yes, then the card on the right is an ace. If the answer is no, the card on the left is an ace.  This solution works because if you're pointing to an ace then he's obviously telling the truth and if you're pointing to the jack the answer doesn't matter anyway because you will pick one of the other two which are both aces.
Response:
Label the three face-down cards  
(from your left to your right) 1, 2, 3.

Step 1.  Point to card 1.  
Step 2.  Ask the single yes/no question  

  “Is card 2 an ace?”

Step 3.  Act on the reply.  
 • If the answer is Yes – take card 2.  
 • If the answer is No  – take card 3.

Why the procedure always gives an ace

There are two possible kinds of card 1, the one you pointed at:

1. Card 1 is the jack.  
   Then both of the other cards (2 and 3) are aces.  
   The jack answers randomly, but whatever it says you will
   choose either card 2 or card 3—and both are aces.  

2. Card 1 is an ace.  
   Then exactly one of cards 2 and 3 is the other ace.  
   Because you are pointing at an ace, the answer you receive is
   truthful.  
   • If you are told “Yes”, card 2 really is an ace, so you take it.  
   • If you are told “No”, card 2 is not an ace, which forces card 3
     to be the ace, and you take card 3.

In every possible configuration of the three cards the procedure
leads you to turn over an ace with certainty.

Final answer: Point at one card and ask “Is this other specified card an ace?”; if the reply is Yes, take that specified card, otherwise take the remaining card—you will always obtain an ace.

Question:
At a family get-together, four married couples played bridge at two different tables (4 people at each table). From the statements below determine which players were at which table and who their partner was.
1. Mrs. Johnson was partnered with her son-in-law.
2. Mr. Jones' partner was his wife's brother-in-law.
3. Mrs. Jones played against her sister.
4. Mr. Johnson played against his father-in-law.
5. Mrs. Smith's partner was her daughter.
6. Mrs. Williams partner was her grandfather.
7. Mr. Johnson's partner was a man.
Hint: From statements 3, 5 and 6 the four couples consist of 3 generations since there is a set of sisters involved and there are grandparents present.
Human Solution:
From statements 3, 5 and 6 the four couples consist of 3 generations since there is a set of sisters involved and there are grandparents present.
From 2 and 3, the Jones are definitely one of the sisters, and from 6, the Williams are definitely on the 3rd generation. Looking at 1 and 4, the Johnson's are on the 2nd generation and since the Smiths have a daughter, they are on the 1st or 2nd generation. But since the Jones must be one of the sisters, the Smiths cannot fall in the 2nd generation with the Johnson's. Therefore the Smiths are the grandparents.
From 6, Mrs. Williams' partner is Mr. Smith.  From 1 and 6, Mrs. Johnston and Mrs. Williams both have male partners, therefore from 5, Mrs. Smith's partner could have only been Mrs. Jones. Which also means that Jones and Johnson are the pair of sisters.
Thus from 2, Mr. Jones is then partnered with Mr. Johnson, and from 3, Mrs Jones (who is partnered with Mrs. Smith) is playing against Mrs. Johnson (whose partner is Mr. Williams from 1).
In summation, Mr. Jones and Mr. Johnson play against Mrs. Williams and Mr Smith, while Mrs Jones and Mrs. Smith play against Mrs. Johnson and Mr. Williams.
Response:
Family relationships that satisfy every clue  

Grandparents: Mr. Smith – Mrs. Smith  
Their daughters (sisters): Mrs. Johnson and Mrs. Jones  
  Mrs. Johnson is married to Mr. Johnson  
  Mrs. Jones is married to Mr. Jones  
Grand-daughter: Mrs. Williams (daughter of the Johnsons)  
  Mrs. Williams is married to Mr. Williams  

Bridge seating and partnerships  

Table 1  
• Partnership 1: Mrs. Smith & Mrs. Jones  
• Partnership 2: Mrs. Johnson & Mr. Williams  

Table 2  
• Partnership 3: Mrs. Williams & Mr. Smith  
• Partnership 4: Mr. Johnson & Mr. Jones  

Verification of every statement  

1. Mrs. Johnson’s partner was her son-in-law → Mr. Williams ✔  
2. Mr. Jones’s partner (Mr. Johnson) is his wife’s brother-in-law ✔  
3. Mrs. Jones played against her sister Mrs. Johnson (same table, opposite sides) ✔  
4. Mr. Johnson played against his father-in-law Mr. Smith ✔  
5. Mrs. Smith’s partner was her daughter Mrs. Jones ✔  
6. Mrs. Williams’s partner was her grandfather Mr. Smith ✔  
7. Mr. Johnson’s partner was a man (Mr. Jones) ✔  

All clues are simultaneously satisfied, giving a unique arrangement.

Final answer:  
Table 1 – Mrs. Smith & Mrs. Jones versus Mrs. Johnson & Mr. Williams;  
Table 2 – Mrs. Williams & Mr. Smith versus Mr. Johnson & Mr. Jones.

Question:
The following task involves several steps, but they are out of order.  Arrange them so that a person who follows the steps exactly can perform the task:
You have three heavy beams marked A, B, and C, and want to find out which one is the heaviest.  You also have a scale that tells you which of any two beams is heavier, but it does not give the specific weight of any beam.  In what order must you perform the following steps to determine which beam is the heaviest, and to mark it accordingly?  Assume that all three have different weights.
a)  Weigh A against B.
b)  Weigh B against C.
c)  Weigh A against C.
d)  If A is heavier, skip the next three statements.
e)  If A is heavier, skip the next four statements.
f)  If B is heavier, skip the next five statements.
g)  Mark A "heaviest."
h)  Mark B "heaviest."
i)  Mark C "heaviest."
j)  Skip the next statement.
k)  Skip the next two statements.
l)  Skip the next three statements.
m)  End.
Hint: The first two steps are "a" and "d", in that order.
Human Solution:
a)  Weigh A against B.
d)  If A is heavier, skip the next three statements.
b)  Weigh B against C.
f)  If B is heavier, skip the next five statements.
k)  Skip the next two statements.
c)  Weigh A against C.
e)  If A is heavier, skip the next four statements.
i)  Mark C "heaviest."
l)  Skip the next three statements.
h)  Mark B "heaviest."
j)  Skip the next statement.
g)  Mark A "heaviest."
m)  End.
Response:
Just one sequence satisfies every “if … skip …” instruction while guaranteeing that exactly one beam is marked “heaviest’’ and that the procedure always terminates:

1) a) Weigh A against B.  
2) d) If A is heavier, skip the next three statements.  
3) b) Weigh B against C.  
4) f) If B is heavier, skip the next five statements.  
5) k) Skip the next two statements.  
6) c) Weigh A against C.  
7) e) If A is heavier, skip the next four statements.  
8) i) Mark C “heaviest.”  
9) l) Skip the next three statements.  
10) h) Mark B “heaviest.”  
11) j) Skip the next statement.  
12) g) Mark A “heaviest.”  
13) m) End.

Verification of every possible outcome

• If A > B (step 2 true)  
 Skip 3–5 → step 6 compares A with C.  
  – If A > C (step 7 true): skip 8–11 → step 12 marks A, then End.  
  – If C > A (step 7 false): step 8 marks C, step 9 skips 10–12 → End.

• If B > A (step 2 false)  
 Step 3 weighs B vs C.  
  – If B > C (step 4 true): skip 5–9 → step 10 marks B; step 11 skips 12; End.  
  – If C > B (step 4 false): step 5 skips 6–7; step 8 marks C; step 9 skips 10–12; End.

Thus exactly one of g, h, i is executed in every case, and the algorithm always finishes.

Final answer: a → d → b → f → k → c → e → i → l → h → j → g → m.

Question:
LTVX
AFHKNZ
_ _ _
What three letters fill in the blanks?
Hint:
- The title has a partial clue.
- Look down.
- They are grouped horizontally.
Human Solution:
E M W
The first row requires two straight lines to make. (LTVX)
The Second row requires three straight lines to make.  (AFHKNZ)
Following the pattern, the next row should have four straight lines to make, and the only letters that do that are EMW.
(Also everything has been so far in alphabetical order so it has to be "EMW", not EWM, MEW, MWE, WME, or WEM.)
Response: Final answer: E M W

Question:
List the order in which each person finished.
Tommy Tombstone finished after Lance Lamers and Brett Brown but before Mitch Monday.
Peter Poultry finished before Daniel Dusk and Lance Lamers.
Sam Sunny finished after Peter Poultry and before Jack Jill and Harry Hills.
Keri Kernel finished after Peter Poultry, Mitch Monday and Tommy Tombstone.
Lance Lamers finished after Brett Brown and Daniel Dusk, but before Jack Jill and Mitch Monday.
Mitch Monday finished after Sam Sunny and Brett Brown.
Brett Brown finished before Jack Jill, Mitch Monday and Peter Poultry.
Daniel Dusk finished before Keri Kernel and Tommy Tombstone, but after Sam Sunny.
Jack Jill finished before Keri Kernel, Tommy Tombstone and Mitch Monday, but after Peter Poultry and Daniel Dusk.
Harry Hills finished before Mitch Monday but after Lance Lamers, Jack Jill and Tommy Tombstone.
Hint: Figure out who could possibly be first? Work from there
Human Solution:
1.Brett Brown
2.Peter Poultry
3.Sam Sunny
4.Daniel Dusk
5.Lance Lamers
6.Jack Jill
7.Tommy Tombstone
8.Harry Hills
9.Mitch Monday
10.Keri Kernel
Response:
Final answer:  
1st Brett Brown, 2nd Peter Poultry, 3rd Sam Sunny, 4th Daniel Dusk, 5th Lance Lamers, 6th Jack Jill, 7th Tommy Tombstone, 8th Harry Hills, 9th Mitch Monday, 10th Keri Kernel

Question: A prisoner sat alone in his cell staring through the bars at the six doors to the guardroom beyond them. Suddenly, there was the sound of footsteps. One guard came in through door A and a second entered through door F. They unlocked the cell door. "We shall set you free," said one of the guards, "but first you must pass through all six doors, each door once only, in the correct order. Three are entrances only and three are exits only. Door A must be followed by door B or E; B by C or E; C by D or F; D by A or F; E by B or D; and F by C or D." With that the guards left through door B. In what order must the prisoner pass through the doors?
Hint: The prisoner must alternate exits and entrances. List the six possible orders then study the conditions to eliminate possibilities.
Human Solution:
The order is CFDABE. The guards entered through doors A and F and exited at door B. The prisoner must alternate exits and entrances. Let the unknown entrance be X. With a "_" denoting an exit door the possible orders are:
(a) _A_F_X ; (b) _F_A_X ; (c) _X_A_F ; (d) _X_F_A ; (e) _A_X_F ; (f) _F_X_A
Neither (a) nor (c) are possible since A is followed by B or E and neither leads to F. Since A can only be preceded by D, (e) and (f) are possible as DA_X_F and _F_XDA, respectively. With D used, door F can only be preceded by C to give DA_XCF and CF_XDA, respectively. Door B must occupy the remaining space in each possibility (third door is exit) so X=E but C cannot follow E in the former and for the latter, B cannot follow F. This eliminates (e) and (f). Since only D precedes A, (b) is possible as _FDA_X and (d) as _X_FDA. For (d), the exit B must occupy a "_" but cannot be followed by F, and if it is the first door, neither the C or E that must follow as X can be followed by the remaining E or C, respectively. This only leaves (b) and only C (of the possible B,C,E) can precede F as CFDA_X and B must occupy the final "_" as an exit leaving E=X. Notice that the condition that E is followed by B or D cannot be satisfied until the prisoner has completed his task and finally wins his freedom through B or D!
Response:
First decide which doors are entrances and which are exits.

1.  From the story  
   •  Door A and door F were used by the guards to come in ⇒ A , F are entrances.  
   •  Door B was used to go out ⇒ B is an exit.

2.  While the prisoner passes through the six doors he must alternate
    exit – entrance – exit – entrance – exit – entrance.
    Hence three doors are exits and three doors are entrances.

3.  Let the third entrance be one of C, D, E.  
    Examine each possibility with the given “follow-on’’ rules

    •  If D were an entrance, it would have to be followed by A or F (both
       entrances), breaking the required alternation.  So D cannot be an entrance.

    •  If E were an exit it would have to be followed by B or D, both exits
       (again breaking alternation).  Therefore E cannot be an exit.

    Consequently
            Entrances :  A , E , F
            Exits     :  B , C , D

4.  Now build the required six-door chain, starting with an exit.

    Try each exit as the first door and use the follow-on rules:

    a) Start with B  
       B → E (only way to reach an entrance)  
       E → D (the only unused exit)  
       D → A or F ( entrances )  
           • D→A gives A→B but B is already used.  
           • D→F gives F→C/D, both already used.  
       Impossible.

    b) Start with D  
       D → A or F  
           • D→A gives A→B →E, but E then has no legal follower.  
           • D→F gives F→C, but C must be followed by F, already used.  
       Impossible.

    c) Start with C  
       C (exit) → F (entrance)  
       F → D (exit)  
       D → A (entrance)  
       A → B (exit)  
       B → E (entrance)  

       Sequence obtained:   C  F  D  A  B  E

       Every pair satisfies the prescribed rule, the doors alternate
       exit/entrance, and each door is used exactly once.

Since starting with B or D is impossible, the sequence found starting with
C is the only one that works.

Final answer: C → F → D → A → B → E

Question:
You've been placed on a course of expensive medication in which you are to take one tablet of Sildenafil and one tablet of Citrate daily. You must be careful that you take just one of each because taking more of either can have serious side effects.
Taking Sildenafil without taking Citrate, or vice versa, can also be very serious, because they must be taken together in order to be effective. In summary, you must take exactly one of the Sildenafil pills and one of the Citrate pills at one time. Therefore, you open up the Sildenafil bottle, and you tap one Sildenafil pill into your hand. You put that bottle aside and you open the Citrate bottle. You do the same, but by mistake, two Citrates fall into your hand with the Sildenafil pill.
Now, here's the problem. You weren't watching your hand as the pills fell into it, so you can't tell the Sildenafil pill apart from the two Citrate pills. The pills look identical. They are both the same size, same weight (10 micrograms), same color (Blue), same shape (perfect square), same everything, and they are not marked differently in any way.
What are you going to do? You cannot tell which pill is which, and they cost $300 a piece, so you cannot afford to throw them away and start over again. How do you get your daily dose of exactly one Sildenafil and exactly one Citrate without wasting any of the pills?
Hint: You can cut pills in half
Human Solution: Carefully cut each of the three pills in half, and carefully separate them into two piles, with half of each pill in each pile. You do not know which pill is which, but you are 100% sure that each of the two piles now contains two halves of Citrate and half of Sildenafil. Now go back into the Sildenafil bottle, take out a pill, cut it in half, and add one half to each stack. Now you have two stacks, each one containing two halves of Sildenafil and two halves of Citrate. Take one stack of pills today, and save the second stack for tomorrow.
Response:
1. Put the three indistinguishable tablets that are now in your hand on the table.  
   (Among them there is 1 Sildenafil and 2 Citrate.)

2. With a pill-cutter divide each of the three tablets exactly in half.  
   You now have six half-tablets.  From every original tablet one half is on the left, one half on the right; each half still contains exactly half of whatever that tablet originally was.

3. Make two piles:  
   • Pile A – take one half from each of the three original tablets.  
   • Pile B – the remaining three halves.

   Because one of the original tablets was Sildenafil and the other two were Citrate, each pile now contains  
        ½ Sildenafil  +  (½ Citrate + ½ Citrate)  = ½ Sildenafil + 1 Citrate.

4. From the Sildenafil bottle (which is correctly labeled) take one fresh Sildenafil tablet and cut it in half.  
   Put one half of this known Sildenafil into Pile A and the other half into Pile B.

   After this step each pile contains  
        (½ Sildenafil from the mix + ½ Sildenafil just added)  = 1 whole Sildenafil  
        plus the 1 whole Citrate already present.

5. Swallow the contents of Pile A today; keep Pile B for tomorrow.

Result:  
• Today you take exactly one Sildenafil and one Citrate.  
• Tomorrow you will again have exactly one Sildenafil and one Citrate ready.  
No tablets are discarded; none are mis-dosed.

Question:
The first chess tournament ended. Bab, Beb, Bib, Bob and Bub became good friends, and returned to their houses.
They told their wives about the tournament. Their wives were also chess players, and they decided to hold another tournament.
This time, each of the 10 players was going to play against each other player once, with an exception that no games were played between the couples. So a total of 40 games would be played.
After some days passed, they decided to have a get-together. Bub asked the other people how many matches until then they had played.
Something fun was that Bub heard 9 different answers.
How many matches until then had Mrs. Bub played?
Hint: If you can't figure it out, draw a diagram.
Human Solution:
Each player could play at most 8 matches, so the answers Bub heard was 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8 in some order.
Assume without loss of generality that it was Bab that had played 8 matches. Then all players except Mrs. Bab must have played against Bab, and it must have been Mrs. Bab who had played no matches.
Then, assume without loss of generality that Beb had played 7 matches, and then all players except Mrs. Bab and Mrs. Beb must have played against Beb, and it must have been Mrs. Beb who had played 1 match.
Repeat this and we know that Mrs. Bub had played 4 matches.
Response:
Label the five couples  

 (Bab , Babʹ), (Beb , Bebʹ), (Bib , Bibʹ), (Bob , Bobʹ), (Bub , Bubʹ)  

and call the ten players “persons”.  
In this tournament each person can play at most eight games – against everybody except his or her own spouse.

Let di be the number of games the i-th person has already played.  
Bub asked the other nine persons for their numbers and got nine different
answers; therefore these answers must be the nine integers

 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8.        (1)

(The number 9 is impossible, the maximum is 8.)

1.  The couple with the answers 0 and 8  
Take the person who answered 8.  
He (or she) has already played every allowed opponent; consequently every
one of those eight opponents has played at least one game.  
Hence no one except the spouse of the “8” can possibly have answered 0.
So the answers 0 and 8 come from the two members of the same couple.

2.  The couple with the answers 1 and 7  
Remove that couple and look at the remaining seven persons.
Among them someone has answered 7.  
This person still lacks exactly one of the eight possible games, namely the
game against his (her) spouse.  
Therefore the spouse must be the unique person who has played only one
game; i.e. the answers 1 and 7 belong to another couple.

3.  Repeating the argument  
After removing the couples (0,8) and (1,7) we are left with the answers
2, 3, 5, 6.  
Again, the person who has 6 games is missing exactly the game against the
spouse, so the spouse must be the one with 2 games; hence 2 and 6 form a
couple.  
Removing them leaves the answers 3 and 5, which must of course belong to
the last remaining couple.

We have now paired every answer in (1) except the middle number 4:

 (0,8), (1,7), (2,6), (3,5), 4.        (2)

The unpaired answer 4 must belong to Mrs Bub, because everyone else is
already coupled in (2).

Therefore Mrs Bub had played exactly 4 games.

Final answer: 4

Question:
Al, Ben, Carl, and Dan live in four adjacent apartments. The apartments are set up like this:
|1|2|3|4|
with apartment 1 being the westernmost apartment and apartment 4 being the easternmost. One of the four is the landlord. Here are some facts:
1. If Carl does not live next to Ben, then Al is the landlord and he lives in apartment 1.
2. If Al lives east of Carl, then Dan is the landlord and he lives in apartment 4.
3. If Ben does not live next to Dan, then Carl is the landlord and he lives in apartment 3.
4. If Dan lives east of Al, then Ben is the landlord and he lives in apartment 2.
Who is the landlord?
Hint: All four facts are in the form of "hypothesis and conclusion" statements. If the hypothesis of such a statement is false, the whole statement is true. If the conclusion is true, the whole statement is true. However, if the hypothesis is true and the conclusion is false, the statement is false. This means that each statement has either a false hypothesis or a true conclusion.
Human Solution:
Carl is the landlord.
Obviously only one conclusion is true at most. Let us suppose that all conclusions are false. This would mean that each hypothesis is also false. From facts 1 and 3, Ben lives next to both Carl and Dan, and therefore between Carl and Dan. Then either Al lives east of both Carl and Dan (contradicting fact 4) or Carl and Dan both live east of Al (contradicting fact 2.) So there must be exactly one true hypothesis, which will be paired with the one true conclusion. Obviously each of the three false conclusions is paired with a false hypothesis.
If conclusion 1 is true, then Al lives in apartment 1. But since hypothesis 4 is false, Al has to live east of Dan. So this cannot be right.
If conclusion 2 is true, then Dan lives in apartment 4. But since hypothesis 4 is false, Al must live east of Dan. So this cannot be right, either.
If conclusion 4 is true, Ben lives in apartment 2. Then, since hypotheses 1 and 3 are false, Ben lives between Carl and Dan, putting Al in apartment 4. But since hypothesis 2 is false, Carl must live east of Al. Therefore, conclusion 3 is true.
Response:
Let  

A, B, C, D = Al, Ben, Carl, Dan,  
1, 2, 3, 4 = apartment numbers from west to east,  
L = the landlord.  

Rewrite every given fact H → Q as

Either (¬H) or (Q is true).                    (★)

Fact 1. C not next to B  →  (L=A and A=1)  
 Hence: either C is next to B, or Al is the landlord in 1.

Fact 2. A east of C  →  (L=D and D=4)  
 Hence: either A is not east of C, or Dan is the landlord in 4.

Fact 3. B not next to D  →  (L=C and C=3)  
 Hence: either B is next to D, or Carl is the landlord in 3.

Fact 4. D east of A  →  (L=B and B=2)  
 Hence: either D is not east of A, or Ben is the landlord in 2.

Step 1.  Al cannot be the landlord.  
• If Al were landlord in 1, Fact 4 would require D not east of A, impossible because every other apartment is east of 1.  
• If Al were landlord not in 1, Fact 1 would force C next to B; Facts 3 and 4 would then force B next to D and D west of A, giving the order D-B-C with A between D and C – impossible.  
So L ≠ A and Fact 1 tells us C is next to B.

Step 2.  Dan cannot be the landlord.  
a) If L=D in 4, Fact 3 forces B=3 and C=2, but then D is east of A (who must be 1) and Fact 4 is violated.  
b) If L=D not in 4, Facts 2, 3, 4 force the chain D-B-C with A east of D and west of C, which cannot be fitted into four distinct apartments.  
Thus L ≠ D.

Step 3.  Test Carl as landlord.  
Take the branch of Fact 3 that makes its conclusion true: L=C and C=3.  
Since L≠A, Fact 1 already gives C next to B, so B must be 2 or 4.

• If B=2, apartments 1 and 4 remain for A and D.  
 Fact 2 (whose hypothesis must be false) needs A west of C; hence A=1, leaving D=4.  
 But then D is east of A, making Fact 4’s hypothesis true while its conclusion (L=B) is false – contradiction.

• If B=4, then C=3, B=4.  
 To make Fact 2’s hypothesis false A must be west of C, so A=1 or 2.  
 Fact 4’s hypothesis must be false, so D must be west of A.  
 Choosing A=2 gives D=1, satisfying all four facts:

 1 : D  2 : A  3 : C (landlord)  4 : B.

Every statement checks:

1. C is next to B – hypothesis false, statement true.  
2. A (2) is not east of C (3) – hypothesis false, statement true.  
3. B not next to D – true; conclusion (C landlord in 3) true.  
4. D (1) east of A (2) – false; statement true.

All conditions are satisfied; the arrangement is unique.

Therefore the landlord is Carl, and he lives in apartment 3.

Final answer: Carl

Question:
In the following code, each symbol stands for one of five letters.
@ stands for M, O, F, L, or V
$ stands for B, N, R, E, or J
% stands for T, F, B, L, or A
! stands for W, T, S, E, or I
# stands for F, O, A, T, or L
The five letter code word, %$#@!, can be translated into two English words that are opposites. What are the two words?
Hint: Prepositions
Human Solution: Above and Below
Response:
We must choose, for each symbol in %$#@!, a letter from the set assigned to that symbol:

%  →  T, F, B, L, A  
$  →  B, N, R, E, J  
#  →  F, O, A, T, L  
@  →  M, O, F, L, V  
!  →  W, T, S, E, I  

The hint says the resulting English words are prepositions and are opposites.

A natural pair of opposite five-letter prepositions is ABOVE and BELOW.  
Check that each fits the allowed choices, position by position:

ABOVE  
% = A  (allowed)  
$ = B  (allowed)  
# = O  (allowed)  
@ = V  (allowed)  
! = E  (allowed)

BELOW  
% = B  (allowed)  
$ = E  (allowed)  
# = L  (allowed)  
@ = O  (allowed)  
! = W  (allowed)

Each word respects the symbol–letter constraints, and ABOVE and BELOW are exact opposites.

Final answer: ABOVE and BELOW

Question: Two friends, Joe and Smoe, were born in May, one in 1932, the other a year later. Each had an antique grandfather clock of which he was extremely proud. Both of the clocks worked fairly well considering their age, but one clock gained ten seconds per hour while the other one lost ten seconds per hour. On a day in January, the two friends set both clocks correctly at 12:00 noon. "Do you realize," asked Joe, "that the next time both of our clocks will show exactly the same time will be on your 47th birthday?" Smoe agreed. Who is older, Joe or Smoe?
Hint: To find the answer, we have to find how long it will be before the clocks show the same time again
Human Solution: To find the answer, we have to find how long it will be before the clocks show the same time again. This is when the slow clock loses six hours, and the fast one gains six hours. This will take 90 days. In 90 days they will come together at 6:00. On a calendar, there are 90 days between noon January 31, and noon May 1 in years with no leap year. If Smoe had been born in 1933, his 47th birthday would have been in 1980, a leap year. This means that Smoe must be older, born in 1932, and the time of this problem is 1979.
Response:
First, decide when the two faulty clocks will next read exactly the same.

• One clock gains 10 s every true hour ⇒ its dial advances 3610 s per 3600 s of real time.  
• The other loses 10 s every true hour ⇒ its dial advances 3590 s per 3600 s of real time.  

Hence the two dials separate (or “run past” one another) at a rate of  
3610 s – 3590 s = 20 s of dial-time per real hour.

Because a 12-hour dial looks the same after it is 12 h ( = 43 200 s) ahead, the dials will coincide again after

43 200 s ÷ 20 s per hour = 2160 h = 2160 h ÷ 24 h per day = 90 days.

So, 90 calendar days after the January setting the faces will next match.

------------------------------------------------------------
Relating the 90 days to a birthday
------------------------------------------------------------
Joe said this coincidence will occur “on your 47th birthday,” i.e. on Smoe’s 47th birthday.  
Therefore the interval from the January setting date to Smoe’s 47th birthday must be exactly 90 days.

Let the January setting be on the k-th day of the year (1 ≤ k ≤ 31) and let Smoe’s birthday be on day k + 90.

Non-leap year day-numbers:

  Jan 31  → day 31  
  Feb 28  → day 59  
  Mar 31  → day 90  
  Apr 30  → day 120  
  May  1  → day 121  

Since k + 90 must fall in May, the only possibility with k between 1 and 31 is

  k + 90 = 121  ⇒  k = 31.

Thus

  setting date: 31 January,  
  birthday:     1 May,  

and the year must be a non-leap year (otherwise 1 May would be day 122, not 121, and 31 January + 90 days would land on 30 April).

------------------------------------------------------------
Whose 47th birthday can be 1 May of a non-leap year?
------------------------------------------------------------
The two friends were born in May, one in 1932 and one in 1933.

• A person born 1 May 1932 turns 47 on 1 May 1979.  1979 is NOT a leap year – acceptable.  
• A person born 1 May 1933 turns 47 on 1 May 1980.  1980 IS a leap year – impossible (we just ruled leap years out).

Therefore the friend whose 47th birthday is involved must be the one born in 1932.  That friend is Smoe.

Consequently, Smoe is the older of the two and Joe is the younger.

Final answer: Smoe is older than Joe.

Question:
Ole Santa's pack held thirty toys
Made by his elfin crew;
And though none made the same amount,
Each elf made more than two.
The elf named Cher made one more Christmas toy
Than the elf who dressed in reds,
But Cher made one less Christmas toy
Than the elf who made the sleds.
Spry Johnny Elf made racing cars;
Five toys were made by Jane.
The elf who dressed in yellow suits
Made each and every train.
The elf who always dressed in green
Made one-third as many as Sue;
Cute Marcia elf was dressed in orange,
And one elf dressed in blue.
The elf who made the spinning tops
Made the most toys of them all.
Another perky smiling elf
Made each and every ball.
Ole Santa's pack held thirty gifts
All tagged for girls and boys.
From the clues that you've been given,
Now guess who made the toys!
Hint: This puzzle involves five elves dressed in five different colors each making a different toy. Figure out the numbers that fit these conditions and can add up to thirty!
Human Solution:
Cute Marcia was in orange and made seven sleds.
Sue was in blue and made nine spinning tops.
Jane was in red and made five balls.
Spry Johnny was in green and made three racing cars.
Cher was in yellow and made six trains.
Response:
The only way to make all of the clues fit is the following arrangement.

Name    Colour  Toy   Number made  
Johnny   Green  Racing cars 3  
Jane    Red   Balls   5  
Cher    Yellow  Trains   6  
Marcia   Orange  Sleds   7  
Sue    Blue   Spinning tops 9  

Check against every clue  

• The five numbers 3, 5, 6, 7, 9 are all different, each exceeds 2, and their sum is 30.  
• Cher (6) made one more than the red-clad elf Jane (5) and one less than the sled-maker Marcia (7).  
• Johnny made the racing cars and, being the green elf, produced 3—exactly one-third of Sue’s 9.  
• The yellow-suited elf (Cher) made all the trains.  
• Sue, the only blue-clad elf, made the spinning tops, and her 9 tops are the greatest number made by any elf.  
• Jane made five balls.  
• Marcia is dressed in orange.  

All clues are satisfied, so the table above is the correct solution.

Question:
You are back on the same game show with four other contestants. You didn't realise last time that the winner gets another appearance on the show! You now have another chance to win half a million dollars and become a millionaire! The objective is to crack the combination of the safe using the clues. The first person to do so will win $500,000.
The safe combination looks like this:
??-??-??-??
A digit can be used more than once in the code, and there are no zeroes.
Here are the clues:
1. When adding the first number of the third set with the second number of the second set, you will get a number below 8.
2. The only digits not used in the code are 5 and 7.
3. When adding the two digits of the first set together, you will not get 10.
4. If you multiply the second set by 4, you will get the fourth set reversed.
5. No set has a number above 90.
6. The product of both the digits in the first set is below 30 but above 20.
7. One of the number sets is 66.
8. There is only one 8 in the combination, and it is in the last set.
Now, get cracking!
Human Solution:
The set is 39-21-66-48.
First of all, the second clue tells you there are no 5's or 7's in the combination.
Now we go to the fourth clue. It tells you that if you multiply the second set by 4, you will get the fourth set reversed. There are only a few numbers that will satisfy this:
11, 12, 16, 21, 22, 23 and 24.
Now we skip down to clue 8, which tells us there is one 8 only, and it is in the last set. It could either be the first digit or the second digit.
However, this eliminates these numbers from being in the second set: 11, 16, 23 and 24. Now, only 12, 21 and 22 are the possibilities for being in the second set.
Now, let's look at clue 7. This tells us that 66 is one of the four number sets. We know it can't be in the second, or fourth, and since clue six tells us the product of the two numbers in the first set ranges from 21-29, 66 must go in the third set.
??-??-66-??
Now we must look at the first clue. The first number of the third set (6) plus the second number of the second set will get a number below 8. This means it cannot be 12 or 22, because they would both total 8. This means that the second set of numbers is 21. Making good progress!
??-21-66-??
Now, we come back to clue 4 which tells us the second set multiplied by 4 equals the fourth set reversed. 21 multiplied by 4 is 84, which when reversed is 48!
??-21-66-48
