Now, we come back to clue 6, which tells us the product of the digits in the first set is above 20 but below 30. These are the only numbers that satisfy that condition - and remember, no 5's, 7's or 8's are left in the combination:
39 (3 * 9 = 27)
46 (4 * 6 = 24)
64 (6 * 4 = 24)
93 (9 * 3 = 27)
Now, we look at clue 5. This eliminates 93. Now, come to clue 3. This tells us the sum of the two digits in the first set does not equal 10. This eliminates 46 and 64. The only number left is.... 39!
Now you have your answer;
39-21-66-48
Congratulations!!! You won, again!! You are over the moon! You have become the first millionaire in five generations of your family history!!
Response: Final answer: 39-21-66-48

Question: A warden at a prison decides to give some prisoners a chance to escape by working together to solve a puzzle. He prepares a colored hat for every one of them and tells them the rules. The hats can be either black or white and will be placed on everyone's head.  The prisoners will get a chance to discuss a strategy together, which they will all follow, then they will be marched out into a large room where they will see everybody else's hat color. Each prisoner will then simultaneously guess which of the two hat colors they have. If every one of them is right, or every one of them is wrong, they will all go free. However, the prisoners will not be allowed to communicate in any way during this process. Also, the warden will hear their strategy and place hats any way he can to prevent them from going free. What strategy do they use to escape?
Hint: Think about it for two people and then three people. What will be the difference between what a white hatted person sees and a black hatted person sees?
Human Solution: Every prisoner should count up how many black hats they see. If they count an odd number of black hats, they say that they have a black hat. If they count an even number of black hats, then they say that they have a white hat.
Response:
Strategy agreed upon in advance  

1.  Before they are lined up the prisoners pick one simple rule that every
    one of them will obey.  
    (Any equivalent rule will work; the usual one is)

        “We want the total number of WHITE hats to be EVEN.
         When my turn comes I will say the colour that
         would make the overall number of white hats even.”

    In other words

        • count how many white hats you can see;  
        • if that number is even, say “black”;  
        • if that number is odd,  say “white”.  

    No other communication is ever used.

Why it works – first look at two and three prisoners  

• Two prisoners  
  If the real hats are (W , W) the number of whites is 2 (even).
  Each man wearing W sees 1 white (odd) and therefore says “white”.
  Both guesses are correct.  

  If the real hats are (W , B) the total number of whites is 1 (odd).
  The man with W sees 0 whites (even) and says “black” – wrong.  
  The man with B sees 1 white (odd) and says “white” – wrong.
  Both are wrong.  

  The other two assignments behave the same way, so with two prisoners
  they are always both right or both wrong.

• Three prisoners behave the same way, and the argument below shows
  the rule works for any number n ≥ 2.

General proof for any number of prisoners  

Call the actual (unknown to each prisoner) total number of white hats T.

Case 1 :  T is even.  
          A prisoner who really wears a white hat sees T–1 whites, an odd
          number, so he says “white” – correct.  
          A prisoner who really wears a black hat sees T whites, an even
          number, so he says “black” – correct.  
          Every single guess is correct.

Case 2 :  T is odd.  
          A prisoner who really wears a white hat now sees T–1 whites, an
          even number, so he says “black” – wrong.  
          A prisoner who really wears a black hat sees T whites, an odd
          number, so he says “white” – wrong.  
          Every single guess is wrong.

So no matter how the warden distributes the hats,
either every guess is right (when T is even) or every guess is wrong
(when T is odd).  In both situations the prisoners satisfy the warden’s
escape condition.

Therefore the prisoners are guaranteed to go free.

Final answer:  They agree that each man will announce the colour which makes the overall number of white hats even; this forces the whole group to be simultaneously all correct or all incorrect, so they always win.

Question:
Madadian Multi-Squillionaire Sheik Ratelunroll has bought four prestige cars from the Madadian Motor Company (MMC) - The Silver Dream, The Golden Pleasure, The Devine Lightning, and a The Rusting Bucket, - as presents for his sons' birthdays, all of which are next week (strange things like this happen in Madadia all the time). Given the following information, what will each son get?
1, Derek will not get The Golden Pleasure unless Berrick gets The Silver Dream and Eric gets The Rusting Bucket.
2, Berrick will not get The Rusting Bucket unless Merick gets The Devine Lightning and Derek gets The Silver Dream.
3, Eric will not get The Devine Lightning unless Derek gets The Golden Pleasure and Berrick gets The Silver Dream.
4, Derek will not get The Silver Dream unless Merick gets The Devine Lightning and Eric gets The Rusting Bucket.
5, Berrick will not get The Silver Dream unless Derek gets The Devine Lightning and Eric gets The Rusting Bucket.
6, Derek will not get The Devine Lightning unless Berrick gets The Golden Pleasure and Merick gets The Silver Dream.
7, Merick will not get The Devine Lightning unless Berrick gets The Golden Pleasure and Derek gets The Rusting Bucket.
8, Derek will not get The Rusting Bucket unless Berrick gets The Devine Lightning and Eric gets The Golden Pleasure.
9, Merick will not get The Silver Dream unless Eric gets The Golden Pleasure.
Hint: Starting with the simplest requirement, #9, assume that Eric does in fact get The Golden Pleasure, then Merick gets The Silver Dream.
Human Solution:
Starting with the simplest requirement, #9, assume that Eric does in fact get The Golden Pleasure, then Merick gets The Silver Dream. This leaves The Rusting Bucket and The Devine Lightning for Berrick and Derek. Going to rule #8, Eric already has The Golden Pleasure, so if Berrick gets The Devine Lightning, then Derek can have The Rusting Bucket. This gives us the following that complies with rules 8 & 9:
Eric = The Golden Pleasure
Merick = The Silver Dream
Berrick = The Devine Lightning
Derek = The Rusting Bucket
Now, to see if this works, just check it out against rules 1 through 7, where you'll find no rules are violated and everyone's happy except Derek who got stuck with The Rusting Bucket.
Response:
Let  

D = car Derek receives  
B = car Berrick receives  
E = car Eric receives  
M = car Merick receives  

and the four cars be  

SD = The Silver Dream  
GP = The Golden Pleasure  
DL = The Devine Lightning  
RB = The Rusting Bucket.  

Because each son receives exactly one car and the cars are all different, {D, B, E, M} is a permutation of {SD, GP, DL, RB}.

All nine statements are of the form  
“X will not get Y unless (other conditions)”,  
i.e.  

  (X gets Y) ⇒ (those other conditions).

Step 1 – use the hint (statement 9).  
9. (M = SD) ⇒ (E = GP).  
The hint tells us to begin by supposing that Eric does get GP.  
So put  

  E = GP.                                                       (1)

Step 2 – decide what Merick can receive.  
With E already taking GP, the remaining cars for D, B, M are {SD, DL, RB}.  
Examine the possibilities for M.

• Suppose M = DL.  
 Then statement 7 applies: (M = DL) ⇒ (B = GP & D = RB).  
 But GP is already assigned to Eric, so B cannot be GP – contradiction.  
 Therefore M ≠ DL.

• Suppose M = RB.  
 Then the cars left for D and B are SD and DL.  
   – If D = SD, statement 4 would require E = RB, contradicting E = GP.  
   – If D = DL, statement 6 would require B = GP, impossible.  
 So M ≠ RB.

Hence the only remaining possibility is  

  M = SD.                                                      (2)

(Notice that (2) also automatically satisfies statement 9.)

Step 3 – assign the two cars still unallocated.  
The unused cars are DL and RB, for Derek and Berrick in some order.

Case A D = DL, B = RB.  
 Statement 6 says (D = DL) ⇒ (B = GP & M = SD); but B would be RB, not GP.  
 Contradiction, so Case A is impossible.

Case B D = RB, B = DL.  
 Statement 8 says (D = RB) ⇒ (B = DL & E = GP).  
 Both conditions are exactly met.  
 No other statement has its antecedent true, so no further requirements arise.

Therefore  

  D = RB, B = DL.                                             (3)

Step 4 – check every statement.

1. D ≠ GP ⇒ antecedent false – satisfied.  
2. B ≠ RB ⇒ antecedent false – satisfied.  
3. E ≠ DL ⇒ antecedent false – satisfied.  
4. D ≠ SD ⇒ antecedent false – satisfied.  
5. B ≠ SD ⇒ antecedent false – satisfied.  
6. D ≠ DL ⇒ antecedent false – satisfied.  
7. M ≠ DL ⇒ antecedent false – satisfied.  
8. D = RB ⇒ consequent (B = DL and E = GP) holds – satisfied.  
9. M = SD ⇒ consequent (E = GP) holds – satisfied.

Every rule is honored, and the assignment uses each car exactly once, so it is the unique solution.

Final answer: Derek receives The Rusting Bucket, Berrick receives The Devine Lightning, Eric receives The Golden Pleasure, and Merick receives The Silver Dream.

Question:
Thirty fans hire a bus to attend a football game. On the way to the stadium, they realize that exactly half of them are fans of one team and the other half are fans of the other team. With still some way to go before reaching the stadium, the bus develops mechanical problems and the driver announces to his passengers that the only way to continue the journey is for half of them to get out and walk. There is a huge fight that doesn't stop until the driver speaks to them again and suggests a way of selecting the passengers who are to get off the bus.
"All of you," he said, "get into a big circle. When you are ready, beginning at this spot, I'll count nine people clockwise. The ninth person leaves the circle and continues on foot. Then I'll count another nine starting from where I stopped, and the ninth person leaves the circle and continues on foot. And so on until fifteen people have left the circle."
Suppose that you are one of the fans. How should you arrange all the other fans of your team so that none of them will have to leave?
Hint: Just keep counting in circles and see where you each spot lands
Human Solution: If the two teams are A and B and you are a supporter of team A and don't want any of your fellow supporters to end up walking to the stadium, organize them in a circle starting at the point where the driver starts and reading clockwise as follows: A, A, A, A, B, B, B, B, B, A, A, B, A, A, A, B, A, B, B, A, A, B, B, B, A, B, B, A, A, B.
Response:
Number the places in the circle consecutively 1, 2, 3, … , 30, beginning with the spot from which the driver starts counting and moving clockwise.  
Now follow exactly what the driver will do, always starting the next count with the person who is immediately clockwise from the one who has just stepped out.

Eliminations (k = 9 each time)

1st 9  
2nd 18  
3rd 27  
4th 6  
5th 16  
6th 26  
7th 7  
8th 19  
9th 30  
10th 12  
11th 24  
12th 8  
13th 22  
14th 5  
15th 23  

After these fifteen names have been called the numbers still standing are

1, 2, 3, 4, 10, 11, 13, 14, 15, 17, 20, 21, 25, 28, 29.

Therefore place the fifteen supporters of your team (including yourself) in the seats whose numbers are

1, 2, 3, 4, 10, 11, 13, 14, 15, 17, 20, 21, 25, 28, 29,

and seat the fifteen supporters of the other team in the remaining fifteen places.  
When the driver counts off every ninth person, only the opponents’ fans (the numbers listed in the left column above) will have to leave, while every member of your own group will still be on the bus when the counting stops.

Final answer: seat your team in positions 1, 2, 3, 4, 10, 11, 13, 14, 15, 17, 20, 21, 25, 28, 29 in the clockwise circle that the driver will use.

Question:
It appears that you have angered the spirit of Halloween by failing to revere the Great Pumpkin, and now a curse has befallen you.  On the walkway to your house is a Ward of Seven Jack O'Lanterns arranged in a circle.  If midnight comes and any of the seven are still lit, a dark reaper and seven dark horses with seven dark riders shall visit thy abode.  They shall surround thy domicile and, while circling it, they will proceed to pelt thy dwelling with eggs and cream of shaving.  And come morn there will be a great mess to be reckoned with.  Verily.  So you better get those lanterns out.
You quickly discover something odd about these lanterns.  When you blow out the first one, the lanterns on either side extinguish as well!  But there is more.  If you blow out a lantern adjacent to one that is extinguished, the extinguished one(s) will relight.  It seems that blowing on any lantern will change the state of three - the one you blew on and its two neighbors.  Finally, you can blow on an extinguished lantern and it will relight, and its neighbors will light/extinguish as applicable.  After trying once and finding all seven lit again, you decide, being the excellent puzzler, you sit down and examine this closer.  But hurry, I hear the beating of many hooves...
Hint: If you examine the setup carefully, you'll note a number of facts which make the puzzle easier to solve by deduction.  First, blowing on a lantern is a commutative property; blowing on lanterns 1, 5, then 3 is the same as blowing on 3, then 1, and then 5.  No matter what order the lanterns are blown on, if the same lanterns are blown on the same number of times, the result won't change.
Human Solution:
If you examine the setup carefully, you'll note a number of facts which make the puzzle easier to solve by deduction.  First, blowing on a lantern is a commutative property; blowing on lanterns 1, 5, then 3 is the same as blowing on 3, then 1, and then 5.  No matter what order the lanterns are blown on, if the same lanterns are blown on the same number of times, the result won't change.  For that reason, blowing on a lantern twice is as good as not blowing on it at all.  And three times is as good as one time. So, it seems that it should be able to be done in seven steps or less.
What else can we tell about the solution?  Since each operation changes the state of three lanterns, and there are 7 lanterns, and each lantern must change its state an odd number of times, it's a safe bet that there will need to be an odd number of steps.  We can easily see it can't be done in 1 or 3 steps, so it must be 5 or 7.  Trying 5 steps comes up with 3 different patterns that are not symmetrical and fail to leave all lanterns extinguished.  So that leaves 7 steps and to your surprise, based on the commutative property, the easiest solution is to blow on each one in order!  So doing this, the Great Pumpkin has decided to give you a treat for figuring this out and you find all seven lanterns full of candy the next morning!  Congratulations!
Response:
Let the seven lanterns be L₀ , L₁ , … , L₆ in clockwise order (indices taken mod 7).  
Blowing on Lᵢ toggles the state (lit ↔ out) of the triple

 Lᵢ₋₁ , Lᵢ , Lᵢ₊₁ .

Because blowing twice has no net effect, it is enough to know whether each lantern is blown an even (0) or odd (1) number of times.  
Write

 xᵢ  =  0  if Lᵢ is never blown,  
 xᵢ  =  1  if Lᵢ is blown once.

After the whole procedure a lantern is out exactly when it has been toggled an odd number of times.  
Lantern Lᵢ is toggled by the blows on Lᵢ₋₁ , Lᵢ , and Lᵢ₊₁ , so its final condition is

 xᵢ₋₁ + xᵢ + xᵢ₊₁  ≡  1 (mod 2)        (1)

(the right-hand side is 1 because Lᵢ starts lit and must finish out).

This gives seven simultaneous equations:

x₆+x₀+x₁ =1  
x₀+x₁+x₂ =1  
x₁+x₂+x₃ =1  
x₂+x₃+x₄ =1  
x₃+x₄+x₅ =1  
x₄+x₅+x₆ =1  
x₅+x₆+x₀ =1                (all mod 2).

Add the first two equations:

 (x₆+x₀+x₁)+(x₀+x₁+x₂)=x₆+x₂=0 ⇒ x₆ = x₂.

Adding the next pair gives x₀ = x₃; the next pair x₁ = x₄; the next x₂ = x₅; the next x₃ = x₆; and the last x₄ = x₀; finally x₅ = x₁.  
Chaining these equalities forces

 x₀ = x₂ = x₃ = x₅ = x₆ ,  x₁ = x₄ .

Insert these relations in the first equation:

 x₆ + x₀ + x₁ = x₀ + x₀ + x₁ = x₁ = 1 ⇒  x₁ = 1.

Hence x₄ = 1, and all other x’s equal x₀.  
Use the seventh equation:

 x₅ + x₆ + x₀ = x₀ + x₀ + x₀ = x₀ = 1.

Therefore every variable is 1:

 x₀ = x₁ = … = x₆ = 1.

There is no alternative solution; the seven equations determine the xᵢ uniquely.

Conclusion  
Each lantern must be blown on exactly once.  Because order is irrelevant (the operations commute), any sequence that touches every lantern once will toggle every lantern three times in total, turning every initially lit lantern off.

Final answer: Blow on every one of the seven lanterns exactly once (in any order); after the seventh blow all lanterns are extinguished.

Question:
Every day from Monday through Sunday in this week, Mr. Peter picks two shirts from the five colours red, blue, yellow, green and black. Peter follows the rules:
1. Peter doesn't use the same combination on two days of this week.
2. Peter doesn't use the same colour on two consecutive days of this week.
3. Peter uses some colour on four days.
4. Peter uses blue and black on Monday.
5. Peter uses green on Thursday.
6. Peter doesn't use yellow on Friday.
7. Peter doesn't combine red with black.
What colours does Peter use on Saturday?
Hint: Start from rules 2 and 3
Human Solution:
From rules 2 and 3, Peter must use one colour on Monday, Wednesday, Friday and Sunday, which can be blue or black.
If it's black, from rules 1 and 4, Peter must combine black with red, yellow and green on Wednesday, Friday and Sunday, but rule 7 disallows combining black with red.
Therefore, it's blue, and Peter must combine blue with red, yellow and green on Wednesday, Friday and Sunday. From rule 5, Peter uses green on Thursday, he can't use green on Wednesday or Friday, and only on Sunday.
From rule 6, Peter doesn't use yellow on Friday, and he can only use red on Friday and yellow on Wednesday.
Since Peter uses blue, red and green on Friday and Sunday, from rule 2, he can only use black and yellow on Saturday.
Response:
Let the colours be abbreviated  
R = red, B = blue, Y = yellow, G = green, K = black.

We must choose an unordered pair of different colours for every day, obeying

(1) the seven pairs are all different;  
(2) no colour is repeated on two consecutive days;  
(3) one colour is used on exactly four days;  
(4) Monday = B K; (5) Thursday contains G; (6) Friday contains no Y;  
(7) R is never paired with K.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
I.  Which colour can occur on four days?
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Because a colour cannot appear on two consecutive days (rule 2), the only way
to use a colour four times in the week is on the alternating days

  Mon – Wed – Fri – Sun.

So the colour that is used four times must occur on Monday.
The Monday pair is B K, hence the four–day colour is either B or K.

•  Could it be K?  
  K would then have to be paired with four different partners
  (otherwise rule 1 would be broken).
  Rule 7 forbids the pair R K, leaving only the three partners B, Y, G.  
  That gives at most three different pairs with K, not four, so K cannot be the
  four–day colour.

•  Therefore B is the colour used on four days:  
  Mon, Wed, Fri, Sun.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
II.  Construct the week day by day
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Write down the days already fixed and keep rule 2 in mind.

Mon   B K  (given)

Tue   – –  (must avoid B, K) → choose G R.

Wed   – –  (must avoid G, R and must contain B)  
       → choose B Y.    (pair B K is forbidden by rule 1)

Thu   – –  (must contain G and avoid B, Y)  
       → choose G K.

Fri   – –  (must avoid G, K and may not contain Y; must contain B)  
       → choose B R.

So far we have

Mon  B K  
Tue  G R  
Wed  B Y  
Thu  G K  
Fri  B R

--------------------------------------------------------------------
III.  Determine Saturday and Sunday
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Saturday must avoid the colours of Friday, i.e. must avoid B and R.
The available colours are G, Y, K.

Because Sunday must contain B (to give the fourth use of blue) and must avoid
Saturday’s colours, Saturday cannot contain G or Y simultaneously with
either of them appearing again on Sunday.  Testing the possibilities:

•  Sat = G Y  ⇒  Sun would need B with neither G nor Y; the only choices are
   B R (already used) or B K (already used).  Impossible.

•  Sat = G K  already used on Thursday.  Impossible.

•  Sat = Y K  is new and leaves the colours G and R free for Sunday.

Choose Sat = Y K.

Now Sunday must avoid Y and K, must contain B, and must be a new pair.
The only available new pair is B G.

Thus the complete and unique week is

Mon  B K  
Tue  G R  
Wed  B Y  
Thu  G K  
Fri  B R  
Sat  Y K  
Sun  B G

Verify all rules:

•  All seven pairs are different.  
•  Adjacent days share no colour.  
•  Blue is used four times (Mon, Wed, Fri, Sun).  
•  Rules 4–7 are clearly respected.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Hence on Saturday Peter wears the colours

Final answer: Yellow and Black

Question:
At the Christmas party of the "Sweaty Chef" kebab shop, the owner Mr Juan, took note of how many people were present. Although he was a bit tipsy when he made his note, and thus made a mistake.  His notes were as follows:-
1, There were 9 men and children.
2, There were 2 more women than children.
3, The number of different man-woman couples possible was 24. Note that if there were 7 men and 5 women, then there would have been 35 man-woman couples possible.
Also, of the three groups - men, women and children - at the party:
4, There were 4 of one group.
5, There were 6 of one group.
6, There were 8 of one group.
Exactly one of the above 6 statements is false.
Can you tell which one is false? Also, how many men, women and children are there at the party?
Hint: Can 4,5,6 all be true at the same time?
Human Solution:
Statement (4) is false. There are 3 men, 8 women and 6 children.
Assume that Statements (4), (5) and (6) are all true. Then, Statement (1) is false. But then Statement (2) and (3) both can not be true. Thus, contradictory to the fact that exactly one statement is false.
So Statement (4) or Statement (5) or Statement (6) is false. Also, Statements (1), (2) and (3) all are true.
From (1) and (2), there are 11 men and women. Then from (3), there are 2 possible cases - either there are 8 men and 3 women or there are 3 men and 8 women.
If there are 8 men and 3 women, then there is 1 child. Then Statements (4) and (5) both are false, which is not possible.
Hence, there are 3 men, 8 women and 6 children. Statement (4) is false.
Response:
Let  

 m = number of men, w = number of women, c = number of children  

( all are positive integers ).

Take the five true statements to be T and the single false one to be F.  

-------------------------------------------------
1.  m + c = 9                                             (1)  
2.  w = c + 2                                             (2)  
3.  m·w = 24                                              (3)  
4.  “One group numbered 4”  
5.  “One group numbered 6”  
6.  “One group numbered 8”
-------------------------------------------------

Step 1 – Assume statements 1, 2, 3 are true  
From (2) put w = c + 2 in (3) and use (1):

 m = 9 – c  
 (9 – c)(c + 2) = 24  
 −c² + 7c + 18 = 24 ⟹ c² – 7c + 6 = 0 ⟹ c = 1 or 6

• If c = 1  ⇒  (m,w,c) = (8,3,1)  
 Among (4),(5),(6) only statement 6 is true (there are 8 men);  
 statements 4 and 5 are both false – too many false statements.

• If c = 6  ⇒  (m,w,c) = (3,8,6)  
 Here statement 6 is true (8 women), statement 5 is true (6 children)  
 and statement 4 is false (nobody is 4).  
 Exactly one statement – No. 4 – is false.  
 So this triple satisfies the “exactly one false” requirement.

Step 2 – Show no other choice of the false statement is possible  
Suppose instead that statement 4, 5 or 6 were the single false one, so the other two size–statements are true.  
Then all three group–sizes would have to be 4, 6, 8 in some order.

But with {m,w,c} = {4,6,8}:

• m + c can never be 9 (the possible sums are 10,12,14),  
 so statement 1 would be false.

Hence whenever statements 4, 5, 6 are all true, statement 1 is also false, giving at least two false statements.  
Therefore the lone false statement cannot be 5 or 6; it must be 4 as found in Step 1.

Conclusion  
The only arrangement consistent with “exactly one statement is false” is

 men m = 3  
 women w = 8  
 children c = 6  

and the single incorrect note Mr Juan wrote is statement 4 (“There were 4 of one group”).

Final answer: 3 men, 8 women, 6 children; the false statement is No. 4.

Question: Write on a piece of paper a 5x5 letter square using the alphabet, minus the letter Q, where A is in the upper left-hand corner and Z is in the lower right-hand corner.  After you have done this, can you tell me which letter comes just above the letter which comes between the letter just before the letter just below B and the letter just before the letter just above Y?
Hint: One step at a time
Human Solution:
The letter is G.
The two letters to initially find are F & S. The letter above the one which is between them is G.
Response:
We first construct the required 5 × 5 square by writing the 25-letter alphabet (Q omitted) row-by-row from left to right, making sure that A is the upper-left entry and Z the lower-right entry.

A  B  C  D  E  
F  G  H  I  J  
K  L  M  N  O  
P  R  S  T  U  
V  W  X  Y  Z  

(1)  “The letter just below B”  
B is in the first row, second column.  Directly beneath it (same column, next row) is G.

(2)  “The letter just before the letter just below B”  
The alphabetic predecessor of G (remember, Q is missing) is F.

(3)  “The letter just above Y”  
Y sits in the fifth row, fourth column.  The square directly above it is T.

(4)  “The letter just before the letter just above Y”  
The alphabetic predecessor of T is S.

(5)  “The letter which comes between … F and S”  
On the square, F is at (row 2, col 1) and S is at (row 4, col 3).  
The single square that lies exactly midway between those two (one step down and one step right from F, or one step up and one step left from S) is L, at (row 3, col 2).

(6)  “The letter just above” that midway letter  
Above L (row 3, col 2) is the square (row 2, col 2), which contains G.

Hence, the letter asked for is G.

Final answer: G

Question:
Consider a grid of size 4 x 4 (i.e. sixteen squares), where all squares should get a color. The colored grid should meet the following conditions:
4 squares should be colored blue,
3 squares should be colored red,
3 squares should be colored white,
3 squares should be colored green,
3 squares should be colored yellow, and
How can these squares be arranged so that no color appears more than once in any horizontal, vertical, or diagonal line?
Hint: Start by placing the blues.
Human Solution:
There are multiple possible answers. Just check that the conditions in the original problem statement hold: 
4 squares should be colored blue,
3 squares should be colored red,
3 squares should be colored white,
3 squares should be colored green,
3 squares should be colored yellow, and
How can these squares be arranged so that no color appears more than once in any horizontal, vertical, or diagonal line?

One possible arrangement:
W B G R
R Y W B
B G R Y
Y W B G
Response:
One convenient way to satisfy the requirement is to let every colour occupy squares that never share a row, a column, or a ±45°-diagonal with another square of the same colour.  
Begin, as suggested, with the four blues; place them exactly as four non-attacking queens:

               C1   C2   C3   C4
            ┌────┬────┬────┬────┐
        R1  │    │ B  │    │    │
            ├────┼────┼────┼────┤
        R2  │    │    │    │ B  │
            ├────┼────┼────┼────┤
        R3  │ B  │    │    │    │
            ├────┼────┼────┼────┤
        R4  │    │    │ B  │    │
            └────┴────┴────┴────┘

(Blue at (1,2), (2,4), (3,1), (4,3).)

Each of the four remaining colours has to appear three times.  
Give every colour its own non-attacking “mini-queen” set of three squares; this automatically keeps any colour from repeating on a row, column or diagonal.

A possible complete filling is

               C1   C2   C3   C4
            ┌────┬────┬────┬────┐
        R1  │ R  │ B  │ G  │ W  │
            ├────┼────┼────┼────┤
        R2  │ W  │ Y  │ R  │ B  │
            ├────┼────┼────┼────┤
        R3  │ B  │ G  │ W  │ Y  │
            ├────┼────┼────┼────┤
        R4  │ Y  │ R  │ B  │ G  │
            └────┴────┴────┴────┘

• Blues (B) lie at (1,2), (2,4), (3,1), (4,3).  
• Reds (R) lie at (1,1), (2,3), (4,2).  
• Whites (W) lie at (1,4), (2,1), (3,3).  
• Greens (G) lie at (1,3), (3,2), (4,4).  
• Yellows (Y) lie at (2,2), (3,4), (4,1).

For every individual colour:

– no two of its squares share a row,  
– no two share a column,  
– no two lie on the same ↘ diagonal (equal row − column),  
– no two lie on the same ↗ diagonal (equal row + column).

Hence “no colour appears more than once in any horizontal, vertical, or diagonal line,” and the quota of 4 B, 3 R, 3 W, 3 G, 3 Y is met.

Final answer: one arrangement is  

Row 1  R B G W  
Row 2  W Y R B  
Row 3  B G W Y  
Row 4  Y R B G

Question:
I woke up late that morning to welcome a bright sunny day after a long and hectic week. It was a holiday and I was determined to spend the day playing cards with my friend Tweeto. Tweeto's favorite card game was the Romankachi card game.
The rules of the game are as follows :-
1) One person 'serves' and the other 'receives' cards in each round.
2) The person who serves cards in the round gains 2 cards if he wins the round and loses only 1 card if he loses the round.
3) On the other hand, the person who receives cards in the round, gains only 1 card if he wins the round and loses 2 cards if he loses the round.
4) Finally the person who wins in one round, serves in the next round.
5) The game is stopped when a player loses all his cards.
We started off with 5 cards each and I served in the first round.
At the end of three rounds if I had exactly 4 cards then which of the following statements must be true:-
A) Tweeto must have won exactly two rounds.
B) I must have won the first round.
C) Tweeto must have won the third round.
NOTE: Out of the given set of 3 statements, it is not necessary that one and only one statement is true. One or more statements may be true.
Hint: First, think about what possible results could lead to you having 4 cards?
Human Solution:
Statements A and C must be true.
The rules of the Romankachi card game are given below.
1) One person 'serves' and the other 'receives' cards in each round.
2) The person who serves cards in the round gains 2 cards if he wins the round and loses only 1 card if he loses the round.
3) On the other hand, the person who receives cards in the round, gains only 1 card if he wins the round and loses 2 cards if he loses the round.
4) Finally the person who wins in one round, serves in the next round.
5) The game is stopped when a player loses all his cards.
The given statements are
A) Tweeto must have won exactly two rounds.
B) I must have won the first round.
C) Tweeto must have won the third round.
Since we started the card game with 5 cards each and I started of the first round, at the end of three rounds I can have 4 cards due to any one of the following two results.
First Result :
I served in the first round and won. Hence I served in the second round but lost. Tweeto served in the third round and again I lost thus ending up with 4 cards.
The number of cards with me and Tweeto is tabulated below.
Round      Me    Tweeto
Initially     5           5
Round 1    7           3
Round 2    6           4
Round 3    4           6
Applying the given statements  to the above table, we can observe that statements A and C are true since Tweeto won exactly two rounds and Tweeto won the third round. Statement B is true here because I won the first round.
Second Result :
I served in the first round and lost. Hence Tweeto served in the second round but he lost. I served in the third round and I lost thus ending up with 4 cards.
The number of cards with me and Tweeto is tabulated below.
Round     Me    Tweeto
Initially     5           5
Round 1    4           6
Round 2    5           5
Round 3    4           6
Applying the given statements  to the above table, we can observe that statements A and C are true since Tweeto won exactly two rounds and Tweeto won the third round. Statement B is false here because I lost the first round.
Hence it is clear from both the results that statements A and C must be true for me to end up with 4 cards at the end of three rounds.
Response:
Let A be “I” and B be Tweeto.  
Start: A = 5 cards, B = 5 cards; A serves in Round 1.

Card-count changes for A  
• serving & win  →  +2  
• serving & lose →  −1  
• receiving & win →  +1  
• receiving & lose →  −2  

After three rounds A must have 4 cards, i.e. a net change of −1.

--------------------------------------------------
1.  Suppose A wins Round 1.  
   Change: +2 ⇒ A now 7 cards and still serves.

   a. If A also wins Round 2, change = +2 again (A=9).  
      Whatever happens in Round 3 ( +2 or −1 ), A cannot drop to 4.  
      So Round 2 cannot be a win.

   b. Therefore A must lose Round 2.  
      Change in Round 2: −1 ⇒ A now 6 cards and becomes receiver.

      • If A wins Round 3 (receiving), change = +1 ⇒ A = 7 (too many).  
      • If A loses Round 3 (receiving), change = −2 ⇒ A = 4.  (works)

   Sequence obtained: W L L  
   (A wins 1st, loses 2nd, loses 3rd)

--------------------------------------------------
2.  Suppose A loses Round 1.  
   Change: −1 ⇒ A now 4 cards and becomes receiver in Round 2.

   a. If A loses Round 2 as well, change = −2 ⇒ A drops to 2 cards;  
      he cannot reach 4 after Round 3 (and might even be out), so impossible.

   b. Hence A must win Round 2.  
      Change in Round 2: +1 ⇒ A back to 5 cards and now serves Round 3.

      • To finish with 4 cards, Round 3 must give −1,  
        i.e. A must lose Round 3 while serving.

   Sequence obtained: L W L  
   (A loses 1st, wins 2nd, loses 3rd)

--------------------------------------------------
These are the only possible three-round histories:

 (i) W L L  (ii) L W L

Now test the statements.

A) “Tweeto won exactly two rounds.”  
 Sequence (i): B wins R2 & R3 – two wins.  
 Sequence (ii): B wins R1 & R3 – two wins.  
 Always true.

B) “I won the first round.”  
 False in sequence (ii).  
 Not necessarily true.

C) “Tweeto won the third round.”  
 In both sequences A loses Round 3, so B wins it.  
 Always true.

Hence the statements that must be true are A and C.

Final answer: A and C

Question:
Phil Fegit was sitting in his bedroom watching the torrential rain pour down on his home town of MADADIA.  The water had caused floods throughout the town and water over six feet deep had forced people to abandon the downstairs of their homes and they had to retreat to the upstairs rooms. The yearly Kebab harvest had been washed away as the downpour had continued unabated for a full month.
Just at that moment Phil's wife, Norma, walked into the bedroom and he commented upon the rain. She replied that she could really care less. No matter how much Phil tried to stress the importance of the rain falling in Madadia, she refused to take it seriously.
How come?
Human Solution:
Phil was watching a news report about his home town on TV, he had recently moved away from the area and it was sunny where he was.
His wife wasn't from Madadia, hence she didn't care what happened there.
Response:
Phil was only “watching” what was happening in Madadia on a television (or computer) screen – he and Norma were living somewhere else.  
Madadia was Phil’s old home town, not the place where the couple presently lived.  
Since the storm and the flooding were taking place far away and posed no threat at all to the life the two of them were leading now, Norma had no personal stake in the disaster: for her it simply was not an important, “real” problem.  
That is why, however much Phil worried about what was happening back in his home town, Norma could truthfully say she “could really care less.”

Question:
There were 9 portraits of animals (bear, cat, dog, hamster, horse, lion, monkey, mouse, and tiger) on a wall of a museum.  As I was studying them, I tripped and fell into the wall and they all fell down. I have to get them back up on the wall in the correct order before I get into some serious trouble.  I only remember a couple of things about the order of the portraits.  Can you help me figure out the order of the portraits using the clues I remember about them?
They were displayed as follows:
Note: The Letter and Numbers in the graph are labels for their corresponding rows.
...........A...............B.............C
1    _________ l _________ l _________
2    _________ l _________ l _________
3    _________ l _________ l _________
Clues:
1.  The bear is in the same row as the hamster.
2.  Two portraits in both rows 3 and C have two animals that start with the same letter.
3.  The horse is in the same row as the monkey.
4.  The dog is in 2A.
5.  Either the lion or the tiger is below the cat.
6.  The monkey is either above or below the dog.
7.  The dog is not next to the tiger.
Hint: Monkey, mouse, hamster, horse are the only two pairs with same letter. Focus on this
Human Solution:
bear      l cat        l hamster
dog       l lion       l tiger
monkey l mouse  l horse
Response:
The only arrangement that satisfies every one of the seven clues simultaneously is  

Row 1 (A) Bear (B) Cat (C) Hamster  
Row 2 (A) Dog  (B) Lion (C) Tiger  
Row 3 (A) Monkey (B) Mouse (C) Horse  

Check of all clues  
1. Bear and Hamster are together in Row 1.  
2. Row 3 has Monkey & Mouse (both ‘M’).  Column C has Hamster & Horse (both ‘H’).  
3. Horse is in the same row as Monkey (Row 3).  
4. Dog is at 2A.  
5. Lion (row 2) is directly below Cat (row 1) in column B.  
6. Monkey (3A) is directly below Dog (2A).  
7. Dog (2A) is not next to Tiger (2C).  

Every clue is met, so this is the unique correct ordering.

Final answer:  
Row 1 – Bear, Cat, Hamster  
Row 2 – Dog, Lion, Tiger  
Row 3 – Monkey, Mouse, Horse

Question:
In the purely fictitious land of Fiddledeboox, the Minister of Finance emerged from a top-level meeting.   Reporters had gathered to hear his announcement about either an increase or a decrease in either wages, subsidies or tax levels.
It was widely known that this Minister [M] told the truth to reporters [R] only once in every three statements.
M:  Well, I can tell you that it's about subsidies.
R:  Are they going down again?
M:  Nothing is going down.
R:  So it's good news for the people?
M:  Of course.  Either subsidies are going down or there will be a wage increase.
While others jostled to ask the next question, one logically minded newshound was already leaving with the hot headline news.
From the Minister's three statements above, can you also deduce the truth?
Hint:
Assume each statement, in turn, to be true.  Then examine the truth or otherwise of the others.
Or check the statements in the light of each of the six possibilities.
Human Solution:
It was a tax increase.
Solution:
Remember that only one statement can be true.
If (1) is true then either (2) or (3) will be true as well.  So (1) is a lie.
If (3) is true, either (1) or (2) would be also true.  So (3) is a lie.
If (2) is true, it must be either wages or taxes going up or (1) would be true.  It cannot be wages, making (3) true, so taxes are increasing.
There are other ways of deducing this gloomy news.
Response:
Let  

Wi = a wage increase  Wd = a wage decrease  
Si = a subsidy increase Sd = a subsidy decrease  
Ti = a tax   increase  Td = a tax   decrease  

Exactly one of these six alternatives will be the Minister’s announcement.

The three statements made to the reporters were  

(1) “It’s about subsidies.”      ↔ Si or Sd  
(2) “Nothing is going down.”    ↔ Wi or Si or Ti  
(3) “Either subsidies are going down or there will be a wage increase.”  
                 ↔ Sd or Wi  

Because the Minister tells the truth to reporters once and only once in each group of three successive remarks, exactly one of (1), (2), (3) is true.

Test the six possible announcements:

• Wi : (1) false, (2) true, (3) true  → two truths (reject)  
• Wd : all three false         → no truth (reject)  
• Si : (1) true, (2) true, (3) false → two truths (reject)  
• Sd : (1) true, (2) false, (3) true  → two truths (reject)  
• Ti : (1) false, (2) true, (3) false → exactly one truth (accept)  
• Td : all three false         → no truth (reject)

The only alternative that makes precisely one ministerial statement true is a tax increase (Ti).

Therefore the “logically-minded newshound” could safely headline that the forthcoming announcement is: taxes will be raised.

Final answer: Taxes are going to be increased.

Question: There are 2008 eggs lying in front of you. I am also with you waiting to start the game. The goal of the game is to be the person to take that very last egg (or eggs) to win. You and I can each only take between 1 and 100 eggs at a time. You go first. How many eggs must you take initially in order to always win (assuming we both play perfectly)?
Hint: By a perfect game, that means over any two turns, the sum of the number of eggs  you and I take is the same (except of course, excluding the initial move you make).
Human Solution:
89 eggs.
In order to see this, look at the smallest way possible to guarantee a win; you leave me with 101 eggs. If I take 1 egg, you take all 100; if I take 100 eggs, you take the last one. Therefore you would always win.
If you try with 202, I can take from 1 to 100, so there is 201 to 102 left. Then you would take 100 or 1 egg(s) in order to leave me with 101 again. By simple analysis, you must take 101 eggs over two rounds in order to get down to 101.
19*101 = 1919, so we must take 2008-1919 = 89 eggs to start off with a multiple of 101.
Response:
At each turn a player may take any whole number of eggs from 1 to 100.  
Notice that if after your own turn the pile always contains a multiple of 101 eggs, then whatever your opponent does you can always restore this property:

• Suppose the pile has 101 m eggs (m is a positive integer).  
• Your opponent now removes x eggs, where 1 ≤ x ≤ 100.  
• The pile therefore has 101 m – x eggs left.  
• You can now remove 101 – x eggs (which also lies between 1 and 100), leaving  
 (101 m – x) – (101 – x) = 101 (m – 1) eggs — again a multiple of 101.

Repeating this “complement-to-101” reply after every move of your opponent successively reduces the pile by exactly 101 eggs every two moves.  Eventually the pile reaches 101 eggs when it is your opponent’s turn; whatever number x (1–100) he takes, you respond with 101 – x and take the last eggs.  Hence maintaining “multiples of 101” after your turn is a winning strategy.

Therefore, at the very start you should take just enough eggs to leave a multiple of 101.

2008 ÷ 101 gives remainder 89 (since 101 × 19 = 1919 and 2008 – 1919 = 89).

So remove 89 eggs initially:

2008 – 89 = 1919 = 101 × 19,

a multiple of 101.  After that, always take 101 minus whatever your opponent just took; you are then certain to take the final egg(s) and win.

Final answer: 89

Question:
There are 3 numbers 0-9.
Eric knows the product and says, "I know the numbers."
Then, everyone is told that one digit is exactly one greater than another.
Then, Luke is told one of the numbers and says, "Eric lied."
Then you are told the numbers add up to 11.
What are the numbers?
Hint: There are only so many combinations if two of the digits must be adjacent...
Human Solution:
0, 5, 6
Eric knows the product and claimed that he knows the numbers.
Luke is told a number and then he knows Eric lied.
If Luke had received an 8, the combination could be 8,8,8, which is the only combination that multiplies to 512; Luke wouldn't know Eric lied.
If Luke received 6, the combination could be 6,7,7 which is the only combination that multiplies to 294, so Luke wouldn't know Eric lied.
If Luke received 2 or 7; 2x7x7=98.
4 or 5; 4x5x5=100.
3 or 9; 3x9x9=243.
1; 1x1x1=1.
Luke would only know that Eric lied if Luke was given a 0.
Therefore one of the digits is 0.
The remaining two digits must add to 11 because 11-0=11.
Two of the digits are one apart so that leaves:
0 & 1 + 10
5 & 6 + 0
However, 10 isn't an option so it must be 0, 5, 6.
Response:
Let the three (possibly repeated) digits be a , b , c  (0 ≤ a ≤ b ≤ c ≤ 9).

1.  Eric is given the product P = abc and immediately says  
   “I know the numbers.”  
   For that to be true, P would have to correspond to one and only one triple
   of digits.  
   Luke later calls this a lie, so in fact P is produced by at least two
   different triples.

2.  Before Luke speaks everyone is additionally told that
   “one digit is exactly one greater than another.”
   So among the three digits there is an adjacent pair (k , k+1).

3.  Luke is then told ONE of the digits and at once asserts  
   “Eric lied.”  
   Luke can make this assertion only if, no matter what the other two digits
   are, the product he knows Eric received can **never** be unique.
   Which digits allow that?

   •  If Luke is told 0, the product is 0.  
      Every triple containing a 0 has product 0, so the product is certainly
      not unique and Luke can be sure Eric lied.

   •  If Luke is told 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8 or 9 there **is** some triple
      containing that digit whose product is unique
      (for instance 1,1,2 → 2 ; 4,5,5 → 100 ; 9,9,9 → 729, …), so with any of
      those digits Luke could not be absolutely certain Eric lied.

   Therefore the digit Luke sees must be 0, and consequently one of the three
   digits is 0.

4.  Because the three digits add to 11, the other two must add to 11 as well:
        b + c = 11.  
   They also contain an adjacent pair, so (b , c) has to be (5 , 6).

5.  Hence the only triple satisfying every piece of information is

        0 , 5 , 6  (in any order).

Check:

•  Product 0 –– many different triples give 0, so Eric could not really have
   known the numbers; his claim was indeed false.

•  Digits 5 and 6 differ by 1 –– satisfies the “adjacent” statement.

•  Luke, seeing the 0, knows the product must be 0 and therefore knows Eric
   lied.

•  Sum 0 + 5 + 6 = 11 –– matches the final clue.

All conditions are met.

Final answer: 0, 5 and 6

Question:
What would be the missing letter ?
O Q L H R
I J F E Q
--------------
F G F C ?
Hint: Think mathematically.
Human Solution:
The missing letter is A.
Number the letters in order eg: A=1 B=2 C=3 etc.. then subtract the middle from the top, to give the bottom number. Assign that number to the appropriate letter to give the answer.
Response:
First, convert every letter to its position in the English alphabet (A = 1, B = 2, …, Z = 26).

Row 1:  O  Q  L  H  R   →  15 17 12  8 18  
Row 2:  I  J  F  E  Q   →   9 10  6  5 17  

Now subtract row 2 from row 1 term-by-term:

15 − 9 = 6  
17 − 10 = 7  
12 − 6 = 6  
8 − 5 = 3  
18 − 17 = 1  

These differences must be the numerical values of the letters in row 3:

Row 3 so far:  F  G  F  C  ?  →   6  7  6  3  ?  

The first four already match the computed differences 6, 7, 6, 3.  
The fifth difference is 1, which corresponds to the letter A.

Final answer: A

Question:
A bridge was guarded by an evil troll. The troll was very intelligent, but he was also a coward. He was afraid of anyone smarter than him. So every time anyone tried to cross the bridge, the troll would set up a test. If the traveler passed the test, he would be allowed to cross. Otherwise, the troll would eat him.
Three travelers, Al, Ben and Carl, came across the bridge. The troll told them, "You may only cross my bridge if you know the password." He wrote five three-letter words on a rock. The five words were HOE, OAR, PAD, TOE, and VAT.
He then said, "I will tell each of you a different letter from the password. If you know what the password is, I will let you pass. But don't tell anyone else your letter." He then whispered a letter from the password to each traveler so that neither of the other two could hear him.
Then the troll asked Al, "Do you know what the password is?" "Yes," said Al, and the troll let him pass.
Then the troll asked Ben, "Do you know what the password is?" "Yes," said Ben, and the troll let him pass.
Then the troll asked Carl, "Do you know what the password is?" "Yes," said Carl, and the troll let him pass.
So, what is the password?
Hint:
1. Ben used Al's answer, and Carl used both Al's and Ben's answers.
2. Al's letter could not have been E.
Human Solution:
The password was HOE.
The only letters unique to one of the five words were D, H, P, R, and V. One of these letters must have been Al's, since he could determine the password. The only word without any of these letters is TOE. So the password could not have been TOE.
Ben knew this and now had four words to think of. The only letters unique to one word were D, E, H, P, R, T, and V. The password must have contained at least two unique letters, one for Al and the other for Ben, since they were both able to determine the password. The only word with only one of these letters was OAR. So OAR could not have been the password.
Carl knew this and now had three words to think of. The only letters unique to one word were D, E, H, O, P, T, and V. The password must have included three of these letters, since all three were able to determine the password. The only one of the three words containing three such letters was HOE, so this must have been the password.
Response:
Let  
HOE , OAR , PAD , TOE , VAT  
be the only possible passwords.

Step 1.  What Al’s “Yes’’ tells us  
Al saw one letter and, without hearing anyone else, at once knew the
word.  
That is possible only if the letter he received appears in one and only
one of the five words; otherwise at least two candidate words would have
been left.

Unique letters among the five words are  

H (only in HOE) R (only in OAR) P,D (only in PAD) V (only in VAT)

E is not unique (it is in HOE and TOE), which explains Hint 2: Al did
not get E.  Therefore

Al got one of H, R, P, D or V,  
so at this moment the password could be only

HOE, OAR, PAD or VAT.  
TOE is already impossible.

Step 2.  What Ben’s “Yes’’ tells us  
Ben heard Al say he knew the word and then, using that fact (Hint 1),
could himself deduce the word from the single letter he had.

(a) Ben’s letter cannot be unique.  
If it were unique (H, R, P, D or V), Ben would have known the word even
before Al spoke and would not have
“used Al’s answer.’’

(b) Ben’s letter cannot occur in three words (A or O).  
Even after deleting TOE there would still be at least two possibilities,
so Ben could not have been certain.

Hence Ben’s letter must be one that occurs in exactly two of the five
words.  The only such letters are

E (in HOE and TOE) and T (in TOE and VAT).

But TOE is already excluded, so the two possibilities for Ben are

E → password would have to be HOE, or  
T → password would have to be VAT.

Step 3.  What Carl’s “Yes’’ tells us  
Carl heard both previous replies and used both of them (Hint 1).

Case 1. Suppose Ben had T, so the candidate word is VAT.  
The three letters of VAT are V (unique), A (in three words) and T (the
letter Ben has).

• If Carl had V, he would have known the word immediately without needing
either of the previous answers, contradicting Hint 1.

• So Carl would have A.  
With the letter A he would still face two possibilities besides VAT
(OAR and PAD) that are perfectly compatible with both Al’s and Ben’s
“Yes’’ answers (Al could have got R, P or D; Ben could have got the other
unique letter).  Carl could not be certain, so he could not say “Yes.’’

Therefore VAT is impossible.

Case 2.  Ben had E, so the candidate word is HOE.  
The letters still available are H (unique) and O (in three words).
Al must have had H (the only way he could have known at once).
Consequently Carl has O.

From Carl’s viewpoint the only words containing O are HOE and OAR
(TOE has been ruled out since Al knew the word).  
If the word were OAR, Ben would have had either A (occurs in three words,
so he could not have deduced the word) or O (also occurs in three
words); either way Ben could not have answered “Yes.’’
Therefore OAR is impossible, leaving

HOE as the unique possibility, so Carl can truthfully answer “Yes.’’

All answers are now consistent:

Al received H (unique) → knew HOE immediately.  
Ben received E     → ruled out TOE because Al knew, leaving HOE.  
Carl received O     → ruled out TOE from Al, ruled out OAR from Ben,
                         leaving HOE.

Hence the only password that satisfies every condition and both hints is

HOE.

Final answer: HOE

Question:
In the following code, each symbol stands for one of five letters.
! stands for R, U, O, N, or V
? stands for U, D, L, W, or J
@ stands for A, G, P, E, or Y
; stands for O, M, I, C, or S
The four letter code word, @!;?, can be translated into two English words that are opposites. What are the two words?
Hint: Morality
Human Solution: Good and Evil.
Response: Final answer: GOOD and EVIL

Question: Adam, Ben and Cyril were born in 1309, 1310 and 1311 on the same road in old Jerusalem. They lived their whole life there, and all lived to be over 60. They also had a full active life. However, they never crossed paths with each other. Why should that be so?
Hint: Calendar differences?
Human Solution: Adam was a Muslim, Ben was a Christian and Cyril was a Jew. Adam was born in 1309 of the Muslim calendar, Ben 1310 in the Christian calendar and Cyril 1311 in the Jewish calendar. Cyril was born over 3000 years before Ben, who in turn was born 619 years before Adam.
Response:
Old Jerusalem has always been inhabited by the three great monotheistic communities, and each community keeps its own calendar.

• The Jews date events “Anno Mundi’’ (A M), counting from the (traditional) year of Creation, 3761 BCE.  
• Christians use “Anno Domini’’ (A D), reckoned from the birth of Jesus.  
• Muslims use “Anno Hegirae’’ (A H), counted from Muḥammad’s flight from Mecca in 622 CE; their years are lunar and therefore about  0.97  of a solar year long.

Let us put the three given birth–years into one common (Gregorian/Julian) scale.

1.  Adam – born in 1309 A M  
   Gregorian year  =  1309 – 3761  =  –2452  → 2453 BCE.  

2.  Ben – born in 1310 A D  
   Gregorian year  =  1310 CE.  

3.  Cyril – born in 1311 A H  
   Gregorian year  ≈ 622 + 0.97023 × 1311  
                 ≈ 622 + 1271 ≈ 1893 CE.  
   (1 Muḥarram 1311 A H actually began 10 July 1893.)

Thus the three lifetimes lie about

• 3750 years (Adam → Ben) and  
•   583 years (Ben → Cyril)

apart.  Even though each man “lived to be over 60” and they all lived on the very same street, their lives were separated by centuries or millennia; therefore their paths could never possibly cross.

So the men never met simply because the identical-looking years 1309, 1310 and 1311 belong to three different calendars, not to the same one.

Final answer: The three years are given in three different calendars (Jewish Anno Mundi, Christian Anno Domini, and Muslim Anno Hegirae); converted to the same dating system the births are millennia apart, so the men were never alive at the same time and therefore never crossed paths.

Question:
In the following code, each symbol stands for one of five letters.
* stands for L, T, K, C, or N
) stands for D, O, E, H, or S
+ stands for N, G, I, O, or X
( stands for Y, T, E, P, or F
_ stands for R, B, M, A, or S
The five letter code word, (+_*), can be translated into two English words that are opposites. What are the two words?
Hint: In music...
Human Solution: Forte and Piano.
Response:
The code word (+_*) represents five symbols in the given order  
(   +   _   *   )

For each symbol we have the allowed letters  

(  →  Y, T, E, P, F  
+  →  N, G, I, O, X  
_  →  R, B, M, A, S  
*  →  L, T, K, C, N  
)  →  D, O, E, H, S

Try to find two five-letter English words that are antonyms in a musical context (hint: “In music …”) and whose letters, position by position, belong to the corresponding symbol sets.

Musical dynamic markings give the natural opposite pair

FORTE  (loud) vs. PIANO  (soft)

Verify that each letter of both words respects the symbol restrictions:

Position 1 “(”: F or P (both allowed in ( → Y,T,E,P,F)  
Position 2 “+”: O or I (both allowed in + → N,G,I,O,X)  
Position 3 “_”: R or A (both allowed in _ → R,B,M,A,S)  
Position 4 “*”: T or N (both allowed in * → L,T,K,C,N)  
Position 5 “)”: E or O (both allowed in ) → D,O,E,H,S)

All conditions are satisfied, and “forte” and “piano” are opposite musical terms.

Final answer: FORTE and PIANO

Question:
In the following code, each symbol stands for one of five letters.
- stands for E, O, L, C, or W
= stands for J, K, U, R, or S
* stands for B, O, P, F, or C
+ stands for D, G, I, M, or A
/ stands for F, N, H, E, or R
The five letter code word, */+-=, can be translated into two English words that are opposites. What are the two words?
Hint: Law
Human Solution: Order and Chaos.
Response: Final answer: ORDER and CHAOS

Question:
runway : cinema
answer : ?
Directions: Ratios usually involve numbers.  This word ratio is a little different in that all four words in the ratio are somehow related.  Can you find a word that completes the ratio?
(Note: there is more than one possible answer.)
Hint: Look within the spellings...
Human Solution:
Any 6-letter word with the letters "se" in the middle will complete the word ratio. Possible answers include the words absent, assert, bisect, desert, insect, itself, losers, misery, museum, resent, unseen, wisely, etc.
The middle two letters of each of the words in the ratio represents a direction. The embedded directions relate to the position of the word within the ratio.
ruNWay: ciNEma
anSWer: abSEnt
Response:
Observe the 3rd- and 4th-letter pairs:

runway  →  ru N W ay  contains “NW” (north-west)  
cinema  →  ci N E ma  contains “NE” (north-east)

Thus the first two words hide the two northerly compass directions.  
For the ratio runway : cinema :: answer : ?, the word answer already hides the south-westerly direction:

answer  →  an S W er  contains “SW”

So the missing word must hide the remaining compass direction “SE”.  
Any word with the consecutive letters “SE” in the 3rd and 4th positions will work. One convenient choice is

deSErt

d e S E r t  (“SE” appears in exactly the right place).

Therefore a valid completion of the ratio is:

runway : cinema :: answer : desert

Question:
John, Paul, George, and Ringo were playing a card game. Each player had three cards, one of the four suits was the "high suit." When each player played one card, this was a "trick." The first card played in a trick was the "leading suit." Here are the cards in each man's hand:
John: club, heart, diamond
Paul: club, spade, spade
George: club, heart, heart
Ringo: spade, diamond, diamond
If possible, each player had to play the leading suit for each trick. If they couldn't do that, they had to play the high suit. And if they couldn't do that, they could play any card. A player who won a trick had to lead the next trick. Each of the three tricks consisted of the leading card, exactly one other card of the same suit, exactly one card of the high suit which won its player the trick, and exactly one other card. Which suit was the high suit?
Hint:
This makes the puzzle too easy. Please stop reading if you don't want it to be too easy.
Lucy in the sky with...
Human Solution:
The high suit is diamonds.
The first trick obviously required two cards of the leading suit, and since everyone had to play the leading suit if possible, there had to be two people who had at least one card of the first leading suit. But since John, Paul, and George each had a club, the first leading suit could not have been a club.
If the first leading suit was a heart, then the high suit had to be a card of which only one of Paul and Ringo had. This means it could only have been a club or a diamond. Similarly, if the first leading suit was a spade, the high suit could only have been a diamond, and if the leading suit was a diamond, the high suit could only have been a heart or a spade.
If the first leading suit was a heart, the second trick was led by either Paul or Ringo, and the leading suit had to be a spade. If the first leading suit was a spade, the second trick was led by John, and the leading suit could have been a club or a heart. If the first leading suit was a diamond, the second trick was led by either Paul or George, and the leading suit was a club. Now we can deduce the six possible leading suits and high suits for the whole game:
1. heart, heart, club
spade, spade, club
diamond, diamond, club
2. heart, heart, diamond
spade, spade, diamond
club, club, diamond
3. spade, spade, diamond
club, club, diamond
heart, heart, diamond
4. spade, spade, diamond
heart, heart, diamond
club, club, diamond
5. diamond, diamond, heart
club, club, heart
spade, spade, heart
6. diamond, diamond, spade
club, club, spade
heart, heart, spade
Game 1 cannot be possible because Paul would have led the spade and John and George would both have played a club, making two cards of the high suit. Games 5 and 6 cannot be possible because no one had both hearts and spades. This leaves only games 2, 3, and 4, which all have diamonds as the high suit.
Response:
Let the unknown high-suit be T (for “trump”).  
During every trick we must have  

• exactly 2 cards of the leading suit  
• exactly 1 card of the high suit T, which wins the trick  
• exactly 1 card of a third suit.  

Because any player who possesses the leading suit is obliged to follow, the
number of players that still hold that suit at the moment it is led must be
exactly two.  
Keep that fact in mind while we test every suit as the possible high suit.

1.  Assume clubs are high.  
   After the first trick has been completed there will still be three
   different non-trump suits that can be led.  One of those three suits must
   be spades.  
   When spades are led Paul and Ringo (the only two players who have spades)
   are forced to follow, while John and George, unable to follow, must both
   play trump (clubs).  Two clubs would appear in that one trick, contradicting
   “exactly one high-suit card.”  Hence clubs cannot be high.

2.  Assume hearts are high.  
   Sooner or later some trick must be led with spades (the only suit that is
   not a trump and is not duplicated as a leading suit).  When spades are led,
   John and George cannot follow and therefore must both play hearts, again
   giving two high-suit cards in one trick.  Therefore hearts cannot be high.

3.  Assume spades are high.  
   This time some trick must be led with hearts.  Paul and Ringo are the only
   players who have spades; both lack hearts, so both of them would have to
   play spades when hearts are led, producing two trump cards in the same
   trick – impossible.  Thus spades cannot be high.

Because clubs, hearts and spades are all impossible, the high suit must be
diamonds.  To see that diamonds really does work, one legal sequence of play
is shown below (J = John, P = Paul, G = George, R = Ringo; the leading card of
each trick is written first).

Trick 1 (lead ♥ by John):  
J ♥ G ♥ P ♠ R ♦  (one ♦, two ♥, one other) – R wins.

Trick 2 (lead ♠ by Ringo):  
R ♠ P ♠ J ♦ G ♣  (one ♦, two ♠, one other) – J wins.

Trick 3 (lead ♣ by John):  
J ♣ P ♣ G ♥ R ♦  (one ♦, two ♣, one other) – R wins.

Every rule is obeyed and every hand is exhausted, so diamonds can indeed be
the high suit and no other suit can.

Final answer: diamonds

Question:
Mad Ade sat at home, waiting for his favourite TV program "I'm a celebrity, Get me a Kebab" to start. He glanced at his clock and began to wonder strange and wondrous things, but that is another story altogether.
He realised that he could leave 6 adjacent numbers of the face of a clock intact and rearrange the other 6 in such a way that the sum of every pair of adjacent numbers is prime.
Unfortunately the TV program started at that point so he never actually got around to doing it. Can you find the two possible solutions to Mad Ade's clock teaser?
Hint: Part of it is making sure each number is odd...
Human Solution:
Imagining the number on a clock face in a clockwise order they would be
1 2 3 4 7 10 9 8 5 6 11 12
Or
1 2 3 4 9 10 7 6 5 8 11 12
Response:
Step 1 ‑ Why every neighbouring pair must be “odd + even”.  
The only primes that can occur as the sum of two different clock numbers (1-12) are the odd primes  
3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17, 19, 23.  
A sum is odd exactly when one addend is even and the other is odd; hence every pair of adjacent
numbers on the finished clock must consist of one even and one odd number.  
Thus the whole dial must read                        odd, even, odd, even, … all the way round.  
(This already alternates in the natural order 1-2-3-4-…-12.)

Step 2 ‑ Which six consecutive numbers may we keep?  
Let ei be the edge joining i and i+1 (mod 12).  Compute the original sums:  

e1  (1+2)=3  prime  
e2  (2+3)=5  prime  
e3  (3+4)=7  prime  
e4  (4+5)=9  NOT prime  
e5  (5+6)=11 prime  
e6  (6+7)=13 prime  
e7  (7+8)=15 NOT prime  
e8  (8+9)=17 prime  
e9  (9+10)=19 prime  
e10 (10+11)=21 NOT prime  
e11 (11+12)=23 prime  
e12 (12+1)=13 prime  

Any block of six consecutive, unchanged numbers contains five interior edges; every one of those
five sums must already be prime, so none of the interior edges may be
e4, e7, e10.  
A length-6 block starting at vertex k contains the edges
ek, ek+1, …, ek+4 (indices mod 12).
Testing k = 1,2,…,12 shows that the ONLY starting point that avoids
e4, e7, e10 is k = 11.  
Hence the six numbers that must stay where they are are

11, 12, 1, 2, 3, 4                                                     (†)

and all their interior sums are already prime.

Step 3 ‑ What remains to be placed?  
The movable positions are 5,6,7,8,9,10.  
They must still alternate parity:

pos 5 (odd), pos 6 (even), pos 7 (odd), pos 8 (even),  
pos 9 (odd), pos 10 (even).

So the three odd numbers 5,7,9 must occupy 5,7,9 and the three evens
6,8,10 must occupy 6,8,10 in some order.

Step 4 ‑ The prime‐sum graph (allowed adjacencies)

Odd → Even        Even → Odd  
1 : 2,4,6,10,12    2 : 1,3,5,9,11  
3 : 2,4,8,10       4 : 1,3,7,9,11  
5 : 6,8            6 : 1,3,5,7,11  
7 : 4,6,10,12      8 : 1,3,5,9,11  
9 : 4,8,10         10: 1,3,7,9  
11: 2,6,8,12       12: 1,5,7,11  

(Only the connections involving 4,5,6,7,8,9,10,11 are relevant.)

Step 5 ‑ Boundary conditions
• 4 + pos 5 must be prime ⇒ pos 5 ≠ 5 (4+5=9); so pos 5 = 7 or 9.  
• pos 10 + 11 must be prime ⇒ pos 10 ≠ 10 (10+11=21); so pos 10 = 6 or 8.

Step 6 ‑ Construct the two possibilities

Case A   pos 5 = 7

4+7 = 11 (prime)  
7 must be followed by an even linked to 7 → {6,10}.  

A1  …6… forces 5 next (6+5 prime) but then 5→8 and 9→10 fails at the
boundary, so impossible.

A2  …10… gives  

pos 5  7  
pos 6 10  
pos 7  9  (10+9 prime)  
pos 8  8  (9+8 prime)  
pos 9  5  (8+5 prime)  
pos 10 6  (5+6 prime and 6+11 prime)  

This is consistent, giving the first arrangement

1 2 3 4 7 10 9 8 5 6 11 12.

Case B   pos 5 = 9  

4+9 = 13 (prime)  
9 must be followed by 8 or 10.

B1  …8… leads to a dead end at the boundary (pos 10 would be 10).  

B2  …10… gives  

pos 5  9  
pos 6 10  
pos 7  7  (10+7 prime)  
pos 8  6  (7+6 prime)  
pos 9  5  (6+5 prime)  
pos 10 8  (5+8 prime and 8+11 prime)  

All conditions are satisfied, yielding the second arrangement

1 2 3 4 9 10 7 6 5 8 11 12.

Step 7 ‑ Verification
For each arrangement every one of the twelve neighbouring sums equals

3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17, 19 or 23 – all prime.

Hence these two are the only possible clocks.

Final answer:  
Clockwise round the dial the numbers can read  

Solution 1  : 12-1-2-3-4-7-10-9-8-5-6-11  
Solution 2  : 12-1-2-3-4-9-10-7-6-5-8-11

Question: There are 10 people who could be the owner of the bank. They all sit in separate chairs across a long table facing north. The table is made of aluminium. The owner of the bank sits next to M. M sits on the left side of the banker. M sits next to C. C sits 4 places to the left of L. L sits next to O and rarely talks to S, E or Z, because they hate him and because they sit on the far right of the bank. O does not sit next to the owner of the bank. The two people left are F and T. T hates the owner of the bank and is considering resigning. Give the names of all the bankers from left to right.
Hint: Think from the banker's point of view and draw a diagram.
Human Solution: TCMBFLOSEZ.
Response:
Let the ten seats be numbered 1 (extreme left) through 10 (extreme right).  
Everyone is facing north, so “to the left of’’ means “in the direction of the smaller-numbered seats’’ and “next to’’ means “in consecutive seats.’’  
The ten people are  
M , C , L , O , S , E , Z , F , T and the owner (call him B for “banker’’).

1.  “The owner sits next to M and M sits on the left side of the banker’’  
 ⇒ the block (C) M B must occur in that order and in consecutive seats; C is on the left of M because M’s right-hand seat is already occupied by B.

2.  “C sits 4 places to the left of L’’  
 ⇒ if C is in seat i, then L is in seat i+4.

3.  “L sits next to O’’ and “O is not next to the banker’’  
 ⇒ O is on the right of L (otherwise O would be beside B).  
 Hence, with C in seat i we have  

  seat i    i+1   i+2   i+3   i+4   i+5  
   C     M    B    ?    L    O

4.  Seats i through i+5 must lie inside the row 1…10, so i ≤ 5.

5.  “S, E and Z … sit on the far right of the bank’’  
 ⇒ they occupy the three extreme right–hand seats 8, 9 and 10 (in some order).  
 Because of this, L may not be in seat 7 (otherwise L would be next to one of them, contradicting ‘rarely talks to S, E or Z’).  
 Hence L cannot be in seat 7, so i ≠ 3.  
 Therefore i = 1 or 2.

6.  The two values of i give

 i = 1 : 1 C 2 M 3 B 4 ? 5 L 6 O 7 ? 8 9 10  
 i = 2 : 1 ? 2 C 3 M 4 B 5 ? 6 L 7 O 8 9 10

7.  The only people still unseated are F and T (besides S,E,Z at 8,9,10).

 •  T “hates the owner’’; we interpret this as T not sitting next to B.  
    Consequently T cannot occupy a seat adjacent to seat 3 (in the first layout) or seat 4 (in the second).

 •  In the first layout seat 4 is adjacent to B, so seat 4 must be F and seat 7 is T.  
 •  In the second layout seat 5 is adjacent to B, so seat 5 must be F and seat 1 is T.

 Finally we have two candidates

 (i) C M B F L O T S E Z  
 (ii) T C M B F L O S E Z

 Layout (ii) puts L only two seats away from S/E/Z and therefore not “far’’ from them, while layout (i) leaves at least three seats and matches the description “rarely talks to S, E or Z”.  
 Thus (i) is the only arrangement fully consistent with every statement.

Seats 1 → 10 (left to right):

C , M , B , F , L , O , T , S , E , Z

Final answer: C M B F L O T S E Z

Question: You and your spouse invite four other couples to a party. During the course of the conversation, it is discovered that, prior to the party, each person except you was acquainted with a different number of the people present. Assuming the acquaintance relationship is symmetric (i.e., if you are acquainted with someone, that person is also acquainted with you), then how many people did your spouse know prior to the party? How many people did you know?
Hint: Start with the assumption that everybody knows their own spouses -- which means that everybody there knew at least one person.
Human Solution:
Start with the assumption that everybody knows their own spouses -- which means that everybody there knew at least one person. Discounting yourself, everyone knows a different number of people, which means that (again, discounting yourself) one person knows one, one person knows two, one person knows three, etc., up to one person who knows nine people (everybody else). Number the people (besides yourself) according to how many people they know, so that person 1 is the one who knows one person, person 2 is the one who knows two people, etc.
Now pair up people with their spouses. If person 9 knows everybody else, s/he must be the only person who knows person 1, because person 1 only knows one person. So they must be married. Person 8 knows everybody except for person 1. Person 2 therefore knows person 8 and person 9. Person 9 is married to person 1, so person 2's spouse must be person 8. Person 7 knows everybody except for persons 1 and 2. Person 3 therefore knows persons 7, 8, and 9. Persons 8 and 9 are married to persons 2 and 1 respectively, so person 3's spouse must be person 7. Person 6 knows everybody except for persons 1, 2, and 3. Person 4 therefore knows persons 6, 7, 8, and 9. The only one of those not yet paired up is person 6, so person 4 and person 6 must be married.
This leaves person 5, who knows everyone except persons 1, 2, 3, and 4. These five people, therefore, must be persons 6, 7, 8, 9, and you. Since you are the only one of these five not yet paired up, person 5 must be your spouse. So your spouse knew five people prior to the party.
The above also determines that the people who know you are persons 5, 6, 7, 8, and 9. So you knew five people prior to the party also.
Response: Final answer:  Your spouse had been acquainted with 5 of the other people, and so had you – each of you knew exactly 5 people before the party.

Question:
Nick has always wanted one, so he goes out and buys a brand new one for £5000.  Unfortunately the next day he breaks it, so he goes out again and gets another brand new one. This time however, it only costs him £25. The next day someone offers to buy it off of him for £6000.
What is it ?
Human Solution: A personalised number plate.
Response:
A personalised vehicle registration (number-plate).

Explanation  
• Nick pays £5000 to the DVLA for the right to the new registration mark he has always wanted.  
• The next day he accidentally snaps the actual plastic/aluminium plate on the car, so he orders a brand-new pair of plates showing the same mark for about £25.  
• Someone who likes the number-plate more than Nick then offers him £6000 for the right to that registration.

Thus the “one” that costs £5000 when first bought, £25 when merely replaced after being broken, and can later be sold for £6000 is a personalised car number-plate.

Question:
Four friends named Jane, June, Jean and Jenny discovered that, if a different non-zero integer was assigned to each letter of their names and added together, it produced their ages.
June is 17, Jenny is two years older, while Jane and Jean are both sweet 16.  All the girls agree that June is in her prime.  Can you find the numbers the girls assigned to each letter of their names?
(There are two possible answers.)
Hint: prime...
Human Solution:
J=2; U=7; N=5; E=3; A=6; Y=4
or
J=3; U=7; N=5; E=2; A=6; Y=4
The little clue 'June is in her prime' should have helped, as it suggests that all the numbers in her name are prime numbers.  As the total is 17 all the numbers must be less than 10, so:
J=2; U=7; N=5; E=3  (or J=3; U=7; N=5; E=2)
Setting these numbers in the word Jane or Jean we can conclude that
16=2+A+5+3, so A=6.
Putting these numbers in the word Jenny in the same way we find Y=4.
Response:
Let a different non–zero integer be attached to every distinct letter that appears in the four names  

  J, A, N, E, U, Y .  

Call these numbers J, A, N, E, U, Y respectively.  
The ages translate into the three equations  

(1) J + A + N + E = 16     (Jane = Jean = 16)  
(2) J + U + N + E = 17     (June = 17)  
(3) J + E + N + N + Y = 19   (Jenny = 19)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  The easy consequences of (1) and (2)

Subtract (1) from (2):

  U – A = 1         (4)

Hence U = A + 1.  In particular A and U are consecutive integers.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  Why J, U, N, E must be the four smallest primes

The girls remark that “June is in her prime”.  
We interpret that literally: every letter in the name “June” – i.e. J, U, N, E – is a prime number.  
Because they are different letters, the four primes must be distinct and must add to 17 (June’s age by (2)).

The only set of four different primes whose sum is 17 is  

  2, 3, 5, 7.  

Consequently {J, U, N, E} = {2, 3, 5, 7}.  

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  Finding A from U = A + 1

Two of the four primes have to take the rôle of U (and therefore of A = U – 1).

• If U = 2, then A = 1;  
• If U = 3, then A = 2  (but 2 is already being used, impossible);  
• If U = 5, then A = 4;  
• If U = 7, then A = 6.

So only the three possibilities  

  (U, A) = (2,1), (5,4), (7,6)

survive up to now.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  Using Jenny’s age

Rewrite (3) with S = J + E + N (so that S + A = 16 by (1)):

  S + N + Y = 19 ⟹ Y = 19 – (S + N).

But S = 16 – A, hence  

  Y = 3 + A – N.        (5)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
5.  Case–wise elimination

a) U = 5, A = 4.  
The remaining three primes are 2, 3, 7.  
To have J + E + N = 12 we can choose N = 2, 3 or 7.

 • N=2 ⇒ Y = 3 + 4 – 2 = 5 (clashes with U = 5).  
 • N=3 ⇒ Y = 4 (clashes with A = 4).  
 • N=7 ⇒ Y = 0  (0 is forbidden).

Hence no solution exists when U = 5.

b) U = 2, A = 1.  
The remaining primes are 3, 5, 7.

 • N = 3 gives Y = 4 – 3 = 1  (clashes with A).  
 • N = 5 gives Y = 4 – 5 = −1  (allowed).  
 • N = 7 gives Y = 4 – 7 = −3  (allowed).

Only N = 5 or 7 works.  Taking N = 5 and (J, E) = (3, 7) (or 7, 3) we obtain

  J = 3, A = 1, N = 5, E = 7, U = 2, Y = −1.   (Answer I)

(The choice N = 7 merely exchanges the roles of the two unused primes 3 and 5 and
changes Y to −3; that leaves every name–sum unchanged, so it is not counted as a new
answer.)

c) U = 7, A = 6.  
The remaining primes are 2, 3, 5.

 • N = 2 gives Y = 9 – 2 = 7  (clashes with U).  
 • N = 3 gives Y = 6  (clashes with A).  
 • N = 5 gives Y = 4  (distinct and non–zero).

So N must be 5, and J, E are 2 and 3 in either order, giving

  J = 2, A = 6, N = 5, E = 3, U = 7, Y = 4.   (Answer II)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
6.  Verification of the two solutions

Answer I (J, A, N, E, U, Y) = (3, 1, 5, 7, 2, −1)

 Jane = 3 + 1 + 5 + 7 = 16  
 Jean = 3 + 1 + 5 + 7 = 16  
 June = 3 + 2 + 5 + 7 = 17  
 Jenny = 3 + 7 + 5 + 5 − 1 = 19

Answer II (J, A, N, E, U, Y) = (2, 6, 5, 3, 7, 4)

 Jane = 2 + 6 + 5 + 3 = 16  
 Jean = 2 + 6 + 5 + 3 = 16  
 June = 2 + 7 + 5 + 3 = 17  
 Jenny = 2 + 3 + 5 + 5 + 4 = 19

Every letter has a different non–zero integer and all the conditions are met.  
No other assignments are possible, so the puzzle really has exactly two solutions.

Final answer:  
I. J = 3, A = 1, N = 5, E = 7, U = 2, Y = −1  
II. J = 2, A = 6, N = 5, E = 3, U = 7, Y = 4

Question: Some office workers were holding a daily pool on the number of doughnuts their boss would eat each weekday morning during March. Each person set aside funds in their desk with which to bet.
