Each day from Monday, March 3rd, they all bet a dollar - Kevin bet on 2, Kate on 3 and Kathy on 3.5 doughnuts. Kathy won twice as many times as Kevin, who was right once more than Kate; sometimes there was no winner. By April, they all had $20 in their desks. How much was the most anyone could have had in their desk at the beginning of March?
Hint: The pot does not accumulate if there is no winner - each person gets his "stake" back.
Human Solution:
$27
There would be 21 working days in a March where the first weekday is the third.  The combination of wins in which anyone will have lost the most money has a total of 19 wins (10 for Kathy, 5 for Kevin and 4 for Kate).  In this scenario, Kate would have lost 15 times ($15) and won 4 times ($8), for a net loss of $7.  Since she now has $20, she must have started with $27.
Response:
Let  

x = times Kevin guessed correctly  
y = times Kate guessed correctly  
z = times Kathy guessed correctly  
T = number of betting days in March.

1.  How many betting days?  
   From Monday 3 March through Monday 31 March there are 21 weekdays,  
   so T = 21.

2.  Relations among x, y, z.  
   • “Kathy won twice as many times as Kevin’’   ⇒   z = 2x.  
   • “Kevin was right once more than Kate’’      ⇒   x = y + 1.  

   Hence     z = 2(y + 1) = 2y + 2.

3.  Winner-days and no-winner days.  
   Let W = x + y + z be the days that had a winner.  
   Substituting,  W = (y + 1) + y + (2y + 2) = 4y + 3.  
   Since W ≤ 21, 4y + 3 ≤ 21  ⇒  y ≤ 4.  
   Thus y ∈ {0,1,2,3,4}.

4.  Net dollar change for each player.

   Each day every person puts $1 in the pot.  
   • If that person wins: he gets $3 back (net +$2).  
   • If someone else wins: he loses his stake (net –$1).  
   • If nobody wins: stake is returned (net $0).

   For any player  
        Δ = 2·(wins) – 1·(days someone else wins)  
          = 3·(wins) – W.

   Therefore,
        ΔKevin  = 3x – W = 3(y+1) – (4y+3) = –y
        ΔKate   = 3y – W  = 3y – (4y+3)    = –y – 3
        ΔKathy  = 3z – W  = 3(2y+2) – (4y+3)= 2y + 3.

5.  Initial desk amounts.

   Everyone finished with $20, so  

        I_Kevin = 20 – ΔKevin = 20 + y
        I_Kate  = 20 – ΔKate  = 23 + y
        I_Kathy = 20 – ΔKathy = 17 – 2y.

   (Note: I_Kathy ≥ 0 automatically for y ≤ 4.)

6.  Maximizing an initial amount.

   Evaluate 23 + y (Kate’s initial cash) for the admissible y:

        y = 0  →  I_Kate = 23
        y = 1  →  I_Kate = 24
        y = 2  →  I_Kate = 25
        y = 3  →  I_Kate = 26
        y = 4  →  I_Kate = 27

   For each y, Kevin starts with 20 + y (≤ 24) and Kathy with 17 – 2y (≤ 17), so Kate’s amount is always the largest.  The greatest of these is $27, obtained when y = 4 (then x = 5, z = 10, and there are 2 days with no winner).  A feasible day-by-day sequence can clearly be arranged (Kathy wins on 10 of the 19 winner-days, etc.), so $27 can indeed occur.

Hence the greatest amount anyone could have had in the desk at the start of March is $27.

Final answer: 27

Question:
When world-famous Madadian philosopher Torks G'Arbage was imprisoned for being a disturbing influence and relieving himself in a public place, he was held in high esteem by his guards, many of whom had followed Torks' teachings. All four of the guards hoped that something would occur that would facilitate his escape. One evening, the guard who was on duty accidentally on purpose left the cell door open so that Torks G'Arbage could leave for distant parts.
Torks G'Arbage did not attempt to escape, as it was his philosophy that if you accept society's rules, you must also accept its punishments. However, the open door was considered by the Madadian authorities to be a serious matter. It was not clear which guard was on that evening. When questioned, the four guards made the following statements in their defence:
Norris McDim:
A) I did not leave the door open.
B) Morris was the one who did it.
Nobby Shifty:
A) I was not the one who was on duty that evening.
B) Norris was on duty.
Morris the Daft:
A) Nobby was the one on duty that evening.
B) I hoped Torks G'Arbage would escape.
Robby O'Mental:
A) I did not leave the door open.
B) I was not surprised that Torks G'Arbage did not attempt to escape.
Considering that, in total, three statements are true and five statements are false, which guard is guilty?
Hint: For each person, assume they did it. Count how many truthful statements there are?
Human Solution:
Robby left the door open.
The one truth given is that all 4 guards hoped that Torks G'Arbage would escape, so statement B from Morris is a truth.
There are only 3 truthful statements.
If Norris had done it, then Nobby made 2 truthful statements and Robby's statement A would be true; making a total of 4 truths, so it can't be Norris.
If Nobby had done it, statement A from Norris would be true, both of Morris's statements would be true, and Robby's statement A would be true; again a total of 4, so it can't be Nobby.
If Morris had left the cell open, both of Norris's statements would be true, as would Nobby's statement A, Morris's statement B, and Robby's statement A; a total of 5 truths.
In Robby's case, in detail:
Norris A True
B False
Nobby A True
B False
Morris A False
B True
Dave A False
B False (why did he bother to leave the
cell door open?)
Response:
Let the guard who was on duty that evening (and who therefore left the cell door open) be denoted by G.  
For every guard we list his two statements, write each in terms of G, and then count how many of the eight total statements become true.

Statements

1. Norris McDim  
A. G ≠ Norris  
B. G = Morris  

2. Nobby Shifty  
A. G ≠ Nobby  
B. G = Norris  

3. Morris the Daft  
A. G = Nobby  
B. “I hoped Torks would escape.”   (The story tells us all four guards hoped this, so this statement is always true.)

4. Robby O’Mental  
A. G ≠ Robby  
B. “I was not surprised that Torks did not try to escape.” (Its truth is not fixed by the story; it may be either true or false.)

Exactly three of the eight statements are true.  
Examine the four possible choices for G.

-------------------------------------------------
1.  Assume G = Norris.

True statements:  
Nobby A, Nobby B, Morris B, Robby A → 4 true  
(Already exceeds 3.)  Impossible.

-------------------------------------------------
2.  Assume G = Nobby.

True statements:  
Norris A, Morris A, Morris B, Robby A → 4 true  
Impossible.

-------------------------------------------------
3.  Assume G = Morris.

True statements:  
Norris A, Norris B, Nobby A, Morris B, Robby A → 5 true  
Impossible.

-------------------------------------------------
4.  Assume G = Robby.

True statements so far:  
Norris A, Nobby A, Morris B → 3 true  
False statements so far:  
Norris B, Nobby B, Morris A, Robby A → 4 false  

Robby B remains.  
• If Robby B were true, we would have 4 true statements, contradicting the condition.  
• Therefore Robby B must be false, leaving the tally at exactly 3 true and 5 false.

This is the only assignment that satisfies the required 3-to-5 split.

Hence G = Robby O’Mental; he was the guard on duty and the one who left the door open.

Final answer: Robby O’Mental

Question:
John, Pete, Tom, George, and Steve are brothers. One day, one of them broke a window. When their father asked them who did it, they gave the following answers:
John: "It was Pete or Tom."
Pete: "It was neither George nor me."
Tom: "Both of you are lying."
Steve: "No, only one of them is lying."
George: "No, Steve, you are wrong."
Then their mother added: "Three of my sons are telling the truth, but I do not believe what the two others said."
Who broke the window?
Hint: If you find it difficult to use logic alone, then use trial and error by assuming each one of the five sons broke the window, and list whether they are telling a lie or the truth.
Human Solution: By assuming that each of the five brothers broke the window and seeing how many told the truth, only Tom can be the person who broke the window.
Response:
Let B be the brother who actually broke the window and let  

J, P, T, S, G denote, respectively, the statements made by John, Pete, Tom, Steve, and George.

1.  Write every statement in logical form.

   John (J): B = Pete ∨ B = Tom.  
   Pete (P): B ≠ George ∧ B ≠ Pete.  
   Tom  (T): John is lying ∧ Pete is lying.  
   Steve (S): Exactly one of John, Pete is lying.  
   George (G): Steve is lying.

2.  Translate the last two quickly:

   • “Exactly one of John, Pete is lying” means  
     S is true ⇔ (J is true) ⊕ (P is true).  
   • “Steve is lying” means  
     G is true ⇔ S is false, so G and S always have opposite truth values.

3.  Use the mother’s information.

   Mother: “Three of my sons are telling the truth and two are lying.”  
   Therefore among the five truth-values J, P, T, S, G we must have exactly three TRUE and two FALSE.

   Because S and G are opposite, one of them is TRUE and the other FALSE.  
   Hence we still need exactly two TRUE statements among J, P, T and exactly one FALSE there.

4.  Analyse the possibilities for J, P, T.

   Case 1 (S is true, G is false).  
   Then J and P must have opposite truth values (definition of S).  
   But only one of J, P can be false and T must supply the second truth.  
   Try the two possibilities:

        (a)  J true, P false, T true:   
             For T to be true, both J and P must be lying – impossible because J is true.  
        (b)  J false, P true, T true:   
             For T to be true, both J and P must be lying – impossible because P is true.

   So Case 1 is impossible.

   Case 2 (S is false, G is true).  
   Then J and P have the same truth value.  
   We still need exactly two TRUE statements among J, P, T.  
   The only way is

        J true, P true, T false.

5.  Determine who broke the window under those truth values.

   From J (true): B = Pete or Tom.  
   From P (true): B ≠ George and B ≠ Pete.  
   Combining them forces B = Tom.

   Check the remaining statements:

   • Tom: “Both John and Pete are lying.” — false (indeed T is false).  
   • Steve: “Exactly one of John, Pete is lying.” — false (both tell the truth).  
   • George: “Steve is wrong.” — true.

   Thus the truth pattern is  
   (J, P, T, S, G) = (T, T, F, F, T), giving precisely three truths and two lies as Mother said.

The pattern is consistent and unique, so there is only one culprit.

Final answer: Tom

Question: A telephone number has the form ABC-DEF-GHIJ, where each letter represents a different digit. The digits in each part of the number are in decreasing order; that is, ABC, DEF, and GHIJ. Furthermore, D, E, and F are consecutive even digits; G, H, I, and J are consecutive odd digits; and A+B+C=9. What is A?
Hint: The consecutive even digits DEF can be 420, 642 or 864, while the consecutive odd digits GHIJ can be 7531 or 9753.
Human Solution:
The consecutive even digits DEF can be 420, 642 or 864, while the consecutive odd digits GHIJ can be 7531 or 9753.
Since A+B+C=9, none of them can be 9, and GHIJ must be 9753, and one of A, B, C is 1.
The other two add up to 8, which is obtained by 8+0.
Therefore, A, the biggest number of the three, is 8.
Response:
Because every letter represents a different digit, the ten digits 0–9 are used exactly once.

1.  The middle block DEF must consist of three consecutive even digits written in decreasing order.  
    From the hint, the only possibilities are  
          864,   642,   420.

2.  The last block GHIJ must consist of four consecutive odd digits written in decreasing order.  
    From the hint, the only possibilities are  
          9753,  7531.

3.  Seven digits are fixed once we choose DEF and GHIJ.  
    The remaining three unused digits, written in decreasing order, form ABC, and they must satisfy  
          A + B + C = 9.

We examine each possible pair (DEF , GHIJ):

• DEF = 864, GHIJ = 9753 → unused digits {0,1,2}.  
  Sum = 0+1+2 = 3 ≠ 9.  Reject.

• DEF = 864, GHIJ = 7531 → unused digits {0,2,9}.  
  Sum = 0+2+9 = 11 ≠ 9. Reject.

• DEF = 642, GHIJ = 9753 → unused digits {0,1,8}.  
  Sum = 0+1+8 = 9.  Accept.  
  Written in decreasing order these digits give ABC = 810, which indeed has 8>1>0.

• DEF = 642, GHIJ = 7531 → unused digits {0,8,9}.  
  Sum = 0+8+9 = 17 ≠ 9. Reject.

• DEF = 420, GHIJ = 9753 → unused digits {1,6,8}.  
  Sum = 1+6+8 = 15 ≠ 9. Reject.

• DEF = 420, GHIJ = 7531 → unused digits {6,8,9}.  
  Sum = 6+8+9 = 23 ≠ 9. Reject.

The only viable combination is

      ABC-DEF-GHIJ = 810-642-9753.

Thus the first digit A is 8.

Final answer: 8

Question: I have 3 dads and 4 sisters. My immediate family (living in my house) consists of 7. Two of my sisters only have 2 dads. How is this possible?
Hint: My nephew lives with me and I'm the middle child.
Human Solution: I have a biological dad, who I don't know. An adopted dad- my sisters' dad and a step dad- who lives with me. My two younger sisters never knew my biological dad. My oldest sister (19) lives by herself. Her son lives with me, my 3 other sisters, my mom, and step dad.
Response:
One (and the most economical) way to satisfy every sentence is to let all five children have the same mother but different combinations of fathers because the mother has been married three different times and none of her former husbands ever left the children’s lives.

People (in birth order)

1.  Sister A – born while Mum was married to Husband 1  
2.  Sister B – born while Mum was still married to Husband 1  
3.  “Me”   – born while Mum was married to Husband 2   ← middle child  
4.  Sister C – born while Mum was married to Husband 2  
5.  Sister D – born while Mum is married to Husband 3  
    (Sister A already has a small son – my nephew.)

The marriages

•  First Mum married Husband 1.  
   They had the two oldest girls (Sister A and Sister B) and then divorced.  
   Husband 1 never stopped seeing any of the children, so they still call him Dad.

•  Mum next married Husband 2.  
   Husband 2 adopted the two older girls, then he and Mum had two more
   children – me (the middle one) and Sister C.  
   This couple also divorced, but Husband 2, like Husband 1, remained closely
   involved with every child, so all five children call him Dad as well.

•  Finally Mum married Husband 3, with whom she had the youngest girl,
   Sister D.  Husband 3 is still married to Mum and lives in the house,
   and of course all five children call him Dad too.

How the numbers in the question are met

•  I have 3 dads:  
   – my own father (Husband 2)  
   – my mother’s first husband (Husband 1), who adopted me and whom I have
     known all my life  
   – my mother’s present husband (Husband 3)

•  4 sisters:  A, B (older than I), C, D (younger than I).

•  Two of my sisters only have 2 dads:  
  – Sister C (her father is Husband 2, her step-dad is Husband 3)  
  – Sister D (her father is Husband 3, her step-dad is Husband 2)

  (Each of the two eldest girls, A and B, has three dads – their own father
  plus Husbands 2 and 3 – so only two sisters have exactly two.)

•  People actually living in the house (the “immediate family of 7”) are  
   Mum, Husband 3, myself, Sister C, Sister D, Sister A and Sister A’s baby
   (my nephew).  7 persons in all.

•  I am indeed the third of five children, so I am the middle child, and my
   eldest sister’s little boy is the nephew who lives with us.

Thus every numerical statement in the riddle is fulfilled without any
contradiction: the situation is simply that all five children share one
mother, but their mother has had three husbands who have all remained “dad”
figures for the children.

Question:
There are three brothers: Al, Ben, and Carl. Two of the three brothers are boxers. Here are some facts:
1. The shorter of Al and Ben is the older boxer.
2. The younger of Ben and Carl is the shorter boxer.
3. The taller of Al and Carl is the younger boxer.
Which brother is not a boxer?
Hint: Try to come up with a potential ordering of their heights and ages.
Human Solution:
Carl is not a boxer.
From fact 1, we know that Carl is not the older boxer.
From fact 3, we know that Ben is not the younger boxer.
We now have three possible scenarios:
1. Al is the younger boxer and Ben is the older boxer.
2. Ben is the older boxer and Carl is the younger boxer.
3. Al is the older boxer and Carl is the younger boxer.
If scenario 1 is true, fact 1 tells us that Ben is shorter than Al.
If scenario 2 is true, fact 1 tells us that Ben is shorter than Al; fact 3 tells us that Carl is taller than Al, making Ben shorter than Carl.
If scenario 3 is true, fact 3 tells us that Carl is taller than Al.
We can now expand our three scenarios:
1. Al is the younger, taller boxer, and Ben is the older, shorter boxer.
2. Ben is the older, shorter boxer, and Carl is the younger, taller boxer.
3. Al is the older, shorter boxer, and Carl is the younger, taller boxer.
Scenario 2 cannot be possible because it contradicts fact 2 by making the younger of Ben and Carl the taller boxer.
Fact 2 also tells us that Al is not the shorter boxer, so scenario 3 cannot be possible, either.
Therefore, scenario 1 is true, which means that Carl is not a boxer.
Response:
Let  

• heights be compared by “taller / shorter”,  
• ages be compared by “older / younger”,  

and remember that exactly two of the three brothers are boxers.

Step 1.  Interpret each statement.

(1)  “The shorter of Al and Ben is the older boxer.”  
 ⇒  the person who is shorter between Al and Ben is a boxer and he is the older of the two boxers.

(2)  “The younger of Ben and Carl is the shorter boxer.”  
 ⇒  the person who is younger between Ben and Carl is a boxer and he is the shorter (in height) of the two boxers.

(3)  “The taller of Al and Carl is the younger boxer.”  
 ⇒  the person who is taller between Al and Carl is a boxer and he is the younger of the two boxers.

Call the older boxer OB and the younger boxer YB.

Step 2.  Locate the older boxer.

From (1) the older boxer is the shorter of Al and Ben.  
If Al were shorter than Ben, then OB would be Al.

• Because there are only two boxers, OB and YB must be different people.  
• Then YB must come from statement (3).  (3) says YB is the taller of Al and Carl.  
 If Al were OB, the taller of Al and Carl would have to be Carl (so YB = Carl).

Now check (2): the younger of Ben and Carl (Ben vs Carl) would have to equal the shorter boxer.  
But the shorter boxer, being the shorter of OB and YB, would be Al (Al is shorter than Carl).  
Al cannot be “the younger of Ben and Carl.”  Contradiction.

Hence our supposition was wrong: Al is not shorter than Ben.  
Therefore Ben is shorter than Al, and

 OB = Ben.                                               (4)

Step 3.  Locate the younger boxer.

From (3) the younger boxer is the taller of Al and Carl.  
Because OB = Ben, YB cannot be Ben; it must be either Al or Carl.

Case A:  Al is taller than Carl ⇒ YB = Al.  
Case B:  Carl is taller than Al ⇒ YB = Carl.

Step 4.  Test Case A (YB = Al).

Heights:  Ben < Al (from (4)); Al > Carl (assumed in Case A).  
So among the two boxers (Ben and Al) the shorter boxer is Ben.

Ages required:  
• Ben must be older than Al (because OB is the older boxer).  
• Statement (2) says the younger of Ben and Carl equals the shorter boxer, i.e. Ben.  
 Thus Ben must be younger than Carl.

Put together: Carl (oldest), Ben (middle), Al (youngest).  
All three statements are satisfied, so Case A is consistent.

Step 5.  Test Case B (YB = Carl).

Heights: Ben < Al (from (4)); Al < Carl (assumed in Case B); hence Ben is the shortest of all three.  
Among the two boxers (Ben and Carl) the shorter boxer is Ben.

Ages required:  
• Ben must be older than Carl (because OB is the older boxer).  
• Statement (2) again says the younger of Ben and Carl is Ben, i.e. Ben younger than Carl.  
Contradiction.  Case B is impossible.

Step 6.  Conclusion.

The only consistent arrangement is Case A: the boxers are Ben (older) and Al (younger).  
Therefore Carl is the brother who is not a boxer.

Final answer: Carl

Question:
On Sunday, December 22, four Madadian cruise ships - W, X, Y, Z - started their series of winter cruises to various ports around Madadia.
Ship W left at 4:00 PM on Sunday, December 22, for a series of 8-days cruises to Madport.
Ship X left at 4:30 PM on Sunday, December 22, for a series of alternating 11-days and 13-days cruises to Adeville.
Ship Y left at 5:00 PM on Sunday, December 22, for a series of 5-days cruises to Kebabtown.
Ship Z left on Monday for a series of 7-days cruises.
Each ship is scheduled to return back early in the morning after the last day of the cruise and leave again late in the afternoon of the same day.
On how many days occasions between December 22 and February 28 will three ships be moored at the port?
Hint: Find out the days on when each ship will be in port
Human Solution:
On no occasions (other than start date December 22) between December 22 and February 28, three ships will be moored at the port.
Find out the days on when each ship will be in port:
Ship W will be in port on days 1, 9, 17, 25, 33, 41, 49, 57 and 65.
Ship X will be in port on days 1, 12, 25, 36, 49, 60 and 73.
Ship Y will be in port on days 1, 6, 11, 16, 21, 26, 31, 36, 41, 46, 51, 56, 61 and 66.
Ship Z will be in port on days 1, 2, 9, 16, 23, 30, 37, 44, 51, 58 and 65.
From above data, it is clear that - on no occasion (other than December 22) will three ships be moored at the port.
Also, on 8 occasions, there will be 2 ships moored at the port.
Response:
Because every ship leaves late in the afternoon and comes back early in the morning of the day that follows the last cruising-day, a vessel is moored in Madport  

• on the morning of its departure day (until it sails in the afternoon), and  
• again on the “turn-round” day which is exactly (length-of-cruise + 1) days after that departure.  

Hence, if the length of the cruise is N days, consecutive mooring days for that ship are spaced N + 1 days apart.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  List of mooring days for each ship
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Ship W (8-day cruises ⇒ spacing 9 days)  
12 / 22, 12 / 31, 01 / 09, 01 / 18, 01 / 27, 02 / 05, 02 / 14, 02 / 23

Ship X (alternating 11- and 13-day cruises, first cruise 11 days)  
spacing 12,14,12,14,… days  
12 / 22, 01 / 03, 01 / 17, 01 / 29, 02 / 12, 02 / 24

Ship Y (5-day cruises ⇒ spacing 6 days)  
12 / 22, 12 / 28, 01 / 03, 01 / 09, 01 / 15, 01 / 21, 01 / 27, 02 / 02,  
02 / 08, 02 / 14, 02 / 20, 02 / 26

Ship Z (7-day cruises ⇒ spacing 8 days; first sailing Monday 23 December)  
Besides being in port all day 12 / 22 it is again moored on  
12 / 23, 12 / 31, 01 / 08, 01 / 16, 01 / 24, 02 / 01, 02 / 09, 02 / 17, 02 / 25

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  Look for dates on which at least three sets coincide
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Checking every date that appears in the lists (all other dates have no ships in port):

• 12 / 22 W, X, Y, Z → 4 ships  
• 12 / 23 Z only  
• 12 / 28 Y only  
• 12 / 31 W, Z  
• 01 / 03 X, Y  
• 01 / 08 Z  
• 01 / 09 W, Y  
• 01 / 15 Y  
• 01 / 16 Z  
• 01 / 17 X  
• 01 / 18 W  
• 01 / 21 Y  
• 01 / 24 Z  
• 01 / 27 W, Y  
• 01 / 29 X  
• 02 / 01 Z  
• 02 / 02 Y  
• 02 / 05 W  
• 02 / 08 Y  
• 02 / 09 Z  
• 02 / 12 X  
• 02 / 14 W, Y  
• 02 / 17 Z  
• 02 / 20 Y  
• 02 / 23 W  
• 02 / 24 X  
• 02 / 25 Z  
• 02 / 26 Y  

Only one calendar day, Sunday 22 December, sees three or more ships (in fact all four) simultaneously moored.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Answer
--------------------------------------------------------------------
There is exactly one such occasion.

Final answer: 1

Question:
Henry and Gretchen are going to play a game.  Henry explains, "You and I will take turns saying numbers.  The first person will say a number between 1 and 10.  Then the other person will say a number that is at least 1 higher than that number, and at most 10 higher.  We will keep going back and forth in this way until one of us says the number 50.  That person wins.  I'll start."
"Not so fast!" says Gretchen.  "I want to win, so I will start."
What number should Gretchen say to start?
Hint: By following this strategy, she is assured a victory.  Think of all of the numbers she will want to say.
Human Solution:
She wants to say, "6."
The series of numbers she will say is 6, 17, 28, 39, 50.
Since she wants to say 50, she needs Henry to say a number between 40 and 49.  Therefore, she wants to say 39.
Knowing she wants to say 39, she needs Henry to say a number between 29 and 38.  So she wants to say 28.  Following this same logic recursively, she will want to say 17, and she will want to say 6 to start the game, and be assured victory.
Response:
Because each move may increase the running total by any whole amount from 1 to 10, a player who can force the total to advance by 11 in every complete pair of turns (the opponent’s move followed by her own) will keep control of the game.

1. Let the “target numbers’’ be those that are exactly 11 apart, ending with 50:
   50 − 11 = 39,
   39 − 11 = 28,
   28 − 11 = 17,
   17 − 11 = 6.

   Thus the special numbers are 6, 17, 28, 39, 50.

2. If Gretchen can utter 6 on her first turn, she is guaranteed always to be able to reply in such a way that the pair of moves (Henry’s plus hers) advances the total by 11 and therefore lands on the next special number:

   • After she says 6, Henry must say a number from 7 to 16.
   • Whatever Henry says, Gretchen can add just enough (between 1 and 10) to reach 17.
   • From 17 Henry can reach 18–27; Gretchen can then move to 28.
   • From 28 Henry can reach 29–38; Gretchen moves to 39.
   • From 39 Henry can reach 40–49; Gretchen then reaches 50 and wins.

   At every intermediate step Gretchen’s required addition is between 1 and 10, so it is always legal.

Therefore Gretchen must begin by saying 6; following the reply-to-make-11 strategy afterward guarantees she will be the one to speak 50.

Final answer: 6

Question:
One of four people - two men (Jack and Mike) and two women (Carol and Lily) - was murdered.
The following facts refer to the people mentioned:
(a) Jack's sister argued exactly once with Carol's legal husband after the murder.
(b) Mike's sister argued twice with the victim's legal spouse after the murder. Who was the victim?
Hint: They may or may not share sisters?
Human Solution:
Mike is the victim.
If Mike's sister and Jack's sister are the same person, then (a) reads "Lily argued exactly once with (Mike or Jack)" and (b) reads "Lily argued twice with (the same Mike or Jack)".  These two statements contradict each other.  Therefore Mike's sister must be different from Jack's sister.
If this is the case then there are two possibilities:
1)  Jack and Carol are brother and sister.  Mike and Lily are brother and sister.  Jack is married to Lily and Mike is married to Carol.  If this is the case, then (a) reads "Carol argued once with Mike" and (b) reads "Lily argued twice with herself", leaving Jack dead.  Since Lily did not likely argue with herself, this is not the solution.
2)  Jack and Lily are brother and sister.  Mike and Carol are brother and sister.  Jack is married to Carol and Lily is married to Mike.  If this is the case, then (a) reads "Lily argued once with Jack" and (b) reads "Carol argued twice with Lily", leaving Mike dead.  Since there are no contradictions, this is the solution.
Response:
Let  

• Jack’s sister be S₁ ∈ {Carol , Lily},  
• Mike’s sister be S₂ ∈ {Carol , Lily},  
• Carol’s legal husband be H (∈ {Jack , Mike}),  
• the victim be V, and  
• the victim’s legal spouse be W.  

The two factual statements are

(a) S₁ argued exactly once with H after the murder.  
(b) S₂ argued twice with W after the murder.  

Because the arguments take place after the murder, S₁, S₂, H, W are all alive; hence none of them can be the victim.

Step 1.  Carol cannot simultaneously be sister to both men.  
If S₁ = S₂ = Carol, she would be sister to Jack and to Mike, so Carol could not be legally married to either Jack or Mike, contradicting the fact that H (Carol’s husband) must be one of the two men.  
Therefore at least one of S₁, S₂ is Lily.

Step 2.  Exactly one woman is sister to each man.  
The only viable distributions are  
(i) S₁ = Carol, S₂ = Lily or (ii) S₁ = Lily, S₂ = Carol.  
Case (i) soon fails (see below); case (ii) will work.

Take case (ii): S₁ = Lily (Jack’s sister) and S₂ = Carol (Mike’s sister).

Step 3.  Determine Carol’s husband.  
Since Carol is Mike’s sister, she cannot be married to Mike; therefore H = Jack.

So Jack is alive (he is H) and Lily is alive (she is S₁).  
By (a): Lily argued exactly once with Jack.

Step 4.  Identify the victim.  
Jack and Carol are both alive (H and S₂ cannot be victims).  
Thus the victim is either Mike or Lily.

But Lily is alive (she is S₁), so the only possible victim is Mike.

Step 5.  Check consistency with statement (b).  
If V = Mike, his spouse W cannot be his own sister Carol, so W must be Lily.  
Now (b) reads: S₂ (Carol) argued twice with W (Lily). Both women are alive, so this is possible and consistent with (a) (Lily’s single argument with Jack).

All conditions are satisfied:

• Jack is married to Carol.  
• Mike is married to Lily.  
• Jack’s sister = Lily argued once with Jack.  
• Mike’s sister = Carol argued twice with Lily.  
• The only person not appearing in either argument role is Mike, so Mike is indeed the victim.

No other assignment of “sisters’’ and “spouses’’ meets every requirement without contradiction, hence the solution is unique.

Final answer: Mike

Question:
Walter, Xavier, Yoshi, and Zeke crossed a river in a tiny rowboat. They all started on the same side of the river. They made three trips from the starting side to the destination side, and two trips from the destination side to the starting side. Here are some facts:
1. On each trip from the starting side of the river to the destination side, two people were in the boat, but only one person rowed the boat, and that person rowed the boat for the entire trip.
2. On each return trip, only one person was in the boat.
3. Walter is the weakest of the group. He could only row the boat if no one else is in it.
4. Xavier is the second weakest of the group. He can only row the boat if he is by himself or if Yoshi, the lightest of the group, is a passenger.
5. Each man rowed the boat at least once.
Who rowed twice?
Hint: Fact 5 tells us that Walter had to row the boat at least once, but fact 3 tells us that he had to go by himself. This means he could only row the boat on a return trip,.
Human Solution:
Yoshi rowed twice.
Fact 5 tells us that Walter had to row the boat at least once, but fact 3 tells us that he had to go by himself. This means he could only row the boat on a return trip, which means he rowed on at least one return trip.
The man who rowed twice could not have rowed on two trips from the starting side to the destination side, because he would have had to make a third trip by himself back to the starting side. So the man who rowed twice must have made a return trip at least once.
Now we know that if Walter made two trips, they must both have been return trips, and Xavier, Yoshi, and Zeke each rowed for one of the other three trips. If Walter made only one trip, the other person who made a return trip must have been the person who rowed twice (Xavier, Yoshi, or Zeke) and that person would also have made one of the other three trips. So the three trips from the starting side to the destination side must have been rowed by Xavier, Yoshi, and Zeke.
Fact 1 tells us that Xavier's trip to the destination side must have had a passenger, and fact 4 tells us that that passenger must have been Yoshi. Yoshi would have had to row back to row his trip to the destination side, or else Yoshi rowed to the destination side, then back to the start, then got rowed across by Xavier.
Response:
First recall the five trips have to be (in order)
F₁ , R₁ , F₂ , R₂ , F₃  
where the three F–trips go from the starting side to the destination side with two men in the boat, and the two R–trips go the opposite way with a single man in the boat.

Step 1.  Walter’s (W’s) rowing.  
•  Fact 3 says W can row only when he is alone, therefore only on an R-trip.  
•  Fact 5 says every man rows at least once, so W rows one of the two R-trips – no more and no less (because he can never row an F-trip).

Step 2.  Can Xavier (X) row an R-trip?  
Assume X rows some R-trip.  Because a return trip starts on the destination side, X first has to be taken to that side.  If X himself rows the preceding F-trip, his passenger must be Yoshi (Y) (Fact 4); if he is a passenger, some other man rows.  After X rows back alone, he is again on the starting side together with W, while Y is on the opposite side.  The only men left on the starting side just before the last crossing would then be W and X, but  
•  W cannot row an F-trip at all, and  
•  X cannot row with W as passenger (Fact 4).  
Hence the last crossing would be impossible.  Therefore X never rows an R-trip; he rows exactly one F-trip, and when he does, Y must be his passenger.

Step 3.  Who rows the second R-trip?  
It cannot be X (see Step 2).  Suppose Zeke (Z) rows an R-trip.  To do so he must first be ferried to the destination side, and the only way to put him back on the starting side afterward is for him to row there himself.  But when Z arrives back alone, the only men remaining on the starting side for the very last crossing are Z and W.  Again W cannot row an F-trip, so Z would have to row a second time, giving him at least three total trips (two returns and one forward), which is impossible because only one person is allowed to row twice.  Hence Z cannot row any R-trip.

Consequently Y must row the R-trip that W does not row.

Step 4.  Counting the rows.  
So far we have  
•  W – 1 row (an R-trip),  
•  Y – 1 row (the other R-trip),  
•  X – 1 row (the single F-trip he is allowed to make, with Y as passenger),  
•  Z – at least 1 row (some F-trip).

That accounts for four of the five trips.  One F-trip is still unassigned, and the only man who has not yet reached his quota of “at least once” and can still legally row is Y.  Therefore Y must row this remaining F-trip.

Thus the totals are  
W : 1  X : 1  Z : 1  Y : 2.

Step 5.  A concrete schedule (showing that the deductions are feasible).

Trip 1 (start → dest) X rows, Y passenger  
Trip 2 (dest → start) Y rows alone  
Trip 3 (start → dest) Z rows, W passenger  
Trip 4 (dest → start) W rows alone  
Trip 5 (start → dest) Y rows, W passenger

All four men finish on the destination side, every fact is satisfied, and only Yoshi rows twice.

Final answer: Yoshi

Question: There is a famous diamond displayed in a room that measures 15 meters by 15 meters by 15 meters. The room is made entirely of concrete blocks and the floor is covered with a thick carpet. The only thing in the room is the diamond that is housed under a glass cube. The glass cube stands on a one-meter pedestal in the centre of the room. Alarm wires spaced eight centimetres apart and running parallel to each other lie under the carpet. The alarm will trigger if more than four kilograms of pressure is applied to any individual wire. Will Carlo who weighs 74 kilograms was able to steal the famous diamond using the following equipment: a five meter 2 x 4 board, four leather straps (each two meters long and five cm wide), a hammer, and a saw. How could he do it without triggering the alarm?
Hint: How can he spread out his weight?
Human Solution: Will Carlo stole the diamond in the following manner: First, he cut five meter 2 x 4 boards in half. Then using the available straps, he fastened the two boards to his feet like skies. With the boards strapped to his feet, his weight was displacing enough so that he did not exceed the wire's weight tolerance and triggers the alarm. Carlo then slowly and carefully walked to the centre of the room, smashed the glass cube with the hammer, took the diamond and returned the same way he came in.
Response:
The alarm will sound the moment any single wire is asked to carry more than 4 kg.  
Therefore Carlo must always keep his weight spread over

 74 kg ÷ 4 kg ≈ 18.5 → at least 19 different wires.

The wires are 8 cm = 0.08 m apart, so to stand on 19 wires at once he must place his foot-support on a strip of carpet that is at least

 19 × 0.08 m = 1.52 m

wide in the direction perpendicular to the wires.

Carlo’s equipment lets him make two “skis” longer than this minimum and fix them to his feet.

Construction
1. Saw the 5-m 2 × 4 into two equal planks, each 2.5 m long.  
   (2.5 m > 1.52 m, so each plank will cover more than 30 wires.)
2. With the hammer make two small transverse notches near each end of every plank; thread the four 2-m leather straps through these notches and knot them to form loops that will hold his boots firmly to the planks.  
   Each plank is now a 2.5-m-long “ski”.

Why it is safe
• A 2.5 m ski laid perpendicular to the wires touches

 2.5 m ÷ 0.08 m ≈ 31 wires.

• Even if Carlo’s whole 74 kg is momentarily on one ski, each wire bears

 74 kg ÷ 31 ≈ 2.4 kg < 4 kg,

so the alarm remains silent.

Crossing the room
Keeping the skis perpendicular to the wires, Carlo moves exactly like a cross-country skier:

1. Stand with both skis on the carpet; weight is safely distributed over ~62 wires.  
2. Shift all weight onto the left ski (still safe: ~2.4 kg per wire).  
3. Slide the right ski forward a step, set it down, transfer weight to it.  
4. Slide the left ski forward, and so on, “gliding” toward the centre.

Throughout the walk at least one 2.5 m plank is always on the floor, so no wire ever carries more than 4 kg.

Reaching the pedestal he can lift the glass cube or break it as he wishes—nothing in that action involves the alarm wires.

Thus, by turning the board into two long wooden skis and strapping them to his feet, Carlo spreads his weight over many wires at every moment and crosses the carpet without triggering the alarm, enabling him to steal the diamond.

Final answer: He saws the 5-m board into two long planks, straps one plank to each foot as 2.5-m “skis”, keeps the skis perpendicular to the alarm wires, and “skis” across the carpet; each ski rests on more than 30 wires, so no single wire bears more than 4 kg, and the alarm never goes off.

Question:
Hans Ernest Froopaloop, Jr. will marry one of three women: Audrey, Brenda, and Charlotte. Here are some facts:
1. Of Audrey and Brenda:
a. Either they both have blue eyes or neither has blue eyes.
b. One has red hair and the other does not.
2. Of Audrey and Charlotte:
a. Either they both have red hair or neither has red hair.
b. One is 5'11" and the other is not.
3. Of Brenda and Charlotte:
a. One has blue eyes and the other does not.
b. One is 5'11" and the other is not.
4. Of the three characteristics; blue eyes, red hair and 5'11":
a. If any of the three women has exactly two of the three characteristics, Mr. Froopaloop will marry the one with the least number of characteristics.
b. If any of the three women has exactly one of the three characteristics, Mr. Froopaloop will marry the one with the greatest number of characteristics.
Who will Mr. Froopaloop marry?
Hint: Start with facts 1a and 3a
Human Solution:
Mr. Froopaloop will marry Charlotte.
Facts 1a and 3a tell us that Charlotte is either the only one with blue eyes or the only one without blue eyes. Facts 1b and 2a tell us that Brenda is either the only one with red hair or the only one without red hair. Facts 2b and 3b tell us that Charlotte is either the only one who is 5'11" or the only one who isn't 5'11". Fact 4 tells us that no one woman can have one characteristic while another has two characteristics. This gives us two scenarios:
1. Audrey has blue eyes, does not have red hair, and is 5'11". Brenda has blue eyes, red hair, and is 5'11". Charlotte does not have blue eyes, does not have red hair, and is not 5'11".
2. Audrey does not have blue eyes, has red hair, and is not 5'11". Brenda does not have blue eyes, does not have red hair, and is not 5'11". Charlotte has blue eyes, red hair, and is 5'11".
Fact 4a tells us that in scenario 1, Mr. Froopaloop will marry Charlotte. Fact 4b tells us that in scenario 2, Mr. Froopaloop will marry...Charlotte.
Response:
Let  

B  = “has blue eyes”,  
R  = “has red hair”,  
T  = “is 5′ 11″ tall”.

For each woman write the three-letter string of Y (yes) or N (no) that tells whether she possesses B, R and T in that order.

Step 1 – Translate the first three groups of facts.

Eyes  
1a  Audrey and Brenda have the same eye-colour.  
3a  Brenda and Charlotte have opposite eye-colour.  

⇒ Audrey and Brenda are alike, Charlotte is opposite.  
So either        A B blue / C not-blue            …(E1)  
or               C blue / A B not-blue.           …(E2)

Hair  
1b  Audrey and Brenda differ in hair colour.  
2a  Audrey and Charlotte have the same hair colour.  

⇒ Audrey and Charlotte are alike, Brenda is opposite.  
So either        A C red / B not-red             …(H1)  
or               B red / A C not-red.            …(H2)

Height  
2b  Audrey and Charlotte differ in height.  
3b  Brenda and Charlotte differ in height.  

With only two possible heights, this forces Audrey and Brenda to be alike and Charlotte the opposite:  
either          A B tall / C not-tall            …(T1)  
or              C tall / A B not-tall.           …(T2)

Thus each of the three characteristics comes in the pattern  

          A   B   C  
  eyes :  S   S   O        (same, same, opposite)  
  hair :  S   O   S  
  tall :  S   S   O  

where “S” means “same as Audrey” and “O” the opposite value.

Step 2 – List the eight logical possibilities.

Pick one choice from each pair (E1,E2), (H1,H2), (T1,T2).  
Write the resulting Y/N strings and count how many Y’s each woman has.

Possibility 1   E1 H1 T1 :  
A  YYY  (3) B  YNY  (2) C  NYN  (1)

Possibility 2   E1 H1 T2 :  
A  YYN  (2) B  YNN  (1) C  NYY  (2)

Possibility 3   E1 H2 T1 :  
A  YNY  (2) B  YYY  (3) C  NNN  (0)

Possibility 4   E1 H2 T2 :  
A  YNN  (1) B  YYN  (2) C  NYY  (1)

Possibility 5   E2 H1 T1 :  
A  NNY  (2) B  NNY  (1) C  YYN  (2)

Possibility 6   E2 H1 T2 :  
A  NYN  (1) B  NNN  (0) C  YYY  (3)

Possibility 7   E2 H2 T1 :  
A  NNY  (1) B  NYY  (2) C  YNN  (1)

Possibility 8   E2 H2 T2 :  
A  NNN  (0) B  NYN  (1) C  YYN  (2)

Step 3 – Apply Mr Froopaloop’s rule 4.

• If any woman has exactly 2 characteristics, he marries the woman
  with the LEAST number of characteristics.

• If any woman has exactly 1 characteristic, he marries the woman
  with the GREATEST number of characteristics.

Both clauses may never be allowed to trigger together (they would conflict), so discard every possibility containing simultaneously a “1” and a “2”.

The table above shows that only Possibility 3 and Possibility 6 avoid that conflict:

Possibility 3 : counts  (2, 3, 0)  – “2” occurs but “1” does not  
 He marries the woman with the least count ⇒ Charlotte (0).

Possibility 6 : counts  (1, 0, 3)  – “1” occurs but “2” does not  
 He marries the woman with the greatest count ⇒ Charlotte (3).

Step 4 – Conclusion.

In every logically consistent assignment of characteristics that respects all given facts and Mr Froopaloop’s rule, Charlotte is the one he weds.

Final answer: Charlotte

Question:
Draw a diagram of the Fantasylands to help you with this teaser...
Beethoven's Wig has been stolen again!  Instead of hiding it in a box, the enemy, who remains anonymous, has hidden it inside one of four castles.  Each castle is located in a different fantasyland and has a creature guarding its gates.  Use the clues below to put the lands in order (1st,2nd,3rd, and 4th), figure out which castle belongs in which land, which creature belong to which castle, and help Beethoven reclaim his wig!
Object: Beethoven's Wig
Fantasylands: Lothlorien, Mordor, Narnia, and Malacandra.
Creatures: Dragon, Troll, Giant, and Balrog.
Castles: Stone, Gold, Glass, and Silver.
1.  Narnia is to the left of Lothlorien, which is to the right of the Balrog.
2.  The Stone Castle is to the right of the Wig, and is placed at either Malacandra or Lothlorien.
3.  The Giant is not at Lothlorien and is not in the same place as the wig.
4.  The Balrog is not in Lothlorien, but he stays at the Stone Castle.
5.  The Troll doesn't live at the Golden Castle, which is to the left of where the Balrog stays and to the right of the Silver Castle.
6.  Mordor is to the left of the Dragon, who stays at the second place.
7.  The Troll is not at the Silver Castle, which is 1 fantasyland to the left of the wig.
Hint: Mordor and Lothlorien must be at the edges of the sequence
Human Solution:
Mordor is the first fantasyland.  It contains the Giant and the Silver Castle.
Narnia is the second land.  It has the Dragon, the Golden Castle, and the Wig.
Malacandra is the third land.  It has the Stone Castle and the Balrog.
Lothlorien is the fourth land.  It contains the Troll and the Glass Castle.
Response:
1st place: Mordor ‒ Silver Castle ‒ Giant  
2nd place: Narnia ‒ Golden Castle ‒ Dragon  (beethoven’s wig is here)  
3rd place: Malacandra ‒ Stone Castle ‒ Balrog  
4th place: Lothlorien ‒ Glass Castle ‒ Troll  

Final answer: Beethoven’s Wig is hidden in the Golden Castle in Narnia, the second land from the left; the full left-to-right arrangement is  
Mordor/Silver/Giant, Narnia/Gold/Dragon (wig), Malacandra/Stone/Balrog, Lothlorien/Glass/Troll.

Question:
Just before the end of the term four high school students were discussing their chances for certain grades. The following remarks contain the gist of their hopes and fears.
Jack: We'll all get different grades. If I get an A, then Lucy will get a D.
Jean: If Lucy gets a C, then Jack will get a D. Jack will get a better grade than Paul.
Lucy: If Jean doesn't get an A, then Jack will get a C. If I get a B, then Paul won't get a D.
Paul: If Lucy gets an A, then I'll get a B. if Jean doesn't get a B, I won't either.
When the final examinations were graded and the term marks made out each of the four passed, and strange as it may seem, each received a grade that checked exactly with all the ideas they had previously expressed.
What grade did each receive?
Hint: Is it possible for Jack to get an A? Also note that Paul is below Jack
Human Solution: Jack, Jean, Lucy, and Paul received B, A, D, and C, respectively.
Response:
Let the grades A ( best ) > B > C > D ( worst ) be the only possible passing marks and let  
J, Je, L, P denote the grades of Jack, Jean, Lucy and Paul respectively.  
All four statements made by every student must be true (a conditional is
true whenever its hypothesis is false).

1.  Jack:  
    a) “All four of us will get different grades.”               (1)  
    b) “If I get an A, then Lucy will get a D.”               (2)

2.  Jean:  
    a) “If Lucy gets a C, then Jack will get a D.”             (3)  
    b) “Jack will get a better grade than Paul.”             (4)

3.  Lucy:  
    a) “If Jean doesn’t get an A, then Jack will get a C.”        (5)  
    b) “If I get a B, then Paul won’t get a D.”              (6)

4.  Paul:  
    a) “If Lucy gets an A, then I’ll get a B.”               (7)  
    b) “If Jean doesn’t get a B, I won’t either.”             (8)

-----------------------------------------------------
Step 1.  Jack cannot get an A.  
Suppose J = A.  
By (2) L = D.  Then Jean is not A (because of (1)), so hypothesis of (5)
is true and we would need J = C – impossible.  Hence J ≠ A.      (9)

-----------------------------------------------------
Step 2.  Consider two exhaustive cases for Jean.

CASE I Jean gets an A (Je = A).

•  From (8): “Jean not B” is true, so conclusion “Paul not B” must hold;
   hence P ≠ B.                                             (10)

   The remaining three different grades for Jack, Lucy and Paul are
   B, C, D with P ≠ B.

   Sub-case I-1  P = D  
      Then L = C or B, J = B or C.  
      If L = C, (3) would force J = D – impossible.  
      If L = B, (6) would make P ≠ D – contradiction.  
      Hence P = D is impossible.

   Sub-case I-2  P = C  
      By (4) Jack must be better than Paul, so J = B.  
      The only unused grade for Lucy is D, i.e. L = D.

      Check every statement:

      – (2): J is not A ⇒ statement true.  
      – (3): L is D, not C ⇒ hypothesis false ⇒ true.  
      – (4): B better than C ⇒ true.  
      – (5): Jean is A ⇒ hypothesis false ⇒ true.  
      – (6): L is D, not B ⇒ hypothesis false ⇒ true.  
      – (7): L not A ⇒ hypothesis false ⇒ true.  
      – (8): Jean not B (true) ⇒ Paul not B (true).

      All conditions are satisfied with  
      Je = A, J = B, P = C, L = D.

CASE II Jean is not A (Je ≠ A).

•  Then by (5) Jack must get a C: J = C.                    (11)  
•  From (4) Paul must be below Jack ⇒ P = D.                (12)  
•  Grades left for Jean and Lucy are A and B.  
   If L = A, (7) forces P = B – impossible by (12).  
   Therefore L = B and Je = A, contradicting the assumption Je ≠ A.

Thus CASE II is impossible.

-----------------------------------------------------
The only possible assignment is the one found in CASE I-2.

Jack   : B  
Jean   : A  
Lucy   : D  
Paul   : C

All four grades are different and every stated implication is true.

Final answer: Jean got A; Jack got B; Paul got C; Lucy got D.

Question:
Mad Ade has placed five Queens on a chessboard, such that every square including those occupied by the Queens are under attack.
Imagine the chessboard is set out with reference points 1 to 8 on the vertical and A to H across the horizontal.
At what positions would the five Queens need to be?
Hint: A couple queens next to each other can cover a lot.
Human Solution: A5, D5, E5, F5, H1 (multiple correct arrangements, check to see that every single position on the board is attacked by at least one queen)
Response: Final answer: A1, C8, D6, F3, H5

Question:
You are stuck in a room. All that is there is a slip of paper on a table, and many bottles. The only exit is guarded by a heat sensor that will not let you out. The only way out is to drink one of the bottles' contents, and the liquid will cool down your body heat (with no harm to yourself) enough so that the heat sensor doesn't detect you anymore. There are nine bottles on the ground beyond the table. The content of the slip of paper will tell you what each of the bottles are. Find out what all the bottles are, and then find out which one to drink to get out.
Three of me are poison, and will kill you if you drink.
Two of me are water, nothing bad will happen with these.
Two of me are wine, and it will only get you drunk.
One will heat you up forever, and this room will never let you out. (hinder)
Only one here will help you, it will cool down your body heat.
No medium bottles are poison.
Wine is bad in large doses, so none are large.
Each of the end bottles have the same contents.
No matter how help hides, it will be on poison's left side, but its left side is safe.
No two small bottles are the same.
The hinderer is harder, for it resides between wine and water.
The hinder bottle is large, so it works forever.
Neither big nor medium will save your life.
Poison is all you will get from the bottle on the far right.
Water is next to the helper.
Bottle Order:
Large--Small--Large--Medium--Small--Large--Medium--Large--Small
Hint: Use the fact that help must be small.
Human Solution:
Poison--wine--hinder--water--help--poison--wine--water--poison
Only the middle bottle will save your life.
Response:
Bottle positions (size given in the statement)

1 (L) 2 (S) 3 (L) 4 (M) 5 (S) 6 (L) 7 (M) 8 (L) 9 (S)

Step-by-step deduction

1.  Bottle 9 is poison.  Ends are identical ⇒ bottle 1 is also poison.  
2.  Help must be small and immediately left of a poison, with its own left neighbour safe.  
    • If help were at 2, its right neighbour (3) would be poison, but 1 would have to be safe—contradiction (1 is poison).  
    • If help were at 8 it would not be small.  
    ⇒ Help is the only remaining small position with two neighbours: bottle 5.  
    Hence bottle 6 (its right neighbour) is the third poison, and bottle 4 (its left neighbour) is safe.
3.  “Water is next to the helper” ⇒ bottle 4 is water.  One water remains to be placed.
4.  No medium bottle is poison, already satisfied.  Wine is never large.  
5.  Hinder is large and “between wine and water”.  Possible large positions with two neighbours are 3 and 8.  
    • 8 cannot work (right neighbour 9 is poison, not water or wine).  
    ⇒ Bottle 3 is hinder; therefore bottle 2 (left neighbour) is wine and bottle 4 (right neighbour) is the water found in step 3.
6.  Totals so far  
    Poison: 1, 6, 9  Wine: 2  Water: 4  Hinder: 3  Help: 5  
    One wine and one water still unused, to be placed at bottles 7 (medium) and 8 (large).  
    Wine cannot be large ⇒ bottle 7 is wine, bottle 8 is the second water.
7.  “No two small bottles are the same”:  
    Small bottles 2 (wine), 5 (help), 9 (poison) are all different – condition met.
8.  All other given conditions are now satisfied.

Final catalogue of the nine bottles
1. Large – Poison  
2. Small – Wine  
3. Large – Hinder (heats you forever)  
4. Medium – Water  
5. Small – Help (cools you) ← drink this one  
6. Large – Poison  
7. Medium – Wine  
8. Large – Water  
9. Small – Poison

Final answer: Drink the fifth bottle (the small bottle in position 5); it is the only one that will cool you and let you escape.

Question:
You have the following equations:
a + c = a
b - c = c
c / b = c
a * a = b
You also know that a, b, c have the values 0, 1 and 2, but not necessarily in that order.
But to make matters more complicated the symbols + - * / have been mixed up: all you know is that each represents a different arithmetical operation (addition, subtraction, multiplication or division).
Can you work out the values of a, b and c, and what each of the symbols actually mean?
Hint: The only thing you should assume about the arithmetical symbols is that no two represent the same operation.
Human Solution:
a = 1
b = 2
c = 0
+ = -
- = *
* = +
/ = /
(Yes, the division symbol escaped the bedlam!)
Response:
Let  

 ‘+’, ‘–’, ‘*’, ‘/’  stand for the four ordinary operations in some unknown order,  
 a , b , c be the three different numbers 0 , 1 , 2,  

and satisfy  

(1) a + c = a  
(2) b – c = c  
(3) c / b = c  
(4) a * a = b .  (★)

Because every symbol represents a different operation, we decide which actual operation each symbol denotes and which numeral each letter denotes only by logical necessity – no trial-and-error enumeration is used.

────────────────────────
1.  Consequences of (1): a + c = a
────────────────────────
Let the actual operation represented by ‘+’ be called ⊕.

For all real numbers x,y,

• x ⊕ y = x  is always true only for
  y = 0 if ⊕ is +  or –  
  y = 1 if ⊕ is × or ÷ (and x ≠ 0).

Hence either
 (i) c = 0 and ‘+’ is + or –, or
 (ii) c = 1 and ‘+’ is × or ÷.

────────────────────────
2.  Put c = 0 (case (i))
────────────────────────
The remaining letters are {a , b} = {1 , 2}.

Equation (3): c / b = c becomes 0 / b = 0.  
For every non-zero b this is true if the symbol ‘/’ denotes × or ÷, and false for + or –.  
So  

 ‘/’ is × or ÷.  (5)

Equation (2): b – c = c becomes b – 0 = 0.  
Among the four operations only multiplication yields 0 from (b , 0): b × 0 = 0.  
Therefore  

 ‘–’ denotes ×.  (6)

Because each symbol has its own operation, (5) now forces  

 ‘/’ denotes ÷.  (7)

The two untouched ordinary operations are + and –; one of them must be represented by ‘+’, the other by ‘*’.

────────────────────────
3.  Fix the last two symbols by (4)
────────────────────────
With a ∈ {1,2} and b the other value, (4) reads

 a * a = b.

If ‘*’ were subtraction, we would have a – a = 0, contradicting b ≠ 0.  
Hence ‘*’ cannot be subtraction, so

 ‘*’ denotes +, and therefore  
 ‘+’ denotes –.  (8)

Now (4) gives a + a = b ⇒ 2a = b,  
forcing a = 1 , b = 2.

────────────────────────
4.  Verification
────────────────────────
Using (6)–(8) and (a , b , c) = (1 , 2 , 0):

(1) a + c = a means 1 – 0 = 1 ✓  
(2) b – c = c means 2 × 0 = 0 ✓  
(3) c / b = c means 0 ÷ 2 = 0 ✓  
(4) a * a = b means 1 + 1 = 2 ✓

All four statements hold and every symbol represents a different operation, so the solution is consistent.

────────────────────────
5.  Uniqueness
────────────────────────
If case (ii) (c = 1, ‘+’ is × or ÷) is examined, one soon meets an unavoidable clash of operations in (2) and (3) or a contradiction in (4); hence no other assignment satisfies (★).

────────────────────────
Result
────────────────────────
Numbers: a = 1 , b = 2 , c = 0  

Symbols: + means subtraction  
     – means multiplication  
     * means addition  
     / means division

Final answer: a = 1, b = 2, c = 0; ‘+’ = –, ‘–’ = ×, ‘*’ = +, ‘/’ = ÷

Question:
You are in a game show with four other contestants.  The objective is to crack the combination of the safe using the clues, and the first person to do so will win $500,000.
The safe combination looks like this:
??-??-??-??
A digit can be used more than once in the code, and there are no leading zeroes.
Here are the clues:
1. The third set of two numbers is the same as the first set reversed.
2. There are no 2's, 3's, 4's or 5's in any of the combination.
3. If you multiply 4 by the third set of numbers, you will get the fourth set of numbers.
4. If you add the first number in the first set with the first number in the second set you will get 8.
5. The second set of numbers is not greater than 20.
6. The second number in the second set multiplied by the second number in the fourth set equals one higher than the numbers in the first set.
And get moving, I think another contestant has almost figured it out!
Hint: Clue 3 says if you multiply 4 by the third set of numbers you will get the fourth set of numbers.  From this, you can tell a 1 is the first number in the third set - any other number would be too high.
Human Solution:
The combination is 71-19-17-68.
From the second clue, we know that there are no 2's, 3's, 4's or 5's in any of the sets.  Therefore, only 1's, 6's, 7's, 8's and 9's could be in the remaining spots.
Clue 3 says if you multiply 4 by the third set of numbers you will get the fourth set of numbers.  From this, you can tell a 1 is the first number in the third set - any other number would be too high.
11 * 4 = 44
16 * 4 = 64
17 * 4 = 68
18 * 4 = 72
19 * 4 = 76
Of these, 17 * 4 and 19 * 4 are the only ones that are possible; as the answer of the other numbers contains a number which we know is not in the combination.
Now we skip all the way to clue 5, which tells us the second set of numbers is not greater than 20.  This means that the first digit of that set is also a 1.
So far, we know this much:
??-1?-1?-??
Now, we can come to clue 4, which tells us if you add the first number in the first set with the first number in the second set you will get 8.  The first number in the second set is 1, so the first number in the first set must be 7.  Since the first clue tells us the first set is the third set reversed, and we know that a 1 is the first number in the third set, a 1 must be the second number in the first set and a 7 must be the second number in the third set.
So far, we know this much:
71-1?-17-??
Now, the third set (17) multiplied by 4 will get us 68.  Now we know the fourth set is 68.
71-1?-17-68
Now we come to the final clue.  This tells us the second number in the second set (unknown) multiplied by the second number in the fourth set (8) equals one higher than the numbers in the first set.  We know that the first set is 71, so adding one to that (72) and then dividing it by 8 will get us 9.  So, the finished combination is:
71-19-17-68
Response:
Let the four two-digit sets be  
S₁ = a b, S₂ = c d, S₃ = e f, S₄ = g h (each letter a digit).

Step 1  (Clue 1)  
S₃ is S₁ reversed  ⇒ e f = b a ⇒ S₃ = b a and S₁ = a b.

Step 2  (Clues 2 & 3 with the hint)  
Digits 2,3,4,5 are forbidden.  
S₃ must satisfy 4·S₃ ≤ 99 (so that S₄ is still two-digit).  
With allowed digits the only possibilities for S₃ are 10,11,16,17,18,19.  
Compute 4·S₃:

10→40 (contains 4, forbidden)  
11→44 (contains 4)  
16→64 (contains 4)  
17→68 (allowed)  
18→72 (contains 2)  
19→76 (allowed)

Hence S₃ is either 17 or 19, giving S₄ = 68 or 76 respectively.

Step 3  (Consequences for S₁)  
Because S₃ is the reverse of S₁, we have  
• if S₃ = 17 then S₁ = 71,  
• if S₃ = 19 then S₁ = 91.

Step 4  (Clue 4)  
First digit of S₁ plus first digit of S₂ equals 8: a + c = 8.

Step 5  (Clue 5)  
S₂ ≤ 20, and its first digit cannot be 0,2,3,4,5.  
Thus S₂ can only be 10,11,16,17,18,19 – all of which have first digit c = 1.

Therefore a + 1 = 8  ⇒ a = 7.  
So S₁ must start with 7; hence S₁ = 71 and S₃ = 17.  
(The alternative pair 91/19 is eliminated.)

We now have
S₁ = 71  S₃ = 17  S₄ = 68  S₂ = 1d (with d ∈ {0,1,6,7,8,9})

Step 6  (Clue 6)  
(second digit of S₂) × (second digit of S₄) = S₁ + 1  
  d × 8 = 71 + 1 = 72  
  d = 9.

Thus S₂ = 19.

Final verification
1. S₃ = 17 is 71 reversed ✔  
2. Only digits 0,1,6,7,8,9 appear ✔  
3. 4 × 17 = 68 ✔  
4. 7 (from 71) + 1 (from 19) = 8 ✔  
5. S₂ = 19 ≤ 20 ✔  
6. 9 × 8 = 72 = 71 + 1 ✔

All clues are satisfied.

Final answer: 71-19-17-68

Question:
Five men at a board games club meet once a week to play their favourite board game 'Hollywood Quest'. In this game each space is colour coded one of five colours, each one representing a category of questions.
The five categories are Books, Celebrities, Films, Music, Television.
The five colours are blue, green, grey, orange and purple.
Can you name all five men, their favorite categories and the colours represented by those categories?
CLUES
1. Mr Everett prefers the purple coloured squares.
2. Mr Harper likes Films category best, which is not the blue nor the orange squares.
3. Johns Sanders doesn't like literature-based questions.
4. Patrick's favourite colour is the blue (this is not the colour of the TV questions).
5. The grey squares indicate a player must answer a question about books, and Mr Erwin won't land on these if he can help it.
6. Graham prefers the celebrities category.
7. James avoids the green and orange squares.
8. Kendal is the fifth surname, and Paul the missing first name.
Hint:
Clues 1,2 and 5 should help you work out the colour Mr Harper likes.
Work out Johns Sanders' favourite colour.
You should now be able to work out the colours of all five subjects.
Human Solution:
Graham Everett, purple, celebrities
James Kendal, grey, books
John Sanders, orange, TV
Patrick Erwin, blue, music
Paul Harper, green, films
Response:
Graham Everett – Celebrities – Purple  
Paul Harper – Films – Green  
John Sanders – Television – Orange  
Patrick Erwin – Music – Blue  
James Kendal – Books – Grey  

(Final colour–category map: Books = Grey, Celebrities = Purple, Films = Green, Music = Blue, Television = Orange)

Question:
In Major League Baseball, the World Series is a best of seven series.  The first team to win four games is the champion.  The Series is scheduled so that one team hosts the first two games and the last two games, while the other team hosts the middle three games.  The World Series ends as soon as one team wins four games, so the Series could be completed in as few as four games.
In this fantasy Series, the New York Yankees played the Los Angeles Dodgers.  Los Angeles hosted the first two games.  The final scores of the games were:
Game 1:  4 to 3
Game 2:  6 to 5 (11 innings)
Game 3:  11 to 7
Game 4:  16 to 9
Game 5:  9 to 6 (10 innings)
Game 6:  2 to 1
Game 7:  13 to 8 (13 innings)
Which team won the World Series?
Hint: In baseball, the home team bats last.
Human Solution:
Seven games were played, which means that the teams split the first six games, each team winning three games.  It does not matter who won each of the first six games, since neither team had yet to win four games.  The winner of game 7 will have won four games, and therefore, the World Series.
The team that hosts the first two games also hosts the last two games.  Since Los Angeles hosted the first two games, game 7 was in Los Angeles.  In baseball, the home team bats last.  Los Angeles batted last in game 7.  Since game 7 went 13 innings, Los Angeles would have batted in the bottom of the inning.  In this situation, the home team can never win by more than four runs.  When the home team bats in the last inning, the game ends as soon as the winning run is scored.  The only way the home team can win by more than one run is via a home run, in which case all runners on base at the time can score.  A grand slam home run would only provide a margin of four runs.  Therefore, the home team's margin of victory in an extra-inning game can never exceed four runs.  The final score was 13 to 8, a margin of five runs.  Los Angeles, being the home team, could not have won by that margin.  The game was tied 8 to 8 going into the 13th inning.  New York scored five runs in the top of the 13th inning.
Therefore, the New York Yankees won the World Series, four games to three.
Response:
In a 2-3-2 World-Series schedule the same club is the home team in Games 1, 2, 6 and 7.  
We are told the Dodgers hosted Games 1 and 2, so they must also have been the home team in Games 6 and 7; the Yankees were the home team in Games 3, 4 and 5.

In baseball the game ends the moment the home club scores the run that puts it ahead.  
Consequently, if the home team wins an extra-inning game the final margin of victory can be at most four runs:

• Before the last play the game is tied (otherwise it would already be over).  
• The greatest number of runs that can score on one play is four (a grand-slam homer).  
  Hence the home team can finish an extra-inning game with a margin of 1, 2, 3 or 4, but never 5 or more.

Now examine Game 7, which was played in Los Angeles (Dodgers home):

Game 7 final score: 13 – 8 (13 innings)  
The margin is 5 runs, which is impossible for a home-team walk-off.  
Therefore the home team (Dodgers) did not win Game 7; the visiting team (Yankees) did.

Because the Series lasted the full seven games, each club had won three games after Game 6.  
The Yankees’ victory in Game 7 gave them a fourth win, so they captured the Series.

Final answer: the New York Yankees won the World Series.

Question:
A tourist group of 86 people broke up into two groups. The smaller group went to the beach, and the bigger group went to see a water mill. The following statements are all true. How many people were in each group?
a) A quarter of the people in one of the groups is more than the number of people in the other group.
b) One of the groups contains 6 times as many women as men.
c) One of the groups contains only married couples.
d) The number of people in one of the groups is divisible by 4.
e) One of the groups contains 8 times as many people who are younger than 50 as those who are at least 50 years old.
Hint: Set up an equation.
Human Solution:
The first thing is to make this question an equation. The equation is x+y=86. x is the larger group and y is the smaller group. So, y=86-x. So, x+86-x=86. If the first statement is true then ¼(x)>y. Since y=86-x, then ¼(x)>86-x. Now find out the greatest possible number that will satisfy the equation ¼(x)>86-x. The largest number y could be is 17. The smallest number x could be is 69.
If c) is true, then one of the groups must be even since "couples" are the multiples of 2 (1 couple consists of 2 people, 2 couples consists of 4 people). Then, you figure out that 1 group affects the other group. If there is 1 more person in group x, then there is one less person in group y. So, that means that both group must be even or else both groups are odd and no group will satisfy c). So x must consist of 70, 72, 74, 76, 78, 80, 82, 84, or 86 people and y must consist of 16, 14, 12, 10, 8, 6, 4, 2, or 0 people. Now try to make the groups satisfy e). Substitute c for young people and o for old people. The equation is 8o=c. So, o+c equals the number of people in one of the groups. If c=8o, then that will mean o+8o equals the number of people in one of the groups. Then, simplified the equation.
o+8o=9o.
So 9o equal the number of people in one of the groups. So one of the groups has to be a multiple of 9. Since y consists of a group that has 16 people or under, then the only multiple of 9 is 9. But the groups have to consist of an even number of people, so group x must satisfy e). The only multiples of 9 above 70 and under 86 are 72 and 81. But, the number has to be even. So, group x consists of 72 people and y consists of 14 people.
So, the answer is that there are 72 people that went to see the water mill and 14 people went to the beach.
Response:
Let  

 S = number of tourists in the smaller (beach) group,  
 L = number of tourists in the larger (water-mill) group.  

We know  
 S + L = 86 and L > S.  (1)

-------------------------------------------------
1.  Using statement (a)
-------------------------------------------------
If the “one of the groups’’ mentioned in (a) were the smaller group, we would have  
 (¼)S > L, which is impossible because S < L.  
Hence (a) refers to the larger group:

 ¼ L > S ⇔ L > 4S.  (2)

Insert L = 86 – S from (1) into (2):

 86 – S > 4S  
 86 > 5S  
 S < 17.2.

Therefore  
 S ≤ 17 and L = 86 – S ≥ 69.  (3)

-------------------------------------------------
2.  Using the divisibility statements (b), (d) and (e)
-------------------------------------------------
• (b)  “Six times as many women as men’’ ⇒ group size is a multiple of 7.  
• (d)  “Number of people … divisible by 4’’ ⇒ one group multiple of 4.  
• (e)  “Eight times as many under-50 as at least-50’’ ⇒ group size multiple of 9.

So among the two numbers S and L (with S ≤ 17, L ≥ 69) we must find
 a multiple of 7, a multiple of 4 and a multiple of 9.

Within 1–17 the only multiples relevant are  
 of 4: 4, 8, 12, 16  of 7: 7, 14  of 9: 9.

Try each admissible S (1–17) together with L = 86 – S and demand L > 4S.

A quick check eliminates every value except S = 14:

S   L   L > 4S?   4|?   7|?   9|?
------------------------------------
14  72     ✓      L      S      L

Thus the only possibility is  

 S = 14, L = 72.  (4)

-------------------------------------------------
3.  Verifying all five statements
-------------------------------------------------
• (a)  ¼ L = 18 > S = 14. ✔

• (b)  S = 14 = 12 women + 2 men (12 = 6·2). ✔

• (c)  L = 72 can consist of 36 married couples (36 men, 36 women). ✔

• (d)  L = 72 is divisible by 4. ✔

• (e)  L = 72 = 64 under-50 + 8 at-least-50 (ratio 8 : 1; 72 is 9·8). ✔

Every statement is satisfied and no other split of 86 people meets all the conditions.

-------------------------------------------------
Final answer: 14 people went to the beach and 72 people went to the water mill.

Question:
This teaser is a mixture of logic and math. In a number pyramid, the numbers 0-9 are each used once and formed into a pyramid, with one digits at the top, and right below it two digits, below those three digits, and below those four, all arranged in pyramid form. I can not show you a pyramid due to formatting issues.
In this puzzle, you will follow the clues given, and using these clues, create a number pyramid. There is only one answer.
Clues:
1. The number at the apex, or top, of the pyramid minus the leftmost number in the fourth row equals 7.
2. The middle, or second, number in the third row minus the rightmost number in the third row equals 4.
3. The four numbers in row 4 sum to 8.
4. In the second row, the rightmost number minus the leftmost number equals 1.
5. The four rightmost numbers in each row sum to 25.
6. The numbers 1 and 2 are not adjacent to each other.
Hint: The apex of this pyramid is 9.
Human Solution:
Here is the way the number pyramid is filled out:
Row 1: 9
Row 2: 6, 7
Row 3: 3, 8, 4
Row 4: 2, 0, 1, 5
Response:
Row 1:     9  
Row 2:    6  7  
Row 3:   3  8  4  
Row 4:  2  0  1  5  

Final answer: 9 ; 6 7 ; 3 8 4 ; 2 0 1 5

Question:
The answer I give is yes, but what I mean is no.
What was the question?
Human Solution: Do you mind?
Response: Final answer: “Do you mind?”

Question:
Recently, Snow White's seven dwarfs met up with three of their friends and went to the cinema to see Bambi. From the clues below, can you determine the order in which they stood in the ticket queue?
Grumpy was in front of Dopey. Stumpy was behind Sneezy and Doc. Doc was in front of Droopy and Happy.
Sleepy was behind Stumpy, Smelly and Happy.
Happy was in front of Sleepy, Smelly and Bashful.
Bashful was behind Smelly, Droopy and Sleepy.
Sneezy was in front of Dopey. Smelly was in front of Grumpy, Stumpy and Sneezy.
Dopey was in front of Droopy.
Sleepy was in front of Grumpy and Bashful.
Dopey was behind Sneezy, Doc and Sleepy.
Stumpy was in front of Dopey. Smelly was behind Doc.
Hint: Lots of people must be behind Doc...
Human Solution:
Doc
Happy
Smelly
Sneezy
Stumpy
Sleepy
Grumpy
Dopey
Droopy
Bashful
Response: Final answer: Doc, Happy, Smelly, Sneezy, Stumpy, Sleepy, Grumpy, Dopey, Droopy, Bashful

Question:
You are a spy trying to gain access to a high profile building that contains very classified information. The only thing standing between you and those secrets is a keypunch security system containing the digits 1-9 that will open the door to the building. Your spy agency has provided you details about the order of the keys you need to enter:
1. Each digit is pressed once and only once.
2. No two consecutive digits are pressed consecutively.
3. The digits 2 and 4 are pressed 2nd and 4th in some order; the digits 6 and 8 are pressed 6th and 8th in some order.
4. The sum of the first 5 digits pressed is 19; the sum of the last 5 digits pressed is 27.
As you wonder why your agency couldn't just write down the sequence for you, you crack the code and enter the building.
What sequence of keys did you press on the security system to get into the building?
Hint: You can figure out the 5th digit to enter from clue 4 and some algebra.
Human Solution:
5, 2, 7, 4, 1, 8, 3, 6, 9
From  clue 4, the sum of the first 4 digits to be pressed, the last 4 digits to be pressed, and two times the 5th digit to be pressed is 19 + 27 = 46. The sum of the first and last 4 digits to be pressed and the 5th digit must be the sum of the digits 1-9, from clue 1. This sum is 45, meaning the 5th digit is 46-45 = 1.
From clues 2 and 3, 2 must be the 2nd digit and 4 must be the 4th digit.
From clue 3, 7 must be the 1st or 3rd digit pressed since it can not be pressed before or after the 6 or 8. From clue 4, this means 5 must be pressed 1st or 3rd. But, from clue 2, it can not be the 3rd digit, so it must be the first, meaning 7 is the 3rd digit pressed.
That leaves 3, 6, 8, and 9 as the last 4 digits to be pressed. If 8 were pressed 8th, then the 9 must be pressed 6th, a contradiction with clue 4. So 8 must be pressed 6th meaning 9 is to be pressed last. This leaves 6 to be entered 8th and 3 to be entered 7th.
Response: Final answer: 527418369

Question:
In a mathematics contest, A, B, C, D, E, F, G and H got the top eight places. The teacher asked them to guess who got first.
A said: "Either F or H is first."
B said: "I'm first."
C said: "G is first."
D said: "B is not first."
E said: "A is wrong."
F said: "Neither I nor H is the first."
G said: "C is not first."
H said: "I agree with A."
The teacher told them that exactly three of them guessed correctly. Then, who got first?
Hint: It's OK to use trial and error, however, there might be better methods.
Human Solution:
Since B and D contradict each other, exactly one of them must be true.
Since A and H agree with each other while E and F are against them, exactly two of these four must be true.
Therefore, neither C nor G guessed correctly. Since G guessed that C is not first, C must be first.
Response:
Step 1.  Relate the three statements that talk about A.  

• A : “F or H is first.”  
• H : “I agree with A.”  ⟹  H is asserting “A is correct.”  
• E : “A is wrong.”  

Hence  

 A and H always have the same truth–value,  
 E always has the opposite truth–value.                        (1)

So among A, H, E there are either 2 true & 1 false or 1 true & 2 false.

Step 2.  Show that A cannot be true.  

If A were true, the winner would be F or H.  
Then H (who “agrees with A”) would also be true, while E would be false.  
So we would already have 2 true statements.  

• If the winner were F, then  
 D (“B is not first”) and G (“C is not first”) are both true.  
 That gives at least 4 true statements – too many.

• If the winner were H, the same happens: D and G are true as well,  
 so again at least 4 true statements.

Therefore A (and hence H) must be false and E true.  
We now have exactly one true statement so far (E).              (2)

Step 3.  Analyze F’s statement.  

Let T(F) denote the truth–value of F’s sentence  
“Neither I nor H is first.”  

Case 3a.  T(F) = false.  
 Then the sentence “Neither F nor H is first” is false,  
 so the winner must be F or H.  
 But we just checked that either choice gives at least 4 true statements,  
 contradicting the required total of 3.  
 Hence this case is impossible.

Case 3b.  T(F) = true.  
 Thus the winner is neither F nor H.  
 We now have two true statements: E and F.                    (3)

Step 4.  Examine B and D together.  

B : “I’m first.”  D : “B is not first.”  

Exactly one of B or D is true, because they are negations of each other.  
Since we already have 2 true statements, we need exactly one more;  
hence C and G must both be false.                              (4)

Step 5.  Force the identity of the winner.

G is false: “C is not first” is false ⟹ C is first.  
C is false: “G is first” is false ⟹ the winner is not G.  
Both conditions are fulfilled precisely when C is the winner.

Check the count of true statements when C is first:

A false  
B false  
C false  
D true (B is not first)  
E true (A is wrong)  
F true (neither F nor H is first)  
G false  
H false

Exactly three statements (D, E, F) are true.  All conditions are satisfied.

Therefore the only possible winner is C.

Final answer: C

Question:
The warden meets with 23 new prisoners when they arrive. He tells them, "You may meet today and plan a strategy. But after today, you will be in isolated cells and will have no communication with one another.
"In the prison there is a switch room which contains two light switches labeled A and B, each of which can be in either the 'on' or the 'off' position. BOTH SWITCHES ARE IN THEIR OFF POSITIONS NOW.*  The switches are not connected to anything.
"After today, from time to time whenever I feel so inclined, I will select one prisoner at random and escort him to the switch room. This prisoner will select one of the two switches and reverse its position. He must move one, but only one of the switches. He can't move both but he can't move none either. Then he'll be led back to his cell."
"No one else will enter the switch room until I lead the next prisoner there, and he'll be instructed to do the same thing. I'm going to choose prisoners at random. I may choose the same guy three times in a row, or I may jump around and come back."
"But, given enough time, everyone will eventually visit the switch room as many times as everyone else. At any time any one of you may declare to me, 'We have all visited the switch room.'
"If it is true, then you will all be set free. If it is false, and somebody has not yet visited the switch room, you will be fed to the alligators."
