1.  For any word the four letters must lie on four different blocks, because only one face of a block can show at a time.  
2.  Start by fixing one word to label the blocks.  
   •  From BRIM set  
        B → block 1, R → block 2, I → block 3, M → block 4.  
3.  Letter E occurs in many words.  
   •  In HOME the blocks already used are 4 (M) and (unknown) for H,O.  
   •  In RUDE E must differ from R (block 2) and in VEIN & WIFE E must differ from I (block 3).  
   •  Therefore E can only go on block 1.  
4.  Using HOME (H,O,M,E) we must have H and O on blocks 2 and 3.  
   •  Choose H → block 3 and O → block 2.  
5.  Work through the words systematically, always keeping the “all-different” rule.  
   •  From RUDE put U on block 4 and D on block 3.  
   •  VEIN then forces N on block 2 and V on block 4 would collide with HANK, so swap:  
        N → block 2, V → block 4 (checked later).  
   •  WIFE makes W block 4 and F block 2.  
   •  STOW then fixes S block 3 and T block 1, hence in QUIT Q must be block 2.  
   •  HOAX needs A and X on the two remaining blocks 1 and 4; pick A → 4, X → 1.  
   •  ZEAL now gives L → 2 and Z → 3.  
6.  The remaining words finish the placement:  
   •  CLIP (with I on block 3, L on 2) forces P on 1 and C on 4.  
   •  PUNY (U on 4, N on 2, P on 1) puts Y on 3.  
   •  HANK is now H 3, A 4, N 2, so K must be on 1.

All 24 letters are now placed and each block has six letters.

Block 1:  B E K P T X  
Block 2:  F L N O Q R  
Block 3:  D H I S Y Z  
Block 4:  A C M U V W  

Checking every word shows its four letters are indeed on four different blocks.

Final answer:  
Block 1 – B, E, K, P, T, X  
Block 2 – F, L, N, O, Q, R  
Block 3 – D, H, I, S, Y, Z  
Block 4 – A, C, M, U, V, W

Question:
There are three men, Alex, Bob and Chuck.  One of the men always tells the truth and one always lies.  The third man always tells a lie after telling the truth and always tells the truth after telling a lie.  The third man can answer the first question truthfully or can lie.
Can you tell who is the truth teller, the liar and the unreliable man by asking just three questions?  Each question is directed to a single person.
Hint: Ask someone a question about someone else.
Human Solution:
First ask Alex, "Does Bob sometimes tell the truth and sometimes lie?"
A "yes" answer means one of the following must be true:
1) Alex is the truth teller and Bob is unreliable;
2) Alex is the liar and Bob is the truth teller;
3) Alex is unreliable and is lying and Bob is the truth teller; or
4) Alex is unreliable and is lying and Bob is the liar.
A "no" answer means one of these must be true:
1) Alex is the truth teller and Bob is the liar;
2) Alex is the liar and Bob is unreliable;
3) Alex is unreliable and is telling the truth and Bob is the truth teller; or
4) Alex is unreliable and is telling the truth and Bob is the liar.
If the answer is "yes", you ask Alex "Is Bob the liar?"; if the answer is "no", you ask Alex "Is Bob the truth teller?"
Depending on the answers to the first two questions, you know one of the following:
A) If the answer to both questions was "yes" then either
1) Alex is the liar and Bob is the truth teller; or
2) Alex is unreliable and lied on the first question and Bob is the liar.
B) If the answer to both questions is "no" then either
1) Alex is the truth teller and Bob is the liar; or
2) Alex is unreliable and Bob is the truth teller.
C) If the answer to the first question was "yes" and the second question was "no" then either
1) Alex is the truth teller and Bob is unreliable; or
2) Alex is unreliable and lied on the first question and Bob is the truth teller.
In either case, Chuck is the liar.
D) If the answer to the first question was "no" and the second question was "yes" then either
1) Alex is the liar and Bob is unreliable; or
2) Alex is unreliable and Bob is the liar.
In either case, Chuck is the truth teller.
In cases A & B you've identified one person as either the liar or the truth teller and you've identified another person as either not the liar or not the truth teller.  In these cases you ask the person who is neither the liar or the truth teller a question you know the answer to.  In cases C & D you've identified Chuck as either the liar or truth teller.  At this point you simply ask Chuck a question to identify either Alex or Bob.
So the final question and results for each case are:
A) You ask Bob "Is Alex the truth teller?"
"yes" means that
Alex is unreliable, Bob is the liar and Chuck is the truth teller;
"no" means that
Alex is the liar, Bob is the truth teller and Chuck is unreliable.
B) You ask Bob "Is Alex the liar?"
"yes" means that
Alex is the truth teller, Bob is the liar and Chuck is unreliable;
"no" means that
Alex is unreliable, Bob is the truth teller and Chuck is the liar.
C) You ask Chuck "Is Alex the truth teller?"
"yes" means that
Alex is unreliable, Bob is the truth teller and Chuck is the liar;
"no" means that
Alex is the truth teller, Bob is unreliable and Chuck is the liar.
D) You ask Chuck "Is Alex the liar?"
"yes" means that
Alex is the liar, Bob is unreliable and Chuck is the truth teller;
"no" means that
Alex is unreliable, Bob is the liar and Chuck is the truth teller.
Response:
Call the three men Alex (A), Bob (B) and Chuck (C).  
We are allowed only YES/NO questions and may decide each new question after hearing the previous replies.

Question 1 to Alex  
Q1 : “Is 2 + 2 = 4 ?”

Question 2 to Alex  
Q2 : “Is 2 + 2 = 4 ?”   (exactly the same question)

After Q1 and Q2 we have already singled out the unreliable (alternating) man.

• If the two answers are different, Alex is the alternating man (he must change his
answer to the same question).  
• If the two answers are identical, Alex is not the alternating man; moreover  
 – two “YES” answers mean Alex is the Truth-teller,  
 – two “NO”  answers mean Alex is the Liar (because a liar must deny a
true statement).

Only one question is still unused.  We now finish the identification in three different ways,
according to what we have just learned.

──────────────────────────────────
Case 1 Alex is the alternating man (the two answers were different)

Question 3 to Bob  
Q3 : “Is 2 + 2 = 4 ?”

Bob cannot be alternating (Alex already is), so he is either the Truth-teller or the Liar.  
 • If Bob answers YES ⇒ Bob is the Truth-teller, Chuck the Liar.  
 • If Bob answers  NO  ⇒ Bob is the Liar,  Chuck the Truth-teller.

──────────────────────────────────
Case 2 Alex is the Truth-teller (the two answers were YES, YES)

Question 3 to Alex  
Q3 : “Is Bob the Liar ?”

Alex answers truthfully.  
 • YES  ⇒ Bob is the Liar, Chuck the Alternator.  
 • NO   ⇒ Bob is the Alternator, Chuck the Liar.

──────────────────────────────────
Case 3 Alex is the Liar (the two answers were NO, NO)

Question 3 to Alex  
Q3 : “Is Bob the Truth-teller ?”

Alex must lie.  
 • YES  (a lie) ⇒ Bob is not the Truth-teller → Bob is the Alternator, Chuck the Truth-teller.  
 • NO   (a lie) ⇒ Bob is the Truth-teller,    Chuck the Alternator.

In every possible situation all three roles are completely determined after exactly three
questions.

Final answer:  Yes, with the three questions above one can always identify which man is the Truth-teller, which is the Liar and which is the Alternator.

Question:
You have:
- two 10-liter jugs, full of water
- one 9-liter jug, empty
- two large pools, empty
Your objective is to end up having 4 liters of water in each pool, and one liter of water in the 9-liter jug.
You have nothing else at your disposal and you can not measure using eye or shape of jugs. You can not pour water from pools, only into them.
Hint: This needs 29 steps to fill two pools with 4-liters, and an additional 4 steps to get 1 liter in the 9-liter jug, for a total of 33 steps.
Human Solution:
Label the 10-liter jugs as A and B, the 9-liter jug as C, and the two pools as Pa and Pb. The problem can be solved in 33 steps, as shown below. Each step is shown in one row, starting with the step number, followed by the jug we poured water from, then the quantity of water, then the jug/pool we poured water into... i.e. A ->( 1)-> Pb means we poured 1 liter of water from jug A (being 1st 10-liter jug)  to pool Pb  (being 2nd pool). Finally in the row we show how much water we have in each jug/pool after performing this step.
------------------------------------
#:  From -> Qty -> To =  A  B  C Pa Pb
------------------------------------
0: _____________ =  10 10  0  0  0
1:  A ->( 9)->  C =   1 10  9  0  0
2:  A ->( 1)-> Pa =   0 10  9  1  0
3:  C ->( 9)->  A =   9 10  0  1  0
4:  B ->( 9)->  C =   9  1  9  1  0
5:  B ->( 1)-> Pa =   9  0  9  2  0
6:  C ->( 1)->  A =  10  0  8  2  0
7:  C ->( 8)->  B =  10  8  0  2  0
8:  A ->( 9)->  C =   1  8  9  2  0
9:  A ->( 1)-> Pa =   0  8  9  3  0
10:  C ->( 9)->  A =   9  8  0  3  0
11:  A ->( 2)->  B =   7 10  0  3  0
12:  B ->( 9)->  C =   7  1  9  3  0
13:  B ->( 1)-> Pa =   7  0  9  4  0
14:  C ->( 3)->  A =  10  0  6  4  0
15:  C ->( 6)->  B =  10  6  0  4  0
16:  A ->( 9)->  C =   1  6  9  4  0
17:  A ->( 1)-> Pb =   0  6  9  4  1
18:  C ->( 9)->  A =   9  6  0  4  1
19:  A ->( 4)->  B =   5 10  0  4  1
20:  B ->( 9)->  C =   5  1  9  4  1
21:  B ->( 1)-> Pb =   5  0  9  4  2
22:  C ->( 5)->  A =  10  0  4  4  2
23:  C ->( 4)->  B =  10  4  0  4  2
24:  A ->( 9)->  C =   1  4  9  4  2
25:  A ->( 1)-> Pb =   0  4  9  4  3
26:  C ->( 9)->  A =   9  4  0  4  3
27:  A ->( 6)->  B =   3 10  0  4  3
28:  B ->( 9)->  C =   3  1  9  4  3
29:  B ->( 1)-> Pb =   3  0  9  4  4
30:  C ->( 7)->  A =  10  0  2  4  4
31:  C ->( 2)->  B =  10  2  0  4  4
32:  A ->( 9)->  C =   1  2  9  4  4
33:  C ->( 8)->  B =   1 10  1  4  4
After the 33rd step we end up with 4 liters in each pool (Pa and Pb), and 1 liter in the 9-liter jug (C),  as requested in the problem.
Response:
Let  

• A be the first 10-litre jug (initially 10 L)  
• B be the second 10-litre jug (initially 10 L)  
• C be the 9-litre jug (initially 0 L)  
• P₁ and P₂ be the two pools (initially empty).

At every step pour from the “source’’ vessel into the “destination’’ vessel until the source is empty or the destination is full.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Steps 1–29 : put exactly 4 L in each pool
--------------------------------------------------------------------
 1. A → C   (A 1,  C 9)  
 2. A → P₁   (P₁ 1, A 0)  

 3. C → A   (A 9,  C 0)  
 4. B → C   (B 1,  C 9)  
 5. B → P₁   (P₁ 2, B 0)  

 6. C → B   (B 9,  C 0)  
 7. B → A   (A10, B 8)  
 8. A → C   (A 1,  C 9)  
 9. A → P₁   (P₁ 3, A 0)  

10. C → A   (A 9,  C 0)  
11. A → B   (A 7,  B10)  
12. B → C   (B 1,  C 9)  
13. B → P₁   (P₁ 4, B 0)           (Pool 1 finished)

14. C → B   (B 9,  C 0)  
15. B → A   (A10, B 6)  
16. A → C   (A 1,  C 9)  
17. A → P₂   (P₂ 1, A 0)  

18. C → A   (A 9,  C 0)  
19. A → B   (A 5,  B10)  
20. B → C   (B 1,  C 9)  
21. B → P₂   (P₂ 2, B 0)  

22. C → B   (B 9,  C 0)  
23. B → A   (A10, B 4)  
24. A → C   (A 1,  C 9)  
25. A → P₂   (P₂ 3, A 0)  

26. C → A   (A 9,  C 0)  
27. A → B   (A 3,  B10)  
28. B → C   (B 1,  C 9)  
29. B → P₂   (P₂ 4, B 0)           (Pool 2 finished)

State after 29 steps :  
A = 3 L  B = 0 L  C = 9 L  P₁ = 4 L  P₂ = 4 L  

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Steps 30–33 : leave 1 L in the 9-litre jug
--------------------------------------------------------------------
30. C → B   (B 9,  C 0)  
31. B → A   (A10, B 2)  
32. A → C   (A 1,  C 9)  
33. C → B   (B10, C 1)           (done)

Final configuration  
• Pool 1 = 4 L  
• Pool 2 = 4 L  
• 9-litre jug C = 1 L  
• 10-litre jugs A and B contain 1 L and 10 L respectively (their contents are irrelevant to the goal).

Total number of steps = 29 + 4 = 33, exactly as hinted.

Question:
In the following code, each symbol stands for one of five letters.
^ stands for N, F, D, R, or E
{ stands for A, W, L, T, or O
@ stands for M, E, C, A, or B
] stands for L, P, O, A, or T
The four letter code word, {@^], can be translated into two English words that are opposites. What are the two words?
Hint: The words start with "W"
Human Solution: Warp and Weft.
Response:
Step-by-step reasoning  

1.  The first symbol in the code word is “{”.  
    The hint says the two English words both start with the letter W,  
    so we must have  
          {  →  W  

2.  The remaining symbols can take the letters listed in the problem:

          @  →  M, E, C, A, or B  
          ^  →  N, F, D, R, or E  
          ]  →  L, P, O, A, or T  

   Hence any deciphered word must have the form

          W  (one of M E C A B)  (one of N F D R E)  (one of L P O A T)

3.  Search for real 4-letter English words that fit this pattern.

    • With second letter A  
      – WAR P  (P is allowed for ])  gives the word WARP.  

    • With second letter E  
      – WE F T  (F allowed for ^, T allowed for ])  gives the word WEFT.

    Both WARP and WEFT satisfy all letter–symbol restrictions.

4.  Are the two words opposites?  
   In weaving, warp threads run lengthwise while weft threads run crosswise; they are at right angles and serve opposite directions in the fabric.  Thus they are considered complementary opposites.

5.  Therefore the code word {@^] can be read in two ways:

          {  @  ^  ]   →   W  A  R  P   =  WARP  
          {  @  ^  ]   →   W  E  F  T   =  WEFT  

Final answer: WARP and WEFT

Question:
With the death of Arthur Minit, the legendary country of MADADIA's only clock maker, no one else had much experience yet with making clocks. The new church of MADADIA had just been completed and a new clock was needed to fit into the bell tower. A clock was made by the locals, using the books of Arthur Minit as a guide.The newly made clock was officially put into use when it showed 6 o'clock. But soon it was noticed that the hour-hand and minute-hand had been interchanged and attached to the wrong spindles. The result was that the hour-hand moved with a speed twelve times higher than the minute-hand. When a clock maker arrived from another area, a remarkable thing happened: on the moment he inspected the clock, it showed exactly the right time.
The Question: If the clock started in the 6 o'clock position, then what was the first moment that it showed the correct time again?
Hint: Suppose that a second pair of hands turns together with the wrong pair of hands, but then in the correct way. When the wrong pair is in the same position as the correct pair, this means that the time is shown in the right way.
Human Solution:
Suppose that a second pair of hands turns together with the wrong pair of hands, but then in the correct way. When the wrong pair is in the same position as the correct pair, this means that the time is shown in the right way. First look at the hour-hands that are at the twelve. One turns with the correct speed, the other with a speed that is twelve times as small. These two hands are in the same position again when the 'slow' hand has progressed x minutes. The fast hand then has progressed 60+x minutes. For the time x that passed, then holds: (60+x)/12 = x. This means that x = 5 5/11 minutes.
For the minutes-hands that start at six holds the same. The confused clock therefore shows the correct time again at 5 5/11 minutes past 7.
Response:
Let t be the number of hours that have elapsed since the faulty clock was started at 6 o’clock.

1.  Speeds of the two wrong hands  
   • Long hand (meant to be the minute–hand but mounted on the hour-wheel):  
     one revolution in 12 h  ⟹ 30° h⁻¹.  
   • Short hand (meant to be the hour-hand but mounted on the minute-wheel):  
     one revolution in 1 h   ⟹ 360° h⁻¹.

2.  Speeds of the two correct (imaginary) hands that we use for comparison  
   • Correct minute-hand: 360° h⁻¹.  
   • Correct hour-hand:   30° h⁻¹.

3.  Initial positions  
   At 6 o’clock both hands point straight down, i.e. they are 180° from the 12-o’clock position.  
   Thus at t = 0 the angle (measured clockwise from 12) of every hand is 180°.

4.  Angles after t hours  
   Wrong minute-hand:   M₍w₎(t) = 180° + 30° t  
   Wrong hour-hand:     H₍w₎(t) = 180° + 360° t  
   Correct minute-hand: M₍c₎(t) = 180° + 360° t  
   Correct hour-hand:   H₍c₎(t) = 180° + 30° t

5.  “Clock shows the right time”  
   This happens when the long hand of the wrong clock coincides with the (imaginary) correct minute-hand, and simultaneously the short hand coincides with the correct hour-hand:  

        M₍w₎(t) ≡ M₍c₎(t)   (mod 360°)  
        H₍w₎(t) ≡ H₍c₎(t)   (mod 360°)

6.  Solving the congruences  

        180 + 30t ≡ 180 + 360t  (mod 360)  
        ⇒ 30t ≡ 360t        (mod 360)  
        ⇒ 330t ≡ 0          (mod 360)

   Divide by 30 (the gcd of 330 and 360):

        11t ≡ 0 (mod 12)

   The smallest positive solution is  

        t = 12/11 hours.

   The second congruence gives the same condition, so it is automatically satisfied.

7.  Converting 12/11 hours to clock time  

        12/11 h = (12/11)·60 = 720/11 min = 65 5/11 min  
                 = 1 h 5 min (5/11) min  
                 = 1 h 5 min 27 3⁄11 s.

   Adding this to the starting moment 6 : 00 : 00 gives  

        7 : 05 : 27 3⁄11.

Thus the first instant at which the faulty clock again displays the correct time is a little over one hour after it was started.

Final answer: 7 : 05 : 27 3⁄11 (= 12⁄11 hours after 6 o’clock).

Question:
You roll five dice.
If you roll 5, 3, 2, 1, 6 you get 8 points.
2, 2, 3, 5, 1 = 8 points
6, 5, 4, 3, 2 = 8 points
1, 2, 6, 6, 6 = 6 points
2, 2, 5, 6, 6 = 6 points
4, 3, 6, 2, 6 = ? points
Hint: Think about how you spell the numbers
Human Solution: 7 points. You get one point per vowel.
Response:
Step–by–step reasoning  

1.  Write each die value in words  
   one, two, three, four, five, six  

2.  Count the vowels (A, E, I, O, U) in each word  
   • one → 2 vowels (o, e)  
   • two → 1 vowel (o)  
   • three → 2 vowels (e, e)  
   • four → 2 vowels (o, u)  
   • five → 2 vowels (i, e)  
   • six → 1 vowel (i)  

3.  The “points” for any roll are the total number of vowels that appear in the written-out words of the five dice.

   Check with the given examples  
   • 5 3 2 1 6  → five(2)+three(2)+two(1)+one(2)+six(1)=8  
   • 2 2 3 5 1  → two(1)+two(1)+three(2)+five(2)+one(2)=8  
   • 6 5 4 3 2  → six(1)+five(2)+four(2)+three(2)+two(1)=8  
   • 1 2 6 6 6  → one(2)+two(1)+six(1)+six(1)+six(1)=6  
   • 2 2 5 6 6  → two(1)+two(1)+five(2)+six(1)+six(1)=6  

   All match the listed point totals.

4.  Apply the rule to 4 3 6 2 6  
   four  → 2 vowels  
   three → 2 vowels  
   six   → 1 vowel  
   two   → 1 vowel  
   six   → 1 vowel  
   Total = 2 + 2 + 1 + 1 + 1 = 7

Final answer: 7 points

Question:
Five pirates are trying to split up 1000 gold pieces.  The rules are as follows:
Pirate #1 must divide the gold up in such a way that a majority of the pirates (including himself) agree to.  If he does not get a majority vote, he will be killed, and pirate #2 will get to propose a solution to the remaining 3 pirates, and the same rules will follow.  This continues until someone comes up with a plan that earns a majority vote.
What is the most amount of gold pieces that pirate #1 can keep to himself, and what would his proposal be?
The pirates are infinitely greedy, infinitely ruthless (the more dead pirates the better), and infinitely intelligent.
Hint: Start backwards - what would pirate #4's options be if the first 3 pirates were killed?
Human Solution:
Like the hint says, start backwards:
If there are two pirates left (#4 & #5), #4 has no options.  No matter what he proposes, pirate #5 will disagree, resulting in a 1-1 vote (no majority).  #5 will kill #4 and will keep all of the gold.
Now say there are 3 pirates left.  #4 has to agree with whatever #3 decides, because if he doesn't #3 will be killed (because #5 won't vote for #3's proposal no matter what it is).  #3 will just propose that he keep all of the gold and will get a 2-1 vote in his favor.
Now if there are 4 pirates left:
#3 won't vote for #2's proposal because if #2's fails, #3 will get all of the gold. #4 and #5 know that they will get nothing if the decision goes to #3, so they will vote for #2's proposal if he gives them one gold piece each. Therefore, #2 would keep 998 gold, and #4 and #5 would each get one gold.
So let's wrap this up:
Pirate #1 needs 2 other votes.  He will not get a vote from #2 because #2 will get 998 gold if #1's plan fails.
#1 offers #3 one gold piece to vote for him, which #3 will accept (if it gets to #2's plan, #3 will get nothing).
#1 then offers #4 or #5 (doesn't matter which) two gold pieces, which is more than they would get with #2's plan.
So #1 can end up with 997 gold pieces, with #3 getting one piece and #4 or #5 getting two pieces.
...whew!
Response:
Step 1 – understand the pirates’ priorities  
For every pirate the order of preference is  
1. Stay alive.  
2. Get as much gold as possible.  
3. If 1 & 2 are the same, prefer more pirates dead.  

A division is accepted if at least half of the living pirates vote “yes”.  
(The proposer always votes for his own plan.)

Step 2 – work backwards  

2 pirates left : pirates 4 & 5  
• Pirate 4 proposes.  
• He already has one vote (his own). 1 out of 2 votes is 50 %, which is enough, so he needs no-one else’s support.  
⇒ He offers  
 P4 : 1000 P5 : 0  
 and it passes 1–1 (50 %).  
Outcome recorded: (1000,0)

3 pirates left : pirates 3, 4, 5  
• If pirate 3 is killed, the 2-pirate result above will occur, giving P4 = 1000, P5 = 0.  
• Pirate 3 needs one extra vote (his + one more = 2/3).  
 – P4 would get 1000 if P3 dies, so he is too expensive to bribe.  
 – P5 would get 0 if P3 dies, so any positive amount buys his vote.  
• Cheapest successful offer:  
 P3 : 999 P4 : 0 P5 : 1  
Yes-votes : P3, P5 (2/3) – accepted.  
Outcome recorded: (0,999,1)

4 pirates left : pirates 2, 3, 4, 5  
• If pirate 2 dies the 3-pirate result above gives P3 = 999, P4 = 0, P5 = 1.  
• Pirate 2 needs one more “yes” besides his own (2/4 = 50 %).  
 – P3 gets 999 if P2 dies ⇒ impossible to bribe.  
 – P4 gets 0 if P2 dies ⇒ 1 coin buys him.  
 – P5 gets 1 if P2 dies ⇒ needs at least 2 coins.  
• Cheapest plan is to buy P4:  
 P2 : 999 P3 : 0 P4 : 1 P5 : 0  
Yes-votes : P2, P4 (2/4) – accepted.  
Outcome recorded: (0,999,1,0)

5 pirates left : pirates 1, 2, 3, 4, 5  
• If pirate 1 dies the 4-pirate result above gives P2 = 999, P3 = 0, P4 = 1, P5 = 0.  
• Pirate 1 needs two extra votes besides his own (3/5).  
 – P2 gets 999 if P1 dies ⇒ cannot be bribed.  
 – P3 gets 0 if P1 dies ⇒ 1 coin buys him.  
 – P4 gets 1 if P1 dies ⇒ needs at least 2 coins.  
 – P5 gets 0 if P1 dies ⇒ 1 coin buys him.  
• Cheapest way to obtain two extra “yes” votes is to pay P3 and P5 one coin each:

 P1 : 998 P2 : 0 P3 : 1 P4 : 0 P5 : 1  

Yes-votes : P1, P3, P5 (3/5) – the plan passes.

Therefore pirate #1 can keep at most 998 gold pieces.

Final answer: Pirate #1 keeps 998 pieces and proposes the division  
(998, 0, 1, 0, 1).

Question: How is it possible that 3 + 4 = 5?
Human Solution:
Using VECTORS
i.e. 3 m North + 4 m East
= 5 metres North East
3^2 = 9
4^2 = 16
9 + 16 = 25
SQ Root of 25 = 5
Response:
Reasoning  

1.  In ordinary arithmetic the symbol “+” stands for the operation of adding two numbers that lie on the same straight line (the real number line).  
    •  On that line 3 + 4 is, of course, 7.  

2.  But the symbol “+” need not always refer to that particular operation.  
    •  If we are working with vectors (directed line-segments) it is natural to let “+” mean vector addition: put the tail of the second vector at the head of the first and draw the resulting diagonal.  

3.  Take a vector of length 3 units pointing, say, due east.  
    •  Call it v₁.  
    Take a vector of length 4 units pointing due north.  
    •  Call it v₂.  
    These two vectors are perpendicular.  

4.  Form their vector sum v₁ + v₂.  
    •  Place v₂ so that its tail is at the head of v₁.  
    •  Draw the diagonal from the tail of v₁ to the head of v₂.  

5.  The Pythagorean theorem tells us the length of this diagonal:  
        (length)² = 3² + 4² = 9 + 16 = 25,  
        so length = √25 = 5.  

6.  Thus, in the context of vector addition (or, equivalently, in the geometry of a right triangle with legs 3 and 4) the statement  
        “3 + 4 = 5”  
    is perfectly correct: the two perpendicular displacements of 3 and 4 units “add” to a single displacement of 5 units.

7.  Nothing mystical is going on; we have merely changed the meaning of the plus sign from “add numbers on a line” to “add vectors at right angles.”  

Final answer:  When “+” denotes vector (or right-triangle) addition rather than ordinary arithmetic addition, a 3-unit vector added at right angles to a 4-unit vector produces a single 5-unit vector, so in that legitimate sense 3 + 4 = 5.

Question: I am a word of five letters. Multiply my fifth by two and you have my first. Divide my first by twenty and you have my third. Divide my third by five and you have my second or fourth.
Hint: Roman numerals
Human Solution:
CIVIL.
L (50) multiplied by 2 equal C (100).
Divide C by 20 and you have V. Divide V by 5 and you have I.
Response:
Let the five letters of the word be  

1st 2nd 3rd 4th 5th  
A  B  C  D  E  

Because of the hint, interpret every letter as a Roman–numeral symbol and let its value be  

A,B,C,D,E ∈ {1,5,10,50,100,500,1000}  
(for I,V,X,L,C,D,M respectively).

The riddle gives three equations:

1. “Multiply my fifth by two and you have my first.”  → 2·E = A  
2. “Divide my first by twenty and you have my third.” → A/20 = C  
3. “Divide my third by five and you have my second or fourth.” → C/5 = B = D  

Work successively.

Step 1.  Combine (1) and (2).

From (2): A = 20 C  
From (1): A = 2 E  
Hence 2 E = 20 C ⇒ E = 10 C

So C must be a numeral whose ten-fold is also a Roman-numeral value, and A must be 20 C, likewise a Roman-numeral value.

Step 2.  List the possibilities for C and check A and E.

C = 1 → E = 10 (X) A = 20 (not a Roman numeral) ✗  
C = 5 → E = 50 (L) A = 100 (C) ✓  
C = 10 → E = 100 (C) A = 200 (not a numeral) ✗  
C = 50 → E = 500 (D) A = 1000 (M) ✓  
C = 100 → E = 1000 (M) A = 2000 (not a numeral) ✗  

Only the second and fourth rows survive.

Step 3.  Use equation (3): C/5 = B = D.

• If C = 5, then C/5 = 1 → B = D = I.  
  The letters are C I V I L, i.e. “CIVIL”.

• If C = 50, then C/5 = 10 → B = D = X.  
  The letters are M X L X D, which is not an English word.

Only the first choice yields a real word.

Thus the five letters are C I V I L.

Checks:
E = L (50); 2·50 = 100 = C ✓  
A = C (100); 100/20 = 5 = V ✓  
C = V (5); 5/5 = 1 = I (second & fourth) ✓

All conditions are satisfied.

Final answer: CIVIL

Question:
Mary Beem, who was a wife, mother of four and grandmother of nine, was shot to death by an angry relative. Find out the name of the relative it was by piecing together the relationships of each person with the clues below.
The killer's sister was suspicious of her sibling and confirmed her distrust by talking to three people: her grandfather Bob, her cousin Bo, and her uncle (blood relative) Bill. She called the police, and the suspect was apprehended at the victim's funeral service. Only the direct descendants and their spouses were present. (Note: None of Mary's grandchildren were married or had kids, and no two people have the same first name.)
1. Bill was talking with his brother-in-law Barry.
2. Bart, Buck, and Bruce (who were all brothers) were by their grandmother's casket.
3. Mary's daughter May, who was with her husband Ben, had their two children: Missy and Bernie.
4. Mo, Bob's son-in-law, was comforting his wife Robin, and both were keeping an eye on their sons.
5. Bo was by himself in a corner grieving, while his sister Molly was talking with their cousin Megan.
6. Myra was consoling one of her two children, Brad, who had been very close to his grandmother.
7. Bob was with his daughter Maria.
NOTE: Each of the 4 couples has at least 2 kids.
WHO IS THE KILLER?
Hint:
Draw a family tree.
Each of the 4 children of Mary Beem has a spouse, and each couple has children.  Since all must have at least two kids, only one couple has three kids (a total of 9 grandchildren).
Human Solution:
From the killer's sister's conversation, Bob is Mary's husband, Bill is one of Mary's children, and Bo is a grandchild.
From clue 1 and 2, Barry was a spouse, and since Bart, Buck and Bruce were all brothers, they were the set of three kids. Clue 3 is straightforward - Mary's daughter May is married to Ben and has two kids: Missy and Bernie.
From 4, Robin is a daughter and Bob her spouse.  From 5, Bo and Molly are siblings and grandchildren (since they have a cousin present). Megan has to be from the last couple.  Mo and Robin could only have been parents to the three boys (Bart Bruce and Buck), since all other siblings were a boy and girl.
Clue 6 gives the name of the remaining child, Brad, who must be a sibling of Megan. Both have a mother by the name of Myra. It is unknown at this point if Myra is a spouse or a direct relative.
Since clue 7 says that Bob (Mary's husband) was with his daughter Maria, Myra becomes a spouse. Then, by default, Bo and Molly belong to Maria.
So now, knowing that the killer's sister is COUSIN to Bo, Bill's NIECE, and Bob's GRANDDAUGHTER, the killer must be BERNIE.
Response:
Step-by-step reconstruction of the Beem family  

1.  The four children of Bob and the late Mary Beem  
    • Bill – married to Myra  
    • May – married to Ben  
    • Robin – married to Mo  
    • Maria – married to Barry   (Bill was “talking with his brother-in-law Barry”, so Barry must have married one of Bill’s sisters; Maria is that sister.)

2.  The grandchildren (exactly 9) must be divided among the four couples, each couple having at least two children and only one couple having three.  
    • May & Ben → Missy, Bernie   (given)  
    • Bill & Myra → Brad, Megan   (Myra is “consoling one of her two children, Brad”; Megan is the other.)  
    • Robin & Mo → Bart, Buck, Bruce   (Robin & Mo were “keeping an eye on their sons” – the only all-male sibling group, and it is the unique group of three.)  
    • Maria & Barry → Bo, Molly   (leaves Bo and Molly together and satisfies “Bo … his sister Molly”.)

3.  Check that every name listed is used and the total grandchildren count is 9:  
   Bart, Buck, Bruce, Missy, Bernie, Brad, Megan, Bo, Molly  → 9. ✔

4.  Interpret the clue about the killer’s sister.  
    “The killer's sister … talked to her grandfather Bob, her cousin Bo, and her (blood) uncle Bill.”  
    • The only female grandchildren who have Bo as a cousin (not a sibling) are Missy and Megan.  
    • Missy’s cousin Bo condition works (Bo is child of Maria, Missy is child of May).  
    • Megan’s cousin Bo also works, but Bill would then be her father, not her uncle, so Megan is ruled out.

    Therefore the suspicious sister is Missy.

5.  The killer is Missy’s sibling – the only one is Bernie.

Final answer: Bernie

Question:
Edward, Howard, and John are three high school students each of whom is taking three of the four subjects, biology, chemistry, history, and mathematics. One day while talking about their programs they made the following statements.
Edward: There is just one subject we're all taking. I'm the only one of us who is taking mathematics. No two of us are taking the same three subjects. John is wrong when he says that Howard and I are both taking chemistry.
Howard: Ed is the only one of us who is taking history. John and I are taking the same subjects. We're all taking biology. Two of us are taking both chemistry and biology.
John: We're all taking mathematics. Howard is taking history. Ed is taking one subject that I'm not. Both Howard and Ed are taking chemistry.
If two and only two of each boy's statements are true, what subjects is each boy taking?
Hint: It is true that there is only one subject they are all taking.
Human Solution:
Edward: chemistry, biology, history
Howard: chemistry, biology, mathematics
John: biology, mathematics, history
Response:
Let  

B = Biology, C = Chemistry, H = History, M = Mathematics.  
Each boy takes exactly three of the four subjects.

1.  The hint (and Edward’s first statement) tells us that
    There is exactly one subject that all three boys take.        (†)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Step 1 – Work with Edward’s statements  
Edward must have exactly two true and two false statements.

•  E1 : “There is just one subject we’re all taking.” – by the hint this is TRUE.  
  ⇒ Edward now needs exactly one more true statement among E2, E3, E4.

We next try to make E3 (“No two of us are taking the same three subjects”) TRUE  
and E2, E4 FALSE.  That will later turn out to be consistent.

If E3 is true then the three subject-sets must be pairwise different.      (1)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Step 2 – Make E4 false and see what that means  
E4 : “John is wrong when he says that Howard and I are both taking chemistry.”  
For E4 to be false, John’s corresponding statement J4 must be TRUE; hence

J4 (TRUE):  “Both Howard and Ed are taking chemistry.”  
⇒  H and E each have C.                                                    (2)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Step 3 – Analyse John’s four statements  
John also needs exactly two true statements.  We already have J4 = TRUE, so
he needs exactly one more true statement among J1, J2, J3.

J1 : “We’re all taking mathematics.”  
If this were true, M would be common to all three, contradicting (†).  
Therefore J1 is FALSE.                                                     (3)

Hence exactly one of J2 or J3 must be true and the other false.

Suppose J2 (“Howard is taking history”) were true.  
Then J3 would have to be false; but J3 would be false only if Ed had no subject
that John lacked, impossible because by (2) Ed has C while John need not.  
So J2 is FALSE and J3 is TRUE.                                            (4)

J3 (TRUE): “Ed is taking one subject that I’m not.”  
Because of (2) that “one subject” can be chemistry, so John must NOT take C.  (5)

Now we know John’s two true statements: J3 and J4.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Step 4 – Examine Howard’s statements  
Howard also needs exactly two true statements.

H3 : “We’re all taking biology.”  
Taking this as TRUE conveniently provides the single common subject required
by (†).  So Biology is that common subject: every boy has B.                (6)

With B common, H4 (“Two of us are taking both chemistry and biology”) will
be true exactly when exactly two boys have C.  From (2) Ed and Howard have C,
John does not (5), so H4 is TRUE.                                          (7)

Thus the two true Howard statements are H3 and H4, leaving

H1 (“Ed is the only one taking history”) and  
H2 (“John and I are taking the same subjects”) both FALSE.                 (8)

H1 false means either Ed does not take H or someone else also takes H.
Since John is the only boy left who could differ from Ed in this respect,
John must also take History; Howard does not.                              (9)

H2 false simply says Howard’s and John’s whole subject-sets are different,
which we shall satisfy.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Step 5 – Compile each boy’s list of subjects  
From (2), (5), (6), (9):

Edward : B and C, and (to differ from John) H, but not M.  
          ⇒  E = {B, C, H}

Howard : B and C, and (he lacks H) so he must have M.  
          ⇒  H = {B, C, M}

John   : B, must not have C (5), must have H (9), needs a third subject,
         so he takes M.  
          ⇒  J = {B, H, M}

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Step 6 – Final consistency check  
•  Exactly one subject (Biology) is common to all – yes.  
•  No two boys have identical sets – yes (E ≠ H ≠ J).  
•  Count true/false statements:  
   – Edward:  E1, E3 true; E2, E4 false.  
   – Howard:  H3, H4 true; H1, H2 false.  
   – John:    J3, J4 true; J1, J2 false.  
   Each has exactly two true statements.  All requirements are met.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Final answer:  
Edward takes Biology, Chemistry, and History.  
Howard takes Biology, Chemistry, and Mathematics.  
John takes Biology, History, and Mathematics.

Question:
During one meeting with a clan of ninjas, it has been noticed that more ninjas have turned up to the meeting than usual. The ninjas realised that these infiltrators must be the enemy of the ninjas (the pirates). Each person dressed as a ninja at the meeting made a statement. The cunning ninjas lied about their fellow ninjas in order to remain secret and told the truth about the pirates. The pirates tried to mock the cunningness by lying about the pirates and telling the truth about the ninjas. From the following statements, can you identify the ninjas and pirates?
Ninja A: Ninja B is a ninja
Ninja B: Ninja C belongs to Ninja A's group
Ninja C: Ninja C doesn't belong to Ninja F's group
Ninja D: Ninja A belongs to Ninja B's group
Ninja E: Ninja B belongs to Ninja C's group
Ninja F: Ninja E belongs to Ninja A's group
Remember, the ninjas and pirates will lie about individual ninjas or pirates, not groups of ninjas or pirates.
Hint: Think about what Ninja A said, first.
Human Solution:
Ninja A is a pirate
Ninja B is a ninja
Ninja C is a ninja
Ninja D is a pirate
Ninja E is a pirate
Ninja F is a ninja
Ninja A said that Ninja B is a ninja. This is because Ninja A is a pirate and Ninja B is a ninja, so Ninja A told the truth.
Ninja B said that Ninja C belongs to Ninja A's group. Ninja B is a ninja and Ninja C is a ninja, so Ninja B lied.
Ninja C said that Ninja C doesn't belong to Ninja F's group. Ninja C is obviously from the same group as Ninja C, so Ninja C lied.
Ninja D said that Ninja A belongs to Ninja B's group. Ninja D is a pirate and Ninja A is a pirate so Ninja D lied.
Ninja E said that Ninja B belongs to Ninja C's group. Ninja E is a pirate and Ninja B is a ninja, so Ninja E told the truth.
Ninja F said that Ninja E belongs to Ninja A's group. Ninja F is a ninja and Ninja E is a pirate, so Ninja F told the truth.
Response:
Step-by-step reasoning

1.  Examine Ninja A’s statement first (hint).

   A says: “B is a ninja.”

   • If A were a ninja, then
     –  when talking about another ninja he must lie,
     –  when talking about a pirate he must tell the truth.
     Neither choice works:
       –  if B is a ninja, A must lie ⇒ statement should be false, but it would be true;
       –  if B is a pirate, A must tell the truth ⇒ statement should be true, but it would be false.
     Therefore A cannot be a ninja.  
     ⇒ A is a pirate.

2.  Determine B.

   A is a pirate and has just talked about B.  
   Pirates lie about pirates and tell the truth about ninjas.

   • If B were a pirate, A (a pirate talking about a pirate) must lie, so
     “B is a ninja” would be false – which it is.  ✓  Possible.
   • If B were a ninja, A (a pirate talking about a ninja) must tell the truth, so
     “B is a ninja” would be true – which it is.  ✓  Possible.

   So A’s statement lets either choice for B remain, for now.

3.  Look at B’s own statement.

   B says: “C belongs to A’s group” (i.e. C and A are the same type).

   A is a pirate.  The statement is “C is a pirate.”

   If B is a ninja:
     – Talking about C:
         • If C is a ninja, a ninja must lie → statement must be false, so C ≠ A → C is a ninja while A is a pirate.  Works.
         • If C is a pirate, a ninja must tell the truth → statement must be true, so C = A → C is a pirate.  Works.
     Hence B can be a ninja, whichever C is.

   If B were a pirate, check the two possibilities for C:
     – If C is a ninja, a pirate must tell the truth → statement must be true, but C (ninja) ≠ A (pirate) ⇒ false.  Impossible.
     – If C is a pirate, a pirate must lie → statement must be false, but C (pirate) = A (pirate) ⇒ true.  Impossible.

   ⇒ B must be a ninja.

4.  C’s statement.

   C says: “C doesn’t belong to F’s group” (C and F are different).

   Regardless of C’s allegiance, the subject of the sentence is C himself.

   • If C is a ninja, a ninja talking about himself (a fellow ninja) must lie ⇒
     Statement must be false ⇒ C and F are the same.
   • If C is a pirate, a pirate talking about himself (a pirate) must lie ⇒
     Statement must be false ⇒ C and F are the same.

   ⇒ In every case C and F share the same allegiance.

5.  D’s statement.

   D says: “A belongs to B’s group” (A and B are the same).

   Subject: A (a pirate).

   • If D were a ninja, a ninja talking about a pirate must tell the truth: the statement would have to be true, but A (pirate) and B (ninja) differ.  Impossible.

   ⇒ D is a pirate, and being a pirate talking about a pirate he must lie, so the statement must indeed be false – which matches A ≠ B.  ✓

6.  E’s statement.

   E says: “B belongs to C’s group” (B and C are the same).

   Subject: B (a ninja).

   • If E is a ninja: talking about another ninja, he must lie ⇒ statement false ⇒ B and C differ ⇒ C is a pirate.
   • If E is a pirate: talking about a ninja, he must tell the truth ⇒ statement true ⇒ B and C the same ⇒ C is a ninja.

   Thus:
     – E ninja ⇒ C pirate (and from step 4, F pirate),
     – E pirate ⇒ C ninja (and F ninja).

7.  F’s statement settles the choice.

   F says: “E belongs to A’s group” (E and A are the same).

   Subject: E.

   Recall A is a pirate.

   (i)  Suppose E is a ninja, C pirate, F pirate.  
        F is a pirate talking about a ninja, so he must tell the truth.  
        Truth of statement would require E and A the same, but E (ninja) ≠ A (pirate).  Contradiction.

   (ii) Suppose E is a pirate, C ninja, F ninja (because F = C).  
        F is a ninja talking about a pirate, so he must tell the truth.  
        Truth of statement requires E and A the same, and both are pirates.  This is satisfied.

   Hence only the second possibility survives.

Final identities

A – pirate  
B – ninja  
C – ninja  
D – pirate  
E – pirate  
F – ninja

Final answer: Ninjas = {B, C, F}; Pirates = {A, D, E}.

Question:
T4 has a chart in his possession. On it says:
1 stands for O, U, D, or B
2 stands for S, K, Q, or T
3 stands for I, H, E, or N
4 stands for O, I, F, or W
5 stands for Z, U, Y, or S
6 stands for I, L, E, or C
Below that, he wrote the number "123456." This number, using the decryption method above, can mean two words that are antonyms. What are the two words?
Hint: One is the word "useful".
Human Solution: Otiose and useful.
Response:
Step-by-step reasoning

1.  Write down the letter choices that each digit can stand for.

   1 → O, U, D, B  
   2 → S, K, Q, T  
   3 → I, H, E, N  
   4 → O, I, F, W  
   5 → Z, U, Y, S  
   6 → I, L, E, C  

2.  Use the hint  
      1 2 3 4 5 6  =  U S E F U L  
    to verify that the word “USEFUL” really can be produced:
   • 1→U, 2→S, 3→E, 4→F, 5→U, 6→L – every choice is permitted, so “USEFUL” is valid.

3.  Look for another six-letter word that
   • is an antonym of “useful”, and
   • can be formed with the same digit–letter possibilities.

   A good antonym of “useful” is “OTIOSE” (meaning idle, serving no practical purpose, useless).

   Check it against the digit constraints:
   • 1 → O  (allowed)  
   • 2 → T  (allowed)  
   • 3 → I  (allowed)  
   • 4 → O  (allowed)  
   • 5 → S  (allowed)  
   • 6 → E  (allowed)  

   Every letter fits, so “OTIOSE” also corresponds to 123456.

4.  Thus 123456 can stand for either

      USEFUL  or  OTIOSE,

   and those two words are antonyms.

Final answer: USEFUL and OTIOSE

Question:
In the following code, each symbol stands for one of five letters.
) stands for T, E, S, A, or L
< stands for F, E, C, R, or P
> stands for E, R, L, K, or S
[ stands for F, S, E, D, or R
] stands for W, M, J, U, or Y
( stands for N, A, H, O, or B
The six letter code word, <([])>, can be translated into two English words that are opposites. What are the two words?
Hint: Attire
Human Solution: Casual and Formal
Response:
We are given the 6-symbol code < ( [ ] ) > and the five possible letters each symbol may represent:

1. )  →  T, E, S, A, L  
2. <  →  F, E, C, R, P  
3. >  →  E, R, L, K, S  
4. [  →  F, S, E, D, R  
5. ]  →  W, M, J, U, Y  
6. (  →  N, A, H, O, B  

We need two opposite English words of length 6 that can both be read from the same symbol pattern.  
The hint “Attire” suggests we look at words describing clothing style, such as the opposites “formal” and “casual.”

Check if “formal” can be produced:

Symbol   Needed letter   Allowed?  
<        F               F is allowed for <  
(        O               O is allowed for (  
[        R               R is allowed for [  
]        M               M is allowed for ]  
)        A               A is allowed for )  
>        L               L is allowed for >  

All positions work, so <([])> can spell FORMAL.

Check if “casual” can also be produced:

Symbol   Needed letter   Allowed?  
<        C               C is allowed for <  
(        A               A is allowed for (  
[        S               S is allowed for [  
]        U               U is allowed for ]  
)        A               A is allowed for )  
>        L               L is allowed for >  

Again, every letter fits, so the same coded string can also spell CASUAL, the opposite of FORMAL.

Thus the two opposite English words encoded by <([])> are:

Final answer: FORMAL and CASUAL

Question:
When Mad Ade was a private eye he never ceased to astound everyone by how quickly he could wrap up a case. One day he was out to solve yet another crime. It seems that someone had mischievously hacked into the online database maintained by "Honest Ron's Secondhand Underwear Emporium", and changed their password. The hacker then sent an untraceable e-mail that read: "wish about happiness but never ask, 341223." Within a few minutes Mad Ade has found the new password, allowing the company to get back on track.
What was the password?
Hint: Think about reversal
Human Solution:
Kebabs.
Reverse the order of the numbers given, then from beginning to end, that is the number of the letter in each word; once you have all 6 letters reverse them and that forms the password.
Response:
Start with the text that the hacker e-mailed  
wish about happiness but never ask, 341223.

1.  “Think about reversal”  
    → reverse the order of the words, but leave the digits in the same order:

    ask never but happiness about wish   341223

2.  Use the six digits 3-4-1-2-2-3 as letter positions in the six reversed words:

    1st word  ask        3rd letter → k  
    2nd word  never      4th letter → e  
    3rd word  but        1st letter → b  
    4th word  happiness  2nd letter → a  
    5th word  about      2nd letter → b  
    6th word  wish       3rd letter → s  

3.  Reading those letters gives the password:

    k e b a b s  →  kebabs

Final answer: kebabs

Question:
Captain John is the captain of a pirate ship called the "Wasp".  He just heard about a lost treasure on a far away island.  He needs to get his two crew mates, and lead them to a ship, but there are guards around and he needs to do this without passing them, or they will throw him in the brig.  Can you help him get his two crew mates to the ship without getting sent to the brig?
The positions of everything are in a 3-by-3 grid (1 John, 1 ship, 2 crew mates, 2 guards, and 3 grass areas).  John may only move 1 space at a time, either vertically, horizontally, or diagonally.  He can only go to each space once.
But before he can figure out the right way to go, he must figure out where everything is.  This is what he knew:
1. The Wasp is not in the same row or column as John.
2.  John is not in the same row or column as either guard.
3.  Neither guard is in the third column.
4.  Both guards are vertically next to grass.
5.  The ship is in the same row as one guard, and the same column as the other guard.
6.  One of the grass spaces is diagonally next to both crew mates.
7.  One of the grass spaces is in the 2nd column, in the first row.
8.  The two guards are not in the same row or column.
Hint: Use paper and pencil.
Human Solution:
The positions of everything.
Guard - Grass - Crew Mate
Grass - Grass - John
Ship - Guard - Crew Mate
The correct way for John to go (1-7, in order of each space he goes to, X meaning don't go).
X - 5 - 4
6 - 3 - 1
7 - X - 2
Response:
Let the 3 × 3 board be written with rows numbered 1 (top) to 3 (bottom) and columns numbered 1 (left) to 3 (right).  
Each of the nine squares must contain exactly one of  

 J  (John), S (ship “Wasp”), G₁ and G₂ (guards),  
 C₁ and C₂ (crew-mates), X₁ , X₂ , X₃ (grass).

Step-by-step use of the eight clues

1.  Clue 7 tells us that square (1,2) is grass.  
2.  Because of clue 6 we need a grass square that is diagonally adjacent to both crew-mates.  
   • The only square that has at least two diagonal neighbours and is still free is the centre (2,2).  
     ⇒ Let (2,2) be the second grass square.  
   • Its diagonal neighbours are the four corners, so the two crew-mates must occupy two different corners.

3.  Neither guard can stand in column 3 (clue 3).  
   A guard must have a grass square immediately above or below it (clue 4).

   • Square (3,2) is perfect for a guard because the square just above it, (2,2), is grass.  
   • To satisfy clue 8 the other guard must be in column 1 and in a different row from row 3; that leaves
     (1,1) or (2,1).
     – (2,1) would not be vertically next to grass (its neighbours (1,1) and (3,1) are not grass yet),
       so it cannot be a guard.
     – (1,1) works if we make (2,1) a grass square.  
       ⇒ Guards are placed at (1,1) and (3,2); the third grass square is (2,1).

4.  So far the board is  

 Row 1 : (1,1)=G₁ (1,2)=X₁ (1,3)=?  
 Row 2 : (2,1)=X₃ (2,2)=X₂ (2,3)=?  
 Row 3 : (3,1)=? (3,2)=G₂ (3,3)=?

5.  The two remaining corner squares that are diagonal to X₂=(2,2) are (1,3) and (3,3); they become the two crew-mates (clue 6).

6.  John must lie in neither a row nor a column with any guard (clue 2).  
   Guards occupy row 1 / col 1 and row 3 / col 2, so John must be in row 2 and column 3.  
   ⇒ John is at (2,3).

7.  The ship must be in the same row as one guard and in the same column as the other guard (clue 5), and it must avoid John’s row and column (clue 1).  
   • Row of guard G₂ is row 3, column of guard G₁ is column 1.  
     ⇒ Ship goes to (3,1).

8.  Every square is now filled and all clues are satisfied:

 Row 1 :  G₁ X₁ C₁  
 Row 2 :  X₃ X₂ J  
 Row 3 :  S  G₂ C₂  

 (1,1) (1,2) (1,3)  
 (2,1) (2,2) (2,3)  
 (3,1) (3,2) (3,3)

 =  G₁ X₁ C₁  
    X₃ X₂ J  
    S  G₂ C₂

A legal path for John

John starts at (2,3).  
Moving one square at a time, never revisiting a square and never stepping onto a guard, he can collect both crew-mates and finish on the ship as follows:

(2,3) J  →  (3,3) C₂  →  (2,2) X₂  →  (1,3) C₁  →  (1,2) X₁  →  (2,1) X₃  →  (3,1) S.

So John successfully leads both crew-mates to the Wasp without ever passing a guard.

Final answer: the unique placement satisfying all the clues is  

 G (guard) at (1,1) and (3,2);  
 Crew at (1,3) and (3,3);  
 Grass at (1,2), (2,1), (2,2);  
 John at (2,3);  
 Ship at (3,1).

Question:
After days and days of placing things, taking things out of boxes, and arranging furniture, Ellen was set to decorate her new apartment.  She carefully unpacked the 18 prints of her favorite artists she had collected for a long time and decided to place them through the five rooms in her humble abode, displaying at least two prints in each room.  The prints show the works of four artists and Ellen owns no more than six prints of each artist's work.  Now that she's put together her new place, Ellen's living space finally feels like home!  From the information provided, can you figure out the number, if any, of Degas, Monet, Pissaro, and Sisley prints Ellen hung in each room?  This one will require a little math...
Rooms:  Kitchen, Parlor, Bedroom, Dining, Den
Artists:  Degas, Monet, Pissaro, Sisley
1.  Ellen mounted the same quantity of pictures in the kitchen as she did in the parlor.  She placed the same amount of Monet images in the bedroom as she did in the parlor.
2.  Ellen mounted at least one Pissaro picture in the dining room.  She didn't mount any prints by Degas or Sisley in the den.
3.  The sum of Sisley prints Ellen had acquired is the same amount as the sum of Degas prints she owns in addition to the sum of the prints she's placed in the den.
4.  The parlor contains fewer pictures than the only room in which three Sisley images were mounted but more prints than the only room in which two Degas prints were hung.
5.  The total number of Monet pictures Ellen owns is the same as the total number of paintings by Degas she owns plus the total number of prints she mounted in the kitchen.  Ellen didn't place any pictures by Monet or Degas in the kitchen.
6.  Ellen didn't mount any Sisley images in the kitchen or Degas pictures in the bedroom.
Hint: It might be easiest to draw out a chart (5 columns (room, Degas, Monet, Pissaro, Sisley) with 5 rows each to get your answer.
Human Solution:
There are 18 prints total as mentioned in the introduction.
Bedroom:
0 Degas
2 Monet
0 Pissaro
3 Sisley
Den:
0 Degas
2 Monet
0 Pissaro
0 Sisley
Dining:
2 Degas
0 Monet
1 Pissaro
0 Sisley
Kitchen:
0 Degas
0 Monet
4 Pissaro
0 Sisley
Parlor:
0 Degas
2 Monet
1 Pissaro
1 Sisley
Response:
Let  

 K , P , B , Dg , De denote Kitchen, Parlor, Bedroom, Dining-room, Den.  
 D , M , P , S    denote the artists Degas, Monet, Pissarro, Sisley.  

Put the number of prints of each artist in each room in a 5 × 4 table.  
Room totals are denoted Kₜ , Pₜ , Bₜ , Dgₜ , Deₜ ; artist totals T_D , T_M , T_P , T_S.  
All unknowns are non-negative integers.

Facts translated from the six clues  

(1)   Kₜ = Pₜ  and  B_M = P_M  

(2)   Dining has at least one Pissarro  
   Den has no Degas and no Sisley  

(3)   T_S = T_D + Deₜ  (the total number of Sisleys equals the total Degas plus the total in the Den)

(4)   Exactly one room has 3 Sisley prints; exactly one room has 2 Degas prints  
   Pₜ is less than the total of the 3-Sisley room and larger than the total of the 2-Degas room.

(5)   T_M = T_D + Kₜ  and  K has neither Monet nor Degas

(6)   K has no Sisley; B has no Degas

There are 18 pictures altogether and at least two in each room.  
Because K contains neither Degas, Monet, nor Sisley, every print there is a Pissarro; hence Kₜ ≥ 2.  
From (1) Pₜ = Kₜ as well.

------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  Limiting the size of the Parlor

From (5) T_M = T_D + Kₜ = T_D + Pₜ.  
Since no artist total exceeds 6, T_M ≤ 6 gives T_D + Pₜ ≤ 6.  
Further, from (4) the two Degas prints are not in the Parlor (otherwise Pₜ could not exceed the total of that same room), so the 2-Degas room must be the Dining-room.  
Thus T_D = 2 + P_D (P_D is Degas in the Parlor, which cannot equal 2).  
Again using T_M ≤ 6 one gets P_D + Pₜ + 2 ≤ 6 ⇒ P_D + Pₜ ≤ 4.

Because every room has at least two prints, Pₜ is 2, 3, or 4.  
If Pₜ were 2 or 3 the Dining-room, already containing the two Degas prints plus at least one Pissarro, would tie or exceed Pₜ, contradicting clause (4).  
Therefore Pₜ = Kₜ = 4.

With Pₜ = 4, P_D must be 0 (it cannot be 1,3,4 and still satisfy P_D + Pₜ ≤ 4).  
Hence T_D = 2.

------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  Determining the total number of Monet and bounding the Den

From (5) T_M = T_D + Kₜ = 2 + 4 = 6.  
So Ellen owns the maximum possible six Monet prints.

Kitchen and Parlor already account for none and some of them; let P_M = x.  
Because B_M = P_M, 2x Monet prints are in the Parlor and Bedroom.  
The remaining 6 – 2x Monet must be placed in the Den (the Dining-room is full: 2 Degas + 1 Pissarro).  
Since the Den contains only Monet or Pissarro, the smallest value making this possible is x = 2:

 P_M = 2, B_M = 2, Den contains the remaining 2 Monet prints.

With exactly 2 Monet prints, the Den must contain at least 2 pictures; call its total Deₜ = t.  
Clause (3) now reads T_S = T_D + Deₜ = 2 + t.  
Because T_S ≤ 6, t ≤ 4; because every room has ≥2 pictures, t ≥ 2.

------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  Fixing the remaining room totals

The Kitchen, Parlor and Dining totals are fixed: 4 + 4 + 3 = 11.  
Hence Deₜ + Bₜ = 18 – 11 = 7 so Bₜ = 7 – t.

------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  Choosing t and distributing the Sisleys

If t = 2 then T_S = 4 and Bₜ = 5.  
Parlor still has two empty slots and Bedroom has three (after allowing for their Monet prints).  
Only Parlor or Bedroom can hold Sisleys (none are in Kitchen, Dining or Den).  
To satisfy “exactly one room contains three Sisleys”, set  

 Parlor: 1 Sisley,  
 Bedroom: 3 Sisleys.

All numerical requirements now match:

Kitchen   0 D 0 M 4 P 0 S  (4)

Parlor     0 D 2 M 1 P 1 S  (4)

Bedroom    0 D 2 M 0 P 3 S  (5)

Dining-rm   2 D 0 M 1 P 0 S  (3)

Den         0 D 2 M 0 P 0 S  (2)

Totals: D 2, M 6, P 6, S 4 —all not exceeding 6.

------------------------------------------------------------------
5.  Verifying every clue

1.  Kₜ = Pₜ (=4) and B_M = P_M (=2) ✔  
2.  Dining has a Pissarro; Den has no Degas or Sisley ✔  
3.  T_S = 4 = 2 + 2 = T_D + Deₜ ✔  
4.  Parlor (4 prints) is > 2-Degas room (Dining, 3 prints) and < 3-Sisley room (Bedroom, 5 prints) ✔  
5.  T_M = 6 = 2 + 4 = T_D + Kₜ; Kitchen has no Monet or Degas ✔  
6.  Kitchen has no Sisley; Bedroom has no Degas ✔

All conditions are met, so the distribution is unique.

Final answer:  
Kitchen – 0 Degas, 0 Monet, 4 Pissarro, 0 Sisley  
Parlor  – 0 Degas, 2 Monet, 1 Pissarro, 1 Sisley  
Bedroom – 0 Degas, 2 Monet, 0 Pissarro, 3 Sisley  
Dining  – 2 Degas, 0 Monet, 1 Pissarro, 0 Sisley  
Den     – 0 Degas, 2 Monet, 0 Pissarro, 0 Sisley

Question:
In an attempt to further protect his secret chicken recipe, Colonel Sanders has locked it away in a safe with a 10-digit password. Unable to resist his crispy fried chicken, you'd like to crack the code. Try your luck using the following information:
All digits from 0 to 9 are used exactly once.
No digit is the same as the position which it occupies in the sequence.
The sum of the 5th and 10th digits is a square number other than 9.
The sum of the 9th and 10th digits is a cube.
The 2nd digit is an even number.
Zero is in the 3rd position.
The sum of the 4th, 6th and 8th digits is a single digit number.
The sum of the 2nd and 5th digits is a triangle number.
Number 8 is 2 spaces away from the number 9 (one in between).
The number 3 is next to the 9 but not the zero.
Hint: A triangle number is one which can be written with one number on the first line, 2 on the second, 3 on the third etc. Like ten-pin bowling style! (The first of these are 1, 3, 6)
Response:
Let the 10-digit password be  

D₁ D₂ D₃ D₄ D₅ D₆ D₇ D₈ D₉ D₁₀   (positions 1 … 10).

1.  “All digits 0-9 are used once”  ⇒ {Dᵢ}= {0,…,9}.  
2.  “No digit equals its position”  ⇒  Dᵢ ≠ i.  
3.  “Zero is in the 3rd position”  ⇒  D₃ = 0.  

–––––– Using the two conditions that involve the 10th digit ––––––

4.  D₅ + D₁₀ is a square (≠9).  
5.  D₉ + D₁₀ is a cube.

The only cubes ≤ 9+8 =17 are 0,1,8; 8 is the only feasible one here, so

  D₉ + D₁₀ = 8.  (1)

Squares ≤17 other than 9 are 0,1,4,16.  
0 and 1 are impossible (would require another 0).  
Square 4 gives the unordered pair {1,3}; square 16 gives {7,9}.

Case analysis:

•  {1,3}:  
 If (D₅ , D₁₀) = (1,3) then (1) gives D₉ = 5.  
 If (D₅ , D₁₀) = (3,1) then (1) gives D₉ = 7.  
 Both cases will be ruled out later.

•  {7,9}:  
 (D₅ , D₁₀) cannot be (7,9) (would make D₉ = –1).  
 Take (D₅ , D₁₀) = (9,7); then (1) gives D₉ = 1.

Thus the only viable triple is
 D₅ = 9, D₉ = 1, D₁₀ = 7.  (2)

–––––– Apply the remaining statements ––––––

6.  “The 2nd digit is even” and “D₂ + D₅ is triangular”.

   Triangular numbers ≤ 18 are 1,3,6,10,15.  
   With D₅ = 9, we need D₂ + 9 ∈ {10,15}.  
   D₂ is even and not 2 (would clash with its position).

   • 10 ⇒ D₂ = 1 (odd).  
   • 15 ⇒ D₂ = 6 (even, and 6 ≠ 2).  

   So D₂ = 6.  (3)

7.  “3 is next to 9 but not next to 0.”  
   Since 9 is at position 5, the 3 must be at position 4 or 6.  
   Position 4 is adjacent both to 9 (good) and to 0 at position 3 (bad).  
   Therefore D₆ = 3.  (4)

8.  “8 is two spaces away from 9 (one in between).”  
   With 9 at position 5, 8 must be at position 7.  

  D₇ = 8.  (5)

9.  Digits used so far: 0,1,3,6,7,8,9.  
   Remaining unused digits: 2,4,5 to fill positions 1,4,8.

10.  “D₄ + D₆ + D₈ is a single–digit number.”  
    D₆ = 3, so D₄ + D₈ + 3 < 10.  
    Try the possibilities with {2,4,5}:

    • D₄ = 2, D₈ = 4 → 2 + 3 + 4 = 9  (OK)  
    • any other assignment gives ≥10.

    Hence D₄ = 2, D₈ = 4.  (6)

11.  The last unused digit 5 goes to the remaining spot:

  D₁ = 5.  (7)

–––––– Check every condition ––––––

Sequence obtained: 5 6 0 2 9 3 8 4 1 7  

• all ten digits present and distinct – yes  
• no digit equals its position – yes  
• D₅ + D₁₀ = 9 + 7 = 16 (square, not 9) – yes  
• D₉ + D₁₀ = 1 + 7 = 8 (cube) – yes  
• D₂ even – yes (6)  
• 0 in position 3 – yes  
• D₄ + D₆ + D₈ = 2 + 3 + 4 = 9 (single digit) – yes  
• D₂ + D₅ = 6 + 9 = 15 (triangular) – yes  
• 8 two places from 9 – positions 5 and 7 – yes  
• 3 next to 9 but not next to 0 – positions 5 and 6; 3 not adjacent to position 3 – yes  

All clues satisfied uniquely.

Final answer: 5602938417

Question:
There is a plot of land that is 16 square acres, arranged in a 4 X 4 grid.  There are 16 mammals, two each of the following: beaver, cat, dog, goat, horse, lion, tiger, and walrus.  There is one mammal in each acre.  The acres are labeled A through P, as shown below.
A B C D
E F G H
I J K L
M N O P
Given the following clues, determine where each mammal is located.  The terms "next to" and "connected together" mean vertically, horizontally, or diagonally.
1) A and D do not contain the same mammal, but one of them has a dog.
2) E and O do not contain the same mammal, but one of them has a horse.
3) B and L contain the same mammal, but not a tiger.
4) C and M contain the same mammal, but not a beaver.
5) F, K, N, and P are four different mammals.
6) The tigers are in different columns.
7) The goats are located in two of the following locations: B, C, K, and O.
8) The lions are located in two of the following locations: A, E, F, and M.
9) Cats don't get along with dogs, so neither cat is next to a dog.
10) Tigers have goats on their menu, so each tiger must be next to at least one goat and each goat must be next to at least one tiger.
11) The beavers and walruses live on the same body of water, so all four must be connected together in some fashion.
Hint: Look at hint 3, then 4, then 7 as the first three hints
Human Solution:
A = lion, B = cat, C = walrus, D = dog
E = horse, F = lion, G = beaver, H = tiger
I = dog, J = beaver, K = goat, L = cat
M = walrus, N = tiger, O = goat, P = horse
Per #3, B & L are the same; per #4, C & M are the same; therefore, per #7, K & O are goats; therefore, per #2, E is a horse; therefore, per #8, A & F are lions; therefore, per #1, D is a dog.
Per #4, C & M are not beavers; per #9, C is not a cat; per #10, M is not a tiger; therefore, C & M are walruses; therefore, per #11, G & J are beavers.
Per #3, B & L are not tigers; therefore, B & L are cats.  Per #6, N is a tiger; per #9, H & P are not a dog; therefore, I is a dog.
Per #5, P is a horse; therefore, H is a tiger.
Response:
Reasoning steps (summarized):
1. From clues 7 and 3–4 we deduce that the two goats must be at K and O.  
2. Clue 2 then forces E to be the horse.  
3. Clue 8 now puts the two lions in A and F; from clue 1 this makes D the dog.  
4. Cats cannot touch a dog, so B and L (which must contain the same, non-tiger animal) are both cats.  
5. To satisfy clue 11 (the four beavers and walruses form one connected group) the only workable way is  
   C = M = walrus and G = J = beaver, giving the connected chain C-G-J-M.  
6. Clue 10 (tigers next to goats) together with clue 5 (F,K,N,P all different) forces the two tigers to be at H and N.  
7. Because cats are at B and L, the second dog cannot be adjacent to them; the remaining places for the extra dog and the remaining horse are I and P, with P forbidden for a dog (adjacent to cat L). Thus I = dog and P = horse.  
8. All quantities and remaining clues are now satisfied and the solution is unique.

Final answer:  
A lion B cat C walrus D dog  
E horse F lion G beaver H tiger  
I dog J beaver K goat L cat  
M walrus N tiger O goat P horse

Question:
Three sportsmen, Tom, Jim and Sam, are standing in a row, and we can see their backs. Each of them wears a suit, which are red, yellow and blue in no particular order. Each suit has a different number, between 2 and 9, inclusive. Clues are:
1. In the order they stand, the three numbers form a perfect square.
2. Tom's number is smaller than the rightmost sportsman's number.
3. The yellow suit's number is odd.
4. The factorial of Sam's number, plus one, is divisible by the red suit's number.
Hint: One of the clues is very important.
Human Solution:
Left: Tom, yellow, 5;
Middle: Jim, red, 7;
Right: Sam, blue, 6.
From clue 4, the red suit's number must be greater than Sam's number, and must be odd. By trial and error, the possible combinations are (3,2), (5,4), (7,3), (7,6).
From clue 1, the square can only be 324 or 576, where 3 or 7 is the red suit's number.
From clue 3, the square must be 576, and 5 is the yellow suit's number and 6 the blue one.
From clue 2, Tom must be the 5 and Jim the 7.
Response:
Let us denote the three positions we see (from left to right) by L-M-R and write the digit on each suit in that same order.  
Because the three digits form a perfect square (clue 1) and each digit is 2–9, the only three–digit squares that qualify are

256, 289, 324, 529, 576, 625, 729 and 784.

–––––  The key ( “very important” ) clue 4  –––––  
For Sam’s number s and the number r on the red suit we require  
  s! + 1 ≡ 0 (mod r).

Within the range 2–9 the only pairs (s, r) that satisfy this are

(s, r) = (2,3), (3,7), (4,5) or (6,7).

Hence the digits s and r must both appear among the three digits of the square.

Testing each candidate square:

• 256 – contains 2,5,6 (no 3 or 7) → impossible.  
• 289 – contains 2,8,9 (no 3,5 or 7) → impossible.  
• 324 – contains 3,2,4.  It could match (2,3) but the only odd digit 3 would have to be both red (from clue 4) and yellow (clue 3) – impossible.  
• 529 – lacks any suitable (s, r) pair.  
• 625 – lacks a suitable pair.  
• 729 – lacks a suitable pair.  
• 784 – lacks a suitable pair.

• 576 – contains 5,7,6 and fits pair (s, r) = (6,7):

 Sam’s number s = 6, red-suit number r = 7, and 6! + 1 = 721 = 7 × 103 ✔.

Now distribute the remaining facts:

Digits in order L-M-R are 5-7-6.

• Odd digit(s): 5 and 7.  
 Since 7 is already on the red suit, the yellow suit must be the one with 5 (clue 3).

Thus  
 L (digit 5) – yellow suit,  
 M (digit 7) – red suit,  
 R (digit 6) – blue suit.

Sam’s digit is 6, so Sam stands on the right.  
Tom’s number must be smaller than the right-hand digit (clue 2), hence Tom is left with number 5.  
The remaining sportsman, Jim, is in the middle with number 7.

Everything is now consistent:

 • Left : Tom – yellow 5  
 • Middle : Jim – red 7  
 • Right : Sam – blue 6  
 and 576 = 24², a perfect square.

Final answer: Tom stands left wearing the yellow suit with number 5; Jim stands in the middle wearing the red suit with number 7; Sam stands on the right wearing the blue suit with number 6.

Question:
Fred Farley spent his summers up north in a cottage on Stoney Lake. There, he often debated with his friends what type of bait was best to use for the fish in the waters.  He decided one year to hold a fishing tournament with the best fishers on the lake, each using a different casting lure.  5 men competed (Fred Farley was NOT one of them) and points were awarded in four categories to determine a winner:
Greatest total Weight of fish caught: 4 points
Greatest Number of fish caught: 3 points
Largest Fish: 2 points
Second-largest fish: 1 point
Winning more than one category: 1 bonus point
Two fishermen did not win any of the categories and first place ended up being a tie between two men who received the same amount of points.
From the statements below, determine the first and last name of each of the contestants, what casting lure was used, and who won each category.
1. Mike (who was one of the category winners), Mr. Black (who is not Terry), and the one that used the plastic worm live near each other.
2. Vick, who did not win the total weight category, did not use the spinner bait; nor did Mr. McNess.
3. The one that used the weighted jig, who was not Terry, did not win any of the categories.
4. Neither Sam nor Mr. Larson live near any of the other three contestants, nor did either use a spinner bait or deep-running crank bait.
5. The fisherman who won the largest-fish category, who was not Mr. Smith, used spinner bait.
6. Mr. Jones, who caught the most fish, did not use a deep-running crank bait.
7. Both Mr. McNess (who did not use a deep running crank bait) and Terry (who did not use a plastic worm) had boat trouble and started after the others.
8. A wounded-minnow was used as one of the casting lures, and Kevin was one of the contestants.
Hint: Since only 3 of the contestants won the 4 categories, one of them won two and earned a bonus point.  Since there were two first places, the only possible outcome was that they both received 4 points. Therefore, one contestant won the total weight category (4 points), and another won the largest, second largest category and earned a bonus point (2 + 1 + 1 points).
Human Solution:
Kevin Black, spinner bait, largest fish and second largest fish category, bonus for winning two categories, 4 points.
Mike Smith, crank bait, total weight, 4 points
Sam McNess, weighted jig, no category, 0 points
Terry Larson, wounded minnow bait, no category, 0 points
Vick Jones, plastic worm, most fish, 3 points.
From 1: Mike won a category, is not Mr. Black, and did not use the plastic worm.  Mr. Black is not Mike or Terry and did not use the plastic worm.
From 2:  Vick is not Mr. Mc Ness, did not win total weight and did not use the spinner bait. Mr. McNess did not use the spinner bait.
From 3: Terry did not use the weighted jig. The weighted jig won no category.
From 4: Sam is not Larson or Black, and did not use the spinner, deep running crank or plastic worm bait.  Mr. Larson is not Mike, and did not use the spinner, deep running crank or plastic worm bait.
From 5: Mr. Smith did not win the largest fish or use the spinner bait. The largest fish was caught using the spinner bait.
Since Vick and Sam did not use the spinner, they did not win the largest fish category.  Since Mike won a category, he did not use the jig.
From 6: Mr. Jones won the most fish and, therefore, did not use the spinner bait, did not use the deep running crank bait either. Therefore, Black used the spinner and was the largest fish winner. Since Vick did not win the largest fish, by elimination, Kevin is Mr. Black.
From 7: Mr. McNess is not Terry and did not use a deep running crank bait. Therefore, Smith could have only used the crank bait.  Terry did not use a worm. Therefore, Vick used the worm and Sam used the weighted jig (and therefore won no category).
The worm (used by Vick) was thereby only used by either McNess or Jones, and since 2 says Vick is not Mc Ness, Vick is therefore Jones.
Terry, then, is Larson and won no category. Mike then wins the total weight category.
Then by summing up the leftover information, Terry uses the minnow and leaves Mike with the deep-running crank bait. That, in turn, makes Mike's last name Smith. Sam is then McNess.
Response:
Contestants

1. Kevin Black – spinner bait – caught the Largest Fish and the Second-largest Fish (earned bonus point)  
2. Mike Smith – deep-running crank bait – won Greatest Total Weight  
3. Vick Jones – plastic worm – caught the Greatest Number of fish  
4. Sam McNess – weighted jig – no category won  
5. Terry Larson – wounded-minnow lure – no category won  

(The ties for first place were Kevin Black and Mike Smith, each with 4 points.)

Final answer:  
Kevin Black used a spinner bait and won both the largest-fish and second-largest-fish categories (plus the bonus).  
Mike Smith used a deep-running crank bait and won the greatest-total-weight category.  
Vick Jones used a plastic worm and won the greatest-number-of-fish category.  
Sam McNess used a weighted jig and won no category.  
Terry Larson used a wounded-minnow lure and won no category.

Question:
Long ago, back before serious illness existed and the new inventions of today, there lived the Handy People. Their height was measured in hands, and they lived long lives.  From the statements below identify each of the 5 Handy people's height (12, 13, 14, 15 and 16 hands) and their ages (100, 110, 120, 130 and 140 years).
TWIST: One statement is FALSE.
1. Har was not the oldest, nor was he the shortest or tallest.
2. Winn was taller than Edvo, who was taller but younger than Frer.
3. Tolo, who was not the second oldest, was older than Har, and shorter than Frer.
4. The one who was 13 hands tall was the oldest.
5. Har was taller and older than Winn and Tolo.
6. The fourth oldest was taller than Tolo, but shorter than Edvo, who was older than Winn.
Hint: it is impossible that both 3 and 5 be true
Human Solution:
Edvo, 15 hands, 130 years
Frer, 13 hands, 140 years
Har, 14 hands, 110 years
Tolo, 12 hands, 120 years
Winn, 16 hands, 100 years
When going through all the statements, it is impossible that both 3 and 5 be true. (3 says Tolo is older than Har while 5 says Har is older than Tolo.) 2 gives the order of height as Winn, Edvo, and Frer. If 5 is true, then Har must be the tallest, but this contradicts 1, therefore 5 is false.
From 1, 2 and 3 it can be seen that the order of height is Winn, Edvo, Frer, and Tolo - with Har somewhere in between but not the shortest or tallest. Therefore Winn is 16 hands, and Tolo is 12.
Since Har is not the oldest, he is not 13 hands, which makes Frer 13 hands and the oldest.
From 3 and 6, Tolo is not the 2nd or 4th oldest and is not the youngest. Therefore he becomes 120 years. Also from 6, Edvo is not the 4th oldest or youngest. Therefore he is 130 years.
Since the 4th oldest is shorter than Edvo, Har must be it at 110 years. And Winn is the youngest. Since the 4th oldest was shorter than Edvo, Har is 14 hands and Edvo is 15 hands.
Response:
Reasoning  

Let the five Handy people be Har, Winn, Edvo, Frer and Tolo.  
Heights (in hands): 12, 13, 14, 15, 16.  
Ages (in years): 100, 110, 120, 130, 140 (oldest).  
Exactly one of the six statements is false and the hint says that statements 3 and 5 cannot both be true, so one of them must be the single false statement.

────────────────────────────────────────
1.  Assume statement 3 is false and all others true.  
 • From statement 4 the 13-hand person is the 140-year-old; statement 1 then
   forces Har’s height to be 14 or 15 (not 13, 12 or 16).  
 • Statement 5 (true under this assumption) says Har is taller than both Winn and
   Tolo, so Har must be the tallest of the three.  
 • From statement 2 Winn > Edvo > Frer in height, hence at least one of Winn or
   Edvo must be 16 hands, for otherwise 16 hands would be unused.  But Har is
   taller than Winn, so Winn cannot be 16; Edvo can’t be 16 either (Winn > Edvo),
   nor can Frer (Edvo > Frer), nor Tolo (Har > Tolo).  Therefore 16 hands is left
   without an owner – impossible.  
 ⇒ Contradiction: statement 3 cannot be the false one.

────────────────────────────────────────
2.  Therefore statement 3 is true and statement 5 is the single false statement.  
   Record the true information:

 • (1) Har is not the oldest, and his height is neither 12 nor 16.  
 • (2) Heights: Winn > Edvo > Frer. Ages: Frer > Edvo.  
 • (3) Tolo is older than Har, is not the 130-year-old (“second oldest”),
    and Tolo is shorter than Frer.  
 • (4) The 13-hand person is the 140-year-old.  
 • (6) The 110-year-old is taller than Tolo but shorter than Edvo, and
    Edvo is older than Winn.

Let us try to fit the five distinct heights 12–16 to satisfy the chains of
inequalities:

 From (2) and (6): Winn > Edvo > (110-yr-old) > Tolo, and Edvo > Frer > Tolo.  
 So Winn must be the tallest of all five.

Give Winn the only possible tallest height, 16.  
To keep Winn > Edvo > (110-yr-old), let Edvo be 15 and the 110-year-old be 14.  
Frer must be < Edvo and ≥ 13; choose Frer = 13 (which automatically makes
Frer the 140-year-old by statement 4).  
That leaves height 12 for Tolo.  All heights are now distinct:

 Winn 16 > Edvo 15 > (110-yr-old) 14 > Frer 13 > Tolo 12.

The 110-year-old is Har (no one else has height 14), satisfying Har ≠ 12,16.

Ages still to place (besides Frer = 140 and Har = 110): 100, 120, 130.

 • From (6) Edvo > Winn in age, so let Winn be 100 and Edvo be 130.  
 • From (3) Tolo is older than Har (110) but not the 130-year-old; therefore
   Tolo is 120.

All age relations are now satisfied, and statement 5 is indeed false:  
– Har (14 hands, 110 yrs) is NOT taller than Winn (16 hands) and NOT older than
  Tolo (120 yrs).

Thus every statement except 5 is true and all conditions are met.

────────────────────────────────────────
The complete solution

Har – 14 hands, 110 years  
Winn – 16 hands, 100 years  
Edvo – 15 hands, 130 years  
Frer – 13 hands, 140 years  
Tolo – 12 hands, 120 years

Final answer: Har 14 hands 110 yrs; Winn 16 hands 100 yrs; Edvo 15 hands 130 yrs; Frer 13 hands 140 yrs; Tolo 12 hands 120 yrs.

Question:
You have four kiddies' building blocks with a different letter on each side. You notice that by rearranging the blocks several times, the following list of words can be formed:
pink
jest
rope
quip
goal
cony
frog
dark
site
glum
wack
have
tiny
wish
bins
What letters appear on each block?
Hint: The letters n and e are on the same block.
Human Solution:
Block 1: p, a, f, m, y, s
Block 2: i, r, l, c, v, j
Block 3: n, e, d, g, q, w
Block 4: k, o, u, t, h, b
Response:
We have four cubes, each with six different letters, and every 4-letter word in the list must be spelt with one letter from each cube.  That means:

•  all 24 distinct letters occurring in the words must be distributed, six per cube;  
•  within any word no two of its letters may come from the same cube.

─────────────────────────────────────
1.  Putting N and E together
─────────────────────────────────────
The hint tells us that N and E are on one cube.  
Call this cube A.

Any letter that ever appears in the same word as N or E cannot be on A.  
Those letters are  
P I K T Y C O B S R J H A V.

The eight letters that never appear with N or E are  
D F G L M Q U W,  
so the four still-vacant faces of cube A must be chosen from these eight.

─────────────────────────────────────
2.  Finding a cube for I
─────────────────────────────────────
Letter I occurs in six words and cannot share a cube with any of the letters it meets there:
P K Q U S T Y B W H N E.

So put I (and later J, needed for the word JEST) on a second cube, call it B.

─────────────────────────────────────
3.  Completing cube A
─────────────────────────────────────
Choose four of D F G L M Q U W whose members never occur together in any word.  
{D,Q,G,W} satisfies this, giving

Cube A :  D E G N Q W.

─────────────────────────────────────
4.  Completing cube B
