B. With W out, simplify some rules  
 Rule 3 becomes (¬A) ⇒ Ch.  
 Rule 1 becomes (¬V) ⇒ C.

Case 1: V is in P  
 Rule 2 then forbids A, so the mate of V can only be L, C or Ch.  
 But without A (and W already absent), rule 3 demands Ch.  
 Therefore the only possibility is {V, Ch}.  
 Check it:  
  Rule 1 – antecedent false (V present) ✔  
  Rule 2 – V present, A absent ✔  
  Rule 3 – antecedent true, Ch present ✔  
  Rule 4 – no L, no A ⇒ V present ✔  
  Rule 5 – W absent ✔  
  Rule 6 – antecedent false (V present) ✔  
 All conditions satisfied.

Case 2: V is not in P  
 Rule 6 then forbids both A and Ch, so P ⊆ {W, L, C}.  
 W is already impossible, so P must be {L, C}.  
 But with A absent and W absent, rule 3 requires Ch, contradicting the choice of {L, C}.  
 Hence no pair without V works.

Conclusion  
The unique pair satisfying every statement is {V, Ch}: Sir Vincent and Sir Charles rode out to face the dragon.

Final answer: Sir Vincent and Sir Charles

Question:
Mad Ade's cousin Steve lies a lot. He tells the truth on only one day in a week.
One day he said: "I lie on Mondays and Tuesdays."
The next day he said: "Today is either Sunday, Saturday, or Thursday."
The next day he said: "I lie on Fridays and Wednesdays."
On which day of the week does Steve tell the truth?
Hint: The first and third statements are incompatible
Human Solution:
Mad Ade's cousin  Steve tells the truth on Tuesdays
The first and third statements are incompatible; they cannot of course both be true, and they can only be lies if on one of the days mentioned Steve tells the truth. But, they have no such day in common. Therefore one of them must be true, and the other must refer to that day. Looking at the second statement (which must be a lie, as there can at most be one true statement and we have one), the first day cannot be Wednesday, Friday or Saturday. Therefore, the first statement cannot be true, since the third cannot refer to it by day. Therefore, the third statement is true, and must (from the first statement) be a Monday or Tuesday. Statement two, however, rules out Monday, leaving only Tuesday as the 'day of truth'. Thus: 'one day' is a Sunday; on the third day (Tuesday) Steve is truthful.
Response:
Let  

• T = the day of the week on which Steve tells the truth (the same every week).  
• All other days are lying days.  

The three consecutive calendar days on which he speaks we’ll call  
D₁ (first day) → statement S₁  
D₂ (next day) → statement S₂  
D₃ (next day) → statement S₃  

Statements
S₁ : “I lie on Mondays and Tuesdays.”  
S₂ : “Today is either Sunday, Saturday, or Thursday.”  
S₃ : “I lie on Fridays and Wednesdays.”

1.  Translate S₁ and S₃ in terms of T  

   • Steve lies on a day if and only if that day ≠ T.  
   • Therefore  
     – S₁ is TRUE ⇔ T ∉ {Monday, Tuesday}.  
       (It is FALSE ⇔ T ∈ {Monday, Tuesday}.)  
     – S₃ is TRUE ⇔ T ∉ {Friday, Wednesday}.  
       (It is FALSE ⇔ T ∈ {Friday, Wednesday}.)

2.  Use the hint “S₁ and S₃ are incompatible”  

   They cannot both be FALSE, because  
     S₁ false  ⇒ T ∈ {Mon, Tue}  
     S₃ false  ⇒ T ∈ {Wed, Fri}  
   Intersection is empty.  
   They also cannot both be TRUE, because Steve tells the truth on only one
   day per week.  
   Hence exactly one of S₁ and S₃ is TRUE; the other is FALSE.  
   Consequently the truth-telling day is either D₁ or D₃. (D₂ must be a lying day.)

3.  Case analysis  

   Case A: D₁ is the truth day (S₁ true).  
           Then T ≠ Mon, Tue.  
           D₂ is a lying day, so its statement must be false; therefore  
           D₂ ∉ {Sun, Sat, Thu} ⇒ D₂ ∈ {Mon, Tue, Wed, Fri}.  
           D₂ is the calendar day after D₁.  
           S₃ (spoken on D₃) is a lie, hence T ∈ {Fri, Wed}.  
           Thus D₁ (= T) would be Wed or Fri.  
           If T = Wed → (D₁,D₂,D₃) = (Wed,Thu,Fri); on Thu Steve’s false statement
           would actually be true (because it really is Thu) – contradiction.  
           If T = Fri → (D₁,D₂,D₃) = (Fri,Sat,Sun); on Sat his false statement
           would again be true (because it really is Sat) – contradiction.  
           Therefore Case A is impossible.

   Case B: D₃ is the truth day (S₃ true).  
           Then T ∉ {Wed, Fri}.  
           S₁ (spoken on D₁) is a lie, so T ∈ {Mon, Tue}.  
           Hence T is Monday or Tuesday.  
           D₃ = T, D₂ = the day before T, D₁ = two days before T.

           • Sub-case T = Monday → (D₁,D₂,D₃) = (Sat,Sun,Mon).  
             On Sun (D₂) he is lying, but his statement “Today is either
             Sun, Sat, or Thu” would be true (it is Sunday) – contradiction.

           • Sub-case T = Tuesday → (D₁,D₂,D₃) = (Sun,Mon,Tue).  
             – D₁ = Sun: S₁ is false (T = Tue, so he does not lie on Tue); fine.  
             – D₂ = Mon: S₂ must be false; indeed Monday ∉ {Sun, Sat, Thu}; fine.  
             – D₃ = Tue: truth day; S₃ is true because he does lie on Wed and Fri.  
             All conditions are satisfied.

4.  Conclusion  

The only consistent arrangement is that Steve’s sole day of truth-telling is Tuesday.

Final answer: Tuesday

Question:
Mad Ade's Great Uncle Gaseous O' Windpants owned the Madadian Grocery store "The Beggars Can't Be Choosers". Madadia was well renowned for its pungent cheeses, especially its "Kebabrie" and "Chillirella".
On display in the store were six cheese pieces weighing 15, 16, 18, 19 , 20 and 31 Pounds. Five out of the six pieces are "Kebabrie" and the remaining one is "Chillirella".
Norma Leigh-Sobar purchased two pieces of "Kebabrie" and Laura Anne-Hardy also purchased some "Kebabrie" , but she purchased twice as much in weight than Norma .
How much does the remaining "Chillirella" weigh?
Hint: Norma Leigh-Sobar must have purchased at least 31 pounds and so Laura Anne-Hardy must have bought three wedges since the two heaviest wedges together only total 51 pounds.
Human Solution:
Norma Leigh-Sobar must have purchased at least 31 pounds and so Laura Anne-Hardy must have bought three wedges since the two heaviest wedges together only total 51 pounds.
Since Laura bought twice what Norma bought, the total amount of cheese bought by the two together equals 3 times that purchased by Norma alone. Now, the total weight of all the wedges at the grocery divided by 3 leaves a remainder of 2, so the "Chillirella" wedge must leave a remainder of 2 when divided by 3. But the only such wedge is the 20 pound wedge, thus the "Chillirella" wedge must have weighed 20 pounds.
Thus Norma purchased the 15 and 18 pound pieces which equals 33 pounds and Laura purchased the 16, 19 and 31 pound pieces which equals 66 pounds.
Response:
Let the six wedges be  

15 lb, 16 lb, 18 lb, 19 lb, 20 lb and 31 lb.

Five of them are Kebabrie, one is Chillirella.  
Norma buys two Kebabrie whose total weight we call N.  
Laura buys only Kebabrie whose total weight is 2 N.  
All Kebabrie wedges together are therefore N + 2 N = 3 N.

Because Norma buys at least 31 lb (hint) we must have N ≥ 31, so Laura must take the remaining three wedges (the two heaviest wedges together weigh only 51 lb, which is < 2·31 = 62).

Hence  
• Kebabrie = 5 wedges  
• Chillirella = the single wedge left behind.

Step 1 – make the Kebabrie total divisible by 3  
Let T = 15 + 16 + 18 + 19 + 20 + 31 = 119 lb  
If the Chillirella wedge weighs w, the Kebabrie total is 119 − w.

For 119 − w = 3 N we need 119 − w to be divisible by 3.

119 ≡ 2 (mod 3).  
Thus w must also be ≡ 2 (mod 3).

Among the six weights only 20 lb satisfies w ≡ 2 (mod 3).

Therefore the 20-pound wedge is the Chillirella.

Step 2 – check that everything fits  
Kebabrie weights: 15, 16, 18, 19, 31 → total 99 lb.  
Thus N = 99 / 3 = 33 lb.

Find Norma’s two wedges summing to 33 lb: 15 lb + 18 lb = 33 lb.  
Laura then gets the remaining three Kebabrie wedges: 16 lb + 19 lb + 31 lb = 66 lb = 2·33 lb.

All conditions are satisfied.

Final answer: 20 pounds

Question:
Twelve men are in a room, some of them always tell lies, while the others always tell the truth.
The first man says: "None of us is a truthteller."
The second man says: "At most one of us is a truthteller."
The third man says: "At most two of us are truthtellers."
...
The twelfth and last man says: "At most eleven of us are truthtellers."
Who are the liars?
Hint: It's OK to use trial and error, however, there might exist better methods.
Human Solution:
If there are exactly N liars, then the last N men are truthtellers, leaving the first (12-N) men to be liars.
Therefore, N=12-N, N=6. The first 6 men are liars, and the last 6 men are truthtellers.
Response:
Let  
T = the total number of truthtellers among the 12 men.

Statement made by man i (i = 1,…,12):  
“At most i – 1 of us are truthtellers.”  
Symbolically: T ≤ i – 1.

A man tells the truth iff his statement is true.

1. When is the statement of man i true?  
   True ⇔ T ≤ i – 1 ⇔ i ≥ T+1.

2. Therefore  
   • Men with indices i ≥ T+1 are truthtellers.  
   • Men with indices i ≤ T are liars.

3. Count the truthtellers.  
   Indices of truthtellers: T+1, T+2, … , 12  
   Number of truthtellers = 12 – T.

4. Consistency condition:  
   Total truthtellers T must equal the number we just counted:  
   T = 12 – T  ⇒  2T = 12  ⇒  T = 6.

5. Identify them.  
   • Liars: indices 1 through 6 (their statements are false because 6 > i – 1).  
   • Truthtellers: indices 7 through 12 (their statements are true because 6 ≤ i – 1).

All conditions are satisfied: six truthtellers and six liars.

Final answer: Men 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 and 6 are the liars (men 7–12 tell the truth).

Question: A man has 3 cards face down on a table.  One is a jack and two are aces.  He knows the order but you do not.  You can ask him one yes or no question, but when you do, you have to point to one of the cards.  If you point to an ace, he will tell the truth, if you point to the jack, he will randomly say yes or no.  You have to find one of the aces.
Hint: Yes, there is always a chance you will be pointing to the jack, and that the answer will be meaningless (just a random yes/no) but there is a way to work around it.  Don't give up!
Human Solution: Point to the middle card and say,  "Is the card to the right an ace?"  If the answer is yes, then the card on the right is an ace. If the answer is no, the card on the left is an ace.  This solution works because if you're pointing to an ace then he's obviously telling the truth and if you're pointing to the jack the answer doesn't matter anyway because you will pick one of the other two which are both aces.
Response:
Label the three face-down cards 1 – 2 – 3 from your left to your right.  
Point to card 1 and ask the man the single yes-or-no question

  “Is card 2 an ace?”

Then act on his reply this way  
 • If he answers “Yes”, turn over card 2.  
 • If he answers “No”, turn over card 3.

Why this always works

1. Suppose the card you are pointing at (card 1) is an ACE.  
   – The man must tell the truth.  
   – If card 2 is an ace (so the truth is “Yes”), you will turn over card 2 and get an ace.  
   – If card 2 is not an ace (then card 3 is the other ace, so the truth is “No”), you will turn over card 3 and get an ace.  

2. Suppose the card you are pointing at (card 1) is the JACK.  
   – The man’s answer is now a random “Yes” or “No”, but that does not matter because the other two cards, 2 and 3, are both aces.  
   – Whichever of those two cards you are directed to turn over, you will reveal an ace.

In every possible arrangement of the three cards you are guaranteed to expose an ace with this single question.

Final answer: Point to card 1, ask “Is card 2 an ace?”; if the reply is “Yes” pick card 2, otherwise pick card 3.

Question:
At a family get-together, four married couples played bridge at two different tables (4 people at each table). From the statements below determine which players were at which table and who their partner was.
1. Mrs. Johnson was partnered with her son-in-law.
2. Mr. Jones' partner was his wife's brother-in-law.
3. Mrs. Jones played against her sister.
4. Mr. Johnson played against his father-in-law.
5. Mrs. Smith's partner was her daughter.
6. Mrs. Williams partner was her grandfather.
7. Mr. Johnson's partner was a man.
Hint: From statements 3, 5 and 6 the four couples consist of 3 generations since there is a set of sisters involved and there are grandparents present.
Human Solution:
From statements 3, 5 and 6 the four couples consist of 3 generations since there is a set of sisters involved and there are grandparents present.
From 2 and 3, the Jones are definitely one of the sisters, and from 6, the Williams are definitely on the 3rd generation. Looking at 1 and 4, the Johnson's are on the 2nd generation and since the Smiths have a daughter, they are on the 1st or 2nd generation. But since the Jones must be one of the sisters, the Smiths cannot fall in the 2nd generation with the Johnson's. Therefore the Smiths are the grandparents.
From 6, Mrs. Williams' partner is Mr. Smith.  From 1 and 6, Mrs. Johnston and Mrs. Williams both have male partners, therefore from 5, Mrs. Smith's partner could have only been Mrs. Jones. Which also means that Jones and Johnson are the pair of sisters.
Thus from 2, Mr. Jones is then partnered with Mr. Johnson, and from 3, Mrs Jones (who is partnered with Mrs. Smith) is playing against Mrs. Johnson (whose partner is Mr. Williams from 1).
In summation, Mr. Jones and Mr. Johnson play against Mrs. Williams and Mr Smith, while Mrs Jones and Mrs. Smith play against Mrs. Johnson and Mr. Williams.
Response:
Let the eight players be  

Mr & Mrs Johnson, Mr & Mrs Jones, Mr & Mrs Smith, Mr & Mrs Williams.  

We will determine the family relationships first and then the seating.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  Building the family tree
--------------------------------------------------------------------
•  Statement 6:  Mrs Williams’ partner is her grandfather ⇒  
   one of the three men who is not Mr Williams is the grandfather.

•  Statement 5:  Mrs Smith’s partner is her daughter ⇒  
   Mrs Smith is in the oldest generation (otherwise her “daughter” would be
   a grand-daughter of somebody else and we would have four generations).
   So the Smiths are the grandparents.

•  Therefore Mr & Mrs Smith are the grandparents.

•  Statement 3 tells us there is a pair of sisters; by 5
   one of those sisters must be a daughter of Mrs Smith.
   In fact both sisters will be daughters of the Smiths.

•  Statements 1 and 6 together say  

      Mrs Johnson partners her son-in-law,  
      Mrs Williams partners her grandfather (Mr Smith).

   The only way this can happen with three generations is:

        Mr & Mrs Smith  ──►  daughter 1 = Mrs Johnson
                                          │
                                          └──►  grand-daughter = Mrs Williams

        Mr & Mrs Smith  ──►  daughter 2 = Mrs Jones

   Thus the two Smith daughters are Mrs Johnson and Mrs Jones, and  
   Mrs Williams is the Johnsons’ daughter and the Smiths’ granddaughter.

   So far we have

        Grandparents :  Mr Smith  –  Mrs Smith
        Children      :  Mrs Johnson (married to Mr Johnson)
                         Mrs Jones   (married to Mr Jones)
        Grandchild    :  Mrs Williams (married to Mr Williams)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  Determining all partnerships
--------------------------------------------------------------------
•  From 6:  Mrs Williams partners Mr Smith.           ……  (P-A)

•  From 5:  Mrs Smith partners her daughter.  
            Her daughters are Mrs Johnson and Mrs Jones;
            one of them is already used (Mrs Williams is a grand-daughter),
            so her partner must be Mrs Jones.          ……  (P-B)

•  From 1:  Mrs Johnson partners her son-in-law.  
            Her only son-in-law is Mr Williams.        ……  (P-C)

•  The only two people still without partners are
            Mr Johnson and Mr Jones.
  From 7:   Mr Johnson’s partner is a man, so he must partner Mr Jones. ……(P-D)

Check statement 2: Mr Jones’ partner (Mr Johnson) is his wife’s
brother-in-law.  Mrs Jones’ brother-in-law is indeed Mr Johnson
(the husband of her sister, Mrs Johnson).  ✓

Thus the four partnerships are

    P-A :  Mrs Williams  &  Mr Smith
    P-B :  Mrs Smith     &  Mrs Jones
    P-C :  Mrs Johnson   &  Mr Williams
    P-D :  Mr Johnson    &  Mr Jones

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  Placing the partnerships at the two tables
--------------------------------------------------------------------
We still must satisfy the “played against” conditions.

•  Statement 3:  Mrs Jones played against her sister (Mrs Johnson).  
  Hence P-B must oppose P-C.

•  Statement 4:  Mr Johnson played against his father-in-law (Mr Smith).  
  Hence P-D must oppose P-A.

That immediately gives the two complete tables:

TABLE 1  
    Partners:  Mrs Johnson & Mr Williams  
               versus  
               Mrs Smith   & Mrs Jones

TABLE 2  
    Partners:  Mrs Williams & Mr Smith  
               versus  
               Mr Johnson   & Mr Jones

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  Verification
--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  Mrs Johnson is partnered with her son-in-law Mr Williams.        ✓  
2.  Mr Jones’ partner Mr Johnson is his wife’s brother-in-law.       ✓  
3.  At Table 1 Mrs Jones plays against her sister Mrs Johnson.       ✓  
4.  At Table 2 Mr Johnson plays against his father-in-law Mr Smith.  ✓  
5.  Mrs Smith’s partner is her daughter Mrs Jones.                   ✓  
6.  Mrs Williams’ partner is her grandfather Mr Smith.               ✓  
7.  Mr Johnson’s partner is a man (Mr Jones).                        ✓  

All statements are satisfied.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Final seating
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Table 1  
  – Partners:  Mrs Johnson with Mr Williams  
  – Opponents: Mrs Smith   with Mrs Jones  

Table 2  
  – Partners:  Mrs Williams with Mr Smith  
  – Opponents: Mr Johnson   with Mr Jones  

Final answer:  
Table 1 – Mrs Johnson & Mr Williams versus Mrs Smith & Mrs Jones.  
Table 2 – Mrs Williams & Mr Smith versus Mr Johnson & Mr Jones.

Question:
The following task involves several steps, but they are out of order.  Arrange them so that a person who follows the steps exactly can perform the task:
You have three heavy beams marked A, B, and C, and want to find out which one is the heaviest.  You also have a scale that tells you which of any two beams is heavier, but it does not give the specific weight of any beam.  In what order must you perform the following steps to determine which beam is the heaviest, and to mark it accordingly?  Assume that all three have different weights.
a)  Weigh A against B.
b)  Weigh B against C.
c)  Weigh A against C.
d)  If A is heavier, skip the next three statements.
e)  If A is heavier, skip the next four statements.
f)  If B is heavier, skip the next five statements.
g)  Mark A "heaviest."
h)  Mark B "heaviest."
i)  Mark C "heaviest."
j)  Skip the next statement.
k)  Skip the next two statements.
l)  Skip the next three statements.
m)  End.
Hint: The first two steps are "a" and "d", in that order.
Human Solution:
a)  Weigh A against B.
d)  If A is heavier, skip the next three statements.
b)  Weigh B against C.
f)  If B is heavier, skip the next five statements.
k)  Skip the next two statements.
c)  Weigh A against C.
e)  If A is heavier, skip the next four statements.
i)  Mark C "heaviest."
l)  Skip the next three statements.
h)  Mark B "heaviest."
j)  Skip the next statement.
g)  Mark A "heaviest."
m)  End.
Response:
Reasoning in detail

1.  We must compare beams until we can be sure which is heaviest.  
   A simple strategy is:  
   – Weigh A vs B.  
   – If A is heavier, compare A with C; otherwise compare B with C.  
   – From the second weighing mark the heavier of the two beams that were just compared.

2.  We are forced to use every one of the given instructions (a–m) exactly once and only once, and must realise the above strategy with nothing but the three kinds of statements supplied:  
   • weighing statements (a, b, c);  
   • conditional “skip the next … statements” (d, e, f);  
   • unconditional “skip …” (j, k, l);  
   • the three possible markings (g, h, i);  
   • “End” (m).

3.  The hint fixes the first two steps:  
        1  a) Weigh A against B.  
        2  d) If A is heavier, skip the next three statements.  

   So, if A > B we jump over the next three statements; if A < B we execute them.

4.  We put the whole “B-branch” in exactly those three statements (steps 3-5).  
        3  b) Weigh B against C.  
        4  f) If B is heavier, skip the next five statements.  
        5  k) Skip the next two statements.  

   • When B > C, statement 4 skips steps 5-9 and jumps to step 10, where we shall mark B.  
   • When C > B, statement 5 skips steps 6-7 so that we jump directly to step 8, where we shall mark C.

5.  After the three-statement block (steps 3-5) we are at step 6.  
   If A > B we arrive here by the skip in step 2; if A < B we arrive here only when C > B.  
        6  c) Weigh A against C.  
        7  e) If A is heavier, skip the next four statements.  

   • If A > C, the skip in 7 will jump to step 12, where we shall mark A.  
   • If C > A, we go on to step 8 where we shall mark C.

6.  The marking and terminating part of the list is now filled in so that every possible path finishes correctly and no wrong marking can be reached.

        8  i) Mark C “heaviest.”  
        9  m) End.  
       10  h) Mark B “heaviest.”  
       11  j) Skip the next statement.  
       12  g) Mark A “heaviest.”  
       13  l) Skip the next three statements.   (A harmless fill-in at the end.)

   • If step 8 is executed (C is the heaviest), step 9 immediately ends the algorithm.  
   • If we arrived at step 10 (only possible when B > C), we mark B, then step 11 skips over step 12 (so A is not marked) and falls into the harmless filler step 13.  
   • If step 7 jumped over steps 8-11 (only when A > C), we reach step 12, mark A, and are finished because the list ends.

7.  Every instruction a–m is used exactly once, and each possible weighing-outcome path marks exactly the correct beam and terminates.

The complete, correct order of the instructions is therefore

a, d, b, f, k, c, e, i, m, h, j, g, l

written in full:

1  a) Weigh A against B.  
2  d) If A is heavier, skip the next three statements.  
3  b) Weigh B against C.  
4  f) If B is heavier, skip the next five statements.  
5  k) Skip the next two statements.  
6  c) Weigh A against C.  
7  e) If A is heavier, skip the next four statements.  
8  i) Mark C “heaviest.”  
9  m) End.  
10  h) Mark B “heaviest.”  
11  j) Skip the next statement.  
12  g) Mark A “heaviest.”  
13  l) Skip the next three statements.

Followed exactly, these steps always identify and label the heaviest beam and then stop.  

Final answer: a, d, b, f, k, c, e, i, m, h, j, g, l

Question:
Major Steve is forming a five-person Special Task Group for the Madadian army. The group must contain one leader, two bomb-experts and two soldiers.
P, Q and R are possible bomb-experts. R, S and T are possible leaders. U, V and W are possible soldiers. Also, P and R prefers to work with each other in the same team. T prefers to work only if V works.
How many different possible Groups can Major Steve make?
Hint: Draw it out!
Human Solution:
Major Steve can make 8 different possible groups.
As 2 bomb-experts to be selected from the given 3 and also P & R prefers to work together, PR must be there in all the possible Groups. Also, T prefers to work only if V works. It doesn't mean that V won't work without T.
Hence, possible groups are:
PR - S - UV
PR - S - VW
PR - S - WU
PR - T - UV
PR - T - VW
PQ - R - UV
PQ - R - VW
PQ - R - WU
Hence,  8 different groups are possible.
Response:
We have to build a unit consisting of  
• 1 leader   (from R , S , T)  
• 2 bomb–experts (from P , Q , R)  
• 2 soldiers   (from U , V , W)  
subject to

1. P and R want to be together, so either both are in the team or neither is.  
2. If T is chosen as leader, V must be one of the soldiers (T → V).

Because one person can hold only one post, if R is the leader he cannot at the same time be a bomb-expert.

We count the admissible groups by fixing the leader.

────────────────────────────────────
CASE 1 Leader = R  
Then R is already on the team, so (P,R) must both appear ⇒ the two bomb-experts have to be P and Q (R can’t repeat).  
Soldiers: choose any 2 from {U,V,W}.  C(3,2)=3 ways.  
Total for this case = 3.

────────────────────────────────────
CASE 2 Leader = S  
Now R may or may not be selected as bomb-expert.  The only 2-person subsets of {P,Q,R} compatible with the “P with R” rule are:

   {P,R}   (contains both)  

Thus the bomb-experts must be P and R.  
Soldiers: still any 2 from {U,V,W} → 3 ways.  
Total for this case = 3.

────────────────────────────────────
CASE 3 Leader = T  
Because T → V, soldier V is compulsory.  The second soldier can be U or W (2 ways).  
Bomb-experts must again respect the P–R rule; only {P,R} works.  
Hence 1 (bomb-expert set) × 2 (soldier choices) = 2 ways.

────────────────────────────────────
Adding all valid possibilities:  
3  (leader R)  +  3  (leader S)  +  2  (leader T)  =  8.

Final answer: 8

Question:
LTVX
AFHKNZ
_ _ _
What three letters fill in the blanks?
Hint:
- The title has a partial clue.
- Look down.
- They are grouped horizontally.
Human Solution:
E M W
The first row requires two straight lines to make. (LTVX)
The Second row requires three straight lines to make.  (AFHKNZ)
Following the pattern, the next row should have four straight lines to make, and the only letters that do that are EMW.
(Also everything has been so far in alphabetical order so it has to be "EMW", not EWM, MEW, MWE, WME, or WEM.)
Response:
Step 1 –  What the two given rows have in common  
Write every capital letter of the English alphabet in its simplest “straight-line” form and count how many straight strokes are needed to draw it:

1 stroke : I  
2 strokes : L  T  V  X  
3 strokes : A  F  H  K  N  Y  Z  
4 strokes : E  M  W  
(curved letters need more than one kind of stroke, so we ignore them)

Step 2 –  Check the first two rows against the list  
Row 1 : L  T  V  X   → all of the 2-stroke letters, in alphabetical order.  
Row 2 : A  F  H  K  N  Z   → six of the seven 3-stroke letters, again in alphabetical order. (The seventh, Y, is simply omitted.)

Hence each row is a horizontal group of straight-line letters that need the same number of strokes.

Step 3 –  What must go in the third row?  
Continuing the pattern, the third row must contain every capital letter that needs 4 straight strokes, listed in alphabetical order.  From the list in Step 1 those letters are:

E  M  W

Therefore the three blanks should be filled with E, M and W.

Final answer: E M W

Question:
List the order in which each person finished.
Tommy Tombstone finished after Lance Lamers and Brett Brown but before Mitch Monday.
Peter Poultry finished before Daniel Dusk and Lance Lamers.
Sam Sunny finished after Peter Poultry and before Jack Jill and Harry Hills.
Keri Kernel finished after Peter Poultry, Mitch Monday and Tommy Tombstone.
Lance Lamers finished after Brett Brown and Daniel Dusk, but before Jack Jill and Mitch Monday.
Mitch Monday finished after Sam Sunny and Brett Brown.
Brett Brown finished before Jack Jill, Mitch Monday and Peter Poultry.
Daniel Dusk finished before Keri Kernel and Tommy Tombstone, but after Sam Sunny.
Jack Jill finished before Keri Kernel, Tommy Tombstone and Mitch Monday, but after Peter Poultry and Daniel Dusk.
Harry Hills finished before Mitch Monday but after Lance Lamers, Jack Jill and Tommy Tombstone.
Hint: Figure out who could possibly be first? Work from there
Human Solution:
1.Brett Brown
2.Peter Poultry
3.Sam Sunny
4.Daniel Dusk
5.Lance Lamers
6.Jack Jill
7.Tommy Tombstone
8.Harry Hills
9.Mitch Monday
10.Keri Kernel
Response:
Reasoning (step-by-step)

1.  Find who could be first.  
   The only person who is not required to finish after anyone else is Brett Brown, so Brett Brown must be 1st.

2.  Remove Brett Brown from the remaining constraints and look again:  
   Peter Poultry now has no one left who must precede him, so he is 2nd.

3.  With Peter Poultry placed, the only runner who now has no predecessors is Sam Sunny, so Sam Sunny is 3rd.

4.  After Sam Sunny, Daniel Dusk’s predecessors are satisfied, so Daniel Dusk is 4th.

5.  Now Lance Lamers’ predecessors are satisfied, so Lance Lamers is 5th.

6.  Jack Jill now has no remaining predecessors, so Jack Jill is 6th.

7.  Tommy Tombstone’s predecessors are now satisfied, so Tommy Tombstone is 7th.

8.  Harry Hills now has no predecessors left, so Harry Hills is 8th.

9.  Mitch Monday’s predecessors are now satisfied, so Mitch Monday is 9th.

10. Finally, the only one left is Keri Kernel, who becomes 10th.

The sequence satisfies every one of the given statements.

Final answer:  
1) Brett Brown  
2) Peter Poultry  
3) Sam Sunny  
4) Daniel Dusk  
5) Lance Lamers  
6) Jack Jill  
7) Tommy Tombstone  
8) Harry Hills  
9) Mitch Monday  
10) Keri Kernel

Question: A prisoner sat alone in his cell staring through the bars at the six doors to the guardroom beyond them. Suddenly, there was the sound of footsteps. One guard came in through door A and a second entered through door F. They unlocked the cell door. "We shall set you free," said one of the guards, "but first you must pass through all six doors, each door once only, in the correct order. Three are entrances only and three are exits only. Door A must be followed by door B or E; B by C or E; C by D or F; D by A or F; E by B or D; and F by C or D." With that the guards left through door B. In what order must the prisoner pass through the doors?
Hint: The prisoner must alternate exits and entrances. List the six possible orders then study the conditions to eliminate possibilities.
Human Solution:
The order is CFDABE. The guards entered through doors A and F and exited at door B. The prisoner must alternate exits and entrances. Let the unknown entrance be X. With a "_" denoting an exit door the possible orders are:
(a) _A_F_X ; (b) _F_A_X ; (c) _X_A_F ; (d) _X_F_A ; (e) _A_X_F ; (f) _F_X_A
Neither (a) nor (c) are possible since A is followed by B or E and neither leads to F. Since A can only be preceded by D, (e) and (f) are possible as DA_X_F and _F_XDA, respectively. With D used, door F can only be preceded by C to give DA_XCF and CF_XDA, respectively. Door B must occupy the remaining space in each possibility (third door is exit) so X=E but C cannot follow E in the former and for the latter, B cannot follow F. This eliminates (e) and (f). Since only D precedes A, (b) is possible as _FDA_X and (d) as _X_FDA. For (d), the exit B must occupy a "_" but cannot be followed by F, and if it is the first door, neither the C or E that must follow as X can be followed by the remaining E or C, respectively. This only leaves (b) and only C (of the possible B,C,E) can precede F as CFDA_X and B must occupy the final "_" as an exit leaving E=X. Notice that the condition that E is followed by B or D cannot be satisfied until the prisoner has completed his task and finally wins his freedom through B or D!
Response:
Let  

A → B or E  
B → C or E  
C → D or F  
D → A or F  
E → B or D  
F → C or D  

denote the only permissible “next–door” moves.

Because three doors are entrances and three are exits, the prisoner’s route must alternate  

entrance – exit – entrance – exit – entrance – exit  

(or the reverse).  
While the problem does not say which doors are which, the story does:  
• Guards came IN through A and through F  ⇒  A and F are ENTRANCES.  
• Guards went OUT through B               ⇒  B is an EXIT.  
Hence

entrances : A , F , (one of C / D / E)  
exits     : B , (two of C / D / E)

To keep the alternation all entrances must occupy the same parity positions
and all exits the opposite parity positions.  
Put the entrances in the odd positions (1,3,5); the exits will then be in the even positions (2,4,6).

Trying to build a six-door trail with these facts:

1.  Start with A (entrance, position 1).  
    A can only be followed by B or E, both exits.  
    Take B (exit, position 2).

2.  From B we may go to C or E.  
    Choose C?  No, because C would then be an entrance and the only
    continuation dies after five steps.  
    Choose E instead (entrance, position 3).

3.  From E we can go to B or D.  
    B is already used, so go to D (exit, position 4).

4.  From D we can go to A or F.  
    A is already used; take F (entrance, position 5).

5.  From F we can go to C or D.  
    D is already used, so go to C (exit, position 6).

All six doors are different, and every step obeys the rule list:

A → B → E → D → F → C  
  ✓    ✓    ✓    ✓    ✓

The entrances (odd positions) are A, E, F; the exits (even positions) are B, D, C – exactly three of each, so the entrance/exit alternation is satisfied.

No other ordering works once A and F are fixed as entrances and B as an exit, so the prisoner’s unique route is

A  B  E  D  F  C

Final answer: A → B → E → D → F → C

Question:
In a distant planet called Zlymph (pronounced: zl-i-mf) there were 6 different creatures there.
One was called Fymphy.
Another was called Lymfry.
Yet another was called Phyzygwy.
The next one was called Blympy.
Hyjyky was the name of another one.
Finally, there was the Jygzyll.
What you are trying to find out is the following things using the clues after this:
What they enjoyed to eat,
What they hated to eat,
and what planet they were originally from.
Choose from the following:
Food: Humans, other creatures, dragons, dirt from the planet, metal, and salt.
Planets: Venus, Pluto, Sun, Mercury, Jupiter, and Uranus.
CLUES!
1. The one who hates dirt from the planet was from Uranus.
2. The Blympy hates what the Jygzyll loves.
3. The one who loves humans is from a gas planet.
4. The Fymphy should be dehydrated.
5. The Lymfry hates what the Fymphy loves.
6. The one who hates humans is from Pluto.
7. The one who loves dragons is from Venus.
8. The Jygzyll hates what the Lymfry loves.
9. The Hyjyky loves what the Phyzygwy hates.
10. The Hyjyky hates what the Blympy loves.
11. The Blympy hates what the Phyzygwy loves.
12. The Jygzyll loves what the Fymphy hates.
13. The Fymphy loves an organism that is both an herbivore and a carnivore.
14. The Lymfry loves a mythical creature.
15. No human can get near the place the Blympy is from.
16. The Phyzygwy is from Mercury.
17. The Blympy loves dirt from the planet.
Hint: Salt = dehydration
Human Solution:
Fymphy: Loves salt (clue 4), hates humans (clue 6), and is from Pluto (clue 6).
Lymfry: Loves dragons (clue 14), Hates salt (clue 4/5), and is from Venus (7).
Blympy: Loves dirt from the planet (clue 17), hates metal, (clue 11), and is from the sun (clue 15).
Jygzyll: Loves humans (clue 12), hates dragons (clue 8), and is from Jupiter (clue 3).
Phyzygwy: Loves metal (clue 11), hates other creatures (clue 9), and is from Mercury (clue 16).
Hyjyky: Loves other creatures (clue 9), hates dirt from the planet (clue 10), and is from Uranus (clue 1).
Response:
I was not able to reach a logically consistent assignment that simultaneously satisfies

 • every literal clue,
 • the hint,  
 • and the usual “exactly-one-of-each-kind” convention for logic-puzzle tables.  

Repeated attempts produced an unavoidable contradiction centred on the following three clues  

    2  Blympy hates what the Jygzyll loves.  
    11 Blympy hates what the Phyzygwy loves.  
    5  Lymfry hates what the Fymphy loves,  

together with the planet constraints in clues 6 & 7.  
Those three food–love statements can all be true only if two different creatures
(Jygzyll and Phyzygwy) love the very same food.  
But that clashes with the natural requirement that each of the six kinds of food be “loved” by at most one creature – otherwise one of the six foods would not be anyone’s favourite.

If one drops the “all six loves must be different” requirement (letting 2 creatures love the same food)
then one quickly meets the next clash:  
clues 6 and 7 force Lymfry to belong to both Venus and Pluto if the Fymphy’s
omnivorous favourite food is “humans”, and to belong to Venus and *not* Pluto if it is “other creatures”.
Either way, the planet statements cannot be made consistent.

Because the contradiction is intrinsic to the given set of clues, no complete, contradiction-free solution exists.

Question:
You've been placed on a course of expensive medication in which you are to take one tablet of Sildenafil and one tablet of Citrate daily. You must be careful that you take just one of each because taking more of either can have serious side effects.
Taking Sildenafil without taking Citrate, or vice versa, can also be very serious, because they must be taken together in order to be effective. In summary, you must take exactly one of the Sildenafil pills and one of the Citrate pills at one time. Therefore, you open up the Sildenafil bottle, and you tap one Sildenafil pill into your hand. You put that bottle aside and you open the Citrate bottle. You do the same, but by mistake, two Citrates fall into your hand with the Sildenafil pill.
Now, here's the problem. You weren't watching your hand as the pills fell into it, so you can't tell the Sildenafil pill apart from the two Citrate pills. The pills look identical. They are both the same size, same weight (10 micrograms), same color (Blue), same shape (perfect square), same everything, and they are not marked differently in any way.
What are you going to do? You cannot tell which pill is which, and they cost $300 a piece, so you cannot afford to throw them away and start over again. How do you get your daily dose of exactly one Sildenafil and exactly one Citrate without wasting any of the pills?
Hint: You can cut pills in half
Human Solution: Carefully cut each of the three pills in half, and carefully separate them into two piles, with half of each pill in each pile. You do not know which pill is which, but you are 100% sure that each of the two piles now contains two halves of Citrate and half of Sildenafil. Now go back into the Sildenafil bottle, take out a pill, cut it in half, and add one half to each stack. Now you have two stacks, each one containing two halves of Sildenafil and two halves of Citrate. Take one stack of pills today, and save the second stack for tomorrow.
Response:
Step-by-step strategy

1. ​Cut the three tablets that are now in your hand (1 Sildenafil + 2 Citrate, though you do not know which is which) exactly in half.  
   • You now have 6 half-tablets.

2. ​Make two equal piles.  
   • Put one half of every original tablet into pile A and the other half into pile B.  
   • Because each original tablet was split, each pile now contains  
     – ½ of the Sildenafil tablet  
     – ½ of each of the two Citrate tablets  
     i.e. each pile = ½ S + 1 C (two different Citrate halves).

3. ​Complete today’s dose.  
   • Take a new Sildenafil tablet from the bottle, cut it in half.  
   • Swallow pile A together with one of those halves.  
     – Ingested today: ½ S (from pile A) + ½ S (new half) = 1 full Sildenafil  
                             1 C (from pile A)  
     – Exactly today’s required dose.

4. ​Prepare tomorrow’s dose.  
   • Put the other half of the newly cut Sildenafil tablet with pile B.  
   • Pile B now contains ½ S + 1 C (already there) + ½ S (saved half)  
     = 1 S + 1 C.

5. ​Tomorrow simply swallow pile B.

Result

• Over the two days you have taken exactly one Sildenafil and one Citrate each day.  
• No tablets were thrown away or wasted; you used the normal two Sildenafil and two Citrate tablets you would have taken in any case.

Final answer:  Cut each of the three mixed tablets in half, split the halves into two piles, add half of a fresh Sildenafil tablet to the first pile and take it today; save the other half with the second pile for tomorrow.  Each day you ingest exactly one Sildenafil and one Citrate, and no pill is wasted.

Question:
The first chess tournament ended. Bab, Beb, Bib, Bob and Bub became good friends, and returned to their houses.
They told their wives about the tournament. Their wives were also chess players, and they decided to hold another tournament.
This time, each of the 10 players was going to play against each other player once, with an exception that no games were played between the couples. So a total of 40 games would be played.
After some days passed, they decided to have a get-together. Bub asked the other people how many matches until then they had played.
Something fun was that Bub heard 9 different answers.
How many matches until then had Mrs. Bub played?
Hint: If you can't figure it out, draw a diagram.
Human Solution:
Each player could play at most 8 matches, so the answers Bub heard was 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8 in some order.
Assume without loss of generality that it was Bab that had played 8 matches. Then all players except Mrs. Bab must have played against Bab, and it must have been Mrs. Bab who had played no matches.
Then, assume without loss of generality that Beb had played 7 matches, and then all players except Mrs. Bab and Mrs. Beb must have played against Beb, and it must have been Mrs. Beb who had played 1 match.
Repeat this and we know that Mrs. Bub had played 4 matches.
Response:
Let the ten players be  

Bab , Beb , Bib , Bob , Bub , and their wives b , e , i , o , u.  
(Bub’s wife is u.)  

For every player the largest possible number of games is 8  
(ten persons minus himself and his spouse).  

Bub asked the other 9 persons how many games they had played and got nine
different answers, so the numbers he heard were exactly

0 , 1 , 2 , 3 , 4 , 5 , 6 , 7 , 8 .

Call the nine players (excluding Bub) P₀ , P₁ , … , P₈ according to those
numbers:  
deg(Pₖ)=k.

--------------------------------------------------
1.  The 0-player and the 8-player are married
--------------------------------------------------

The 8-player has already played every opponent except his (or her) spouse.
Hence the only person he cannot be connected with is that spouse.  
If the 0-player were not that spouse, the edge 8–0 would have been played,
contradicting deg(P₀)=0.  
Therefore P₈ and P₀ are a couple.

--------------------------------------------------
2.  Remove that couple and lower all remaining degrees by 1
--------------------------------------------------

Because P₈ has played everyone else (except P₀), each of the seven remaining
people and Bub himself has one game with P₈.  
So, after deleting P₈ and P₀ from consideration and subtracting 1 from every
other degree, the degrees left are

0 , 1 , 2 , 3 , 4 , 5 , 6              (for the seven persons)
and (deg(Bub) – 1).

In particular the new maxima and minima among the seven persons are again
6 and 0.

--------------------------------------------------
3.  Repeat the argument
--------------------------------------------------

By the same reasoning, the new 6-player and the new 0-player must be a
married couple; removing them and lowering the remaining degrees by 1
produces the list

0 , 1 , 2 , 3 , 4 , 5                 (for five persons).

Doing the same once more pairs 5 with 0, and leaves only the degrees

2 , 3 , 4                             (for three persons).

A final repetition pairs 3 with 2 and leaves a single player whose degree
is 4.

--------------------------------------------------
4.  Who is still unpaired?
--------------------------------------------------

Among the nine people that Bub questioned there are four couples
{8,0}, {7,1}, {6,2}, {5,3}.  
That accounts for 8 of those 9 persons.

The only one still without a spouse in this list must therefore be Bub’s
wife.  The degree that remained unpaired in the process is 4.

Hence Mrs. Bub is the player whose degree is 4, i.e. she has already played
exactly four games.

Final answer: 4

Question:
Al, Ben, Carl, and Dan live in four adjacent apartments. The apartments are set up like this:
|1|2|3|4|
with apartment 1 being the westernmost apartment and apartment 4 being the easternmost. One of the four is the landlord. Here are some facts:
1. If Carl does not live next to Ben, then Al is the landlord and he lives in apartment 1.
2. If Al lives east of Carl, then Dan is the landlord and he lives in apartment 4.
3. If Ben does not live next to Dan, then Carl is the landlord and he lives in apartment 3.
4. If Dan lives east of Al, then Ben is the landlord and he lives in apartment 2.
Who is the landlord?
Hint: All four facts are in the form of "hypothesis and conclusion" statements. If the hypothesis of such a statement is false, the whole statement is true. If the conclusion is true, the whole statement is true. However, if the hypothesis is true and the conclusion is false, the statement is false. This means that each statement has either a false hypothesis or a true conclusion.
Human Solution:
Carl is the landlord.
Obviously only one conclusion is true at most. Let us suppose that all conclusions are false. This would mean that each hypothesis is also false. From facts 1 and 3, Ben lives next to both Carl and Dan, and therefore between Carl and Dan. Then either Al lives east of both Carl and Dan (contradicting fact 4) or Carl and Dan both live east of Al (contradicting fact 2.) So there must be exactly one true hypothesis, which will be paired with the one true conclusion. Obviously each of the three false conclusions is paired with a false hypothesis.
If conclusion 1 is true, then Al lives in apartment 1. But since hypothesis 4 is false, Al has to live east of Dan. So this cannot be right.
If conclusion 2 is true, then Dan lives in apartment 4. But since hypothesis 4 is false, Al must live east of Dan. So this cannot be right, either.
If conclusion 4 is true, Ben lives in apartment 2. Then, since hypotheses 1 and 3 are false, Ben lives between Carl and Dan, putting Al in apartment 4. But since hypothesis 2 is false, Carl must live east of Al. Therefore, conclusion 3 is true.
Response:
Let  

A₁, A₂, A₃, A₄  be the apartments from west to east  
Pos(X)            be the apartment number occupied by person X  
L                 be the landlord.  

For each of the four facts write  

If (Hypothesis) then (Conclusion).

H₁ : Carl not next to Ben.  
C₁ : (L = Al)  and (Pos(A) = 1)

H₂ : Al east of Carl.  
C₂ : (L = Dan) and (Pos(D) = 4)

H₃ : Ben not next to Dan.  
C₃ : (L = Carl) and (Pos(C) = 3)

H₄ : Dan east of Al.  
C₄ : (L = Ben) and (Pos(B) = 2)

A conditional statement is true unless its hypothesis is true **and** its conclusion false.  
Therefore, in the final arrangement each of the four statements must satisfy

“hypothesis false”  OR  “conclusion true”.

Notice that at most one conclusion can be true, because C₁ … C₄ name different landlords.

Hence exactly one conclusion is true, the other three are false and thus force their
hypotheses to be false.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Case analysis on which conclusion is true
--------------------------------------------------------------------

1.  C₁ true  ⇒  L = Al, Pos(A) = 1.  
    C₄ is false, so H₄ must be false: Dan west of Al.  
    Impossible (there is no apartment west of #1).  
    ⇒ C₁ cannot be the true conclusion.

2.  C₂ true  ⇒  L = Dan, Pos(D) = 4.  
    C₃ false ⇒ H₃ false ⇒ Ben next to Dan ⇒ Pos(B) = 3.  
    C₁ false ⇒ H₁ false ⇒ Carl next to Ben ⇒ Pos(C) = 2.  
    This leaves Pos(A) = 1.  
    C₄ is false, so H₄ must be false: Dan not east of Al.  
    But Pos(D) = 4, Pos(A) = 1, so Dan **is** east of Al.  
    Contradiction ⇒ C₂ cannot be the true conclusion.

3.  C₃ true  ⇒  L = Carl, Pos(C) = 3.  
    C₁ false ⇒ H₁ false ⇒ Carl next to Ben ⇒ Ben in #2 or #4.  
    C₂ false ⇒ H₂ false ⇒ Al west of Carl ⇒ Al in #1 or #2.  
    C₄ false ⇒ H₄ false ⇒ Dan west of Al.  

    Try Ben = 2.  Then Al must be in #1, forcing Dan west of #1 (impossible).  
    Therefore Ben = 4.  
    Now the remaining apartments #1 and #2 go to Al and Dan with Dan west of Al.  
    So Dan = 1, Al = 2.

    Arrangement obtained:
       #1  Dan
       #2  Al
       #3  Carl  (landlord)
       #4  Ben

    Check every statement:
    • H₁ false (Carl next to Ben) ⇒ statement 1 true.  
    • H₂ false (Al not east of Carl) ⇒ statement 2 true.  
    • H₃ true, C₃ true              ⇒ statement 3 true.  
    • H₄ false (Dan not east of Al) ⇒ statement 4 true.

    All four facts are satisfied.  This is a consistent arrangement.

4.  C₄ true  ⇒  L = Ben, Pos(B) = 2.  
    C₁ false ⇒ Carl next to Ben ⇒ Carl in #1 or #3.  
    C₂ false ⇒ Al west of Carl.  
    C₃ false ⇒ Ben next to Dan ⇒ Dan in #1 or #3.

    One quickly sees no way to place Al west of Carl while keeping #1 or #3 free for Dan.  
    Contradiction ⇒ C₄ cannot be the true conclusion.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Only consistent situation
--------------------------------------------------------------------
The only arrangement that makes all four statements true is

Apartment 1 : Dan  
Apartment 2 : Al  
Apartment 3 : Carl  ← landlord  
Apartment 4 : Ben  

Therefore the landlord must be Carl.

Final answer: Carl

Question:
In the following code, each symbol stands for one of five letters.
@ stands for M, O, F, L, or V
$ stands for B, N, R, E, or J
% stands for T, F, B, L, or A
! stands for W, T, S, E, or I
# stands for F, O, A, T, or L
The five letter code word, %$#@!, can be translated into two English words that are opposites. What are the two words?
Hint: Prepositions
Human Solution: Above and Below
Response:
We are told that the five-symbol code % $ # @ ! can be deciphered by replacing each symbol with one letter chosen from the set that accompanies that symbol:

• %  →  T, F, B, L, A  
• $  →  B, N, R, E, J  
• #  →  F, O, A, T, L  
• @  →  M, O, F, L, V  
• !  →  W, T, S, E, I  

The task is to pick, for each position, a letter from the corresponding set so that the resulting 5-letter word is an English preposition, and to do this in two different ways that yield words with opposite meanings.

Step-by-step search guided by the hint “Prepositions”:

1. List common 5-letter prepositions that have obvious opposites.  
   The pair “ABOVE” / “BELOW” immediately suggests itself: both are 5 letters and are natural opposites.

2. Check whether “ABOVE” can be formed from the symbol sets:
   • A  (1st letter) must come from the % set → A ∈ {T, F, B, L, A} ✔  
   • B  (2nd letter) must come from the $ set → B ∈ {B, N, R, E, J} ✔  
   • O  (3rd letter) must come from the # set → O ∈ {F, O, A, T, L} ✔  
   • V  (4th letter) must come from the @ set → V ∈ {M, O, F, L, V} ✔  
   • E  (5th letter) must come from the ! set → E ∈ {W, T, S, E, I} ✔  

   All five letters are available, so “ABOVE” is a valid decoding of %$#@!.

3. Check whether “BELOW” can also be formed:
   • B  (1st letter) from the % set → B ∈ {T, F, B, L, A} ✔  
   • E  (2nd letter) from the $ set → E ∈ {B, N, R, E, J} ✔  
   • L  (3rd letter) from the # set → L ∈ {F, O, A, T, L} ✔  
   • O  (4th letter) from the @ set → O ∈ {M, O, F, L, V} ✔  
   • W  (5th letter) from the ! set → W ∈ {W, T, S, E, I} ✔  

   All five letters are likewise available, so “BELOW” is also a valid decoding.

Therefore the same coded pattern %$#@! can represent either ABOVE or BELOW, two English prepositions that are exact opposites.

Final answer: ABOVE and BELOW

Question: Two friends, Joe and Smoe, were born in May, one in 1932, the other a year later. Each had an antique grandfather clock of which he was extremely proud. Both of the clocks worked fairly well considering their age, but one clock gained ten seconds per hour while the other one lost ten seconds per hour. On a day in January, the two friends set both clocks correctly at 12:00 noon. "Do you realize," asked Joe, "that the next time both of our clocks will show exactly the same time will be on your 47th birthday?" Smoe agreed. Who is older, Joe or Smoe?
Hint: To find the answer, we have to find how long it will be before the clocks show the same time again
Human Solution: To find the answer, we have to find how long it will be before the clocks show the same time again. This is when the slow clock loses six hours, and the fast one gains six hours. This will take 90 days. In 90 days they will come together at 6:00. On a calendar, there are 90 days between noon January 31, and noon May 1 in years with no leap year. If Smoe had been born in 1933, his 47th birthday would have been in 1980, a leap year. This means that Smoe must be older, born in 1932, and the time of this problem is 1979.
Response:
Step 1.  How long before the clocks coincide again?  
 •  Fast clock: +10 s per hour  
 •  Slow clock: –10 s per hour  
 •  Relative rate of separation = 10 s + 10 s = 20 s per real hour.  
 •  For two 12-hour dials the hands look identical whenever one clock is an exact 12 h ahead of (or behind) the other.  
 •  12 h = 43 200 s.  
 •  Time required = 43 200 s ÷ 20 s /h = 2160 h = 90 days.

So the first moment after noon when the two clocks again read the same is exactly 90 days later.

Step 2.  Locate that date in the calendar.  
Let the clocks be set at noon on some January day of the same year as Smoe’s upcoming birthday.  
Call that day January d.  Ninety days later is calendar day d + 90.

In an ordinary (non-leap) year:
  May 1 is the 121st day of the year (counting Jan 1 = 1).  
Hence d + 90 = 121  ⇒  d = 31.  
Thus the setting must have been done on 31 January, and 90 days later is 1 May.

In a leap year:
  May 1 is day 122.  With d ≤ 31 we have d + 90 ≤ 121, so 90 days after 31 January would fall on 30 April, not on 1 May.  Therefore the year in question cannot be a leap year.

Step 3.  Whose 47th birthday is on 1 May of a non-leap year?  
The two birth possibilities are  
 •  May 1932    •  May 1933

A 47th birthday on 1 May occurs in  
 •  1 May 1979 for someone born 1 May 1932 (1979 is not a leap year),  
 •  1 May 1980 for someone born 1 May 1933 (1980 is a leap year).

Because the required year must be non-leap, the 47th birthday has to be 1 May 1979, i.e. the celebrant was born in 1932.

Therefore Smoe—whose 47th birthday it is—is the one born in 1932, and Joe is the one born in 1933.

Final answer: Smoe is older than Joe.

Question:
Ole Santa's pack held thirty toys
Made by his elfin crew;
And though none made the same amount,
Each elf made more than two.
The elf named Cher made one more Christmas toy
Than the elf who dressed in reds,
But Cher made one less Christmas toy
Than the elf who made the sleds.
Spry Johnny Elf made racing cars;
Five toys were made by Jane.
The elf who dressed in yellow suits
Made each and every train.
The elf who always dressed in green
Made one-third as many as Sue;
Cute Marcia elf was dressed in orange,
And one elf dressed in blue.
The elf who made the spinning tops
Made the most toys of them all.
Another perky smiling elf
Made each and every ball.
Ole Santa's pack held thirty gifts
All tagged for girls and boys.
From the clues that you've been given,
Now guess who made the toys!
Hint: This puzzle involves five elves dressed in five different colors each making a different toy. Figure out the numbers that fit these conditions and can add up to thirty!
Human Solution:
Cute Marcia was in orange and made seven sleds.
Sue was in blue and made nine spinning tops.
Jane was in red and made five balls.
Spry Johnny was in green and made three racing cars.
Cher was in yellow and made six trains.
Response:
Step-by-step reasoning  

1.  Let the five elves be Cher, Johnny, Jane, Sue and Marcia.  
    Five different suit-colours: red, yellow, green, orange, blue.  
    Five different toy types: racing cars, trains, spinning tops, balls, sleds.  
    Five different production numbers, each > 2, whose total is 30.

2.  Numerical clues.
    • Jane made 5 toys.  
    • The green-suited elf made one-third as many toys as Sue.  
      Hence Sue’s number must be three times some other elf’s.  
      Possible (green, Sue) pairs that keep the total small enough are (3, 9) or (4, 12).  
    • Let r be the number made by the red-suited elf.  
      Cher made one more than red (r + 1) and one less than the sled maker (r + 2).  
      Thus the three consecutive numbers r, r + 1, r + 2 must all appear among the five totals.

3.  Try (green, Sue) = (3, 9).  
    Add Jane’s 5 ⇒ we already have 3,5,9.  
    Look for three consecutive numbers containing 5: the only possibility is 3-4-5 or 5-6-7.  
    3-4-5 fails to reach 30; 5-6-7 gives exactly the right total:
         3 + 5 + 6 + 7 + 9 = 30, all numbers distinct and > 2.  
    Therefore the five production numbers are 3, 5, 6, 7, 9 with:
         red-suited elf …………… 5  
         Cher …………………… 6  
         sled maker …………… 7  

4.  Assign everything:

    • Numbers
        – Johnny must still have either 3 or 7.  
        – Marcia (orange suit) takes the remaining unassigned number.

    • Colours and toys
        – The green suit must be the 3-toy elf (one-third of Sue’s 9).  
          Choose Johnny (who has 3) for green.  
        – Johnny is already told to make racing cars ⇒ green suit, racing cars, 3 toys.  
        – Red suit already fixed at 5 toys ⇒ that is Jane; the only remaining unclaimed toy for her is balls.  
        – Cher has 6 toys and must differ in both colour and toy from the above; to satisfy the clue
          “yellow suit made each and every train”, let Cher wear yellow and build trains.  
        – Marcia (orange suit) has the last unused number 7, and by earlier deduction that number belongs
          to the sled maker ⇒ Marcia makes sleds.  
        – One colour is still unused — blue — and the last unassigned elf is Sue, so Sue wears blue.
          She has the largest total (9) and therefore, per the clue, she is the spinning-top maker.

5.  Final check: every clue is met (totals distinct, sum 30, relational clues, colours, toys etc.).

Final answer:  
• Cher wore yellow, made the trains, and produced 6 toys.  
• Johnny wore green, made the racing cars, and produced 3 toys.  
• Jane wore red, made the balls, and produced 5 toys.  
• Sue wore blue, made the spinning tops, and produced 9 toys.  
• Marcia wore orange, made the sleds, and produced 7 toys.

Question:
You are back on the same game show with four other contestants. You didn't realise last time that the winner gets another appearance on the show! You now have another chance to win half a million dollars and become a millionaire! The objective is to crack the combination of the safe using the clues. The first person to do so will win $500,000.
The safe combination looks like this:
??-??-??-??
A digit can be used more than once in the code, and there are no zeroes.
Here are the clues:
1. When adding the first number of the third set with the second number of the second set, you will get a number below 8.
2. The only digits not used in the code are 5 and 7.
3. When adding the two digits of the first set together, you will not get 10.
4. If you multiply the second set by 4, you will get the fourth set reversed.
5. No set has a number above 90.
6. The product of both the digits in the first set is below 30 but above 20.
7. One of the number sets is 66.
8. There is only one 8 in the combination, and it is in the last set.
Now, get cracking!
Human Solution:
The set is 39-21-66-48.
First of all, the second clue tells you there are no 5's or 7's in the combination.
Now we go to the fourth clue. It tells you that if you multiply the second set by 4, you will get the fourth set reversed. There are only a few numbers that will satisfy this:
11, 12, 16, 21, 22, 23 and 24.
Now we skip down to clue 8, which tells us there is one 8 only, and it is in the last set. It could either be the first digit or the second digit.
However, this eliminates these numbers from being in the second set: 11, 16, 23 and 24. Now, only 12, 21 and 22 are the possibilities for being in the second set.
Now, let's look at clue 7. This tells us that 66 is one of the four number sets. We know it can't be in the second, or fourth, and since clue six tells us the product of the two numbers in the first set ranges from 21-29, 66 must go in the third set.
??-??-66-??
Now we must look at the first clue. The first number of the third set (6) plus the second number of the second set will get a number below 8. This means it cannot be 12 or 22, because they would both total 8. This means that the second set of numbers is 21. Making good progress!
??-21-66-??
Now, we come back to clue 4 which tells us the second set multiplied by 4 equals the fourth set reversed. 21 multiplied by 4 is 84, which when reversed is 48!
??-21-66-48
Now, we come back to clue 6, which tells us the product of the digits in the first set is above 20 but below 30. These are the only numbers that satisfy that condition - and remember, no 5's, 7's or 8's are left in the combination:
39 (3 * 9 = 27)
46 (4 * 6 = 24)
64 (6 * 4 = 24)
93 (9 * 3 = 27)
Now, we look at clue 5. This eliminates 93. Now, come to clue 3. This tells us the sum of the two digits in the first set does not equal 10. This eliminates 46 and 64. The only number left is.... 39!
Now you have your answer;
39-21-66-48
Congratulations!!! You won, again!! You are over the moon! You have become the first millionaire in five generations of your family history!!
Response:
We have four two–digit “sets”:  
?? – ?? – ?? – ??  
No 0’s are allowed, digits 5 and 7 never appear, and the only 8 in the whole code is in the last set.  
The hint already tells us the third set is 66, so we write  

Set 1 = AB  Set 2 = C1  Set 3 = 66  Set 4 = EF  
(where A,B,C,E,F are digits).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  First‐digit of 3rd set + second‐digit of 2nd set < 8  
   6 + D < 8 ⇒ D = 1.  
   So the second set is C1.

2.  “Multiply the second set by 4 to get the fourth set reversed.”  
   Let N = 10C + 1.  
   4N = 40C + 4 must equal FE (the reverse of EF).  
   Moreover every set is ≤ 90, so 40C + 4 ≤ 90 ⇒ C ≤ 2.  
   And C ≠ 8 (only 8 is in the last set), so C ∈ {1,2}.

   • C = 1 ⇒ N = 11, 4N = 44 ⇒ FE = 44 ⇒ EF = 44 (no 8 in last set → impossible).  
   • C = 2 ⇒ N = 21, 4N = 84 ⇒ FE = 84 ⇒ EF = 48 (contains exactly one 8 → OK).

   Hence Second set = 21 and Fourth set = 48.

3.  Digits 5 and 7 are forbidden, the only 8 has been used, so A,B ∈ {1,2,3,4,6,9}.  
    Their product must be 20 < AB < 30 (clue 6).  
    The only allowed factorizations are 4×6 = 24 and 3×9 = 27.  
    Sum A + B must NOT be 10 (clue 3), so 4 + 6 = 10 is ruled out, leaving 3 and 9.

4.  The first set must be 39 or 93, but no set may exceed 90 (clue 5).  
    Therefore the first set is 39.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Everything now satisfies every clue:

1st set: 39 (3·9 = 27, 3+9 ≠ 10, ≤90)  
2nd set: 21 (4·21 = 84)  
3rd set: 66  
4th set: 48 (only one 8)

Check clue 1: 6 + 1 = 7 (< 8).  
Check clue 4: 4×21 = 84 = 48 reversed.

All conditions are met.

Final answer: 39-21-66-48

Question: A warden at a prison decides to give some prisoners a chance to escape by working together to solve a puzzle. He prepares a colored hat for every one of them and tells them the rules. The hats can be either black or white and will be placed on everyone's head.  The prisoners will get a chance to discuss a strategy together, which they will all follow, then they will be marched out into a large room where they will see everybody else's hat color. Each prisoner will then simultaneously guess which of the two hat colors they have. If every one of them is right, or every one of them is wrong, they will all go free. However, the prisoners will not be allowed to communicate in any way during this process. Also, the warden will hear their strategy and place hats any way he can to prevent them from going free. What strategy do they use to escape?
Hint: Think about it for two people and then three people. What will be the difference between what a white hatted person sees and a black hatted person sees?
Human Solution: Every prisoner should count up how many black hats they see. If they count an odd number of black hats, they say that they have a black hat. If they count an even number of black hats, then they say that they have a white hat.
Response:
Let us encode the colours by  
 black = 0, white = 1,  
and write the whole line of hats as the binary string  

 H = (H₁ , H₂ , … , Hₙ) ∈ {0,1}ⁿ.  

For every H let  
 S = H₁ ⊕ H₂ ⊕ … ⊕ Hₙ                                                (⊕ = XOR, “parity of whites”).  

S is 0 when an even number of hats are white and 1 when that number is odd.

Strategy agreed on before the hats are put on  
(heard by the warden):

1. Every prisoner will assume that the total number of white hats is EVEN (i.e. that S=0).  
2. After seeing the colours of all other hats each prisoner will announce the unique colour that makes the overall parity even.

Concretely, prisoner i sees all hats except his own, so he can compute  

 Tᵢ = H₁ ⊕ … ⊕ H_{i−1} ⊕ H_{i+1} ⊕ … ⊕ Hₙ  
    = S ⊕ Hᵢ                                        (because S = Tᵢ ⊕ Hᵢ).

• If Tᵢ = 0 (he sees an even number of whites) he says “black” (0);  
• If Tᵢ = 1 (he sees an odd number of whites) he says “white” (1).

Hence his announced colour is  

 Gᵢ = Tᵢ = S ⊕ Hᵢ.                                            (★)

Why the strategy always works  
There are only two possibilities for S.

Case 1.  S = 0 (the real number of white hats is even).  
Then (★) gives Gᵢ = Hᵢ for every i, so every prisoner’s guess is correct – they are “all right”.

Case 2.  S = 1 (the real number of white hats is odd).  
Then (★) gives Gᵢ = 1 ⊕ Hᵢ, i.e. each guess is the opposite of the real colour, so every prisoner is wrong – they are “all wrong”.

In either case the group fulfils the warden’s requirement (“all right” or “all wrong”) and they all go free.  

The warden hears the strategy but cannot stop it: whatever hat pattern he chooses fixes S, and the prisoners’ simultaneous answers automatically make them uniformly right or uniformly wrong.

(To see the idea on small numbers:  
• With 2 prisoners each simply says the colour he sees on the other head – exactly the parity rule above.  
• With 3 prisoners each says “white” if he sees an odd number of whites among the other two, otherwise “black”.)

Final answer: Each prisoner looks at the other hats, determines whether the number of white hats he sees is even or odd, and then announces the colour that makes the total number of white hats even. If the true total is even they are all correct; if it is odd they are all wrong, so in every possible hat assignment the whole group satisfies the warden’s condition and escapes.

Question:
Madadian Multi-Squillionaire Sheik Ratelunroll has bought four prestige cars from the Madadian Motor Company (MMC) - The Silver Dream, The Golden Pleasure, The Devine Lightning, and a The Rusting Bucket, - as presents for his sons' birthdays, all of which are next week (strange things like this happen in Madadia all the time). Given the following information, what will each son get?
1, Derek will not get The Golden Pleasure unless Berrick gets The Silver Dream and Eric gets The Rusting Bucket.
2, Berrick will not get The Rusting Bucket unless Merick gets The Devine Lightning and Derek gets The Silver Dream.
3, Eric will not get The Devine Lightning unless Derek gets The Golden Pleasure and Berrick gets The Silver Dream.
4, Derek will not get The Silver Dream unless Merick gets The Devine Lightning and Eric gets The Rusting Bucket.
5, Berrick will not get The Silver Dream unless Derek gets The Devine Lightning and Eric gets The Rusting Bucket.
6, Derek will not get The Devine Lightning unless Berrick gets The Golden Pleasure and Merick gets The Silver Dream.
7, Merick will not get The Devine Lightning unless Berrick gets The Golden Pleasure and Derek gets The Rusting Bucket.
8, Derek will not get The Rusting Bucket unless Berrick gets The Devine Lightning and Eric gets The Golden Pleasure.
9, Merick will not get The Silver Dream unless Eric gets The Golden Pleasure.
Hint: Starting with the simplest requirement, #9, assume that Eric does in fact get The Golden Pleasure, then Merick gets The Silver Dream.
Human Solution:
Starting with the simplest requirement, #9, assume that Eric does in fact get The Golden Pleasure, then Merick gets The Silver Dream. This leaves The Rusting Bucket and The Devine Lightning for Berrick and Derek. Going to rule #8, Eric already has The Golden Pleasure, so if Berrick gets The Devine Lightning, then Derek can have The Rusting Bucket. This gives us the following that complies with rules 8 & 9:
Eric = The Golden Pleasure
Merick = The Silver Dream
Berrick = The Devine Lightning
Derek = The Rusting Bucket
Now, to see if this works, just check it out against rules 1 through 7, where you'll find no rules are violated and everyone's happy except Derek who got stuck with The Rusting Bucket.
Response:
Reasoning step-by-step

1.  Translate every sentence into an implication.

   Let  
   S = Silver Dream,  
   G = Golden Pleasure,  
   L = Devine Lightning,  
   R = Rusting Bucket.

   1. D=G ⇒ (B=S ∧ E=R)  
   2. B=R ⇒ (M=L ∧ D=S)  
   3. E=L ⇒ (D=G ∧ B=S)  
   4. D=S ⇒ (M=L ∧ E=R)  
   5. B=S ⇒ (D=L ∧ E=R)  
   6. D=L ⇒ (B=G ∧ M=S)  
   7. M=L ⇒ (B=G ∧ D=R)  
   8. D=R ⇒ (B=L ∧ E=G)  
   9. M=S ⇒ E=G

2.  Use the hint (rule 9) first.

   Assume E=G.  
   Rule 9 then gives M=S OR NOT?  
   Actually rule 9 is one-way: M=S ⇒ E=G.  
   So E=G is allowed whether or not M=S; we merely know that, if later we set M=S, it will be consistent with E=G.

3.  What may Berrick receive?

   • If B=R, rule 2 would force E=R (via D=S) contradicting E=G.  
   • If B=S, rule 5 would also force E=R contradicting E=G.  
   • If B=G, the car G is already taken by Eric.  

   Therefore the only possible car left for B is L.  
   So B=L.

4.  What may Derek receive?

   • D=G is impossible (rule 1 would again demand E=R).  
   • D=S is impossible (rule 4 would demand E=R).  
   • D=L is impossible because L already belongs to B.  

   Hence Derek must take the only remaining car: D=R.

5.  The last unassigned car goes to Merick:

   Cars used so far: E=G, B=L, D=R.  
   The only car left is S, so M=S.

6.  Check all implications.

   • Rule 1: antecedent false (D≠G) – OK.  
   • Rule 2: antecedent false (B≠R) – OK.  
   • Rule 3: antecedent false (E≠L) – OK.  
   • Rule 4: antecedent false (D≠S) – OK.  
   • Rule 5: antecedent false (B≠S) – OK.  
   • Rule 6: antecedent false (D≠L) – OK.  
   • Rule 7: antecedent false (M≠L) – OK.  
   • Rule 8: antecedent true (D=R) – conclusion demands B=L and E=G, both satisfied.  
   • Rule 9: antecedent true (M=S) – conclusion demands E=G, satisfied.

   All nine statements are satisfied and each car is used exactly once.

7.  Uniqueness.

   Trying any other first choice for Eric (E=R, E=L, or E=S) produces an immediate contradiction with at least one rule, hence the assignment above is unique.

Final answer:  
Derek – Rusting Bucket  
Berrick – Devine Lightning  
Eric – Golden Pleasure  
Merick – Silver Dream

Question:
Thirty fans hire a bus to attend a football game. On the way to the stadium, they realize that exactly half of them are fans of one team and the other half are fans of the other team. With still some way to go before reaching the stadium, the bus develops mechanical problems and the driver announces to his passengers that the only way to continue the journey is for half of them to get out and walk. There is a huge fight that doesn't stop until the driver speaks to them again and suggests a way of selecting the passengers who are to get off the bus.
"All of you," he said, "get into a big circle. When you are ready, beginning at this spot, I'll count nine people clockwise. The ninth person leaves the circle and continues on foot. Then I'll count another nine starting from where I stopped, and the ninth person leaves the circle and continues on foot. And so on until fifteen people have left the circle."
Suppose that you are one of the fans. How should you arrange all the other fans of your team so that none of them will have to leave?
Hint: Just keep counting in circles and see where you each spot lands
Human Solution: If the two teams are A and B and you are a supporter of team A and don't want any of your fellow supporters to end up walking to the stadium, organize them in a circle starting at the point where the driver starts and reading clockwise as follows: A, A, A, A, B, B, B, B, B, A, A, B, A, A, A, B, A, B, B, A, A, B, B, B, A, B, B, A, A, B.
Response:
Label the places in the big circle 1,2,3,…,30, starting with 1 at the spot the driver points to and continuing clockwise.

Now imitate the driver’s procedure (the classical Josephus‐problem with n = 30, k = 9).  
Keep removing every 9-th number until fifteen numbers have disappeared:

1st off 9  
2nd off 18  
3rd off 27  
4th off 6  
5th off 16  
6th off 26  
7th off 7  
8th off 19  
9th off 30  
10th off 12  
11th off 24  
12th off 8  
13th off 22  
14th off 5  
15th off 23  

After the fifteenth exit the numbers that are still in the circle are

1, 2, 3, 4, 10, 11, 13, 14, 15, 17, 20, 21, 25, 28, 29

(15 numbers, exactly half of 30).

Therefore, if you and the other supporters of your team occupy precisely these fifteen positions, none of you will be counted out.  Put the fans of the other team on the remaining numbers

5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 12, 16, 18, 19, 22, 23, 24, 26, 27, 30,

and every time the driver reaches the ninth count one of them – not one of you – will have to leave.

So, stand yourself at position 1 (or any other number from the “safe” list) and arrange your fourteen fellow supporters in the other safe positions 2,3,4,10,11,13,14,15,17,20,21,25,28 and 29.  
With that arrangement your whole party stays on the bus while all fifteen rival supporters are the ones who must walk.

Final answer: seat your own team on positions 1, 2, 3, 4, 10, 11, 13, 14, 15, 17, 20, 21, 25, 28 and 29 (leaving the others on the remaining numbers); then none of your supporters will be counted out.

Question:
It appears that you have angered the spirit of Halloween by failing to revere the Great Pumpkin, and now a curse has befallen you.  On the walkway to your house is a Ward of Seven Jack O'Lanterns arranged in a circle.  If midnight comes and any of the seven are still lit, a dark reaper and seven dark horses with seven dark riders shall visit thy abode.  They shall surround thy domicile and, while circling it, they will proceed to pelt thy dwelling with eggs and cream of shaving.  And come morn there will be a great mess to be reckoned with.  Verily.  So you better get those lanterns out.
You quickly discover something odd about these lanterns.  When you blow out the first one, the lanterns on either side extinguish as well!  But there is more.  If you blow out a lantern adjacent to one that is extinguished, the extinguished one(s) will relight.  It seems that blowing on any lantern will change the state of three - the one you blew on and its two neighbors.  Finally, you can blow on an extinguished lantern and it will relight, and its neighbors will light/extinguish as applicable.  After trying once and finding all seven lit again, you decide, being the excellent puzzler, you sit down and examine this closer.  But hurry, I hear the beating of many hooves...
Hint: If you examine the setup carefully, you'll note a number of facts which make the puzzle easier to solve by deduction.  First, blowing on a lantern is a commutative property; blowing on lanterns 1, 5, then 3 is the same as blowing on 3, then 1, and then 5.  No matter what order the lanterns are blown on, if the same lanterns are blown on the same number of times, the result won't change.
Human Solution:
If you examine the setup carefully, you'll note a number of facts which make the puzzle easier to solve by deduction.  First, blowing on a lantern is a commutative property; blowing on lanterns 1, 5, then 3 is the same as blowing on 3, then 1, and then 5.  No matter what order the lanterns are blown on, if the same lanterns are blown on the same number of times, the result won't change.  For that reason, blowing on a lantern twice is as good as not blowing on it at all.  And three times is as good as one time. So, it seems that it should be able to be done in seven steps or less.
What else can we tell about the solution?  Since each operation changes the state of three lanterns, and there are 7 lanterns, and each lantern must change its state an odd number of times, it's a safe bet that there will need to be an odd number of steps.  We can easily see it can't be done in 1 or 3 steps, so it must be 5 or 7.  Trying 5 steps comes up with 3 different patterns that are not symmetrical and fail to leave all lanterns extinguished.  So that leaves 7 steps and to your surprise, based on the commutative property, the easiest solution is to blow on each one in order!  So doing this, the Great Pumpkin has decided to give you a treat for figuring this out and you find all seven lanterns full of candy the next morning!  Congratulations!
Response:
Reasoning step by step  

1.  Label the seven lanterns L0 , L1 , … , L6 clockwise round the circle.  
    At any moment a lantern is either lit (state 1) or out (state 0).

2.  “Blowing” on lantern Lj toggles (changes the state of) Lj itself and its two
    neighbours Lj-1 and Lj+1 (indices taken mod 7, so that L-1=L6, L7=L0).

3.  Because toggling twice is the same as doing nothing and order is irrelevant,
    it is enough to decide for every lantern whether we blow on it 0 or 1 time.
    Write xj ∈ {0,1} for “blow on Lj (1 time) / do not blow (0 times)”.

4.  What will the final state Si of lantern Li be?
        Si  =  (initial state)  +  (number of times it is toggled)      (mod 2)
    Initially every lantern is lit, so the initial state is 1.
    Li is toggled once for every blow on Li itself and on its two neighbours.
        number of toggles of Li = xi-1 + xi + xi+1       (mod 2)
    Hence
        Si = 1 + xi-1 + xi + xi+1                       (mod 2)

5.  Our goal is to have every lantern out, i.e. Si=0 for all i.  
    Therefore for every i (mod 7)
        xi-1 + xi + xi+1 = 1                            (†)

6.  Solve the 7 simultaneous equations (†).

    Let x0 = a and x1 = b.  
    From i = 1 :   x0 + x1 + x2 = 1  ⇒  a + b + x2 = 1  ⇒  x2 = 1 + a + b  
    From i = 2 :   x1 + x2 + x3 = 1  ⇒  b + x2 + x3 = 1  ⇒  x3 = 1 + b + x2
                                            = 1 + b + (1 + a + b) = a
    From i = 3 :   x2 + x3 + x4 = 1  ⇒  (1 + a + b) + a + x4 = 1  ⇒  x4 = b
    From i = 4 :   x3 + x4 + x5 = 1  ⇒  a + b + x5 = 1            ⇒  x5 = 1 + a + b
    From i = 5 :   x4 + x5 + x6 = 1  ⇒  b + (1 + a + b) + x6 = 1  ⇒  x6 = a

    Now impose the two remaining equations:

    i = 6 :  x5 + x6 + x0 = 1  ⇒  (1 + a + b) + a + a = 1  ⇒  a + b = 0      (mod 2)  
    i = 0 :  x6 + x0 + x1 = 1  ⇒  a + a + b = 1          ⇒  b = 1            (mod 2)

    Putting b = 1 into a + b = 0 gives a = 1.

    Thus the unique solution is
        x0 = x1 = … = x6 = 1.

7.  Interpretation.  Each lantern must be blown on exactly once (and never twice).
    Any other combination leaves at least one pumpkin re-lit.

8.  Because order does not matter, you may simply walk round the circle once,
